column1: 1814 Adam_Smith "Adam Smith  (16 June [O.S. 5 June] 1723 – 17 July 1790) was a Scottish economist
column2: philosopher and author as well as a moral philosopher
column3: a pioneer of political economy and a key figure during the Scottish Enlightenment
column4: also known as ''The Father of Economics'' or ''The Father of Capitalism''. Smith wrote two classic works
column5: The Theory of Moral Sentiments (1759) and An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations (1776). The latter
column6: often abbreviated as The Wealth of Nations
column7: is considered his magnum opus and the first modern work of economics. In his work
column8: Adam Smith introduced his theory of absolute advantage.Smith studied social philosophy at the University of Glasgow and at Balliol College
column9: Oxford
column10: where he was one of the first students to benefit from scholarships set up by fellow Scot John Snell. After graduating
column11: he delivered a successful series of public lectures at the University of Edinburgh
column12: leading him to collaborate with David Hume during the Scottish Enlightenment. Smith obtained a professorship at Glasgow
column13: teaching moral philosophy and during this time
column14: wrote and published The Theory of Moral Sentiments. In his later life
column15: he took a tutoring position that allowed him to travel throughout Europe
column16: where he met other intellectual leaders of his day. Smith laid the foundations of classical free market economic theory. The Wealth of Nations was a precursor to the modern academic discipline of economics. In this and other works
column17: he developed the concept of division of labour and expounded upon how rational self-interest and competition can lead to economic prosperity. Smith was controversial in his own day and his general approach and writing style were often satirised by writers such as Horace Walpole."

column1: 3356 Bill_Clinton "William Jefferson Clinton (born William Jefferson Blythe III; August 19
column2: 1946) is an American politician who served as the 42nd president of the United States from 1993 to 2001. Prior to his presidency
column3: he served as governor of Arkansas (1979–1981 and 1983–1992) and as attorney general of Arkansas (1977–1979). A member of the Democratic Party
column4: Clinton was known as a New Democrat
column5: and many of his policies reflected a centrist ""Third Way"" political philosophy. He is the husband of former Secretary of State and former U.S. Senator Hillary Clinton. In 1998
column6: Clinton was impeached by the House of Representatives. The impeachment was based on accusations that Clinton committed perjury and obstruction of justice for the purpose of concealing his affair with Monica Lewinsky
column7: a 22-year-old White House intern. He was acquitted by the Senate and completed his term in office. Clinton is notable as one of only two U.S. presidents (following Andrew Johnson 130 years earlier) to have been impeached. Clinton was born and raised in Arkansas and attended Georgetown University
column8: University College
column9: Oxford
column10: and Yale Law School. He met Hillary Rodham at Yale and married her in 1975. After graduating from law school
column11: Clinton returned to Arkansas and won election as the Attorney General of Arkansas
column12: serving from 1977 to 1979. He later served as governor of Arkansas. As governor
column13: he overhauled the state's education system and served as chairman of the National Governors Association. Clinton was elected president in 1992
column14: defeating incumbent Republican opponent George H. W. Bush. At age 46
column15: he became the third-youngest president in history. Clinton presided over the longest period of peacetime economic expansion in American history. He signed into law the North American Free Trade Agreement
column16: but failed to pass his plan for national health care reform. In the 1994 elections
column17: the Republican Party won unified control of the Congress for the first time in 40 years. In 1996
column18: Clinton became the first Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt to be elected to a second full term. He passed welfare reform and the State Children's Health Insurance Program
column19: as well as financial deregulation measures. During the last three years of Clinton's presidency
column20: the Congressional Budget Office reported a budget surplus—the first such surplus since 1969. In foreign policy
column21: Clinton ordered U.S. military intervention in the Bosnian and Kosovo wars
column22: signed the Iraq Liberation Act in opposition to Saddam Hussein
column23: participated in the 2000 Camp David Summit to advance the Israeli–Palestinian peace process
column24: and assisted the Northern Ireland peace process. Clinton left office with the highest end-of-office approval rating of any U.S. president since World War II
column25: and has continually received high scores in the historical rankings of U.S. presidents. Since leaving office
column26: he has been involved in public speaking and humanitarian work. He created the William J. Clinton Foundation to address international causes such as the prevention of AIDS and global warming. In 2004
column27: Clinton published his autobiography
column28: My Life. In 2009
column29: he was named the United Nations Special Envoy to Haiti and after the 2010 Haiti earthquake
column30: he teamed with George W. Bush to form the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund. In addition
column31: he secured the release of two American journalists imprisoned by North Korea
column32: visiting the capital Pyongyang in 2009 and negotiating their release with then-North Korean leader Kim Jong-il."

column1: 3747 Bill_Gates "William Henry Gates III  (born October 28
column2: 1955) is an American business magnate
column3: software developer
column4: and philanthropist. He is best known as the co-founder of Microsoft Corporation. During his career at Microsoft
column5: Gates held the positions of chairman
column6: chief executive officer (CEO) and chief software architect
column7: while also being the largest individual shareholder until May 2014. He is one of the best-known entrepreneurs and pioneers of the microcomputer revolution of the 1970s and 1980s. Born and raised in Seattle
column8: Washington
column9: Gates launched Microsoft with childhood friend Paul Allen in 1975 in Albuquerque
column10: New Mexico; it went on to become the world's largest personal computer software company. Gates led the company as chairman and CEO until stepping down as CEO in January 2000
column11: but he remained chairman and became chief software architect. In June 2006
column12: Gates announced that he would be transitioning to a part-time role at Microsoft and full-time work at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
column13: the private charitable foundation that he and his wife
column14: Melinda Gates
column15: established in 2000. He gradually transferred his duties to Ray Ozzie and Craig Mundie. He stepped down as chairman of Microsoft in February 2014 and assumed a new post as technology adviser to support the newly appointed CEO Satya Nadella.Gates has been criticized for his business tactics
column16: which have been considered anti-competitive. This opinion has been upheld by numerous court rulings.Since 1987
column17: he has been included in the Forbes list of the world's wealthiest documented individuals. From 1995 to 2017
column18: he held the Forbes title of the richest person in the world all but four of those years. In 2017 he was surpassed by Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos
column19: who had an estimated net worth of US$90.6 billion. As of November 9
column21: Gates had a net worth of $107.1 billion
column22: still ranked second. Later in his career and since leaving day-to-day operations at Microsoft in 2008
column23: Gates pursued a number of philanthropic endeavors. He donated large amounts of money to various charitable organizations and scientific research programs through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
column24: reported to be the world's largest private charity. In 2009
column25: Gates and Warren Buffett founded The Giving Pledge
column26: whereby they and other billionaires pledge to give at least half of their wealth to philanthropy. The foundation works to save lives and improve global health
column27: and is working with Rotary International to eliminate polio."

column1: 8182 Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight David ""Ike"" Eisenhower ( EYE-zən-how-ər; October 14
column2: 1890 – March 28
column3: 1969) was an American army general and statesman who served as the 34th president of the United States from 1953 to 1961. During World War II
column4: he was a five-star general in the Army and served as Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force in Europe. He was responsible for planning and supervising the invasion of North Africa in Operation Torch in 1942–43 and the successful Invasion of Normandy in 1944–45 from the Western Front. Eisenhower was born David Dwight Eisenhower in Denison
column5: Texas
column6: and he was raised in Kansas in a large family of mostly Pennsylvania Dutch ancestry. His family had a strong religious background. His mother was a Lutheran
column7: married as a River Brethren
column8: and later became a Jehovah's Witness. Eisenhower
column9: however
column10: did not belong to any organized church until 1952. He cited constant relocation during his military career as one reason. He graduated from West Point in 1915 and later married Mamie Doud
column11: with whom he had two sons. During World War I
column12: he was denied a request to serve in Europe and instead commanded a unit that trained tank crews. Following the war
column13: he served under various generals and was promoted to the rank of brigadier general in 1941. After the United States entered World War II
column14: Eisenhower oversaw the invasions of North Africa and Sicily before supervising the invasions of France and Germany. After the war
column15: he served as Army Chief of Staff (1945–1948) and then took on the role as president of Columbia University (1948–1953). In 1951–52
column16: he served as the first Supreme Commander of NATO. In 1952
column17: Eisenhower entered the presidential race as a Republican to block the isolationist foreign policies of Senator Robert A. Taft
column18: who opposed NATO and wanted no foreign entanglements. He won that election and the 1956 election in landslides
column19: both times defeating Adlai Stevenson II. He became the first Republican to win since Herbert Hoover in 1928. Eisenhower's main goals in office were to contain the spread of communism and reduce federal deficits. In 1953
column20: he threatened to use nuclear weapons until China agreed to peace terms in the Korean War. China did agree and an armistice resulted which remains in effect. His New Look policy of nuclear deterrence prioritized inexpensive nuclear weapons while reducing funding for expensive Army divisions. He continued Harry S. Truman's policy of recognizing Taiwan as the legitimate government of China
column21: and he won congressional approval of the Formosa Resolution. His administration provided major aid to help the French fight off Vietnamese Communists in the First Indochina War. After the French left
column22: he gave strong financial support to the new state of South Vietnam. He supported military coups in Iran and Guatemala. During the Suez Crisis of 1956
column23: he condemned the Israeli
column24: British
column25: and French invasion of Egypt
column26: and he forced them to withdraw. He also condemned the Soviet invasion during the Hungarian Revolution of 1956 but took no action. During the Syrian Crisis of 1957 he approved a CIA-MI6 plan to stage fake border incidents as an excuse for an invasion by Syria's pro-Western neighbors. After the Soviet Union launched Sputnik in 1957
column27: Eisenhower authorized the establishment of NASA
column28: which led to the Space Race. He deployed 15
column29: 000 soldiers during the 1958 Lebanon crisis. Near the end of his term
column30: he failed to set up a summit meeting with the Soviets when a U.S. spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union. He approved the Bay of Pigs invasion
column31: which was left to John F. Kennedy to carry out.On the domestic front
column32: Eisenhower was a moderate conservative who continued New Deal agencies and expanded Social Security. He covertly opposed Joseph McCarthy and contributed to the end of McCarthyism by openly invoking executive privilege. He signed the Civil Rights Act of 1957 and sent Army troops to enforce federal court orders which integrated schools in Little Rock
column33: Arkansas. His largest program was the Interstate Highway System. He promoted the establishment of strong science education via the National Defense Education Act. His two terms saw widespread economic prosperity except for a minor recession in 1958. In his farewell address to the nation
column34: he expressed his concerns about the dangers of massive military spending
column35: particularly deficit spending and government contracts to private military manufacturers. Historical evaluations of his presidency place him among the upper tier of American presidents."

column1: 9223 Economics "Economics () is the social science that studies the production
column2: distribution
column3: and consumption of goods and services.Economics focuses on the behaviour and interactions of economic agents and how economies work. Microeconomics analyzes basic elements in the economy
column4: including individual agents and markets
column5: their interactions
column6: and the outcomes of interactions. Individual agents may include
column7: for example
column8: households
column9: firms
column10: buyers
column11: and sellers. Macroeconomics analyzes the entire economy (meaning aggregated production
column12: consumption
column13: saving
column14: and investment) and issues affecting it
column15: including unemployment of resources (labour
column16: capital
column17: and land)
column18: inflation
column19: economic growth
column20: and the public policies that address these issues (monetary
column21: fiscal
column22: and other policies).  See glossary of economics. Other broad distinctions within economics include those between positive economics
column23: describing ""what is""
column24: and normative economics
column25: advocating ""what ought to be""; between economic theory and applied economics; between rational and behavioural economics; and between mainstream economics and heterodox economics.Economic analysis can be applied throughout society
column26: in real estate
column27: business
column28: finance
column29: health care
column30: and government. Economic analysis is sometimes also applied to such diverse subjects as crime
column31: education
column32: the family
column33: law
column34: politics
column35: religion
column36: social institutions
column37: war
column38: science
column39: and the environment."

column1: 10979 Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin Delano Roosevelt (
column2: ; January 30
column3: 1882 – April 12
column5: often referred to by the initials FDR
column6: was an American statesman and political leader who served as the 32nd president of the United States from 1933 until his death in 1945. A member of the Democratic Party
column7: he won a record four presidential elections and became a central figure in world events during the first half of the 20th century. Roosevelt directed the federal government during most of the Great Depression
column8: implementing his New Deal domestic agenda in response to the worst economic crisis in U.S. history. As a dominant leader of his party
column9: he built the New Deal Coalition
column10: which realigned American politics into the Fifth Party System and defined American liberalism throughout the middle third of the 20th century. His third and fourth terms were dominated by World War II
column11: which ended shortly after he died in office. He is rated by scholars as one of the three greatest U.S. presidents
column12: along with George Washington and Abraham Lincoln
column13: but has also been subject to substantial criticism. Roosevelt was born in Hyde Park
column14: New York to a Dutch American family made well known by the reputation of Theodore Roosevelt
column15: the 26th president of the United States
column16: and William Henry Aspinwall. FDR attended Groton School
column17: Harvard College
column18: and Columbia Law School
column19: and went on to practice law in New York City. In 1905
column20: he married his fifth cousin once removed
column21: Eleanor Roosevelt. They had six children
column22: of whom five survived into adulthood. He won election to the New York State Senate in 1910
column23: and then served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy under President Woodrow Wilson during World War I. Roosevelt was James M. Cox's running mate on the Democratic Party's 1920 national ticket
column24: but Cox was defeated by Republican Warren G. Harding. In 1921
column25: Roosevelt contracted a paralytic illness
column26: believed at the time to be polio
column27: and his legs became permanently paralyzed. While attempting to recover from his condition
column28: Roosevelt founded the treatment center in Warm Springs
column29: Georgia
column30: for people with poliomyelitis. In spite of being unable to walk unaided
column31: Roosevelt returned to public office by winning election as Governor of New York in 1928. He was in office from 1929 to 1933 and served as a reform Governor
column32: promoting programs to combat the economic crisis besetting the United States at the time. In the 1932 presidential election
column33: Roosevelt defeated Republican President Herbert Hoover in a landslide. Roosevelt took office in the midst of the Great Depression
column34: the worst economic crisis in United States History. During the first 100 days of the 73rd United States Congress
column35: Roosevelt spearheaded unprecedented federal legislation and issued a profusion of executive orders that instituted the New Deal—a variety of programs designed to produce relief
column36: recovery
column37: and reform. He created numerous programs to provide relief to the unemployed and farmers while seeking economic recovery with the National Recovery Administration and other programs. He also instituted major regulatory reforms related to finance
column38: communications
column39: and labor
column40: and presided over the end of Prohibition. He harnessed radio to speak directly to the American people
column41: giving 30 ""fireside chat"" radio addresses during his presidency and becoming the first American president to be televised. The economy having improved rapidly from 1933 to 1936
column42: Roosevelt won a landslide reelection in 1936. However
column43: the economy then relapsed into a deep recession in 1937 and 1938. After the 1936 election
column44: Roosevelt sought passage of the Judiciary Reorganization Bill of 1937 (the ""court packing plan"")
column45: which would have expanded the size of the Supreme Court of the United States. The bipartisan Conservative Coalition that formed in 1937 prevented passage of the bill and blocked the implementation of further New Deal programs and reforms. Major surviving programs and legislation implemented under Roosevelt include the Securities and Exchange Commission
column46: the National Labor Relations Act
column47: the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
column49: and the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938
column52: prohibited child labor and created the right to a minimum wage. The United States reelected FDR in 1940 for his third term
column53: making him the only U.S. President to serve for more than two terms. With World War II looming after 1938
column54: Roosevelt gave strong diplomatic and financial support to China
column55: the United Kingdom and eventually the Soviet Union while the U.S. remained officially neutral. Following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7
column57: an event he famously called ""a date which will live in infamy""
column58: Roosevelt obtained a congressional declaration of war on Japan
column61: on Germany and Italy. Assisted by his top aide Harry Hopkins and with very strong national support
column62: he worked closely with British Prime Minister Winston Churchill
column63: Soviet leader Joseph Stalin and Chinese Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in leading the Allied Powers against the Axis Powers. Roosevelt supervised the mobilization of the U.S. economy to support the war effort
column64: and implemented a Europe first strategy
column65: making the defeat of Germany a priority over that of Japan. He also initiated the development of the world's first atomic bomb
column66: and worked with the other Allied leaders to lay the groundwork for the United Nations and other post-war institutions. Roosevelt won reelection in 1944
column67: but with his physical health declining during the war years
column69: just 11 weeks into his fourth term. The Axis Powers surrendered to the Allies in the months following Roosevelt's death
column70: during the presidency of his successor

column1: 11826 Free_market "In economics
column2: a free market is a system in which the prices for goods and services are self-regulated by the open market and by consumers. In a free market
column3: the laws and forces of supply and demand are free from any intervention by a government or other authority and from all forms of economic privilege
column4: monopolies and artificial scarcities. Proponents of the concept of free market contrast it with a regulated market in which a government intervenes in supply and demand through various methods such as tariffs used to restrict trade and to protect the local economy. In an idealized free-market economy
column5: prices for goods and services are set freely by the forces of supply and demand and are allowed to reach their point of equilibrium without intervention by government policy. Scholars contrast the concept of a free market with the concept of a coordinated market in fields of study such as political economy
column6: new institutional economics
column7: economic sociology and political science. All of these fields emphasize the importance in currently existing market systems of rule-making institutions external to the simple forces of supply and demand which create space for those forces to operate to control productive output and distribution. Although free markets are commonly associated with capitalism within a market economy in contemporary usage and popular culture
column8: free markets have also been advocated by anarchists
column9: socialists and some proponents of cooperatives and advocates of profit sharing. Criticism of the theoretical concept may regard systems with significant market power
column10: inequality of bargaining power
column11: or information asymmetry as less than free
column12: with regulation being necessary to control those imbalances in order to allow markets to function more efficiently as well as produce more desirable social outcomes."

column1: 11955 George_H._W._Bush "George Herbert Walker Bush (June 12
column2: 1924 – November 30
column3: 2018) was an American politician and businessman who served as the 41st president of the United States from 1989 to 1993 and the 43rd vice president from 1981 to 1989. A member of the Republican Party
column4: Bush also served in the U.S. House of Representatives
column5: as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations
column6: and as Director of Central Intelligence. Bush is usually called George H. W. Bush
column7: Bush Senior
column8: or Bush 41 to distinguish him from his eldest son George W. Bush
column9: who served as the 43rd president from 2001 to 2009.   Bush postponed his university studies after the attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7
column11: enlisted in the Navy on his 18th birthday
column12: and became one of its youngest aviators. He served until September 1945
column13: and then attended Yale University
column14: graduating in 1948. He moved his family to West Texas where he entered the oil business and became a millionaire by the age of 40 (in 1964). Bush won election to the House of Representatives from Texas's 7th congressional district in 1966
column15: and was re-elected in 1968. He also ran unsuccessfully for U.S. Senate twice
column16: in 1964 and again in 1970. In 1971
column17: President Richard Nixon appointed Bush as Ambassador to the United Nations
column18: and he became chairman of the Republican National Committee in 1973. The following year
column19: President Gerald Ford appointed him Chief of the Liaison Office in China and later made him the Director of Central Intelligence. Bush ran for president in 1980
column20: but was defeated in the Republican primary by Ronald Reagan. He was then elected vice president in 1980 and 1984 as Reagan's running mate. During his eight-year tenure as vice president
column21: Bush headed task forces on deregulation and the War on Drugs. In 1988
column22: Bush defeated Democratic opponent Michael Dukakis
column23: becoming the first incumbent vice president to be elected president in 152 years. Foreign policy drove the Bush presidency; military operations were conducted in Panama and the Persian Gulf
column24: the Berlin Wall fell in 1989
column25: and the Soviet Union dissolved two years later. Bush also signed the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
column26: which created a trade bloc consisting of the United States
column27: Canada
column28: and Mexico. Domestically
column29: Bush reneged on a 1988 campaign promise by signing a bill that increased taxes. He lost the 1992 presidential election to Democrat Bill Clinton following an economic recession and the decreased importance of foreign policy in a post–Cold War political climate. After leaving office in 1993
column30: Bush was active in humanitarian activities; he often worked alongside Clinton
column31: his former opponent. With George W. Bush's victory in the 2000 presidential election
column32: Bush and his son became the second father–son pair to serve as the nation's president (following John Adams and John Quincy Adams). After a long battle with vascular Parkinson's disease
column33: Bush died at his home on November 30
column34: 2018. At the time of his death
column35: he was the longest-lived president in U.S. history
column36: a record surpassed by Jimmy Carter on March 22

column1: 13765 Henry_Kissinger "Henry Alfred Kissinger (; German: [ˈkɪsɪŋɐ]; born Heinz Alfred Kissinger; May 27
column2: 1923) is an American politician
column3: diplomat
column4: and geopolitical consultant who served as United States Secretary of State and National Security Advisor under the presidential administrations of Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford. A Jewish refugee who fled Nazi Germany with his family in 1938
column5: he became National Security Advisor in 1969 and U.S. Secretary of State in 1973. For his actions negotiating a ceasefire in Vietnam
column6: Kissinger received the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize under controversial circumstances
column7: with two members of the committee resigning in protest. Kissinger later sought
column8: unsuccessfully
column9: to return the prize after the ceasefire failed.A practitioner of Realpolitik
column10: Kissinger played a prominent role in United States foreign policy between 1969 and 1977. During this period
column11: he pioneered the policy of détente with the Soviet Union
column12: orchestrated the opening of relations with the People's Republic of China
column13: engaged in what became known as shuttle diplomacy in the Middle East to end the Yom Kippur War
column14: and negotiated the Paris Peace Accords
column15: ending American involvement in the Vietnam War. Kissinger has also been associated with such controversial policies as U.S. involvement in the 1973 Chilean military coup
column16: a ""green light"" to Argentina's military junta for their Dirty War
column17: and U.S. support for Pakistan during the Bangladesh War despite the genocide being perpetrated by his allies. After leaving government
column18: he formed Kissinger Associates
column19: an international geopolitical consulting firm. Kissinger has written over one dozen books on diplomatic history and international relations. Kissinger remains widely regarded as a controversial figure in American politics
column20: and has been condemned as an alleged war criminal by journalists
column21: political activists
column22: and human rights lawyers. According to a 2014 survey by Foreign Policy magazine
column23: 32.21% of prominent American international relations scholars considered Kissinger the most effective U.S. Secretary of State since 1965."

column1: 14567 International_trade "International trade is the exchange of capital
column2: goods
column3: and services across international borders or territories.In most countries
column4: such trade represents a significant share of gross domestic product (GDP). While international trade has existed throughout history (for example Uttarapatha
column5: Silk Road
column6: Amber Road
column7: scramble for Africa
column8: Atlantic slave trade
column9: salt roads)
column10: its economic
column11: social
column12: and political importance has been on the rise in recent centuries. Carrying out trade at an international level is a complex process when compared to domestic trade. When trade takes place between two or more nations factors like currency
column13: government policies
column14: economy
column15: judicial system
column16: laws
column17: and markets influence trade. To smoothen and justify the process of trade between countries of different economic standing
column18: some international economic organisations were formed
column19: such as the World Trade Organization. These organisations work towards the facilitation and growth of international trade. Statistical services of intergovernmental and supranational organisations and national statistical agencies publish official statistics on international trade."

column1: 15251 International_Monetary_Fund "The International Monetary Fund (IMF)
column2: also known as the Fund
column3: is an international organization headquartered in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: consisting of 189 countries working to foster global monetary cooperation
column6: secure financial stability
column7: facilitate international trade
column8: promote high employment and sustainable economic growth
column9: and reduce poverty around the world while periodically depending on World Bank for its resources. Formed in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference primarily by the ideas of Harry Dexter White and John Maynard Keynes
column10: it came into formal existence in 1945 with 29 member countries and the goal of reconstructing the international payment system. It now plays a central role in the management of balance of payments difficulties and international financial crises. Countries contribute funds to a pool through a quota system from which countries experiencing balance of payments problems can borrow money. As of 2016
column11: the fund had XDR 477 billion (about US$667 billion).Through the fund and other activities such as the gathering of statistics and analysis
column12: surveillance of its members' economies
column13: and the demand for particular policies
column14: the IMF works to improve the economies of its member countries. The organization's objectives stated in the Articles of Agreement are: to promote international monetary co-operation
column15: international trade
column16: high employment
column17: exchange-rate stability
column18: sustainable economic growth
column19: and making resources available to member countries in financial difficulty. IMF funds come from two major sources: quotas and loans. Quotas
column20: which are pooled funds of member nations
column21: generate most IMF funds. The size of a member's quota depends on its economic and financial importance in the world. Nations with larger economic importance have larger quotas. The quotas are increased periodically as a means of boosting the IMF's resources. The current Managing Director (MD) and Chairwoman of the International Monetary Fund is Bulgarian Economist Kristalina Georgieva
column22: who has held the post since 1 October 2019.Gita Gopinath was appointed as Chief Economist of IMF from 1 October 2018. She received her PhD in economics from Princeton University. Prior to her IMF appointment she was economic adviser to the Chief Minister of Kerala
column23: India."

column1: 15641 Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin (born Ioseb Besarionidzе Jughashvili; 18 December [O.S. 6 December] 1878 – 5 March 1953) was a Georgian revolutionary and Soviet politician who led the Soviet Union from the mid–1920s until 1953 as General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (1922–1952) and Premier (1941–1953). Despite initially governing the Soviet Union as part of a collective leadership
column2: he eventually consolidated power to become the country's de facto dictator by the 1930s. A communist ideologically committed to the Leninist interpretation of Marxism
column3: Stalin formalised these ideas as Marxism–Leninism
column4: while his own policies are known as Stalinism. Born to a poor family in Gori in the Russian Empire (now Georgia)
column5: Stalin joined the Marxist Russian Social Democratic Labour Party as a youth. He edited the party's newspaper
column6: Pravda
column7: and raised funds for Vladimir Lenin's Bolshevik faction via robberies
column8: kidnappings
column9: and protection rackets. Repeatedly arrested
column10: he underwent several internal exiles. After the Bolsheviks seized power during the 1917 October Revolution and created a one-party state under Lenin's newly renamed Communist Party
column11: Stalin joined its governing Politburo. Serving in the Russian Civil War before overseeing the Soviet Union's establishment in 1922
column12: Stalin assumed leadership over the country following Lenin's 1924 death. Under Stalin
column13: ""Socialism in One Country"" became a central tenet of the party's dogma. Through the Five-Year Plans
column14: the country underwent agricultural collectivisation and rapid industrialisation
column15: creating a centralised command economy. This led to significant disruptions in food production that contributed to the famine of 1932–33. To eradicate accused ""enemies of the working class""
column16: Stalin instituted the ""Great Purge""
column17: in which over a million were imprisoned and at least 700
column18: 000 executed between 1934 and 1939. By 1937
column19: he had complete personal control over the party and state. Stalin's government promoted Marxism–Leninism abroad through the Communist International and supported European anti-fascist movements during the 1930s
column20: particularly in the Spanish Civil War. In 1939
column21: it signed a non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany
column22: resulting in the Soviet invasion of Poland. Germany ended the pact by invading the Soviet Union in 1941. Despite initial setbacks
column23: the Soviet Red Army repelled the German incursion and captured Berlin in 1945
column24: ending World War II in Europe. The Soviets annexed the Baltic states and helped establish Soviet-aligned governments throughout Central and Eastern Europe
column25: China
column26: and North Korea. The Soviet Union and the United States emerged from the war as global superpowers. Tensions arose between the Soviet-backed Eastern Bloc and U.S.-backed Western Bloc which became known as the Cold War. Stalin led his country through the post-war reconstruction
column27: during which it developed a nuclear weapon in 1949. In these years
column28: the country experienced another major famine and an anti-semitic campaign peaking in the doctors' plot. After Stalin's death in 1953 he was eventually succeeded by Nikita Khrushchev
column29: who denounced his predecessor and initiated the de-Stalinisation of Soviet society. Widely considered one of the 20th century's most significant figures
column30: Stalin was the subject of a pervasive personality cult within the international Marxist–Leninist movement which revered him as a champion of the working class and socialism. Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991
column31: Stalin has retained popularity in Russia and Georgia as a victorious wartime leader who established the Soviet Union as a major world power. Conversely
column32: his totalitarian government has been widely condemned for overseeing mass repressions
column33: ethnic cleansing
column34: deportations
column35: hundreds of thousands of executions
column36: and famines which killed millions."

column1: 19379 Mahatma_Gandhi "Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (; 2 October 1869 – 30 January 1948) was an Indian lawyer

column25: or short dhoti and
column26: in the winter

column35: and later in calling for the British to Quit India in 1942. He was imprisoned for many years
column36: upon many occasions

column42: and Sikhs made their way to their new lands

column1: 19455 Max_Weber "Maximilian Karl Emil Weber (; German: [ˈveːbɐ]; 21 April 1864 – 14 June 1920) was a German sociologist
column2: philosopher
column3: jurist
column4: and political economist. His ideas profoundly influenced social theory and social research. Weber is often cited
column5: with Émile Durkheim and Karl Marx
column6: as among the three founders of sociology. Weber was a key proponent of methodological anti-positivism
column7: arguing for the study of social action through interpretive (rather than purely empiricist) means
column8: based on understanding the purpose and meaning that individuals attach to their own actions. Unlike Durkheim
column9: he did not believe in monocausal explanations and rather proposed that for any outcome there can be multiple causes.Weber's main intellectual concern was understanding the processes of rationalisation
column10: secularisation
column11: and ""disenchantment""
column12: which he associated with the rise of capitalism and modernity. He saw these as the result of a new way of thinking about the world. Weber is best known for his thesis combining economic sociology and the sociology of religion
column13: elaborated in his book The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism
column14: in which he proposed that ascetic Protestantism was one of the major ""elective affinities"" associated with the rise in the Western world of market-driven capitalism and the rational-legal nation-state. He argued that it was in the basic tenets of Protestantism to boost capitalism. Thus
column15: it can be said that the spirit of capitalism is inherent to Protestant religious values. Against Marx's historical materialism
column16: Weber emphasised the importance of cultural influences embedded in religion as a means for understanding the genesis of capitalism. The Protestant Ethic formed the earliest part in Weber's broader investigations into world religion; he went on to examine the religions of China
column17: the religions of India and ancient Judaism
column18: with particular regard to their differing economic consequences and conditions of social stratification. In another major work
column19: ""Politics as a Vocation""
column20: Weber defined the state as an entity that successfully claims a ""monopoly of the legitimate use of physical force within a given territory"".  He was also the first to categorise social authority into distinct forms
column21: which he labelled as charismatic
column22: traditional
column23: and rational-legal. His analysis of bureaucracy emphasised that modern state institutions are increasingly based on rational-legal authority. Weber also made a variety of other contributions in economic history
column24: as well as economic theory and methodology. Weber's analysis of modernity and rationalisation significantly influenced the critical theory associated with the Frankfurt School. After the First World War
column25: he was among the founders of the liberal German Democratic Party. He also ran unsuccessfully for a seat in parliament and served as advisor to the committee that drafted the ill-fated democratic Weimar Constitution of 1919. After contracting Spanish flu
column26: he died of pneumonia in 1920
column27: aged 56."

column15: he expanded his focus to include opposition towards poverty and the Vietnam War. He alienated many of his liberal allies with a 1967 speech titled ""Beyond Vietnam"". J. Edgar Hoover considered him a radical and made him an object of the FBI's COINTELPRO from 1963 on. FBI agents investigated him for possible communist ties
column16: recorded his extramarital liaisons and reported on them to government officials
column17: and on one occasion mailed King a threatening anonymous letter

Martin Luther King Jr. Day was established as a holiday in numerous cities and states beginning in 1971; the holiday was enacted at the federal level by legislation signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1986. Hundreds of streets in the U.S. have been renamed in his honor

column1: 20979 Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev (born 2 March 1931) is a Russian and formerly Soviet politician. The eighth and last leader of the Soviet Union
column2: he was General Secretary of its governing Communist Party from 1985 until 1991. He was also the country's head of state from 1985 until 1991
column3: serving as Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet from 1988 to 1989
column4: Chairman of the Supreme Soviet from 1989 to 1990
column5: and President of the Soviet Union from 1990 to 1991. Ideologically
column6: he initially adhered to Marxism-Leninism although by the early 1990s had moved toward social democracy. He was the only leader of the Union born after its establishment in 1922. Of mixed Russian and Ukrainian heritage
column7: Gorbachev was born in Privolnoye
column8: Stavropol Krai to a poor peasant family. Growing up under the rule of Joseph Stalin
column9: in his youth he operated combine harvesters on a collective farm before joining the Communist Party
column10: which then governed the Soviet Union as a one-party state according to Marxist-Leninist doctrine. While studying at Moscow State University
column11: he married fellow student Raisa Titarenko in 1953 prior to receiving his law degree in 1955. Moving to Stavropol
column12: he worked for the Komsomol youth organisation and
column13: after Stalin's death
column14: became a keen proponent of the de-Stalinization reforms of Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev. He was appointed the First Party Secretary of the Stavropol Regional Committee in 1970
column15: in which position he oversaw construction of the Great Stavropol Canal. In 1978 he returned to Moscow to become a Secretary of the party's Central Committee and in 1979 joined its governing Politburo. Within three years of the death of Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev
column16: following the brief regimes of Yuri Andropov and Konstantin Chernenko
column17: the Politburo elected Gorbachev as General Secretary
column18: the de facto head of government
column19: in 1985. Although committed to preserving the Soviet state and to its socialist ideals
column20: Gorbachev believed significant reform was necessary
column21: particularly after the 1986 Chernobyl disaster. He withdrew from the Soviet–Afghan War and embarked on summits with United States President Ronald Reagan to limit nuclear weapons and end the Cold War. Domestically
column22: his policy of glasnost (""openness"") allowed for enhanced freedom of speech and press
column23: while his perestroika (""restructuring"") sought to decentralise economic decision making to improve efficiency. His democratisation measures and formation of the elected Congress of People's Deputies undermined the one-party state. Gorbachev declined to intervene militarily when various Eastern Bloc countries abandoned Marxist-Leninist governance in 1989–90. Internally
column24: growing nationalist sentiment threatened to break up the Soviet Union
column25: leading Marxist-Leninist hardliners to launch the unsuccessful August Coup against Gorbachev in 1991. In the wake of this
column26: the Soviet Union dissolved against Gorbachev's wishes and he resigned. After leaving office
column27: he launched his Gorbachev Foundation
column28: became a vocal critic of Russian Presidents Boris Yeltsin and Vladimir Putin
column29: and campaigned for Russia's social-democratic movement. Widely considered one of the most significant figures of the second half of the 20th century
column30: Gorbachev remains the subject of controversy. The recipient of a wide range of awards—including the Nobel Peace Prize—he was widely praised for his pivotal role in ending the Cold War
column31: curtailing human rights abuses in the Soviet Union
column32: and tolerating both the fall of Marxist–Leninist administrations in eastern and central Europe and the reunification of Germany. Conversely
column33: in Russia he is often derided for not stopping the Soviet collapse
column34: an event which brought a decline in Russia's global influence and precipitated an economic crisis."

column1: 22050 North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA; Spanish: Tratado de Libre Comercio de América del Norte
column2: TLCAN; French: Accord de libre-échange nord-américain
column3: ALÉNA) is an agreement signed by Canada
column4: Mexico
column5: and the United States
column6: creating a trilateral trade bloc in North America. The agreement came into force on January 1
column8: and superseded the 1988 Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Canada. The NAFTA trade bloc is one of the largest trade blocs in the world by gross domestic product. The impetus for a North American free trade zone began with U.S. President Ronald Reagan
column9: who made the idea part of his 1980 presidential campaign. After the signing of the Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement in 1988
column10: the administrations of U.S. President George H. W. Bush
column11: Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari
column12: and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney agreed to negotiate what became NAFTA. Each submitted the agreement for ratification in their respective capitals in December 1992
column13: but NAFTA faced significant opposition in both the United States and Canada. All three countries ratified NAFTA in 1993 after the addition of two side agreements
column14: the North American Agreement on Labor Cooperation (NAALC) and the North American Agreement on Environmental Cooperation (NAAEC). Passage of NAFTA resulted in the elimination or reduction of barriers to trade and investment between the U.S.
column15: Canada
column16: and Mexico. The effects of the agreement regarding issues such as employment
column17: the environment
column18: and economic growth have been the subject of political disputes. Most economic analyses indicate that NAFTA has been beneficial to the North American economies and the average citizen
column19: but has harmed a small minority of workers in industries exposed to trade competition. Economists hold that withdrawing from NAFTA or renegotiating NAFTA in a way that reestablishes trade barriers would adversely affect the U.S. economy and cost jobs. However
column20: Mexico would be much more severely affected by job loss and reduction of economic growth in both the short term and long term.After U.S. President Donald Trump took office in January 2017
column21: he sought to replace NAFTA with a new agreement
column22: beginning negotiations with Canada and Mexico. In September 2018
column23: the United States
column24: Mexico
column25: and Canada reached an agreement to replace NAFTA with the United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement (USMCA). NAFTA will remain in force
column26: pending the ratification of the USMCA."

column1: 25433 Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Wilson Reagan (; February 6

He graduated from Eureka College in 1932 and worked as a sports commentator on several regional radio stations. After moving to California in 1937

column30: in which he won 98.5% or 523 of the (then-total) 531 electoral votes.Soon after taking office as president

column39: the economy saw a reduction of inflation from 12.5% to 4.4% and an average real GDP annual growth of 3.4%. Reagan enacted cuts in domestic discretionary spending
column40: cut taxes
column42: which contributed to increased federal outlays overall
column43: even after adjustment for inflation. Foreign affairs dominated his second term
column44: including ending the Cold War

column46: the Iran–Iraq War

column51: which shrank both countries' nuclear arsenals. Reagan began his presidency during the decline of the Soviet Union

column54: 1991 (nearly three years after he left office)

column57: matching those of Franklin D. Roosevelt
column59: as the highest ratings for departing presidents in the modern era. He was the first president since Dwight D. Eisenhower to serve two full terms after a succession of five prior presidents did not. Although he had planned an active post-presidency
column60: Reagan disclosed in November 1994 that he had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease earlier that year. Afterward
column61: his informal public appearances became more infrequent as the disease progressed. He died at home on June 5
column62: 2004. His tenure constituted a realignment toward conservative policies in the United States
column63: and he is an icon among conservatives. Evaluations of his presidency among historians and the general public place him among the upper tier of American presidents."

column1: 25473 Richard_Nixon "Richard Milhous Nixon (January 9

His pursuit of the Hiss Case established his reputation as a leading anti-Communist and elevated him to national prominence. He was the running mate of Dwight D. Eisenhower

column1: 33265 Winston_Churchill "Sir Winston Leonard Spencer-Churchill  (30 November 1874 – 24 January 1965) was a British politician

column26: Marshall became an aide-de-camp to John J. Pershing
column27: who was then the Army's Chief of Staff. Marshall later served on the Army staff
column28: commanded the 15th Infantry Regiment in China
column29: and was an instructor at the Army War College. In 1927
column30: he became assistant commandant of the Army's Infantry School
column31: where he modernized command and staff processes
column32: which proved to be of major benefit during World War II. In 1932 and 1933 he commanded the 8th Infantry Regiment and Fort Screven
column33: Georgia.  Marshall commanded 5th Brigade
column34: 3rd Infantry Division and Vancouver Barracks from 1936 to 1938
column35: and received promotion to brigadier general. During this command
column36: Marshall was also responsible for 35 Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) camps in Oregon and southern Washington. In July 1938
column37: Marshall was assigned to the War Plans Division on the War Department staff
column38: and later became the Army's Deputy Chief of Staff. When Chief of Staff Malin Craig retired in 1939
column39: Marshall became acting Chief of Staff
column40: and then Chief of Staff
column41: a position he held until the war's end in 1945. As Chief of Staff
column42: Marshall organized the largest military expansion in U.S. history
column43: and received promotion to five-star rank as General of the Army. Marshall coordinated Allied operations in Europe and the Pacific until the end of the war. In addition to accolades from Churchill and other Allied leaders
column44: Time magazine named Marshall its Man of the Year for 1943. Marshall retired from active service in 1945
column45: but remained on active duty
column46: as required for holders of five-star rank. From December 15
column47: 1945 to January 1947 Marshall served as a special envoy to China in an unsuccessful effort to negotiate a coalition government between the Nationalists of Chiang Kai-shek and Communists under Mao Zedong. As Secretary of State from 1947 to 1949
column49: a program that became known as the Marshall Plan
column50: and which led to his being awarded the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize. After resigning as Secretary of State
column51: Marshall served as chairman of American Battle Monuments Commission and president of the American National Red Cross. As Secretary of Defense at the start of the Korean War
column52: Marshall worked to restore the military's confidence and morale at the end of its post-World War II demobilization and then its initial buildup for combat in Korea and operations during the Cold War.  After resigning as Defense Secretary
column53: Marshall retired to his home in Virginia. He died in 1959 and was buried with honors at Arlington National Cemetery."

column1: 46313 Globalization "Globalization or globalisation is the process  of interaction and integration among people
column2: companies
column3: and governments worldwide. As a complex and multifaceted phenomenon
column4: globalization is considered by some as a form of capitalist expansion which entails the integration of local and national economies into a global
column5: unregulated market economy. Globalization has grown due to advances in transportation and communication technology. With the increased global interactions comes the growth of international trade
column6: ideas
column7: and culture. Globalization is primarily an economic process of interaction and integration that's associated with social and cultural aspects. However
column8: conflicts and diplomacy are also large parts of the history of globalization
column9: and modern globalization. Economically
column10: globalization involves goods
column11: services
column12: the economic resources of capital
column13: technology
column14: and data. Also
column15: the expansions of global markets liberalize the economic activities of the exchange of goods and funds. Removal of cross-border trade barriers has made formation of global markets more feasible.  The steam locomotive
column16: steamship
column17: jet engine
column18: and container ships are some of the advances in the means of transport while the rise of the telegraph and its modern offspring
column19: the Internet and mobile phones show development in telecommunications infrastructure. All of these improvements have been major factors in globalization and have generated further interdependence of economic and cultural activities around the globe.Though many scholars place the origins of globalization in modern times
column20: others trace its history long before the European Age of Discovery and voyages to the New World
column21: some even to the third millennium BC. Large-scale globalization began in the 1820s. In the late 19th century and early 20th century
column22: the connectivity of the world's economies and cultures grew very quickly. The term globalization is recent
column23: only establishing its current meaning in the 1970s.In 2000
column24: the International Monetary Fund (IMF) identified four basic aspects of globalization: trade and transactions
column25: capital and investment movements
column26: migration and movement of people
column27: and the dissemination of knowledge. Further
column28: environmental challenges such as global warming
column29: cross-boundary water
column30: air pollution
column31: and over-fishing of the ocean are linked with globalization. Globalizing processes affect and are affected by business and work organization
column32: economics
column33: socio-cultural resources
column34: and the natural environment. Academic literature commonly subdivides globalization into three major areas: economic globalization
column35: cultural globalization
column36: and political globalization."

column1: 54533 Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon Baines Johnson (; August 27
column2: 1908 – January 22
column4: often referred to by the initials LBJ
column5: was an American politician who served as the 36th president of the United States from 1963 to 1969. Formerly the 37th vice president from 1961 to 1963
column6: he assumed the presidency following the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. A Democrat from Texas
column7: Johnson also served as a United States Representative and as the Majority Leader in the United States Senate. Johnson is one of only four people who have served in all four federal elected positions.Born in a farmhouse in Stonewall
column8: Texas
column9: Johnson was a high school teacher and worked as a congressional aide before winning election to the US House of Representatives in 1937. Johnson won election to the US Senate in 1948 after winning the Democratic Party's nomination by an extremely narrow margin that was manufactured by friendly political machines. He was appointed to the position of Senate Majority Whip in 1951. He became the Senate Minority Leader in 1953 and the Senate Majority Leader in 1955. He became known for his domineering personality and the ""Johnson treatment""
column10: his aggressive coercion of powerful politicians to advance legislation. Johnson ran for the Democratic nomination in the 1960 presidential election. Although unsuccessful
column11: he accepted the invitation of then-Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts to be his running mate. They went on to win a close election over the Republican ticket of Richard Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. On November 22
column13: Kennedy was assassinated and Johnson succeeded him as president. The following year
column14: Johnson won in a landslide
column15: defeating Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona. With 61.1 percent of the popular vote
column16: Johnson won the largest share of the popular vote of any candidate since the largely uncontested 1820 election. In domestic policy
column17: Johnson designed the ""Great Society"" legislation to expand civil rights
column18: public broadcasting
column19: Medicare
column20: Medicaid
column21: aid to education
column22: the arts
column23: urban and rural development
column24: public services and his ""War on Poverty"". Assisted in part by a growing economy
column25: the War on Poverty helped millions of Americans rise above the poverty line during his administration. Civil rights bills that he signed into law banned racial discrimination in public facilities
column26: interstate commerce
column27: the workplace and housing; the Voting Rights Act prohibited certain requirements in southern states used to disenfranchise African Americans. With the passage of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965
column28: the country's immigration system was reformed
column29: encouraging greater emigration from regions other than Europe. Johnson's presidency marked the peak of modern liberalism after the New Deal era. In foreign policy
column30: Johnson escalated American involvement in the Vietnam War. In 1964
column31: Congress passed the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution
column32: which granted Johnson the power to use military force in Southeast Asia without having to ask for an official declaration of war. The number of American military personnel in Vietnam increased dramatically
column33: from 16
column34: 000 advisors in non-combat roles in 1963 to 525
column36: many in combat roles. American casualties soared and the peace process stagnated. Growing unease with the war stimulated a large
column37: angry anti-war movement based chiefly among draft-age students on university campuses. Johnson faced further troubles when summer riots began in major cities in 1965 and crime rates soared
column38: as his opponents raised demands for ""law and order"" policies. While Johnson began his presidency with widespread approval
column39: support for him declined as the public became frustrated with both the war and the growing violence at home. In 1968
column40: the Democratic Party factionalized as anti-war elements denounced Johnson; he ended his bid for renomination after a disappointing finish in the New Hampshire primary. Nixon was elected to succeed him
column41: as the New Deal coalition that had dominated presidential politics for 36 years collapsed. After he left office in January 1969
column42: Johnson returned to his Texas ranch
column43: where he died of a heart attack at age 64
column44: on January 22
column45: 1973. Johnson is ranked favorably by many historians because of his domestic policies and the passage of many major laws that affected civil rights
column46: gun control
column47: wilderness preservation
column49: although he also drew substantial criticism for his escalation of the Vietnam War."

column1: 80125 John_Foster_Dulles "John Foster Dulles (; February 25
column3: 1959) was an American diplomat. A Republican
column4: he served as United States Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower from 1953 to 1959. He was a significant figure in the early Cold War era
column5: advocating an aggressive stance against communism throughout the world. Born in Washington
column6: D.C.
column7: Dulles joined the New York City law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell after graduating from George Washington University Law School. His grandfather
column8: John W. Foster
column9: and his uncle
column10: Robert Lansing
column11: both served as United States Secretary of State
column12: while his brother
column13: Allen Dulles
column14: served as the Director of Central Intelligence from 1953 to 1961. John Foster Dulles served on the War Industries Board during World War I and he was a U.S. legal counsel at the 1919 Paris Peace Conference. He became a member of the League of Free Nations Association
column15: which supported American membership in the League of Nations. Dulles also helped design the Dawes Plan
column16: which sought to stabilize Europe by reducing German war reparations. Dulles served as the chief foreign policy adviser to Thomas E. Dewey
column17: the Republican presidential nominee in 1944 and 1948. He also helped draft the preamble to the United Nations Charter and served as a delegate to the United Nations General Assembly. In 1949
column18: Dewey appointed Dulles to fill the Senate vacancy caused by the resignation of Sen. Robert F. Wagner. He served for four months but left office after being defeated in a special election by Herbert H. Lehman. After Eisenhower won the 1952 presidential election
column19: he chose Dulles as Secretary of State. As Secretary of State
column20: Dulles concentrated on building and strengthening Cold War alliances
column21: most prominently the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He was the architect of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization
column22: an anti-Communist defensive alliance between the United States and several nations in and near Southeast Asia. He also helped instigate the 1953 Iranian coup d'état and the 1954 Guatemalan coup d'état. He favored a strategy of massive retaliation in response to Soviet aggression. He advocated support of the French in their war against the Viet Minh in Indochina but rejected the Geneva Accords that France and the communists agreed to
column23: and instead supported South Vietnam after the Geneva Conference in 1954. Suffering from colon cancer
column24: Dulles resigned from office in 1959 and died later that year."

column1: 204995 Frederick_Winslow_Taylor "Frederick Winslow Taylor (March 20
column2: 1856 – March 21

column4: broadly conceived

column6: Taylor summed up his efficiency techniques in his book The Principles of Scientific Management which

Taylor made his name

column1: 389401 Scientific_management "Scientific management is a theory of management that analyzes and synthesizes workflows. Its main objective is improving economic efficiency
column2: especially labor productivity. It was one of the earliest attempts to apply science to the engineering of processes and to management. Scientific management is sometimes known as Taylorism after its founder
column3: Frederick Winslow Taylor.Taylor began the theory's development in the United States during the 1880s and '90s within manufacturing industries
column4: especially steel. Its peak of influence came in the 1910s; Taylor died in 1915 and by the 1920s
column5: scientific management was still influential but had entered into competition and syncretism with opposing or complementary ideas. Although scientific management as a distinct theory or school of thought was obsolete by the 1930s
column6: most of its themes are still important parts of industrial engineering and management today. These include: analysis; synthesis; logic; rationality; empiricism; work ethic; efficiency and elimination of waste; standardization of best practices; disdain for tradition preserved merely for its own sake or to protect the social status of particular workers with particular skill sets; the transformation of craft production into mass production; and knowledge transfer between workers and from workers into tools
column7: processes
column8: and documentation."

column1: 436940 Economic_interventionism "Economic interventionism
column2: sometimes also called economic statism and state interventionism
column3: is an economic policy perspective favoring government intervention in the market process to correct the market failures and promote the general welfare of the people. An economic intervention is an action taken by a government or international institution in a market economy in an effort to impact the economy beyond the basic regulation of fraud and enforcement of contracts and provision of public goods. Economic intervention can be aimed at a variety of political or economic objectives
column4: such as promoting economic growth
column5: increasing employment
column6: raising wages
column7: raising or reducing prices
column8: promoting income equality
column9: managing the money supply and interest rates
column10: increasing profits
column11: or addressing market failures. The term intervention assumes on a philosophical level that the state and economy should be inherently separated from each other; therefore the terminology applies to capitalist market-based economies where government action interrupts the market forces at play through regulations
column12: economic policies or subsidies (state-owned enterprises that operate in the market do not constitute an intervention). The term intervention is typically used by advocates of laissez-faire and free markets. Capitalist market economies that feature high degrees of state intervention are often referred to as mixed economies."

column1: 534366 Barack_Obama "Barack Hussein Obama II ( (listen); born August 4
column2: 1961) is an American attorney and politician who served as the 44th president of the United States from 2009 to 2017. A member of the Democratic Party
column3: he was the first African American to be elected to the presidency. He previously served as a U.S. senator from Illinois from 2005 to 2008 and an Illinois state senator from 1997 to 2004. Obama was born in Honolulu
column4: Hawaii. After graduating from Columbia University in 1983
column5: he worked as a community organizer in Chicago. In 1988
column6: he enrolled in Harvard Law School
column7: where he was the first black president of the Harvard Law Review. After graduating

column10: when he ran for the U.S. Senate. He received national attention in 2004 with his March primary win
column11: his well-received July Democratic National Convention keynote address
column12: and his landslide November election to the Senate. In 2008
column13: he was nominated for president a year after his campaign began
column14: after a close primary campaign against Hillary Clinton. He was elected over Republican John McCain and was inaugurated on January 20
column15: 2009. Nine months later
column16: he was named the 2009 Nobel Peace Prize laureate. Regarded as a centrist New Democrat
column17: Obama signed many landmark bills into law during his first two years in office. The main reforms that were passed include the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (commonly referred to as the ""Affordable Care Act"" or ""Obamacare"")
column18: the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
column19: and the Don't Ask
column20: Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 and Tax Relief
column21: Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization
column22: and Job Creation Act of 2010 served as economic stimulus amidst the Great Recession. After a lengthy debate over the national debt limit
column23: he signed the Budget Control and the American Taxpayer Relief Acts. In foreign policy
column24: he increased U.S. troop levels in Afghanistan
column25: reduced nuclear weapons with the United States–Russia New START treaty
column26: and ended military involvement in the Iraq War. He ordered military involvement in Libya
column27: contributing to the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi. He also ordered the military operations that resulted in the deaths of Osama bin Laden and suspected Yemeni Al-Qaeda operative Anwar al-Awlaki. After winning re-election by defeating Republican opponent Mitt Romney
column28: Obama was sworn in for a second term in 2013. During this term
column29: he promoted inclusiveness for LGBT Americans. His administration filed briefs that urged the Supreme Court to strike down same-sex marriage bans as unconstitutional (United States v. Windsor and Obergefell v. Hodges); same-sex marriage was fully legalized in 2015 after the Court ruled that a same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional in Obergefell. He advocated for gun control in response to the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting
column30: indicating support for a ban on assault weapons
column31: and issued wide-ranging executive actions concerning global warming and immigration. In foreign policy
column32: he ordered military intervention in Iraq in response to gains made by ISIL after the 2011 withdrawal from Iraq
column33: continued the process of ending U.S. combat operations in Afghanistan in 2016
column34: promoted discussions that led to the 2015 Paris Agreement on global climate change
column35: initiated sanctions against Russia following the invasion in Ukraine and again after Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
column36: brokered a nuclear deal with Iran
column37: and normalized U.S. relations with Cuba. Obama nominated three justices to the Supreme Court: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan were confirmed as justices
column38: while Merrick Garland faced unprecedented partisan obstruction and was ultimately not confirmed. During his term in office
column39: America's soft power and reputation abroad significantly improved.Obama's presidency has generally been regarded favorably
column40: and evaluations of his presidency among historians
column42: and the general public place him among the upper tier of American presidents. Obama left office and retired in January 2017 and currently resides in Washington
column43: D.C. A December 2018 Gallup poll found Obama to be the most admired man in America for an unprecedented 11th consecutive year
column44: although Dwight D. Eisenhower was selected most admired in twelve non-consecutive years."

column1: 541795 Foreign_direct_investment "A foreign direct investment (FDI) is an investment in the form of a controlling ownership in a business in one country by an entity based in another country. column2: as an FDI: the investment may be made either ""inorganically"" by buying a company in the target country or ""organically"" by expanding the operations of an existing business in that country...."

column1: 1838387 Ben_Bernanke "Ben Shalom Bernanke ( bər-NANG-kee; born December 13
column2: 1953) is an American economist at the Brookings Institution who served two terms as Chair of the Federal Reserve
column3: the central bank of the United States
column4: from 2006 to 2014. During his tenure as chair
column5: Bernanke oversaw the Federal Reserve's response to the late-2000s financial crisis. Before becoming Federal Reserve chair
column6: Bernanke was a tenured professor at Princeton University and chaired the department of economics there from 1996 to September 2002
column7: when he went on public service leave. From August 5
column8: 2002 until June 21
column10: he was a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
column11: proposed the Bernanke Doctrine
column12: and first discussed ""the Great Moderation"" — the theory that traditional business cycles have declined in volatility in recent decades through structural changes that have occurred in the international economy
column13: particularly increases in the economic stability of developing nations
column14: diminishing the influence of macroeconomic (monetary and fiscal) policy. Bernanke then served as chairman of President George W. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers before President Bush nominated him to succeed Alan Greenspan as chairman of the United States Federal Reserve. His first term began February 1
column15: 2006. Bernanke was confirmed for a second term as chairman on January 28
column17: after being renominated by President Barack Obama
column18: who later referred to him as ""the epitome of calm."" His second term ended January 31
column20: when he was succeeded by Janet Yellen on February 3
column21: 2014. Bernanke wrote about his time as chairman of the Federal Reserve in his 2015 book
column22: The Courage to Act
column23: in which he revealed that the world's economy came close to collapse in 2007 and 2008.  Bernanke asserts that it was only the novel efforts of the Fed (cooperating with other agencies and agencies of foreign governments) that prevented an economic catastrophe greater than the Great Depression."

column1: 2731583 Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler (German: [ˈadɔlf ˈhɪtlɐ] (listen); 20 April 1889 – 30 April 1945) was a German politician and leader of the Nazi Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei; NSDAP). He rose to power as Chancellor of Germany in 1933
column2: and as Führer in 1934. During his dictatorship from 1933 to 1945
column3: he initiated World War II in Europe by invading Poland on 1 September 1939. He was closely involved in military operations throughout the war and was central to the perpetration of the Holocaust. Hitler's actions and ideology are almost universally regarded as evil. According to historian Ian Kershaw
column4: ""Never in history has such ruination—physical and moral—been associated with the name of one man.""Hitler was born in Austria—then part of Austria-Hungary—and was raised near Linz. He moved to Germany in 1913 and was decorated during his service in the German Army in World War I. In 1919
column5: he joined the German Workers' Party (DAP)
column6: the precursor of the NSDAP
column7: and was appointed leader of the NSDAP in 1921. In 1923
column8: he attempted to seize power in a failed coup in Munich and was imprisoned. In jail
column9: he dictated the first volume of his autobiography and political manifesto Mein Kampf (""My Struggle""). After his release in 1924
column10: Hitler gained popular support by attacking the Treaty of Versailles and promoting Pan-Germanism
column11: anti-semitism and anti-communism with charismatic oratory and Nazi propaganda. He frequently denounced international capitalism and communism as part of a Jewish conspiracy. By November 1932
column12: the Nazi Party had the most seats in the German Reichstag
column13: but did not have a majority
column14: and no party was able to form a majority parliamentary coalition in support of a candidate for chancellor. Former chancellor Franz von Papen and other conservative leaders persuaded President Paul von Hindenburg to appoint Hitler as Chancellor on 30 January 1933. Shortly after
column15: the Reichstag passed the Enabling Act of 1933
column16: which began the process of transforming the Weimar Republic into Nazi Germany
column17: a one-party dictatorship based on the totalitarian and autocratic ideology of National Socialism. Hitler aimed to eliminate Jews from Germany and establish a New Order to counter what he saw as the injustice of the post-World War I international order dominated by Britain and France. His first six years in power resulted in rapid economic recovery from the Great Depression
column18: the abrogation of restrictions imposed on Germany after World War I
column19: and the annexation of territories inhabited by millions of ethnic Germans
column20: which gave him significant popular support. Hitler sought Lebensraum (""living space"") for the German people in Eastern Europe
column21: and his aggressive foreign policy is considered the primary cause of World War II in Europe. He directed large-scale rearmament and
column22: on 1 September 1939
column23: invaded Poland
column24: resulting in Britain and France declaring war on Germany. In June 1941
column25: Hitler ordered an invasion of the Soviet Union. By the end of 1941
column26: German forces and the European Axis powers occupied most of Europe and North Africa. These gains were gradually reversed after 1941
column27: and in 1945 the Allied armies defeated the German army. On 29 April 1945
column28: he married his longtime lover Eva Braun. Less than two days later
column29: the two committed suicide to avoid capture by the Soviet Red Army; their corpses were burned.  Under Hitler's leadership and racially motivated ideology
column30: the Nazi regime was responsible for the genocide of at least 5.5 million Jews and millions of other victims whom he and his followers deemed Untermenschen (subhumans) or socially undesirable. Hitler and the Nazi regime were also responsible for the killing of an estimated 19.3 million civilians and prisoners of war. In addition
column31: 28.7 million soldiers and civilians died as a result of military action in the European theatre. The number of civilians killed during World War II was unprecedented in warfare
column32: and the casualties constitute the deadliest conflict in history."

column1: 3414021 George_W._Bush "George Walker Bush (born July 6
column2: 1946) is an American politician and businessman who served as the 43rd president of the United States from 2001 to 2009. He had previously served as the 46th governor of Texas from 1995 to 2000. Bush is frequently referred to as George W. Bush
column3: Bush Junior
column4: or Bush 43 to distinguish him from his father
column5: George H. W. Bush
column6: who served as the 41st president from 1989 to 1993.   Bush is the eldest son of Barbara and George H. W. Bush
column7: the 41st president of the United States
column8: and is the second president to so follow in his father's footsteps
column9: the first being John Quincy Adams. After graduating from Yale University in 1968 and Harvard Business School in 1975
column10: he worked in the oil industry. Bush married Laura Welch in 1977 and unsuccessfully ran for the U.S. House of Representatives shortly thereafter. He later co-owned the Texas Rangers baseball team before defeating Ann Richards in the 1994 Texas gubernatorial election. Bush was elected President of the United States in 2000 when he defeated Democratic incumbent Vice President Al Gore after a narrow and contested win that involved a stopped recount in Florida. He became the fourth person to be elected president while receiving fewer popular votes than his opponent.In response to the September 11 terrorist attacks
column11: Bush launched a ""War on Terror"" that initially included the war in Afghanistan in 2001 and the Iraq War in 2003. He signed into law broad tax cuts
column12: the Patriot Act
column13: the No Child Left Behind Act
column14: the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act
