column15: Medicare prescription drug benefits for seniors
column16: and funding for the AIDS relief program known as PEPFAR. In the 2004 presidential race
column17: Bush defeated Democratic Senator John Kerry in a close election. After his re-election
column18: Bush received criticism from across the political spectrum for his handling of the Iraq War
column19: Hurricane Katrina
column20: and other challenges. Amid this criticism
column21: the Democratic Party regained control of Congress in the 2006 elections. In December 2007
column22: the United States entered its longest post-World War II recession
column23: often referred to as the ""Great Recession""
column24: prompting the Bush administration to obtain congressional passage of multiple economic programs intended to preserve the country's financial system. Bush was among the most popular
column25: as well as unpopular
column26: U.S. presidents in history; he received the highest recorded approval ratings in the wake of the 9/11 attacks
column27: but one of the lowest such ratings during the 2008 financial crisis. Bush finished his term in office in 2009 and returned to Texas. In 2010
column28: he published his memoir
column29: Decision Points. His presidential library opened in 2013. His presidency has been rated below average in historians' polls
column30: although his favorability ratings have improved since leaving office."

column1: 3418303 Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman (May 8
column2: 1884 – December 26
column3: 1972) was the 33rd president of the United States from 1945 to 1953
column4: succeeding upon the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt after serving as vice president. He implemented the Marshall Plan to rebuild the economy of Western Europe
column5: and established the Truman Doctrine and NATO. Truman was elected to the United States Senate from Missouri in 1934 and gained national prominence as chairman of the Truman Committee aimed at reducing waste and inefficiency in wartime contracts. Soon after succeeding to the presidency he authorized the first and only use of nuclear weapons in war. Truman's administration engaged in an internationalist foreign policy and renounced isolationism. He rallied his New Deal coalition during the 1948 presidential election and won a surprise victory that secured his own presidential term. Truman oversaw the Berlin Airlift of 1948.  When North Korea invaded South Korea in 1950
column6: he gained United Nations approval for the very large policy action known as the Korean War. It saved South Korea but the Chinese intervened
column7: driving back the UN/US forces and preventing a rollback of communism in North Korea. On domestic issues
column8: bills endorsed by Truman faced opposition from a conservative Congress
column9: but his administration successfully guided the U.S. economy through the post-war economic challenges. In 1948 he submitted the first comprehensive civil rights legislation and issued Executive Orders to start racial integration in the military and federal agencies. Corruption in the Truman administration became a central campaign issue in the 1952 presidential election. After Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower's electoral victory against Democrat Adlai Stevenson II
column10: Truman went into a financially-difficult retirement
column11: marked by the founding of his presidential library and the publication of his memoirs. When he left office
column12: Truman's presidency was criticized
column13: but scholars rehabilitated his image in the 1960s and he is highly ranked by scholars."

column1: 3434750 United_States "The United States of America (USA)
column2: commonly known as the United States (U.S. or US) or simply America
column3: is a country comprising 50 states
column4: a federal district
column5: five major self-governing territories
column6: and various possessions. At 3.8 million square miles (9.8 million km2)
column7: the United States is the world's third or fourth largest country by total area and is slightly smaller than the entire continent of Europe. Most of the country is located in central North America between Canada and Mexico. With an estimated population of over 327 million people
column8: the U.S. is the third most populous country. The capital is Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: and the most populous city is New York City. Paleo-Indians migrated from Siberia to the North American mainland at least 12
column11: 000 years ago. European colonization began in the 16th century. The United States emerged from the thirteen British colonies established along the East Coast. Numerous disputes between Great Britain and the colonies led to the American Revolutionary War lasting between 1775 and 1783
column12: leading to independence. The United States embarked on a vigorous expansion across North America throughout the 19th century
column13: gradually acquiring new territories
column14: displacing Native Americans
column15: and admitting new states until spanning the continent by 1848. During the second half of the 19th century
column16: the American Civil War led to the abolition of slavery in the United States. The Spanish–American War and World War I confirmed the country's status as a global military power. The United States emerged from World War II as a global superpower. It was the first country to develop nuclear weapons
column17: and the only one to use them in warfare. During the Cold War
column18: the United States and the Soviet Union competed in the Space Race
column19: culminating with the 1969 Apollo 11 mission
column20: the spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. The end of the Cold War and collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 left the United States as the world's sole superpower.The United States is a federal republic and a representative democracy. It is a founding member of the United Nations
column21: World Bank
column22: International Monetary Fund
column23: Organization of American States (OAS)
column24: NATO
column25: and other international organizations. It is a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. A highly developed country
column26: the United States is the world's largest economy by nominal GDP
column27: the second-largest by purchasing power parity
column28: and accounts for approximately a quarter of global GDP. The United States is the world's largest importer and the second-largest exporter of goods
column29: by value. Although its population is 4% of the world total
column30: it holds 31% of the total wealth in the world
column31: the largest share of global wealth concentrated in a single country. Despite income and wealth disparities
column32: the United States continues to rank very high in measures of socioeconomic performance
column33: including average wage
column34: median income
column35: median wealth
column36: human development
column37: per capita GDP
column38: and worker productivity. It is the foremost military power in the world
column39: making up a third of global military spending
column40: and is a leading political
column42: and scientific force internationally."

column1: 4848272 Donald_Trump "Donald John Trump (born June 14
column2: 1946) is the 45th and current president of the United States. Before entering politics
column3: he was a businessman and television personality. Trump was born and raised in the New York City borough of Queens
column4: and received a B.S. degree in economics from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He took charge of his family's real-estate business in 1971
column5: renamed it The Trump Organization
column6: and expanded its operations from Queens and Brooklyn into Manhattan. The company built or renovated skyscrapers
column7: hotels
column8: casinos
column9: and golf courses. Trump later started various side ventures
column10: mostly by licensing his name. He owned the Miss Universe and Miss USA beauty pageants from 1996 to 2015
column11: and produced and hosted The Apprentice
column12: a reality television show
column13: from 2003 to 2015. Forbes estimates his net worth to be $3.1 billion.Trump entered the 2016 presidential race as a Republican and defeated 16 other candidates in the primaries. His political positions have been described as populist
column14: protectionist
column15: and nationalist. He was elected in a surprise victory over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton
column16: although he lost the popular vote. He became the oldest first-term U.S. president
column17: and the first one without prior military or government service. His election and policies have sparked numerous protests. Trump has made many false or misleading statements during his campaign and presidency. The statements have been documented by fact-checkers
column18: and the media have widely described the phenomenon as unprecedented in American politics. Many of his comments and actions have also been characterized as racially charged or racist. During his presidency
column19: Trump ordered a travel ban on citizens from several Muslim-majority countries
column20: citing security concerns; after legal challenges
column21: the Supreme Court upheld the policy's third revision. He enacted a tax-cut package for individuals and businesses
column22: rescinding the individual health insurance mandate. He appointed Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. In foreign policy
column23: Trump has pursued an America First agenda
column24: withdrawing the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade negotiations
column25: the Paris Agreement on climate change
column26: and the Iran nuclear deal. He recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel
column27: imposed import tariffs triggering a trade war with China
column28: and started negotiations with North Korea toward their denuclearization. A special counsel investigation led by Robert Mueller found that Trump and his campaign welcomed and encouraged Russian foreign interference in the 2016 presidential election under the belief that it would be politically advantageous
column29: but did not find sufficient evidence to press charges of criminal conspiracy with Russia. Mueller also investigated Trump for obstruction of justice
column30: and his report neither indicted nor exonerated Trump on that score. The House of Representatives launched an impeachment inquiry following a September 2019 report that Trump had abused his presidential power by pressuring the president of Ukraine to undertake actions which would have the effect of helping Trump's 2020 re-election campaign. Among other inducements
column31: Trump ordered congressionally-mandated military aid for Ukraine to be withheld. Witnesses subsequently testified that Trump and his surrogates had been carrying out that pressure campaign for months."

column1: 5119376 John_F._Kennedy "John Fitzgerald Kennedy (May 29
column2: 1917 – November 22
column4: often referred to by the initials JFK and Jack
column5: was an American politician who served as the 35th president of the United States from January 1961 until his assassination in November 1963. Kennedy served at the height of the Cold War
column6: and the majority of his work as president dealt with managing relations with the Soviet Union and Cuba. A Democrat
column7: Kennedy represented Massachusetts in the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate prior to becoming president. Kennedy was born into a wealthy
column8: political family in Brookline
column9: Massachusetts. He graduated from Harvard University in 1940
column10: before joining the U.S. Naval Reserve the following year. During World War II
column11: he commanded a series of PT boats in the Pacific theater and earned the Navy and Marine Corps Medal for his service. After the war
column12: Kennedy represented the 11th congressional district of Massachusetts in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1947 to 1953. He was subsequently elected to the U.S. Senate and served as the junior Senator from Massachusetts from 1953 to 1960. While in the Senate
column13: Kennedy published his book Profiles in Courage
column14: which won a Pulitzer Prize. In the 1960 presidential election
column15: he narrowly defeated Republican opponent Richard Nixon
column16: who was the incumbent vice president. Kennedy's administration included high tensions with communist states in the Cold War. He increased the number of American military advisers in South Vietnam. In April 1961
column17: he authorized a vain attempt to overthrow the Cuban government of Fidel Castro in the Bay of Pigs Invasion. Kennedy authorized the Cuban Project in November 1961. He rejected Operation Northwoods (plans for false flag attacks to gain approval for a war against Cuba) in March 1962
column18: however his administration continued to plan for an invasion of Cuba in the summer of 1962. In October 1962
column19: U.S. spy planes discovered Soviet missile bases had been deployed in Cuba; the resulting period of tensions
column20: termed the Cuban Missile Crisis
column21: nearly resulted in the breakout of a global thermonuclear conflict. Domestically
column22: Kennedy presided over the establishment of the Peace Corps and the continuation of the Apollo space program
column23: and supported the Civil Rights Movement
column24: but was only somewhat successful in passing his New Frontier domestic policies. On November 22
column26: he was assassinated in Dallas
column27: Texas. Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson assumed the presidency upon Kennedy's death. Marxist Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested for the state crime
column28: but he was shot to death by Jack Ruby two days later. The FBI and the Warren Commission both concluded Oswald had acted alone in the assassination
column29: but various groups contested the Warren Report and believed that Kennedy was the victim of a conspiracy. After Kennedy's death
column30: Congress enacted many of his proposals
column31: including the Civil Rights Act and the Revenue Act of 1964. Kennedy ranks highly in polls of U.S. presidents with historians and the general public. His personal life has also been the focus of considerable interest
column32: following revelations of his chronic health ailments and extramarital affairs."

column1: 20949522 Bureaucracy "Bureaucracy () refers to both a body of non-elected government officials and an  administrative policy-making group. Historically
column2: a bureaucracy was a government administration managed by departments staffed with non-elected officials. Today
column3: bureaucracy is the administrative system governing any large institution
column4: whether publicly owned or privately owned. The public administration in many countries is an example of a bureaucracy
column5: but so is the centralized hierarchical structure of a business firm. Various commentators have noted the necessity of bureaucracies in modern society. The German sociologist Max Weber argued that bureaucracy constitutes the most efficient and rational way in which human activity can be organized and that systematic processes and organized hierarchies are necessary to maintain order
column6: maximize efficiency
column7: and eliminate favoritism. On the other hand
column8: Weber also saw unfettered bureaucracy as a threat to individual freedom
column9: with the potential of trapping individuals in an impersonal ""iron cage"" of rule-based
column10: rational control."

column1: 21492751 Nelson_Mandela "Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (; Xhosa: [xolíɬaɬa mandɛ̂ːla]; 18 July 1918 – 5 December 2013) was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary
column2: political leader
column3: and philanthropist who served as President of South Africa from 1994 to 1999. He was the country's first black head of state and the first elected in a fully representative democratic election. His government focused on dismantling the legacy of apartheid by tackling institutionalised racism and fostering racial reconciliation. Ideologically an African nationalist and socialist
column4: he served as President of the African National Congress (ANC) party from 1991 to 1997. A Xhosa
column5: Mandela was born to the Thembu royal family in Mvezo
column6: British South Africa. He studied law at the University of Fort Hare and the University of Witwatersrand before working as a lawyer in Johannesburg. There he became involved in anti-colonial and African nationalist politics
column7: joining the ANC in 1943 and co-founding its Youth League in 1944. After the National Party's white-only government established apartheid
column8: a system of racial segregation that privileged whites
column9: he and the ANC committed themselves to its overthrow. Mandela was appointed President of the ANC's Transvaal branch
column10: rising to prominence for his involvement in the 1952 Defiance Campaign and the 1955 Congress of the People. He was repeatedly arrested for seditious activities and was unsuccessfully prosecuted in the 1956 Treason Trial. Influenced by Marxism
column11: he secretly joined the banned South African Communist Party (SACP). Although initially committed to non-violent protest
column12: in association with the SACP he co-founded the militant Umkhonto we Sizwe in 1961 and led a sabotage campaign against the government. He was arrested and imprisoned in 1962
column13: and subsequently sentenced to life imprisonment for conspiring to overthrow the state following the Rivonia Trial. Mandela served 27 years in prison
column14: split between Robben Island
column15: Pollsmoor Prison
column16: and Victor Verster Prison. Amid growing domestic and international pressure
column17: and with fears of a racial civil war
column18: President F. W. de Klerk released him in 1990. Mandela and de Klerk led efforts to negotiate an end to apartheid
column19: which resulted in the 1994 multiracial general election in which Mandela led the ANC to victory and became president. Leading a broad coalition government which promulgated a new constitution
column20: Mandela emphasised reconciliation between the country's racial groups and created the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to investigate past human rights abuses. Economically
column21: Mandela's administration retained its predecessor's liberal framework despite his own socialist beliefs
column22: also introducing measures to encourage land reform
column23: combat poverty
column24: and expand healthcare services. Internationally
column25: he acted as mediator in the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing trial and served as Secretary-General of the Non-Aligned Movement from 1998 to 1999. He declined a second presidential term
column26: and in 1999 was succeeded by his deputy
column27: Thabo Mbeki. Mandela became an elder statesman and focused on combating poverty and HIV/AIDS through the charitable Nelson Mandela Foundation. Mandela was a controversial figure for much of his life. Although critics on the right denounced him as a communist terrorist and those on the far-left deemed him too eager to negotiate and reconcile with apartheid's supporters
column28: he gained international acclaim for his activism. Widely regarded as an icon of democracy and social justice
column29: he received more than 250 honours—including the Nobel Peace Prize—and became the subject of a cult of personality. He is held in deep respect within South Africa
column30: where he is often referred to by his Xhosa clan name
column31: Madiba
column32: and described as the ""Father of the Nation""."

column1: 31898279 If_Women_Counted "If Women Counted (1988) is a book by New Zealand academic and former politician Marilyn Waring
column2: that is regarded as the ""founding document"" of the discipline of feminist economics. The book is a groundbreaking and systematic critique of the system of national accounts
column3: the international standard of measuring economic growth
column4: and the ways in which women's unpaid work as well as the value of Nature have been excluded from what counts as productive in the economy. The book ""persuaded the United Nations to redefine gross domestic product
column5: inspired new accounting methods in dozens of countries
column6: and became the founding document of the discipline of feminist economics."" A widely cited book
column7: it made the analysis of this topic known to a large audience."

column1: 34781830 Ailsa_McKay "Ailsa McKay (7 June 1963 – 5 March 2014) was a Scottish economist
column2: government policy adviser
column3: a leading feminist economist and Professor of Economics at Glasgow Caledonian University. She was noted for her research on gender inequalities and the economics of the welfare state
column4: for her contributions to feminist economics
column5: as a leading proponent of the basic income concept and as one of the UK's foremost experts on gender budgeting. She served as Vice Dean of the Glasgow School for Business and Society
column6: and was also well known for her support of Scottish independence and as a key adviser to the Scottish government and First Minister Alex Salmond on economic and welfare state policies. Ailsa McKay is highlighted as a leading intellectual figure in the campaign for independence in Alex Salmond's 2015 book The Dream Shall Never Die. Both Salmond and his successor Nicola Sturgeon have highlighted McKay's influence on Scottish gender equality policies. She was a member of the board of directors of the left-wing Jimmy Reid Foundation think tank
column7: and was an adviser to the United Nations. With Margunn Bjørnholt
column8: she co-edited the book Counting on Marilyn Waring: New Advances in Feminist Economics
column9: which was published days before her death. The Ailsa McKay Fellowship
column10: the Ailsa McKay Lecture
column11: one of the foremost honours in feminist economics
column12: and the McKay House at Lenzie Academy are named in her honour."

column1: 51725 Melinda_Gates "Melinda Ann Gates DBE (née French; August 15
column2: 1964) is an American philanthropist and a former general manager at Microsoft. In 2000
column3: she co-founded the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation with her husband Bill Gates
column4: the world's largest private charitable organization. Gates has consistently been ranked as one of the world's most powerful women by Forbes."

column1: 534366 Barack_Obama "Barack Hussein Obama II ( (listen); born August 4
column2: 1961) is an American attorney and politician who served as the 44th president of the United States from 2009 to 2017. A member of the Democratic Party
column3: he was the first African American to be elected to the presidency. He previously served as a U.S. senator from Illinois from 2005 to 2008 and an Illinois state senator from 1997 to 2004. Obama was born in Honolulu
column4: Hawaii. After graduating from Columbia University in 1983
column5: he worked as a community organizer in Chicago. In 1988
column6: he enrolled in Harvard Law School
column7: where he was the first black president of the Harvard Law Review. After graduating
column8: he became a civil rights attorney and an academic
column9: teaching constitutional law at the University of Chicago Law School from 1992 to 2004. He represented the 13th district for three terms in the Illinois Senate from 1997 until 2004
column10: when he ran for the U.S. Senate. He received national attention in 2004 with his March primary win
column11: his well-received July Democratic National Convention keynote address
column12: and his landslide November election to the Senate. In 2008
column13: he was nominated for president a year after his campaign began
column14: after a close primary campaign against Hillary Clinton. He was elected over Republican John McCain and was inaugurated on January 20
column15: 2009. Nine months later
column16: he was named the 2009 Nobel Peace Prize laureate. Regarded as a centrist New Democrat
column17: Obama signed many landmark bills into law during his first two years in office. The main reforms that were passed include the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (commonly referred to as the ""Affordable Care Act"" or ""Obamacare"")
column18: the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
column19: and the Don't Ask
column20: Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 and Tax Relief
column21: Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization
column22: and Job Creation Act of 2010 served as economic stimulus amidst the Great Recession. After a lengthy debate over the national debt limit
column23: he signed the Budget Control and the American Taxpayer Relief Acts. In foreign policy
column24: he increased U.S. troop levels in Afghanistan
column25: reduced nuclear weapons with the United States–Russia New START treaty
column26: and ended military involvement in the Iraq War. He ordered military involvement in Libya
column27: contributing to the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi. He also ordered the military operations that resulted in the deaths of Osama bin Laden and suspected Yemeni Al-Qaeda operative Anwar al-Awlaki. After winning re-election by defeating Republican opponent Mitt Romney
column28: Obama was sworn in for a second term in 2013. During this term
column29: he promoted inclusiveness for LGBT Americans. His administration filed briefs that urged the Supreme Court to strike down same-sex marriage bans as unconstitutional (United States v. Windsor and Obergefell v. Hodges); same-sex marriage was fully legalized in 2015 after the Court ruled that a same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional in Obergefell. He advocated for gun control in response to the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting
column30: indicating support for a ban on assault weapons
column31: and issued wide-ranging executive actions concerning global warming and immigration. In foreign policy
column32: he ordered military intervention in Iraq in response to gains made by ISIL after the 2011 withdrawal from Iraq
column33: continued the process of ending U.S. combat operations in Afghanistan in 2016
column34: promoted discussions that led to the 2015 Paris Agreement on global climate change
column35: initiated sanctions against Russia following the invasion in Ukraine and again after Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
column36: brokered a nuclear deal with Iran
column37: and normalized U.S. relations with Cuba. Obama nominated three justices to the Supreme Court: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan were confirmed as justices
column38: while Merrick Garland faced unprecedented partisan obstruction and was ultimately not confirmed. During his term in office
column39: America's soft power and reputation abroad significantly improved.Obama's presidency has generally been regarded favorably
column40: and evaluations of his presidency among historians
column42: and the general public place him among the upper tier of American presidents. Obama left office and retired in January 2017 and currently resides in Washington
column43: D.C. A December 2018 Gallup poll found Obama to be the most admired man in America for an unprecedented 11th consecutive year
column44: although Dwight D. Eisenhower was selected most admired in twelve non-consecutive years."

column1: 20715044 Game_of_Thrones "Game of Thrones is an American  fantasy drama television series created by David Benioff and D. B. Weiss for HBO. It is an adaptation of A Song of Ice and Fire
column2: George R. R. Martin's series of fantasy novels
column3: the first of which is A Game of Thrones. The show was both produced and filmed in Belfast and elsewhere in the United Kingdom. Filming locations also included Canada
column4: Croatia
column5: Iceland
column6: Malta
column7: Morocco
column8: and Spain. The series premiered on HBO in the United States on April 17
column10: and concluded on May 19
column12: with 73 episodes broadcast over eight seasons.  Set on the fictional continents of Westeros and Essos
column13: Game of Thrones has several plots and a large ensemble cast and follows several story arcs. One arc is about the Iron Throne of the Seven Kingdoms and follows a web of alliances and conflicts among the noble dynasties either vying to claim the throne or fighting for independence from it. Another focuses on the last descendant of the realm's deposed ruling dynasty
column14: who has been exiled and is plotting a return to the throne
column15: while another story arc follows the Night's Watch
column16: a brotherhood defending the realm against the fierce peoples and legendary creatures of the North. Game of Thrones attracted a record viewership on HBO and has a broad
column17: active
column18: and international fan base. The series was acclaimed by critics for its acting
column19: complex characters
column20: story
column21: scope
column22: and production values
column23: although its frequent use of nudity and violence (including sexual violence) was criticized; the final season received further criticism for its condensed story and creative decisions
column24: with many considering it a disappointing conclusion. The series received 58 Primetime Emmy Awards
column25: the most by a drama series
column26: including Outstanding Drama Series in 2015
column29: 2019. Its other awards and nominations include three Hugo Awards for Best Dramatic Presentation (2012–2014)
column30: a 2011 Peabody Award
column31: and five nominations for the Golden Globe Award for Best Television Series – Drama (2012 and 2015–2018). In 2019
column32: the show's final season established a new record for most Emmy nominations received in the same year by any regular series with 32
column33: breaking the 25 years long record of 26 nominations established by NYPD Blue in 1994; it also established Game of Thrones as the drama series with the most overall Emmy nominations
column34: with a total of 161.Of the ensemble cast
column35: Peter Dinklage has won four Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series (2011
column38: and 2019) and the Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Series
column39: Miniseries or Television Film (2012) for his performance as Tyrion Lannister. Alfie Allen
column40: Gwendoline Christie
column42: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau
column43: Lena Headey
column44: Kit Harington
column45: Sophie Turner
column46: Diana Rigg
column47: Carice van Houten
column49: and Maisie Williams have also received Primetime Emmy Award nominations for their performances."

column1: 1203 Alternate_history "Alternate history or alternative history (Commonwealth English) (AH) is a genre of speculative fiction consisting of stories in which one or more historical events occur differently. These stories usually contain ""what if"" scenarios at crucial points in history and present outcomes other than those in the historical record. The stories are conjectural but are sometimes based on fact. Alternate history has been seen as a subgenre of literary fiction
column2: science fiction
column3: or historical fiction; alternate history works may use tropes from any or all of these genres. Another term occasionally used for the genre is ""allohistory"" (literally ""other history"").Since the 1950s
column4: this type of fiction has
column5: to a large extent
column6: merged with science fiction tropes involving time travel between alternate histories
column7: psychic awareness of the existence of one universe by the people in another
column8: or time travel that results in history splitting into two or more timelines. Cross-time
column9: time-splitting
column10: and alternate history themes have become so closely interwoven that it is impossible to discuss them fully apart from one another. In Spanish
column11: French
column12: German
column13: Portuguese
column14: Italian
column15: Catalan and Galician
column16: the genre of alternate history is called uchronie / ucronia / ucronía / Uchronie
column17: which has given rise to the term Uchronia in English. This neologism is based on the prefix ου- (which in Ancient Greek means ""not/not any/no"") and the Greek χρόνος (chronos)
column18: meaning ""time"". A uchronia means literally ""(in) no time"". This term apparently also inspired the name of the alternate history book list
column19: uchronia.net."

column1: 4400 Bear "Bears are carnivoran mammals of the family Ursidae. They are classified as caniforms
column2: or doglike carnivorans. Although only eight species of bears are extant
column3: they are widespread
column4: appearing in a wide variety of habitats throughout the Northern Hemisphere and partially in the Southern Hemisphere. Bears are found on the continents of North America
column5: South America
column6: Europe
column7: and Asia. Common characteristics of modern bears include large bodies with stocky legs
column8: long snouts
column9: small rounded ears
column10: shaggy hair
column11: plantigrade paws with five nonretractile claws
column12: and short tails. While the polar bear is mostly carnivorous
column13: and the giant panda feeds almost entirely on bamboo
column14: the remaining six species are omnivorous with varied diets. With the exception of courting individuals and mothers with their young
column15: bears are typically solitary animals. They may be diurnal or nocturnal and have an excellent sense of smell. Despite their heavy build and awkward gait
column16: they are adept runners
column17: climbers
column18: and swimmers.  Bears use shelters
column19: such as caves and logs
column20: as their dens; most species occupy their dens during the winter for a long period of hibernation
column21: up to 100 days. Bears have been hunted since prehistoric times for their meat and fur; they have been used for bear-baiting and other forms of entertainment
column22: such as being made to dance. With their powerful physical presence
column23: they play a prominent role in the arts
column24: mythology
column25: and other cultural aspects of various human societies. In modern times
column26: bears have come under pressure through encroachment on their habitats and illegal trade in bear parts
column27: including the Asian bile bear market. The IUCN lists six bear species as vulnerable or endangered
column28: and even least concern species
column29: such as the brown bear
column30: are at risk of extirpation in certain countries. The poaching and international trade of these most threatened populations are prohibited
column31: but still ongoing."

column1: 6678 Cat "The cat (Felis catus) is a small carnivorous mammal. It is the only domesticated species in the family Felidae and often referred to as the domestic cat to distinguish it from wild members of the family. The cat is either a house cat or a farm cat
column2: which are pets
column3: or a feral cat
column4: which ranges freely and avoids human contact. A house cat is valued by humans for companionship and for its ability to hunt rodents. About 60 cat breeds are recognized by various cat registries.The cat is similar in anatomy to the other felid species
column5: has a strong flexible body
column6: quick reflexes
column7: sharp teeth and retractable claws adapted to killing small prey. Its night vision and sense of smell are well developed. Cat communication includes vocalizations like meowing
column8: purring
column9: trilling
column10: hissing
column11: growling and grunting as well as cat-specific body language. It is a solitary hunter
column12: but a social species. It can hear sounds too faint or too high in frequency for human ears
column13: such as those made by mice and other small mammals. It is a predator that is most active at dawn and dusk. It secretes and perceives pheromones.Female domestic cats can have kittens from spring to late autumn
column14: with litter sizes ranging from two to five kittens.  Domestic cats are bred and shown as registered pedigreed cats
column15: a hobby known as cat fancy. Failure to control breeding of pet cats by spaying and neutering
column16: as well as abandonment of pets
column17: resulted in large numbers of feral cats worldwide
column18: contributing to the extinction of entire bird species
column19: and evoking population control.It was long thought that cat domestication was initiated in Egypt
column20: because cats in ancient Egypt were venerated since around 3100 BC. However
column21: the earliest indication for the taming of an African wildcat (F. lybica) was found in Cyprus
column22: where a cat skeleton was excavated close by a human Neolithic grave dating to around 7500 BC. African wildcats were probably first domesticated in the Near East.As of 2017
column23: the domestic cat was the second-most popular pet in the U.S. by number of pets owned
column24: after freshwater fish
column25: with 95 million cats owned. In the United Kingdom
column26: around 7.3 million cats lived in more than 4.8 million households as of 2019."

column1: 7164 Color_temperature "Not to be confused with warm and cool colors. The color temperature of a light source is the temperature of an ideal black-body radiator that radiates light of a color comparable to that of the light source. Color temperature is a characteristic of visible light that has important applications in lighting
column2: photography
column3: videography
column4: publishing
column5: manufacturing
column6: astrophysics
column7: horticulture
column8: and other fields. In practice
column9: color temperature is meaningful only for light sources that do in fact correspond somewhat closely to the radiation of some black body
column10: i.e.
column11: light in a range going from red to orange to yellow to white to blueish white; it does not make sense to speak of the color temperature of
column12: e.g.
column13: a green or a purple light. Color temperature is conventionally expressed in kelvins
column14: using the symbol K
column15: a unit of measure for absolute temperature. Color temperatures over 5000 K are called ""cool colors"" (bluish)
column16: while lower color temperatures (2700–3000 K) are called ""warm colors"" (yellowish). ""Warm"" in this context is an analogy to radiated heat flux of traditional incandescent lighting rather than temperature. The spectral peak of warm-coloured light is closer to infrared
column17: and most natural warm-coloured light sources emit significant infrared radiation. The fact that ""warm"" lighting in this sense actually has a ""cooler"" color temperature often leads to confusion."

column1: 10958 Fossil "A fossil (from Classical Latin fossilis; literally
column2: ""obtained by digging"") is any preserved remains
column3: impression
column4: or trace of any once-living thing from a past geological age. Examples include bones
column5: shells
column6: exoskeletons
column7: stone imprints of animals or microbes
column8: objects preserved in amber
column9: hair
column10: petrified wood
column11: oil
column12: coal
column13: and DNA remnants. The totality of fossils is known as the fossil record. Paleontology is the study of fossils: their age
column14: method of formation
column15: and evolutionary significance. Specimens are usually considered to be fossils if they are over 10
column16: 000 years old. The oldest fossils are around 3.48 billion years old to 4.1 billion years old. The observation in the 19th century that certain fossils were associated with certain rock strata led to the recognition of a geological timescale and the relative ages of different fossils. The development of radiometric dating techniques in the early 20th century allowed scientists to quantitatively measure the absolute ages of rocks and the fossils they host. There are many processes that lead to fossilization
column17: including permineralization
column18: casts and molds
column19: authigenic mineralization
column20: replacement and recrystallization
column21: adpression
column22: carbonization
column23: and bioimmuration.  Fossils vary in size from one-micrometre (1 µm) bacteria to dinosaurs and trees
column24: many meters long and weighing many tons. A fossil normally preserves only a portion of the deceased organism
column25: usually that portion that was partially mineralized during life
column26: such as the bones and teeth of vertebrates
column27: or the chitinous or calcareous exoskeletons of invertebrates. Fossils may also consist of the marks left behind by the organism while it was alive
column28: such as animal tracks or feces (coprolites). These types of fossil are called trace fossils or ichnofossils
column29: as opposed to body fossils. Some fossils are biochemical and are called chemofossils or biosignatures."

column1: 11504 Fandom "A fandom is a subculture composed of fans characterized by a feeling of empathy and camaraderie with others who share a common interest. Fans typically are interested in even minor details of the object(s) of their fandom and spend a significant portion of their time and energy involved with their interest
column2: often as a part of a social network with particular practices (a fandom); this is what differentiates ""fannish"" (fandom-affiliated) fans from those with only a casual interest. A fandom can grow around any area of human interest or activity. The subject of fan interest can be narrowly defined
column3: focused on something like an individual celebrity
column4: or more widely defined
column5: encompassing entire hobbies
column6: genres or fashions. While it is now used to apply to groups of people fascinated with any subject
column7: the term has its roots in those with an enthusiastic appreciation for sports. Merriam-Webster's dictionary traces the usage of the term back as far as 1903.Fandom as a term can also be used in a broad sense to refer to the interconnected social networks of individual fandoms
column8: many of which overlap. There are a number of large conventions that cater to fandom in this broad sense
column9: catering to interests in film
column10: comics
column11: anime
column12: television shows
column13: cosplay
column14: and the opportunity to buy and sell related merchandise. Annual conventions such as Comic Con International
column15: Wondercon
column16: Dragon Con and New York Comic Con are some of the more well known and highly attended events that cater to overlapping fandoms."

column1: 11685 Frasier "Frasier () is an American sitcom television series that was broadcast on NBC for 11 seasons
column2: premiering on September 16
column4: and concluding on May 13
column5: 2004. The program was created and produced by David Angell
column6: Peter Casey
column7: and David Lee (as Grub Street Productions) in association with Grammnet (2004) and Paramount Network Television. The series was created as a spin-off of Cheers
column8: continuing the story of psychiatrist Frasier Crane as he returned to his hometown of Seattle and started building a new life as a radio advice show host while reconnecting with his father and brother and making new friends. Frasier stars Kelsey Grammer
column9: Jane Leeves
column10: David Hyde Pierce
column11: Peri Gilpin
column12: and John Mahoney. The show was critically acclaimed
column13: with the show itself and the cast winning thirty-seven Primetime Emmy Awards
column14: a record at the time for a scripted series. It also won the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for five consecutive years. As of 2019
column15: the possibility of a revival was being discussed
column16: to air in 2020."

column1: 11748 List_of_freshwater_aquarium_fish_species "A vast number of aquatic species have successfully adapted to live in the freshwater aquarium. This list gives some examples of the most common species found in home aquariums."
12302 World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire "The fictional world in which the A Song of Ice and Fire novels by George R. R. Martin take place is divided into several continents
column2: known collectively as The Known World. Some unofficial fan groups call it Planetos.Most of the story takes place on the continent of Westeros and in a large political entity known as the Seven Kingdoms. Those kingdoms are spread across nine regions: the North
column3: the Iron Islands
column4: the Riverlands
column5: the Vale
column6: the Westerlands
column7: the Stormlands
column8: the Reach
column9: the Crownlands
column10: and Dorne. A massive wall of ice and old magic separates the Seven Kingdoms from the largely unmapped area to the north. The vast continent of Essos is located east of Westeros
column11: across the Narrow Sea. The closest foreign nations to Westeros are the Free Cities
column12: which is a collection of independent city-states along the western edge of Essos. The lands along the southern coastline of Essos are called the Lands of the Summer Sea and include Slaver's Bay and the ruins of Valyria. The latter is the former home of the ancestors of House Targaryen. To the south of Essos are the continents of Sothoryos and Ulthos
column13: which in the narrative are largely unexplored. The planet experiences erratic seasons of unpredictable duration that can last for many years. At the beginning of A Song of Ice and Fire
column14: Westeros has enjoyed a decade-long summer
column15: and many feared that an even longer and harsher winter would follow.  George R. R. Martin set the Ice and Fire story in an alternative world of Earth
column16: a ""secondary world""
column17: such as that which J. R. R. Tolkien pioneered with Middle-earth. Martin has also suggested that world may be larger than the real world planet Earth. The Ice and Fire narrative is set in a post-magic world where people no longer believe in supernatural things such as the Others. Although the characters understand the natural aspects of their world
column18: they do not know or understand its magical elements. Religion
column19: though
column20: has a significant role in the life of people
column21: and the characters practice many different religions."

column1: 14336 High_fantasy "High fantasy or epic fantasy is a subgenre of fantasy
column2: defined either by the epic nature of its setting or by the epic stature of its characters
column3: themes
column4: or plot. The term ""high fantasy"" was coined by Lloyd Alexander in a 1971 essay
column5: ""High Fantasy and Heroic Romance"" (originally given at the New England Round Table of Children's Librarians in October 1969)."

column1: 18524 Latin_America "Latin America is a group of countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Romance languages such as Spanish
column2: Portuguese
column3: and French are predominantly spoken; it is broader than the terms Ibero-America or Hispanic America. The term ""Latin America"" was first used in an 1856 conference with the title ""Initiative of the Americas. Idea for a Federal Congress of the Republics"" (Iniciativa de la América. Idea de un Congreso Federal de las Repúblicas)
column4: by the Chilean politician Francisco Bilbao. The term was used also by Napoleon III's French government in the 1860s as Amérique latine to consider French-speaking territories in the Americas (French Canadians
column5: French Louisiana
column6: French Guiana
column7: Haiti
column8: Guadeloupe
column9: Martinique
column10: Saint Martin
column11: Saint Barthélemy)
column12: along with the larger group of countries where Spanish and Portuguese languages prevailed
column13: including the Spanish-speaking portions of the United States (Southwestern United States and Florida) Today
column14: areas of Canada (such as Quebec) and the United States (with the exception of Puerto Rico) where Spanish
column15: Portuguese and French are predominant are typically not included in definitions of Latin America. Latin America consists of 13 dependencies and 20 countries which cover an area that stretches from the northern border of Mexico to the southern tip of South America
column16: including the Caribbean. It has an area of approximately 19
column20: 000 sq mi)
column21: almost 13% of the Earth's land surface area. As of 2018
column22: its population was estimated at more than  642 million and in 2014
column23: Latin America had a combined nominal GDP of US$5
column25: 397 million and a GDP PPP of 7
column27: 585 million USD."

column1: 20377 Microorganism "A microorganism
column2: or microbe
column3: is a microscopic organism
column4: which may exist in its single-celled form or in a colony of cells. The possible existence of unseen microbial life was suspected from ancient times
column5: such as in Jain scriptures from 6th century BC India and the 1st century BC book On Agriculture by Marcus Terentius Varro. Microbiology
column6: the scientific study of microorganisms
column7: began with their observation under the microscope in the 1670s by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek. In the 1850s
column8: Louis Pasteur found that microorganisms caused food spoilage
column9: debunking the theory of spontaneous generation. In the 1880s
column10: Robert Koch discovered that microorganisms caused the diseases tuberculosis
column11: cholera and anthrax. Microorganisms include all unicellular organisms and so are extremely diverse. Of the three domains of life identified by Carl Woese
column12: all of the Archaea and Bacteria are microorganisms. These were previously grouped together in the two domain system as Prokaryotes
column13: the other being the eukaryotes. The third domain Eukaryota includes all multicellular organisms and many unicellular protists and protozoans. Some protists are related to animals and some to green plants. Many of the multicellular organisms are microscopic
column14: namely micro-animals
column15: some fungi and some algae
column16: but these are not discussed here. They live in almost every habitat from the poles to the equator
column17: deserts
column18: geysers
column19: rocks and the deep sea. Some are adapted to extremes such as very hot or very cold conditions
column20: others to high pressure and a few such as Deinococcus radiodurans to high radiation environments. Microorganisms also make up the microbiota found in and on all multicellular organisms. A December 2017 report stated that 3.45-billion-year-old Australian rocks once contained microorganisms
column21: the earliest direct evidence of life on Earth.Microbes are important in human culture and health in many ways
column22: serving to ferment foods
column23: treat sewage
column24: produce fuel
column25: enzymes and other bioactive compounds. They are essential tools in biology as model organisms and have been put to use in biological warfare and bioterrorism. They are a vital component of fertile soils. In the human body microorganisms make up the human microbiota including the essential gut flora. They are the pathogens responsible for many infectious diseases and as such are the target of hygiene measures."

column1: 22055 Neil_Gaiman "Neil Richard MacKinnon Gaiman (; born Neil Richard Gaiman
column2: 10 November 1960) is an English author of short fiction
column3: novels
column4: comic books
column5: graphic novels
column6: nonfiction
column7: audio theatre
column8: and films. His  works include the comic book series The Sandman and novels Stardust
column9: American Gods
column10: Coraline
column11: and The Graveyard Book. He has won numerous awards
column12: including the Hugo
column13: Nebula
column14: and Bram Stoker awards
column15: as well as the Newbery and Carnegie medals. He is the first author to win both the Newbery and the Carnegie medals for the same work
column16: The Graveyard Book (2008). In 2013
column17: The Ocean at the End of the Lane was voted Book of the Year in the British National Book Awards."

column1: 25507 Roman_Empire "The Roman Empire (Latin: Imperium Rōmānum
column2: Classical Latin: [ɪmˈpɛrɪ.ũː roːˈmaːnũː]; Koinē Greek: Βασιλεία τῶν Ῥωμαίων
column3: romanized: Basileía tōn Rhōmaíōn) was the post-Republican period of ancient Rome
column4: consisting of large territorial holdings around the Mediterranean sea in Europe
column5: North Africa and West Asia ruled by emperors. From the accession of Caesar Augustus to the military anarchy of the third century
column6: it was a principate with Italy as metropole of the provinces and its city of Rome as sole capital (27 BC – 286 AD). The Roman Empire was then ruled by multiple emperors and divided into a Western Roman Empire
column7: based in Milan and later Ravenna
column8: and an Eastern Roman Empire
column9: based in Nicomedia and later Constantinople. Rome remained the nominal capital of both parts until 476 AD
column10: when it sent the imperial insignia to Constantinople (Byzantium in Ancient Greek) following the capture of Ravenna by the barbarians of Odoacer and the subsequent deposition of Romulus Augustus. The fall of the Western Roman Empire to Germanic kings
column11: along with the hellenization of the Eastern Roman Empire into the Byzantine Empire
column12: is conventionally used to mark the end of Ancient Rome and the beginning of the Middle Ages. The previous Roman Republic
column13: which had replaced Rome's monarchy in the 6th century BC
column14: became severely destabilized in a series of civil wars and political conflict. In the mid-1st century BC Julius Caesar was appointed as perpetual dictator and then assassinated in 44 BC. Civil wars and proscriptions continued
column15: culminating in the victory of Octavian
column16: Caesar's adopted son
column17: over Mark Antony and Cleopatra at the Battle of Actium in 31 BC. The following year Octavian conquered Ptolemaic Egypt
column18: ending the Hellenistic period that had begun with the conquests of Alexander the Great of Macedon in the 4th century BC. Octavian's power was then unassailable and in 27 BC the Roman Senate formally granted him overarching power and the new title Augustus
column19: effectively making him the first emperor. The first two centuries of the Empire were a period of unprecedented stability and prosperity known as the Pax Romana (""Roman Peace""). It reached its greatest territorial expanse during the reign of Trajan (98–117 AD). A period of increasing trouble and decline began with the reign of Commodus. In the 3rd century
column20: the Empire underwent a crisis that threatened its existence
column21: but was reunified under Aurelian. In an effort to stabilize the Empire
column22: Diocletian set up two different imperial courts in the Greek East and Latin West. Christians rose to power in the 4th century following the Edict of Milan in 313 and the Edict of Thessalonica in 380. Shortly after
column23: the Migration Period involving large invasions by Germanic peoples and the Huns of Attila led to the decline of the Western Roman Empire. With the fall of Ravenna to the Germanic Herulians and the deposition of Romulus Augustulus in 476 AD by Odoacer
column24: the Western Roman Empire finally collapsed and it was formally abolished by emperor Zeno in 480 AD. The Eastern Roman Empire
column25: known in the post-Roman West as the Byzantine Empire
column26: collapsed when Constantinople fell to the Ottoman Turks of Mehmed II in 1453. Due to the Roman Empire's vast extent and long endurance
column27: the institutions and culture of Rome had a profound and lasting influence on the development of language
column28: religion
column29: architecture
column30: philosophy
column31: law
column32: and forms of government in the territory it governed
column33: particularly Europe. The Latin language of the Romans evolved into the Romance languages of the medieval and modern world
column34: while Medieval Greek became the language of the Eastern Roman Empire. Its adoption of Christianity led to the formation of Christendom during the Middle Ages. Greek and Roman art had a profound impact on the late medieval Italian Renaissance
column35: while Rome's republican institutions influenced the political development of later republics such as the United States and France. The corpus of Roman law has its descendants in many legal systems of the world today
column36: such as the Napoleonic Code. Rome's architectural tradition served as the basis for Neoclassical architecture."

column1: 26537 Rose "A rose is a woody perennial flowering plant of the genus Rosa
column2: in the family Rosaceae
column3: or the flower it bears.  There are over three hundred species and thousands of cultivars.  They form a group of plants that can be erect shrubs
column4: climbing
column5: or trailing
column6: with stems that are often armed with sharp prickles.  Flowers vary in size and shape and are usually large and showy
column7: in colours ranging from white through yellows and reds.  Most species are native to Asia
column8: with smaller numbers native to Europe
column9: North America
column10: and northwestern Africa. Species
column11: cultivars and hybrids are all widely grown for their beauty and often are fragrant.  Roses have acquired cultural significance in  many societies.  Rose plants range in size from compact
column12: miniature roses
column13: to climbers that can reach seven meters in height. Different species hybridize easily
column14: and this has been used in the development of the wide range of garden roses."

column1: 29370 Snake "Snakes are elongated
column2: legless
column3: carnivorous reptiles of the suborder Serpentes. Like all other squamates
column4: snakes are ectothermic
column5: amniote vertebrates covered in overlapping scales. Many species of snakes have skulls with several more joints than their lizard ancestors
column6: enabling them to swallow prey much larger than their heads with their highly mobile jaws. To accommodate their narrow bodies
column7: snakes' paired organs (such as kidneys) appear one in front of the other instead of side by side
column8: and most have only one functional lung. Some species retain a pelvic girdle with a pair of vestigial claws on either side of the cloaca. Lizards have evolved elongate bodies without limbs or with greatly reduced limbs about twenty-five times independently via convergent evolution
column9: leading to many lineages of legless lizards.  Legless lizards resemble snakes
column10: but several common groups of legless lizards have eyelids and external ears
column11: which snakes lack
column12: although this rule is not universal (see Amphisbaenia
column13: Dibamidae
column14: and Pygopodidae). Living snakes are found on every continent except Antarctica
column15: and on most smaller land masses; exceptions include some large islands
column16: such as Ireland
column17: Iceland
column18: Greenland
column19: the Hawaiian archipelago
column20: and the islands of New Zealand
column21: and many small islands of the Atlantic and central Pacific oceans. Additionally
column22: sea snakes are widespread throughout the Indian and Pacific Oceans. More than 20 families are currently recognized
column23: comprising about 520 genera and about 3
column24: 600 species. They range in size from the tiny
column25: 10.4 cm (4.1 in)-long Barbados thread snake to the reticulated python of 6.95 meters (22.8 ft) in length. The fossil species Titanoboa cerrejonensis was 12.8 meters (42 ft) long. Snakes are thought to have evolved from either burrowing or aquatic lizards
column26: perhaps during the Jurassic period
column27: with the earliest known fossils dating to between 143 and 167 Ma ago. The diversity of modern snakes appeared during the Paleocene epoch (c 66 to 56 Ma ago
column28: after the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event). The oldest preserved descriptions of snakes can be found in the Brooklyn Papyrus. Most species are nonvenomous and those that have venom use it primarily to kill and subdue prey rather than for self-defense. Some possess venom potent enough to cause painful injury or death to humans. Nonvenomous snakes either swallow prey alive or kill by constriction."

column1: 30467 Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus is a genus of coelurosaurian theropod dinosaur. The species Tyrannosaurus rex (rex meaning ""king"" in Latin)
column2: often called T. rex or colloquially T-Rex
column3: is one of the most well-represented of the large theropods. Tyrannosaurus lived throughout what is now western North America
column4: on what was then an island continent known as Laramidia. Tyrannosaurus had a much wider range than other tyrannosaurids. Fossils are found in a variety of rock formations dating to the Maastrichtian age of the upper Cretaceous Period
column5: 68 to 66 million years ago. It was the last known member of the tyrannosaurids
column6: and among the last non-avian dinosaurs to exist before the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event. Like other tyrannosaurids
column7: Tyrannosaurus was a bipedal carnivore with a massive skull balanced by a long
column8: heavy tail. Relative to its large and powerful hind limbs
column9: Tyrannosaurus forelimbs were short but unusually powerful for their size and had two clawed digits. The most complete specimen measures up to 12.3 m (40 ft) in length though T. rex could grow to lengths of over 12.3 m (40 ft)
column10: up to 3.66 meters (12 ft) tall at the hips
column11: and according to most modern estimates 8.4 metric tons (9.3 short tons) to 14 metric tons (15.4 short tons) in weight. Although other theropods rivaled or exceeded Tyrannosaurus rex in size
column12: it is still among the largest known land predators and is estimated to have exerted the strongest bite force among all terrestrial animals. By far the largest carnivore in its environment
column13: Tyrannosaurus rex was most likely an apex predator
column14: preying upon hadrosaurs
column15: armored herbivores like ceratopsians and ankylosaurs
column16: and possibly sauropods. Some experts have suggested the dinosaur was primarily a scavenger. The question of whether Tyrannosaurus was an apex predator or a pure scavenger was among the longest debates in paleontology. Most paleontologists today accept that Tyrannosaurus was both an active predator and a scavenger. More than fifty major specimens of Tyrannosaurus rex have been identified
column17: some of which are nearly complete skeletons. Soft tissue and proteins have been reported in at least one of these specimens. The abundance of fossil material has allowed significant research into many aspects of its biology
column18: including its life history and biomechanics. The feeding habits
column19: physiology and potential speed of Tyrannosaurus rex are a few subjects of debate. Its taxonomy is also controversial
column20: as some scientists consider Tarbosaurus bataar from Asia to be a second Tyrannosaurus species while others maintain Tarbosaurus is a separate genus. Several other genera of North American tyrannosaurids have also been synonymized with Tyrannosaurus. As the archetypal theropod
column21: Tyrannosaurus has been one of the best-known dinosaurs since the early 20th century
column22: and has been featured in film
column23: advertising
column24: postal stamps
column25: and many other media."

column1: 30680 The_New_York_Times "The New York Times (sometimes abbreviated as the NYT and NYTimes) is an American newspaper based in New York City with worldwide influence and readership. Founded in 1851
column2: the paper has won 127 Pulitzer Prizes
column3: more than any other newspaper. The Times is ranked 18th in the world by circulation and 3rd in the U.S.The paper is owned by The New York Times Company
column4: which is publicly traded and is controlled by the Sulzberger family through a dual-class share structure. It has been owned by the family since 1896; A.G. Sulzberger
column5: the paper's publisher
column6: and his father
column7: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr.
column8: the company's chairman
column9: are the fourth and fifth generation of the family to head the paper.Nicknamed ""The Gray Lady
column10: the Times has long been regarded within the industry as a national ""newspaper of record."" The paper's motto
column11: ""All the News That's Fit to Print""
column12: appears in the upper left-hand corner of the front page. Since the mid-1970s
column13: The New York Times has greatly expanded its layout and organization
column14: adding special weekly sections on various topics supplementing the regular news
column15: editorials
column16: sports
column17: and features. Since 2008
column18: the Times has been organized into the following sections: News
column19: Editorials/Opinions-Columns/Op-Ed
column20: New York (metropolitan)
column21: Business
column22: Sports of The Times
column23: Arts
column24: Science
column25: Styles
column26: Home
column27: Travel
column28: and other features. On Sunday
column29: the Times is supplemented by the Sunday Review (formerly the Week in Review)
column30: The New York Times Book Review
column31: The New York Times Magazine and T: The New York Times Style Magazine. The Times stayed with the broadsheet full-page set-up and an eight-column format for several years after most papers switched to six
column32: and was one of the last newspapers to adopt color photography
column33: especially on the front page."

column1: 30770 The_Troubles "The Troubles (Irish: Na Trioblóidí) was an ethno-nationalist conflict in Northern Ireland during the late 20th century. Also known internationally as the Northern Ireland conflict
column2: it is sometimes described as an ""irregular war"" or ""low-level war"". The conflict began in the late 1960s and is usually deemed to have ended with the Good Friday Agreement of 1998. Although the Troubles primarily took place in Northern Ireland
column3: at times the violence spilled over into parts of the Republic of Ireland
column4: England
column5: and mainland Europe. The conflict was primarily political and nationalistic
column6: fuelled by historical events. It also had an ethnic or sectarian dimension
column7: although it was not a religious conflict. A key issue was the constitutional status of Northern Ireland. Unionists/loyalists
column8: who were mostly Protestants
column9: wanted Northern Ireland to remain within the United Kingdom. Irish nationalists/republicans
column10: who were mostly Catholics
column11: wanted Northern Ireland to leave the United Kingdom and join a united Ireland. The conflict began during a campaign to end discrimination against the Catholic/nationalist minority by the Protestant/unionist government and police force. The authorities attempted to suppress this protest campaign and were accused of police brutality; it was also met with violence from loyalists
column12: who alleged it was a republican front. Increasing tensions led to severe violence in August 1969 and the deployment of British troops
column13: in what became the British Army's longest ever operation. They built 'peace walls' to keep the two communities apart. Some Catholics initially welcomed the army as a more neutral force
column14: but it soon came to be seen as hostile and biased
column15: particularly after Bloody Sunday. The emergence of armed paramilitary organisations led to subsequent warfare over the next three decades. The main participants in the Troubles were republican paramilitaries such as the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) and the Irish National Liberation Army (INLA); loyalist paramilitaries such as the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) and Ulster Defence Association (UDA); British state security forces—the British Army and Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC); and political activists and politicians. The security forces of the Republic played a smaller role. Republican paramilitaries carried out a guerrilla campaign against British security forces
column16: as well as a bombing campaign against infrastructure
column17: commercial and political targets. Loyalists targeted republicans/nationalists
column18: and attacked the wider Catholic community in what they described as retaliation. At times there were bouts of sectarian tit-for-tat violence. The British security forces undertook both a policing and a counter-insurgency role
column19: primarily against republicans. There were some incidents of collusion between British security forces and loyalists. The Troubles also involved numerous riots
column20: mass protests and acts of civil disobedience
column21: and led to segregation and the creation of no-go areas. More than 3
column22: 500 people were killed in the conflict
column23: of whom 52% were civilians
column24: 32% were members of the British security forces
column25: and 16% were members of paramilitary groups. There has been sporadic violence since the Good Friday Agreement was signed
column26: including a campaign by anti-ceasefire republicans."

column1: 33545 Welsh_language "Welsh (Cymraeg [kəmˈrɑːɨɡ] (listen) or y Gymraeg [ə gəmˈrɑːɨɡ]) is a Brittonic language of the Celtic language family. It is spoken natively in Wales
column2: by some in England
column3: and in Y Wladfa (the Welsh colony in Chubut Province
column4: Argentina). Historically
column5: it has also been known in English as 'British'
column6: 'Cambrian'
column7: 'Cambric' and 'Cymric'.According to the United Kingdom Census 2011
column8: 19 percent of residents in Wales aged three and over were able to speak Welsh. According to the 2001 Census
column9: 21 per cent of the population aged 3+ were able to speak Welsh. This suggests that there was a decrease in the number of Welsh speakers in Wales from 2001 to 2011 – from about 582
column11: 000 respectively.  The Annual Population Survey conducted by the Office for National Statistics for the year ending in March 2019 suggest that 896
column12: 900 Welsh residents (30 per cent) aged three or over in Wales were able to speak Welsh. The results for the most recent National Survey for Wales (2017-2018) suggest that 19 per cent of the population aged 16 and over were able to speak Welsh
column13: with an additional 12 per cent noting that they had ""some Welsh speaking ability"".The Welsh Language (Wales) Measure 2011 gave the Welsh language official status in Wales
column14: making it the only language that is de jure official in any part of the United Kingdom
column15: with English being de facto official. The Welsh language
column16: along with English
column17: is also a de jure official language of the National Assembly for Wales."

column1: 33557 Whaling "Whaling is the hunting of whales for their usable products such as meat and blubber
column2: which can be turned into a type of oil which became increasingly important in the Industrial Revolution. It was practiced as an organized industry as early as 875 AD. By the 16th century
column3: it had risen to be the principal industry in the coastal regions of Spain and France. The industry spread throughout the world
column4: and became increasingly profitable in terms of trade and resources. Some regions of the world's oceans
column5: along the animals' migration routes
column6: had a particularly dense whale population
column7: and became the targets for large concentrations of whaling ships
column8: and the industry continued to grow well into the 20th century. The depletion of some whale species to near extinction led to the banning of whaling in many countries by 1969
column9: and to a worldwide cessation of whaling as an industry in the late 1980s. The earliest forms of whaling date to at least circa 3000 BC. Coastal communities around the world have long histories of subsistence use of cetaceans
column10: by dolphin drive hunting and by harvesting drift whales. Industrial whaling emerged with organized fleets of whaleships in the 17th century; competitive national whaling industries in the 18th and 19th centuries; and the introduction of factory ships along with the concept of whale harvesting in the first half of the 20th century. By the late 1930s more than 50
column11: 000 whales were killed annually. In 1986
column12: the International Whaling Commission (IWC) banned commercial whaling because of the extreme depletion of most of the whale stocks.Contemporary whaling is subject to intense debate. Countries that support commercial whaling
column13: notably Iceland
column14: Japan
column15: and Norway
column16: wish to lift the ban on certain whale stocks for hunting. Anti-whaling countries and environmental groups oppose lifting the ban. Under the terms of the IWC moratorium
column17: aboriginal whaling is allowed to continue on a subsistence basis. Over the past few decades
column18: whale watching has become a significant industry in many parts of the world; in some countries it has replaced whaling
column19: but in a few others
column20: the two business models exist in an uneasy tension. The live capture of cetaceans for display in aquaria (e.g. captive killer whales) continues."

column1: 33777 Whale "Whales are a widely distributed and diverse group of fully aquatic placental marine mammals. They are an informal grouping within the infraorder Cetacea
column2: usually excluding dolphins and porpoises. Whales
column3: dolphins and porpoises belong to the order Cetartiodactyla
column4: which consists of even-toed ungulates. Their closest living relatives are the hippopotamuses
column5: having diverged about 40 million years ago. The two parvorders of whales
column6: baleen whales (Mysticeti) and toothed whales (Odontoceti)
column7: are thought to have split apart around 34 million years ago.  Whales consist of eight extant families: Balaenopteridae (the rorquals)
column8: Balaenidae (right whales)
column9: Cetotheriidae (the pygmy right whale)
column10: Eschrichtiidae (the grey whale)
column11: Monodontidae (belugas and narwhals)
column12: Physeteridae (the sperm whale)
column13: Kogiidae (the dwarf and pygmy sperm whale)
column14: and Ziphiidae (the beaked whales). Whales are creatures of the open ocean; they feed
column15: mate
column16: give birth
column17: suckle and raise their young at sea. So extreme is their adaptation to life underwater that they are unable to survive on land. Whales range in size from the 2.6 metres (8.5 ft) and 135 kilograms (298 lb) dwarf sperm whale to the 29.9 metres (98 ft) and 190 metric tons (210 short tons) blue whale
column18: which is the largest known creature that has ever lived. The sperm whale is the largest toothed predator on earth. Several species exhibit sexual dimorphism
column19: in that the females are larger than males. Baleen whales have no teeth; instead they have plates of baleen
column20: a fringe-like structure used to expel water while retaining the krill and plankton which they feed on. They use their throat pleats to expand the mouth to take in huge gulps of water. Balaenids have heads that can make up 40% of their body mass to take in water. Toothed whales
column21: on the other hand
column22: have conical teeth adapted to catching fish or squid. Baleen whales have a well developed sense of ""smell""
column23: whereas toothed whales have well-developed hearing − their hearing
column24: that is adapted for both air and water
column25: is so well developed that some can survive even if they are blind. Some species
column26: such as sperm whales
column27: are well adapted for diving to great depths to catch squid and other favoured prey. Whales have evolved from land-living mammals. As such
column28: whales must breathe air regularly
column29: although they can remain submerged under water for long periods of time. Some species such as the sperm whale are able to stay submerged for as much as 90 minutes. They have blowholes (modified nostrils) located on top of their heads
column30: through which air is taken in and expelled. They are warm-blooded
column31: and have a layer of fat
column32: or blubber
column33: under the skin. With streamlined fusiform bodies and two limbs that are modified into flippers
column34: whales can travel at up to 20 knots
column35: though they are not as flexible or agile as seals. Whales produce a great variety of vocalizations
column36: notably the extended songs of the humpback whale. Although whales are widespread
column37: most species prefer the colder waters of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres
column38: and migrate to the equator to give birth. Species such as humpbacks and blue whales are capable of travelling thousands of miles without feeding. Males typically mate with multiple females every year
column39: but females only mate every two to three years. Calves are typically born in the spring and summer months and females bear all the responsibility for raising them. Mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for one to two years. Once relentlessly hunted for their products
column40: whales are now protected by international law. The North Atlantic right whales nearly became extinct in the twentieth century
column42: and the North Pacific grey whale population is ranked Critically Endangered by the IUCN. Besides whaling
column43: they also face threats from bycatch and marine pollution. The meat
column44: blubber and baleen of whales have traditionally been used by indigenous peoples of the Arctic. Whales have been depicted in various cultures worldwide
column45: notably by the Inuit and the coastal peoples of Vietnam and Ghana
column46: who sometimes hold whale funerals. Whales occasionally feature in literature and film
column47: as in the great white whale of Herman Melville's Moby Dick. Small whales
column49: are sometimes kept in captivity and trained to perform tricks
column50: but breeding success has been poor and the animals often die within a few months of capture. Whale watching has become a form of tourism around the world."

column1: 33802 Werewolf "In folklore
column2: a werewolf (Old English: werwulf
column3: ""man-wolf"")
column4: or occasionally lycanthrope  (Greek: λυκάνθρωπος lukánthrōpos
column5: ""wolf-person"")
column6: is a human with the ability to shapeshift into a wolf (or
column7: especially in modern film
column8: a therianthropic hybrid wolf-like creature)
column9: either purposely or after being placed under a curse or affliction (often a bite or scratch from another werewolf) and especially on the night of a full moon. Early sources for belief in this ability or affliction
column10: called lycanthropy
column11: are Petronius (27–66) and Gervase of Tilbury (1150–1228). The werewolf is a widespread concept in European folklore
column12: existing in many variants
column13: which are related by a common development of a Christian interpretation of underlying European folklore developed during the medieval period. From the early modern period
column14: werewolf beliefs also spread to the New World with colonialism. Belief in werewolves developed in parallel to the belief in witches
column15: in the course of the Late Middle Ages and the Early Modern period. Like the witchcraft trials as a whole
column16: the trial of supposed werewolves emerged in what is now Switzerland (especially the Valais and Vaud) in the early 15th century and spread throughout Europe in the 16th
column17: peaking in the 17th and subsiding by the 18th century. The persecution of werewolves and the associated folklore is an integral part of the ""witch-hunt"" phenomenon
column18: albeit a marginal one
column19: accusations of lycanthropy being involved in only a small fraction of witchcraft trials. During the early period
column20: accusations of lycanthropy (transformation into a wolf) were mixed with accusations of wolf-riding or wolf-charming. The case of Peter Stumpp (1589) led to a significant peak in both interest in and persecution of supposed werewolves
column21: primarily in French-speaking and German-speaking Europe. The phenomenon persisted longest in Bavaria and Austria
column22: with persecution of wolf-charmers recorded until well after 1650
column23: the final cases taking place in the early 18th century in Carinthia and Styria.After the end of the witch-trials
