column24: the werewolf became of interest in folklore studies and in the emerging Gothic horror genre; werewolf fiction as a genre has pre-modern precedents in medieval romances (e.g. Bisclavret and Guillaume de Palerme) and developed in the 18th century out of the ""semi-fictional"" chap book tradition. The trappings of horror literature in the 20th century became part of the horror and fantasy genre of modern popular culture."

column1: 36581 Fishing "Fishing is the activity of trying to catch fish. Fish are normally caught in the wild. Techniques for catching fish include hand gathering
column2: spearing
column3: netting
column4: angling and trapping. “Fishing” may include catching aquatic animals other than fish
column5: such as molluscs
column6: cephalopods
column7: crustaceans
column8: and echinoderms. The term is not normally applied to catching farmed fish
column9: or to aquatic mammals
column10: such as whales where the term whaling is more appropriate. In addition to being caught to be eaten
column11: fish are caught as recreational pastimes. Fishing tournaments are held
column12: and caught fish are sometimes kept as preserved or living trophies. When bioblitzes occur
column13: fish are typically caught
column14: identified
column15: and then released. According to the United Nations FAO statistics
column16: the total number of commercial fishermen and fish farmers is estimated to be 38 million. Fisheries and aquaculture provide direct and indirect employment to over 500 million people in developing countries. In 2005
column17: the worldwide per capita consumption of fish captured from wild fisheries was 14.4 kilograms
column18: with an additional 7.4 kilograms harvested from fish farms."

column1: 36858 Wheat "Wheat is a grass widely cultivated for its seed
column2: a cereal grain which is a worldwide staple food. The many species of wheat together make up the genus Triticum; the most widely grown is common wheat (T. aestivum). The archaeological record suggests that wheat was first cultivated in the regions of the Fertile Crescent around 9600 BCE. Botanically
column3: the wheat kernel is a type of fruit called a caryopsis. Wheat is grown on more land area than any other food crop (220.4 million hectares
column4: 2014). World trade in wheat is greater than for all other crops combined. In 2017
column5: world production of wheat was 730 million tonnes
column6: with a forecast of 2019 production at 766 million tonnes
column7: making it the second most-produced cereal after maize. Since 1960
column8: world production of wheat and other grain crops has tripled and is expected to grow further through the middle of the 21st century. Global demand for wheat is increasing due to the unique viscoelastic and adhesive properties of gluten proteins
column9: which facilitate the production of processed foods
column10: whose consumption is increasing as a result of the worldwide industrialization process and the westernization of the diet.Wheat is an important source of carbohydrates. Globally
column11: it is the leading source of vegetable protein in human food
column12: having a protein content of about 13%
column13: which is relatively high compared to other major cereals  but relatively low in protein quality for supplying essential amino acids. When eaten as the whole grain
column14: wheat is a source of multiple nutrients and dietary fiber.In a small part of the general population
column15: gluten – the major part of wheat protein – can trigger coeliac disease
column16: noncoeliac gluten sensitivity
column17: gluten ataxia
column18: and dermatitis herpetiformis."

column1: 37770 Seville "Seville (; Spanish: Sevilla [seˈβiʎa] (listen)) is a Spanish city
column2: the capital of the autonomous community of Andalusia and the province of Seville. It is situated on the lower reaches of the River Guadalquivir
column3: in the southwest of the Iberian Peninsula. Seville has a municipal population of about 690
column5: and a metropolitan population of about 1.5 million
column6: making it the largest city in Andalusia
column7: the fourth-largest city in Spain and the 30th most populous municipality in the European Union. Its old town
column8: with an area of 4 square kilometres (2 sq mi)
column9: contains three UNESCO World Heritage Sites: the Alcázar palace complex
column10: the Cathedral and the General Archive of the Indies. The Seville harbour
column11: located about 80 kilometres (50 miles) from the Atlantic Ocean
column12: is the only river port in Spain. Seville experiences high temperatures in the Summer
column13: with daily maximums routinely above 35 °C (95 °F) in July and August. Seville was founded as the Roman city of Hispalis. It became known as Ishbiliyya after the Muslim conquest in 712. During the Muslim rule in Spain
column14: Seville came under the jurisdiction of the Caliphate of Córdoba before becoming the independent Taifa of Seville; later it was ruled by the Muslim Almoravids and the Almohads until finally being incorporated into the Christian Kingdom of Castile under Ferdinand III in 1248. After the discovery of the Americas
column15: Seville became one of the economic centres of the Spanish Empire as its port monopolised the trans-oceanic trade and the Casa de Contratación (House of Trade) wielded its power
column16: opening a Golden Age of arts and literature. In 1519
column17: Ferdinand Magellan departed from Seville for the first circumnavigation of the Earth. Coinciding with the Baroque period of European history
column18: the 17th century in Seville represented the most brilliant flowering of the city's culture; then began a gradual economic and demographic decline as silting in the Guadalquivir forced the trade monopoly to relocate to the nearby port of Cádiz. The 20th century in Seville saw the tribulations of the Spanish Civil War
column19: decisive cultural milestones such as the Ibero-American Exposition of 1929 and Expo '92
column20: and the city's election as the capital of the Autonomous Community of Andalusia."

column1: 38011 Squid "Squid are cephalopods in the superorder Decapodiformes with elongated bodies
column2: large eyes
column3: eight arms and two tentacles. Like all other cephalopods
column4: squid have a distinct head
column5: bilateral symmetry
column6: and a mantle. They are mainly soft-bodied
column7: like octopuses
column8: but have a small internal skeleton in the form of a rod-like gladius or pen
column9: made of chitin. Squid diverged from other cephalopods during the Jurassic and occupy a similar role to teleost fish as open water predators of similar size and behaviour. They play an important role in the open water food web. The two long tentacles are used to grab prey and the eight arms to hold and control it. The beak then cuts the food into suitable size chunks for swallowing. Squid are rapid swimmers
column10: moving by jet propulsion
column11: and largely locate their prey by sight. They are among the most intelligent of invertebrates
column12: with groups of Humboldt squid having been observed hunting cooperatively. They are preyed on by sharks
column13: other fish
column14: sea birds
column15: seals and cetaceans
column16: particularly sperm whales. Squid can change colour for camouflage and signalling. Some species are bioluminescent
column17: using their light for counter-illumination camouflage
column18: while many species can eject a cloud of ink to distract predators. Squid are used for human consumption with commercial fisheries in Japan
column19: the Mediterranean
column20: the southwestern Atlantic
column21: the eastern Pacific and elsewhere. They are used in cuisines around the world
column22: often known as ""calamari"". Squid have featured in literature since classical times
column23: especially in tales of giant squid and sea monsters."

column1: 42405 Ichthyology "Ichthyology (from Greek: ἰχθύς
column2: ikhthys
column3: ""fish""; and λόγος
column4: logos
column5: ""study"")
column6: also known as fish science
column7: is the branch of zoology devoted to the study of fish. This includes bony fish (Osteichthyes)
column8: cartilaginous fish (Chondrichthyes)
column9: and jawless fish (Agnatha). While many species have been discovered
column10: around 250 new species are officially described each  year. According to FishBase
column12: 400 species of fish had been described as of October 2016."

column1: 45086 Biodiversity "Biodiversity is the variety and variability of life on Earth. Biodiversity is typically a measure of variation at the genetic
column2: species
column3: and ecosystem level. Terrestrial biodiversity is usually greater near the equator
column4: which is the result of the warm climate and high primary productivity. Biodiversity is not distributed evenly on Earth
column5: and is richest in the tropics. These tropical forest ecosystems cover less than 10 percent of earth's surface
column6: and contain about 90 percent of the world's species. Marine biodiversity is usually highest along coasts in the Western Pacific
column7: where sea surface temperature is highest
column8: and in the mid-latitudinal band in all oceans. There are latitudinal gradients in species diversity. Biodiversity generally tends to cluster in hotspots
column9: and has been increasing through time
column10: but will be likely to slow in the future.Rapid environmental changes typically cause mass extinctions. More than 99.9 percent of all species that ever lived on Earth
column11: amounting to over five billion species
column12: are estimated to be extinct. Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 10 million to 14 million
column13: of which about 1.2 million have been documented and over 86 percent have not yet been described. More recently
column14: in May 2016
column15: scientists reported that 1 trillion species are estimated to be on Earth currently with only one-thousandth of one percent described. The total amount of related DNA base pairs on Earth is estimated at 5.0 x 1037 and weighs 50 billion tonnes. In comparison
column16: the total mass of the biosphere has been estimated to be as much as 4 TtC (trillion tons of carbon). In July 2016
column17: scientists reported identifying a set of 355 genes from the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA) of all organisms living on Earth.The age of the Earth is about 4.54 billion years. The earliest undisputed evidence of life on Earth dates at least from 3.5 billion years ago
column18: during the Eoarchean Era after a geological crust started to solidify following the earlier molten Hadean Eon. There are microbial mat fossils found in 3.48 billion-year-old sandstone discovered in Western Australia. Other early physical evidence of a biogenic substance is graphite in 3.7 billion-year-old meta-sedimentary rocks discovered in Western Greenland. More recently
column20: ""remains of biotic life"" were found in 4.1 billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia. According to one of the researchers
column21: ""If life arose relatively quickly on Earth .. then it could be common in the universe.""Since life began on Earth
column22: five major mass extinctions and several minor events have led to large and sudden drops in biodiversity. The Phanerozoic eon (the last 540 million years) marked a rapid growth in biodiversity via the Cambrian explosion—a period during which the majority of multicellular phyla first appeared. The next 400 million years included repeated
column23: massive biodiversity losses classified as mass extinction events. In the Carboniferous
column24: rainforest collapse led to a great loss of plant and animal life. The Permian–Triassic extinction event
column25: 251 million years ago
column26: was the worst; vertebrate recovery took 30 million years. The most recent
column27: the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event
column28: occurred 65 million years ago and has often attracted more attention than others because it resulted in the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.The period since the emergence of humans has displayed an ongoing biodiversity reduction and an accompanying loss of genetic diversity. Named the Holocene extinction
column29: the reduction is caused primarily by human impacts
column30: particularly habitat destruction. Conversely
column31: biodiversity positively impacts human health in a number of ways
column32: although a few negative effects are studied.The United Nations designated 2011–2020 as the United Nations Decade on Biodiversity. and 2021-2030 as the United Nations Decade on Ecosystem Restoration  According to a 2019 Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services by IPBES
column33: 25% of plant and animal species are threatened with extinction as the result of human activity."

column1: 45503 Coelacanth "The coelacanths ( (listen) SEE-lə-kanth) constitute a now-rare order of fish that includes two extant species in the genus Latimeria: the West Indian Ocean coelacanth (Latimeria chalumnae) primarily found near the Comoro Islands off the east coast of Africa and the Indonesian coelacanth (Latimeria menadoensis). They follow the oldest-known living lineage of Sarcopterygii (lobe-finned fish and tetrapods)
column2: which means they are more closely related to lungfish and tetrapods than to ray-finned fish. They are found along the coastlines of the Indian Ocean and Indonesia. The West Indian Ocean coelacanth is a critically endangered species. Coelacanths belong to the subclass Actinistia
column3: a group of lobed-finned fish related to lungfish and certain extinct Devonian fish such as osteolepiforms
column4: porolepiforms
column5: rhizodonts
column6: and Panderichthys. Coelacanths were thought to have become extinct in the Late Cretaceous
column7: around 66 million years ago
column8: but were rediscovered in 1938 off the coast of South Africa.The coelacanth was long considered a ""living fossil"" because scientists thought it was the sole remaining member of a taxon otherwise known only from fossils
column9: with no close relations alive
column10: and that it evolved into roughly its current form approximately 400 million years ago. However
column11: several recent studies have shown that coelacanth body shapes are much more diverse than previously thought."

column1: 47542 Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer "Buffy the Vampire Slayer is  an American supernatural drama television series based on the 1992 film of the same name. It was created by Joss Whedon under his production tag
column2: Mutant Enemy Productions
column3: with later co-executive producers being Jane Espenson
column4: David Fury
column5: David Greenwalt
column6: Doug Petrie
column7: Marti Noxon
column8: and David Solomon. The series premiered on March 10
column10: on The WB and concluded on May 20
column12: on UPN. The series narrative follows Buffy Summers (played by Sarah Michelle Gellar)
column13: the latest in a line of young women known as ""Vampire Slayers""
column14: or simply ""Slayers"". In the story
column15: Slayers or the 'Chosen Ones' are ""called"" (chosen by fate) to battle against vampires
column16: demons
column17: and other forces of darkness. Buffy wants to live a normal life
column18: but as the series progresses
column19: she learns to embrace her destiny. Like previous Slayers
column20: Buffy is aided by a Watcher
column21: who guides
column22: teaches

column1: 50185 Jellyfish "Jellyfish and sea jellies are the informal common names given to the medusa-phase of certain gelatinous members of the subphylum Medusozoa
column2: a major part of the phylum Cnidaria. Jellyfish are mainly free-swimming marine animals with umbrella-shaped bells and trailing tentacles
column3: although a few are not mobile
column4: being anchored to the seabed by stalks.  The bell can pulsate to provide propulsion and highly efficient locomotion. The tentacles are armed with stinging cells and may be used to capture prey and defend against predators. Jellyfish have a complex life cycle; the medusa is normally the sexual phase
column5: the planula larva can disperse widely and is followed by a sedentary polyp phase. Jellyfish are found all over the world
column6: from surface waters to the deep sea. Scyphozoans (the ""true jellyfish"") are exclusively marine
column7: but some hydrozoans with a similar appearance live in freshwater. Large
column8: often colorful
column9: jellyfish are common in coastal zones worldwide. The medusae of most species are fast growing
column10: mature within a few months and die soon after breeding
column11: but the polyp stage
column12: attached to the seabed
column13: may be much more long-lived. Jellyfish have been in existence for at least 500 million years
column14: and possibly 700 million years or more
column15: making them the oldest multi-organ animal group.Jellyfish are eaten by humans in certain cultures
column16: being considered a delicacy in some Asian countries
column17: where species in the Rhizostomae order are pressed and salted to remove excess water. They are also used in research
column18: where the green fluorescent protein
column19: used by some species to cause bioluminescence
column20: has been adapted as a fluorescent marker for genes inserted into other cells or organisms. The stinging cells used by jellyfish to subdue their prey can also injure humans. Many thousands of swimmers are stung every year
column21: with effects ranging from mild discomfort to serious injury or even death; small box jellyfish are responsible for many of these deaths. When conditions are favourable
column22: jellyfish can form vast swarms. These can be responsible for damage to fishing gear by filling fishing nets
column23: and sometimes clog the cooling systems of power and desalination plants which draw their water from the sea."

column1: 54808 Termite "Termites are eusocial insects that are classified at the taxonomic rank of infraorder Isoptera
column2: or as epifamily Termitoidae within the cockroach order Blattodea. Termites were once classified in a separate order from cockroaches
column3: but recent phylogenetic studies indicate that they evolved from cockroaches during the Jurassic or Triassic. However
column4: the first termites possibly emerged during the Permian or even the Carboniferous. About 3
column5: 106 species are currently described
column6: with a few hundred more left to be described. Although these insects are often called ""white ants""
column7: they are not ants. Like ants and some bees and wasps from the separate order Hymenoptera
column8: termites divide labour among castes consisting of male and female ""workers"" and ""soldiers"" that are usually sterile. All colonies have fertile males called ""kings"" and one or more fertile females called ""queens"". Termites mostly feed on dead plant material and cellulose
column9: generally in the form of wood
column10: leaf litter
column11: soil
column12: or animal dung. Termites are major detritivores
column13: particularly in the subtropical and tropical regions
column14: and their recycling of wood and plant matter is of considerable ecological importance. Termites are among the most successful groups of insects on Earth
column15: colonising most landmasses except Antarctica. Their colonies range in size from a few hundred individuals to enormous societies with several million individuals. Termite queens have the longest lifespan of any insect in the world
column16: with some queens reportedly living up to 30 to 50 years. Unlike ants
column17: which undergo a complete metamorphosis
column18: each individual termite goes through an incomplete metamorphosis that proceeds through egg
column19: nymph
column20: and adult stages. Colonies are described as superorganisms because the termites form part of a self-regulating entity: the colony itself.Termites are a delicacy in the diet of some human cultures and are used in many traditional medicines. Several hundred species are economically significant as pests that can cause serious damage to buildings
column21: crops
column22: or plantation forests. Some species
column23: such as the West Indian drywood termite (Cryptotermes brevis)
column24: are regarded as invasive species."

column1: 56230 Cichlid "Cichlids  are fish from the family Cichlidae in the order Cichliformes. Cichlids were traditionally classed in a suborder
column2: Labroidei
column3: along with the wrasses (Labridae)
column4: in the order Perciformes but molecular studies have contradicted this grouping. The closest living relatives of cichlids are probably the convict blennies and both families are classified in the 5th edition of Fishes of the World  as the two families in the Cichliformes
column5: part of the subseries Ovalentaria. This family is both large and diverse. At least 1
column6: 650 species have been scientifically described
column7: making it one of the largest vertebrate families. New species are discovered annually
column8: and many species remain undescribed. The actual number of species is therefore unknown
column9: with estimates varying between 2
column10: 000 and 3
column11: 000.Many cichlids
column12: particularly tilapia
column13: are important food fishes
column14: while others
column15: such as the Cichla species
column16: are valued game fish. The family also includes many popular freshwater aquarium fish kept by hobbyists
column17: including the angelfish
column18: oscars
column19: and discus. Cichlids have the largest number of endangered species among vertebrate families
column20: most in the haplochromine group. Cichlids are particularly well known for having evolved rapidly into a large number of closely related but morphologically diverse species within large lakes
column21: particularly Tanganyika
column22: Victoria
column23: Malawi
column24: and Edward. Their diversity in the African Great Lakes is important for the study of speciation in evolution. Many cichlids introduced into waters outside of their natural range have become nuisances.All cichlids have some form of parental care for their eggs and fry. That parental care may come in the form of guarding the eggs and fry or it may come in the form of mouthbrooding."

column1: 58890 Resin "In polymer chemistry and materials science
column2: resin is a solid or highly viscous substance of plant or synthetic origin that is typically convertible into polymers. Resins are usually mixtures of organic compounds.  This article focuses on naturally occurring resins. Plants secrete resins for their protective benefits in response to injury. The resin protects the plant from insects and pathogens. Resins confound a wide range of herbivores
column3: insects
column4: and pathogens
column5: while the volatile phenolic compounds may attract benefactors such as parasitoids or predators of the herbivores that attack the plant."

column3: is an autonomous community and province in northern Spain
column4: bordering the Basque Autonomous Community
column5: La Rioja
column6: and Aragon in Spain and Nouvelle-Aquitaine in France. The capital city is Pamplona (or Iruñea in Basque)."

column1: 60261 Pinniped "Pinnipeds
column2: commonly known as seals
column3: are a widely distributed and diverse clade of carnivorous
column4: fin-footed
column5: semiaquatic marine mammals. They comprise the extant families Odobenidae (whose only living member is the walrus)
column6: Otariidae (the eared seals: sea lions and fur seals)
column7: and Phocidae (the earless seals
column8: or true seals). There are 33 extant species of pinnipeds
column9: and more than 50 extinct species have been described from fossils. While seals were historically thought to have descended from two ancestral lines
column10: molecular evidence supports them as a monophyletic lineage (descended from one ancestral line). Pinnipeds belong to the order Carnivora and their closest living relatives are believed to be bears and the superfamily of musteloids (weasels
column11: raccoons
column12: skunks
column13: and red pandas)
column14: having diverged about 50 million years ago. Seals range in size from the 1 m (3 ft 3 in) and 45 kg (99 lb) Baikal seal to the 5 m (16 ft) and 3
column16: 100 lb) southern elephant seal
column17: which is also the largest member of the order Carnivora. Several species exhibit sexual dimorphism. They have streamlined bodies and four limbs that are modified into flippers. Though not as fast in the water as dolphins
column18: seals are more flexible and agile. Otariids use their front limbs primarily to propel themselves through the water
column19: while phocids and walruses use their hind limbs. Otariids and walruses have hind limbs that can be pulled under the body and used as legs on land. By comparison
column20: terrestrial locomotion by phocids is more cumbersome. Otariids have visible external ears
column21: while phocids and walruses lack these. Pinnipeds have well-developed senses—their eyesight and hearing are adapted for both air and water
column22: and they have an advanced tactile system in their whiskers or vibrissae. Some species are well adapted for diving to great depths. They have a layer of fat
column23: or blubber
column24: under the skin to keep warm in the cold water
column25: and
column26: other than the walrus
column27: all species are covered in fur. Although pinnipeds are widespread
column28: most species prefer the colder waters of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. They spend most of their lives in the water
column29: but come ashore to mate
column30: give birth
column31: molt or escape from predators
column32: such as sharks and killer whales. They feed largely on fish and marine invertebrates; but a few
column33: like the leopard seal
column34: feed on large vertebrates
column35: such as penguins and other seals. Walruses are specialized for feeding on bottom-dwelling mollusks. Male pinnipeds typically mate with more than one female (polygyny)
column36: although the degree of polygyny varies with the species. The males of land-breeding species tend to mate with a greater number of females than those of ice breeding species. Male pinniped strategies for reproductive success vary between defending females
column37: defending territories that attract females and performing ritual displays or lek mating. Pups are typically born in the spring and summer months and females bear almost all the responsibility for raising them. Mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for a relatively short period of time while others take foraging trips at sea between nursing bouts. Walruses are known to nurse their young while at sea. Seals produce a number of vocalizations
column38: notably the barks of California sea lions
column39: the gong-like calls of walruses and the complex songs of Weddell seals. The meat
column40: blubber and fur coats of pinnipeds have traditionally been used by indigenous peoples of the Arctic. Seals have been depicted in various cultures worldwide. They are commonly kept in captivity and are even sometimes trained to perform tricks and tasks. Once relentlessly hunted by commercial industries for their products
column41: seals and walruses are now protected by international law. The Japanese sea lion and the Caribbean monk seal have become extinct in the past century
column42: while the Mediterranean monk seal and Hawaiian monk seal are ranked endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. Besides hunting
column43: pinnipeds also face threats from accidental trapping
column44: marine pollution
column45: and conflicts with local people.  "

column1: 60857 People_for_the_Ethical_Treatment_of_Animals "People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA ) is an American animal rights organization based in Norfolk
column2: Virginia
column3: and led by Ingrid Newkirk
column4: its international president. A nonprofit corporation with nearly 400 employees
column5: it claims that it has 6.5 million members and supporters
column6: in addition to claiming that it is the ""largest animal rights group in the world."" Its slogan is ""Animals are not ours to eat
column7: wear
column8: experiment on
column9: use for entertainment
column10: or abuse in any other way.""Founded in March 1980 by Ingrid Newkirk and fellow animal rights activist Alex Pacheco
column11: the organization first caught the public's attention in the summer of 1981 during what became known as the Silver Spring monkeys case
column12: a widely publicized dispute about experiments conducted on 17 macaque monkeys inside the Institute of Behavioral Research in Silver Spring
column13: Maryland. The case lasted 10 years
column14: involved the only police raid on an animal laboratory in the United States
column15: triggered an amendment in 1985 to that country's Animal Welfare Act
column16: and established PETA as an internationally known organization. Today
column17: it focuses on four core issues—opposition to factory farming
column18: fur farming
column19: animal testing
column20: and the use of animals in entertainment. It also campaigns for a vegan lifestyle and against eating meat
column21: fishing
column22: the killing of animals regarded as pests
column23: the keeping of chained backyard dogs
column24: cock fighting
column25: dog fighting
column26: beekeeping
column27: and bullfighting.The group is the focus of controversy
column28: both inside and outside the animal rights movement and around the world. Newkirk
column29: and formerly Pacheco
column30: are seen as the leading exporters of animal rights to the more traditional animal-protection groups in the United States
column31: but sections of the movement nonetheless say that PETA is not radical enough—law professor Gary Francione lists the group among what he calls ""the new welfarists
column32: arguing that its work with industries to achieve reform
column33: which continues in the tradition of Henry Spira
column34: makes it an animal welfare group
column35: not an animal rights group. Newkirk told Salon in 2001 that PETA works toward the ideal but tries in the meantime to provide carrot-and-stick incentives. There has also been criticism from feminists within the movement about the use of scantily clad women in PETA's anti-fur campaigns and others
column36: but as Norm Phelps notes
column37: ""Newkirk has been consistent in her response. No one
column38: she says
column39: is being exploited. Everyone ... is an uncoerced volunteer. Sexual attraction is a fact of life
column40: and if it can advance the animals' cause
column41: she makes no apologies for using it."" Also
column42: Phelps notes that some activists believe that the group's media stunts trivialize animal rights
column43: but he qualifies this by saying
column44: ""[I]t's hard to argue with success and PETA is far and away the most successful cutting-edge animal rights organization in the world."" Newkirk's view is that PETA has a duty to be self-proclaimed ""press sluts."" She argues
column45: ""It is our obligation. We would be worthless if we were just polite and didn't make any waves."""

column1: 61770 Bedouin "The Bedouin or Bedu (; Arabic: بَدْو‎
column2: romanized: badw
column3: singular بَدَوِي badawī) are a grouping of nomadic Arab people who have historically inhabited the desert regions in North Africa
column4: the Arabian Peninsula
column5: Iraq and the Levant. The English word bedouin comes from the Arabic badawī
column6: which means ""desert dweller""
column7: and is traditionally contrasted with ḥāḍir
column8: the term for sedentary people. Bedouin territory stretches from the vast deserts of North Africa to the rocky sands of the Middle East. They are traditionally divided into tribes
column9: or clans (known in Arabic as ʿašāʾir; عَشَائِر)
column10: and historically share a common culture of herding camels and goats. The vast majority of Bedouin adhere to Islam
column11: although there are some fewer numbers of Arab Christian Bedouins present in the Fertile Crescent.Bedouins have been referred to by various names throughout history
column12: including Qedarites in the Old Testament and Arabaa by the Assyrians (ar-ba-a-a being a nisba of the noun Arab
column13: a name still used for Bedouins today). They are referred to as the ʾAʿrāb (أعراب) in the Quran. While many Bedouins have abandoned their nomadic and tribal traditions for a modern urban lifestyle
column14: many retain traditional Bedouin culture such as retaining the traditional ʿašāʾir clan structure
column15: traditional music
column16: poetry
column17: dances (such as saas)
column18: and many other cultural practices and concepts. Urbanised Bedouins often organise cultural festivals
column19: usually held several times a year
column20: in which they gather with other Bedouins to partake in and learn about various Bedouin traditions—from poetry recitation and traditional sword dances to playing traditional instruments and even classes teaching traditional tent knitting. Traditions like camel riding and camping in the deserts are still popular leisure activities for urbanised Bedouins who live in close proximity to deserts or other wilderness areas."

column1: 62028 CNN "CNN (Cable News Network) is an American news-based pay television channel owned by AT&T's WarnerMedia. CNN was founded in 1980 by American media proprietor Ted Turner as a 24-hour cable news channel. Upon its launch
column2: CNN was the first television channel to provide 24-hour news coverage and was the first all-news television channel in the United States.While the news channel has numerous affiliates
column3: CNN primarily broadcasts from 30 Hudson Yards in New York City and studios in Washington
column4: D.C. and Los Angeles. Its headquarters at the CNN Center in Atlanta is only used for weekend programming. CNN is sometimes referred to as CNN/U.S. (or CNN Domestic) to distinguish the U.S. channel from its international sister network
column5: CNN International. The network is known for its dramatic live coverage of breaking news
column6: some of which has drawn criticism as overly sensationalistic
column7: and for its efforts to be nonpartisan
column8: which have led to accusations of false balance.As of September 2018
column9: CNN has 90.1 million television households as subscribers (97.7% of households with cable) in the United States.Globally
column10: CNN programming airs through CNN International
column11: which can be seen by viewers in over 212 countries and territories."

column1: 73421 Lilium "Lilium (members of which are true lilies) is a genus of herbaceous flowering plants growing from bulbs

column3: though their range extends into the northern subtropics. Many other plants have ""lily"" in their common name but are not related to true lilies."

column8: style

column10: and material.  They have become collector's items

column12: congratulations
column13: or sympathy."

column1: 88477 Monterey_Bay_Aquarium "Monterey Bay Aquarium is a nonprofit public aquarium in Monterey
column2: California. Known for its regional focus on the marine habitats of Monterey Bay
column3: it was the first to exhibit a living kelp forest when it opened in October 1984. Its biologists have pioneered the animal husbandry of jellyfish and it was the first to successfully care for and display a great white shark. The organization's research and conservation efforts also focus on sea otters
column4: various birds
column5: and tunas. Seafood Watch
column6: a sustainable seafood advisory list published by the aquarium beginning in 1999

Early proposals to build a public aquarium in Monterey County were not successful until a group of four marine biologists affiliated with Stanford University revisited the concept in the late-1970s. Monterey Bay Aquarium was built at the site of a defunct sardine cannery and has been recognized for its architectural achievements by the American Institute of Architects. Along with its architecture
column8: the aquarium has won numerous awards for its exhibition of marine life
column9: ocean conservation efforts
column10: and educational programs. Monterey Bay Aquarium receives around two million visitors each year. It led to the revitalization of Cannery Row

column12: the aquarium has appeared in film and television productions."

column1: 100796 Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records
column2: known from its inception from 1955 until 2000 as The Guinness Book of Records and in previous United States editions as The Guinness Book of World Records

column4: listing world records both of human achievements and the extremes of the natural world. The brainchild of Sir Hugh Beaver

column6: London
column7: in August 1954. The book itself holds a world record
column8: as the best-selling copyrighted book of all time. As of the 2019 edition

The popularity of the franchise has resulted in Guinness World Records becoming the primary international authority on the cataloguing and verification of a huge number of world records. The organisation employs official record adjudicators authorised to verify the authenticity of the setting and breaking of records."

column1: 102226 The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post (sometimes abbreviated to WaPo) is a major American daily newspaper published in Washington
column2: D.C. It has the largest circulation in the Washington metropolitan area. Daily broadsheet editions are printed for the District of Columbia
column3: Maryland
column4: and Virginia. The newspaper has won 47 Pulitzer Prizes. This includes six separate Pulitzers awarded in 2008

column8: the Post's investigations have led to increased review of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center.In October 2013

column1: 161779 Band_of_Brothers_(miniseries) "Band of Brothers is a 2001 American war drama miniseries based on historian Stephen E. Ambrose's 1992 non-fiction book Band of Brothers. The executive producers were Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks

column9: adapting history for dramatic effect and series structure. The characters portrayed are based on members of Easy Company. Some of the men were recorded in contemporary interviews

column1: 217438 Parasitoid "A parasitoid is an organism that lives in close association with its host and at the host's expense
column2: and which sooner or later kills it. Parasitoidism is one of six major evolutionary strategies within parasitism
column3: distinguished by the fatal prognosis for the host
column4: which makes the strategy close to predation. Among parasitoids
column5: strategies range from living inside the host
column6: allowing it to go on growing until the parasitoid emerges as an adult
column7: to paralysing the host and living outside it. Hosts include other parasitoids
column8: resulting in hyperparasitism; in the case of oak galls
column9: up to five levels of parasitism are possible. Some parasitoids influence their host's behaviour in ways that favour the propagation of the parasitoid. Parasitoids are found in a variety of taxa across the endopterygote insects
column10: whose complete metamorphosis may have pre-adapted them for a split lifestyle
column11: with parasitoid larvae and freeliving adults. Most are in the Hymenoptera
column12: where the ichneumons and many other parasitoid wasps are highly specialised for a parasitoidal way of life. Other parasitoids are in the Diptera
column13: Coleoptera and other orders of endopterygote insects. Some of these
column14: usually but not only wasps
column15: are used in biological pest control. The biology of parasitoidism has inspired science fiction authors and scriptwriters to create numerous parasitoidal aliens that kill their human hosts
column16: such as the alien species in Ridley Scott's 1979 film Alien."

column1: 228613 Starfish "Starfish or sea stars are star-shaped echinoderms belonging to the class Asteroidea. Common usage frequently finds these names being also applied to ophiuroids
column2: which are correctly referred to as brittle stars or basket stars. About 1
column3: 500 species of starfish occur on the seabed in all the world's oceans
column4: from the tropics to frigid polar waters. They are found from the intertidal zone down to abyssal depths
column7: 000 ft) below the surface. Starfish are marine invertebrates. They typically have a central disc and five arms
column8: though some species have a larger number of arms. The aboral or upper surface may be smooth
column9: granular or spiny
column10: and is covered with overlapping plates. Many species are brightly coloured in various shades of red or orange
column11: while others are blue
column12: grey or brown. Starfish have tube feet operated by a hydraulic system and a mouth at the centre of the oral or lower surface. They are opportunistic feeders and are mostly predators on benthic invertebrates. Several species have specialized feeding behaviours including eversion of their stomachs and suspension feeding. They have complex life cycles and can reproduce both sexually and asexually. Most can regenerate damaged parts or lost arms and they can shed arms as a means of defence. The Asteroidea occupy several significant ecological roles. Starfish
column13: such as the ochre sea star (Pisaster ochraceus) and the reef sea star (Stichaster australis)
column14: have become widely known as examples of the keystone species concept in ecology. The tropical crown-of-thorns starfish (Acanthaster planci) is a voracious predator of coral throughout the Indo-Pacific region
column15: and the northern Pacific sea star is considered to be one of the world's 100 worst invasive species. The fossil record for starfish is ancient
column16: dating back to the Ordovician around 450 million years ago
column17: but it is rather sparse
column18: as starfish tend to disintegrate after death. Only the ossicles and spines of the animal are likely to be preserved
column19: making remains hard to locate. With their appealing symmetrical shape
column20: starfish have played a part in literature
column21: legend
column22: design and popular culture. They are sometimes collected as curios
column23: used in design or as logos
column24: and in some cultures
column25: despite possible toxicity
column26: they are eaten.  "

column1: 240755 Aesop%27s_Fables "Aesop's Fables
column2: or the Aesopica
column3: is a collection of fables credited to Aesop
column4: a slave and storyteller believed to have lived in ancient Greece between 620 and 564 BCE. Of diverse origins
column5: the stories associated with his name have descended to modern times through a number of sources and continue to be reinterpreted in different verbal registers and in popular as well as artistic media. The fables originally belonged to the oral tradition and were not collected for some three centuries after Aesop's death. By that time a variety of other stories
column6: jokes and proverbs were being ascribed to him
column7: although some of that material was from sources earlier than him or came from beyond the Greek cultural sphere. The process of inclusion has continued until the present
column8: with some of the fables unrecorded before the later Middle Ages and others arriving from outside Europe. The process is continuous and new stories are still being added to the Aesop corpus
column9: even when they are demonstrably more recent work and sometimes from known authors. Manuscripts in Latin and Greek were important avenues of transmission
column10: although poetical treatments in European vernaculars eventually formed another.  On the arrival of printing
column11: collections of Aesop's fables were among the earliest books in a variety of languages. Through the means of later collections
column12: and translations or adaptations of them
column13: Aesop's reputation as a fabulist was transmitted throughout the world. Initially the fables were addressed to adults and covered religious
column14: social and political themes. They were also put to use as ethical guides and from the Renaissance onwards were particularly used for the education of children. Their ethical dimension was reinforced in the adult world through depiction in sculpture
column15: painting and other illustrative means
column16: as well as adaptation to drama and song. In addition
column17: there have been reinterpretations of the meaning of fables and changes in emphasis over time."

column1: 300898 Scallop "Scallop () is a common name that is primarily applied to any one of numerous species of saltwater clams or marine bivalve mollusks in the taxonomic family Pectinidae
column2: the scallops. However
column3: the common name ""scallop"" is also sometimes applied to species in other closely related families within the superfamily Pectinoidea
column4: which also includes the thorny oysters. Scallops are a cosmopolitan family of bivalves which are found in all of the world's oceans
column5: although never in fresh water. They are one of very few groups of bivalves to be primarily ""free-living""
column6: with many species capable of rapidly swimming short distances and even of migrating some distance across the ocean floor. A small minority of scallop species live cemented to rocky substrates as adults
column7: while others attach themselves to stationary or rooted objects such as sea grass at some point in their lives by means of a filament they secrete called a byssal thread. The majority of species
column8: however
column9: live recumbent on sandy substrates
column10: and when they sense the presence of a predator such as a starfish
column11: they may attempt to escape by swimming swiftly but erratically through the water using jet propulsion created by repeatedly clapping their shells together. Scallops have a well-developed nervous system
column12: and unlike most other bivalves all scallops have a ring of numerous simple eyes situated around the edge of their mantles. Many species of scallops are highly prized as a food source
column13: and some are farmed as aquaculture. The word ""scallop"" is also applied to the meat of these bivalves
column14: the adductor muscle
column15: that is sold as seafood. The brightly coloured
column16: symmetrical
column17: fan-shaped shells of scallops with their radiating and often fluted ornamentation are valued by shell collectors
column18: and have been used since ancient times as motifs in art
column19: architecture
column20: and design. Owing to their widespread distribution
column21: scallop shells are a common sight on beaches and are often brightly coloured
column22: making them a popular object to collect among beachcombers and vacationers.  The shells also have a significant place in popular culture
column23: including symbolism."

column1: 322915 Italian_Renaissance "The Italian Renaissance (Italian: Rinascimento [rinaʃʃiˈmento]) was a period of Italian history that began in the 14th century (Trecento) and lasted until the 17th century (Seicento). It peaked during the 15th (Quattrocento) and 16th (Cinquecento) centuries
column2: spreading across Europe and marking the transition from the Middle Ages to Modernity. The French word renaissance (rinascimento in Italian) means ""rebirth"" and defines the period as one of cultural revival and renewed interest in classical antiquity after the centuries labeled the Dark Ages by Renaissance humanists. The Renaissance author Giorgio Vasari used the term ""Rebirth"" in his Lives of the Most Excellent Painters
column3: Sculptors
column4: and Architects but the concept became widespread only in the 19th century
column5: after the works of scholars such as Jules Michelet and Jacob Burckhardt. The Renaissance began in Tuscany (Central Italy)
column6: and was centred in the city of Florence. Florence
column7: one of the several city-states of the peninsula
column8: rose to economic prominence by providing credit for European monarchs and laying down the groundwork for capitalism and banking. The Renaissance later spread to Venice
column9: heart of a mediterranean empire and in control of the trade routes with the east since the participation in the crusades and the voyages of Marco Polo
column10: where the remains of ancient Greek culture were brought together and provided humanist scholars with new texts. Finally the Renaissance had a significant effect on the Papal States and Rome
column11: largely rebuilt by Humanist and Renaissance popes (such as Alexander VI and Julius II)
column12: who were frequently involved in Italian politics
column13: in arbitrating disputes between competing colonial powers and in opposing the Reformation. The Italian Renaissance is best known for its achievements in painting
column14: architecture
column15: sculpture
column16: literature
column17: music
column18: philosophy
column19: science and technology
column20: and exploration. Italy became the recognized European leader in all these areas by the late 15th century
column21: during the Peace of Lodi (1454–1494) agreed between Italian states. The Italian Renaissance peaked in the mid-16th century as domestic disputes and foreign invasions plunged the region into the turmoil of the Italian Wars (1494–1559). However
column22: the ideas and ideals of the Italian Renaissance spread into the rest of Europe
column23: setting off the Northern Renaissance. Italian explorers from the maritime republics served under the auspices of European monarchs
column24: ushering the Age of discovery. The most famous among them are Christopher Columbus who sailed for Spain
column25: Giovanni da Verrazzano for France
column26: Amerigo Vespucci for Portugal
column27: and John Cabot for England. Italian scientists such as Falloppio
column28: Tartaglia
column29: Galileo
column30: Torricelli
column31: played a key role in the scientific revolution and foreigners such as Copernicus and Vesalius worked in Italian universities. Various events and dates of the 17th century
column32: such as the conclusion of the European Wars of Religion in 1648
column33: have been proposed for the end of the Renaissance.Accounts of Renaissance literature usually begin with the three great poets of the 14th century: Dante Alighieri (Divine Comedy)
column34: Petrarch (Canzoniere) and Boccaccio (Decameron). Famous vernacular poets of the Renaissance include the epic authors Luigi Pulci (author of Morgante)
column35: Matteo Maria Boiardo (Orlando Innamorato)
column36: Ludovico Ariosto (Orlando Furioso) and Torquato Tasso (Jerusalem Delivered). 15th-century writers such as the poet Poliziano and the Platonist philosopher Marsilio Ficino made extensive translations from both Latin and Greek. In the early 16th century
column37: Baldassare Castiglione laid out his vision of the ideal gentleman and lady in The Book of the Courtier
column38: while Niccolò Machiavelli cast a jaundiced eye on ""la verità effettuale della cosa""—the effectual truth of things—in The Prince
column39: composed
column40: in humanistic style
column41: chiefly of parallel ancient and modern examples of Virtù. Historians of the period include Machiavelli himself
column42: his friend and critic Francesco Guicciardini and Giovanni Botero (The Reason of State). The Aldine Press
column43: founded by the printer Aldo Manuzio
column44: active in Venice
column45: developed Italic type and pocket editions that could be carried in one's pocket
column46: as well as being the first to publish editions of books in Ancient Greek. Venice also became the birthplace of the Commedia dell'Arte. Italian Renaissance art exercised a dominant influence on subsequent European painting and sculpture for centuries afterwards
column47: with artists such as Leonardo da Vinci
column58: and Titian. The same is true for architecture
column66: and the Tempio Malatestiano in Rimini
column67: as well as several private residences. The musical era of the Italian Renaissance was defined by the Roman School and later by the Venetian School and the birth of Opera in Florence. In philosophy
column70: Giordano Bruno and Pico della Mirandola

column1: 503345 High_Middle_Ages "The High Middle Ages
column2: or High Medieval Period
column3: was the period of European history that commenced around 1000 and lasted until around 1300. The High Middle Ages were preceded by the Early Middle Ages and were followed by the Late Middle Ages
column4: which ended around 1500 (by historiographical convention).Key historical trends of the High Middle Ages include the rapidly increasing population of Europe
column5: which brought about great social and political change from the preceding era
column6: and the Renaissance of the 12th century
column7: including the first developments of rural exodus and of urbanization. By 1250
column8: the robust population increase had greatly benefited the European economy
column9: which reached levels that would not be seen again in some areas until the 19th century. That trend faltered during the Late Middle Ages because of a series of calamities
column10: most notably the Black Death
column11: but also numerous wars as well as economic stagnation. From around 780
column12: Europe saw the last of the barbarian invasions and became more socially and politically organized. The Carolingian Renaissance stimulated scientific and philosophical activity in Northern Europe. The first universities started operating in Bologna
column13: Paris
column14: Oxford
column15: Salamanca
column16: Cambridge and Modena. The Vikings settled in the British Isles
column17: France and elsewhere
column18: and Norse Christian kingdoms started developing in their Scandinavian homelands. The Magyars ceased their expansion in the 10th century
column19: and by the year 1000
column20: a Christian Kingdom of Hungary had become a recognized state in Central Europe that was forming alliances with regional powers. With the brief exception of the Mongol invasions in the 13th century
column21: major nomadic incursions ceased. The powerful Byzantine Empire of the Macedonian and Komnenos dynasties gradually gave way to the resurrected Serbia and Bulgaria and to a successor crusader state (1204 to 1261)
column22: which countered the continuous threat of the Seljuk Turks in Asia Minor. In the 11th century
column23: populations north of the Alps began a more intensive settlement
column24: targeting ""new"" lands
column25: some of which areas had reverted to wilderness after the end of the Western Roman Empire. In what is known as the ""great clearances""
column26: Europeans cleared and cultivated some of the vast forests and marshes that lay across much of the continent. At the same time
column27: settlers moved beyond the traditional boundaries of the Frankish Empire to new frontiers beyond the Elbe River
column28: which tripled the size of Germany in the process. The Catholic Church
column29: which reached the peak of its political power around then
column30: called armies from across Europe to a series of Crusades against the Seljuk Turks. The crusaders occupied the Holy Land and founded the Crusader States in the Levant. Other wars led to the Northern Crusades. The Christian kingdoms took much of the Iberian Peninsula from Muslim control
column31: and the Normans conquered southern Italy
column32: all part of the major population increases and the resettlement patterns of the era. The High Middle Ages produced many different forms of intellectual
column33: spiritual and artistic works. The age also saw the rise of ethnocentrism
column34: which evolved later into modern civic nationalisms in most of Europe
column35: the ascent of the great Italian city-states and the rise and fall of the Islamic civilization of Al-Andalus. The rediscovery of the works of Aristotle
column36: at first indirectly through Medieval Jewish and Islamic Philosophy
column37: led Maimonides
column38: Avicenna
column39: Muhammad Averroes
column40: Thomas Aquinas and other thinkers of the period to expand Scholasticism
column41: a combination of Judeo-Islamic and Catholic ideologies with the ancient philosophy. For much of this period
column42: Constantinople remained Europe's most populous city
column43: and Byzantine art reached a peak in the 12th century. In architecture
column44: many of the most notable Gothic cathedrals were built or completed around this period. The Crisis of the Late Middle Ages began at the start of the 14th century and marked the end of the period."

column1: 512047 African_Great_Lakes "The African Great Lakes (Swahili: Maziwa Makuu) are a series of lakes constituting the part of the Rift Valley lakes in and around the East African Rift. They include Lake Victoria
column2: the third-largest fresh water lake in the world by area
column3: Lake Tanganyika
column4: the world's second-largest freshwater lake by volume and depth
column5: and Lake Malawi
column6: the world's eighth-largest fresh water lake by area. Collectively
column7: they contain 31
column8: 000 km3 (7400 cu mi) of water
column9: which is more than either Lake Baikal or the North American Great Lakes. This total constitutes about 25% of the planet's unfrozen surface fresh water. The large rift lakes of Africa are the ancient home of great biodiversity
column10: and 10% of the world's fish species live there. Countries in the African Great Lakes region (sometimes also called Greater Lakes region) include Burundi
column11: the Democratic Republic of the Congo
column12: Kenya
column13: Malawi
column14: Rwanda
column15: Tanzania and Uganda.The Great Lakes area
column16: where colonial era borders cut through ethnic groups
column17: has in the last 20 years been a crucible of conflict that has launched multiple uprisings and invasions. The United Nations
column18: the United States
column19: and several European countries have special envoys or representatives to the Great Lakes region. Local populations recently have denounced the presence of these 'agency' groups like the UN
column20: saying they often do not actually prevent attacks or protect local villages
column21: but are posted for whitewashing purposes or to safeguard western envoys
column22: citizens and their business interests. They have also been accused by both local and other African nations of participating in human rights abuses and rampant sex-based exploitation and trafficking."

column2: differentiated from other sled-dog types by their fast pulling style. They are an ever-changing cross-breed of the fastest dogs. The Alaskan Malamute

column4: was used for pulling heavier loads. Huskies are used in sled dog racing. In recent years
column5: companies have been marketing tourist treks with dog sledges for adventure travelers in snow regions as well. Huskies are also today kept as pets
column6: and groups work to find new pet homes for retired racing and adventure trekking dogs."

column1: 534366 Barack_Obama "Barack Hussein Obama II ( (listen); born August 4
column2: 1961) is an American attorney and politician who served as the 44th president of the United States from 2009 to 2017. A member of the Democratic Party
column3: he was the first African American to be elected to the presidency. He previously served as a U.S. senator from Illinois from 2005 to 2008 and an Illinois state senator from 1997 to 2004. Obama was born in Honolulu
column4: Hawaii. After graduating from Columbia University in 1983
column5: he worked as a community organizer in Chicago. In 1988
column6: he enrolled in Harvard Law School
column7: where he was the first black president of the Harvard Law Review. After graduating
column8: he became a civil rights attorney and an academic
column9: teaching constitutional law at the University of Chicago Law School from 1992 to 2004. He represented the 13th district for three terms in the Illinois Senate from 1997 until 2004
column10: when he ran for the U.S. Senate. He received national attention in 2004 with his March primary win
column11: his well-received July Democratic National Convention keynote address
column12: and his landslide November election to the Senate. In 2008
column13: he was nominated for president a year after his campaign began
column14: after a close primary campaign against Hillary Clinton. He was elected over Republican John McCain and was inaugurated on January 20
column15: 2009. Nine months later
column16: he was named the 2009 Nobel Peace Prize laureate. Regarded as a centrist New Democrat
column17: Obama signed many landmark bills into law during his first two years in office. The main reforms that were passed include the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (commonly referred to as the ""Affordable Care Act"" or ""Obamacare"")
column18: the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
column19: and the Don't Ask
column20: Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 and Tax Relief
column21: Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization
column22: and Job Creation Act of 2010 served as economic stimulus amidst the Great Recession. After a lengthy debate over the national debt limit
column23: he signed the Budget Control and the American Taxpayer Relief Acts. In foreign policy
column24: he increased U.S. troop levels in Afghanistan
column25: reduced nuclear weapons with the United States–Russia New START treaty
column26: and ended military involvement in the Iraq War. He ordered military involvement in Libya
column27: contributing to the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi. He also ordered the military operations that resulted in the deaths of Osama bin Laden and suspected Yemeni Al-Qaeda operative Anwar al-Awlaki. After winning re-election by defeating Republican opponent Mitt Romney
column28: Obama was sworn in for a second term in 2013. During this term
column29: he promoted inclusiveness for LGBT Americans. His administration filed briefs that urged the Supreme Court to strike down same-sex marriage bans as unconstitutional (United States v. Windsor and Obergefell v. Hodges); same-sex marriage was fully legalized in 2015 after the Court ruled that a same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional in Obergefell. He advocated for gun control in response to the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting
column30: indicating support for a ban on assault weapons
column31: and issued wide-ranging executive actions concerning global warming and immigration. In foreign policy
column32: he ordered military intervention in Iraq in response to gains made by ISIL after the 2011 withdrawal from Iraq
column33: continued the process of ending U.S. combat operations in Afghanistan in 2016
column34: promoted discussions that led to the 2015 Paris Agreement on global climate change
column35: initiated sanctions against Russia following the invasion in Ukraine and again after Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
column36: brokered a nuclear deal with Iran
column37: and normalized U.S. relations with Cuba. Obama nominated three justices to the Supreme Court: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan were confirmed as justices
column38: while Merrick Garland faced unprecedented partisan obstruction and was ultimately not confirmed. During his term in office
column39: America's soft power and reputation abroad significantly improved.Obama's presidency has generally been regarded favorably
column40: and evaluations of his presidency among historians
column42: and the general public place him among the upper tier of American presidents. Obama left office and retired in January 2017 and currently resides in Washington
column43: D.C. A December 2018 Gallup poll found Obama to be the most admired man in America for an unprecedented 11th consecutive year
column44: although Dwight D. Eisenhower was selected most admired in twelve non-consecutive years."

column1: 552748 Rift_Valley_lakes "The Rift Valley lakes are a series of lakes in the East African Rift valley that runs through eastern Africa from Ethiopia in the north to Malawi in the south
column2: and includes the African Great Lakes in the south. These include some of the world's oldest lakes
column3: deepest lakes
column4: largest lakes by area
column5: and largest lakes by volume. Many are freshwater ecoregions of great biodiversity
column6: while others are alkaline ""soda lakes"" supporting highly specialised organisms. The Rift Valley lakes are well known for the evolution of at least 800 cichlid fish species that live in their waters. More species are expected to be discovered.The World Wide Fund for Nature has designated these lakes as one of its Global 200 priority ecoregions for conservation.In this article
column7: the major lakes are listed
column8: generally in order from north to south
column9: and more detailed articles on each lake can be accessed through the linked names."

column1: 697240 Merchandising "In the broadest sense
column2: merchandising is any practice which contributes to the sale of products to a retail consumer. At a retail in-store level
column3: merchandising refers to the variety of products available for sale and the display of those products in such a way that it stimulates interest and entices customers to make a purchase. In the profession of merchandising you are either employed by the store in which you work
column4: or by an independent distributor.  As a professional merchandiser
column5: in a retail setting
column6: you will not only know your products (i.e. coffee
column7: juice
column8: soda
column9: etc.) but you will gauge other “vendors” like products as you tend to your job.  Working with the store and other merchandisers
column10: shelf space is often given or taken as need be in some locations(for some young merchandisers this is known as “war”) In retail commerce
column11: visual display merchandising means merchandise sales using product design
column12: selection
column13: packaging
column14: pricing
column15: and display that stimulates consumers to spend more. This includes disciplines and discounting
column16: physical presentation of products and displays
column17: and the decisions about which products should be presented to which customers at what time. Merchandising helps to understand the ordinary dating notation for the terms of payment of an invoice. Codified discounting solves pricing problems including markups and markdowns. It helps to find the net price of an item after single or multiple trade discounts and can calculate a single discount rate that is equivalent to a series of multiple discounts. Further
column18: it helps to calculate the amount of cash discount for which a payment qualifies."

column1: 884607 Desperate_Housewives "Desperate Housewives is an American mystery comedy-drama television series created by Marc Cherry and produced by ABC Studios and Cherry Productions. It originally aired for eight seasons on ABC from October 3
column2: 2004 until May 13
column3: 2012. Executive producer Cherry served as showrunner. Other executive producers since the fourth season included Bob Daily
column4: George W. Perkins
column5: John Pardee
column6: Joey Murphy
column7: David Grossman
column8: and Larry Shaw. Set on Wisteria Lane
column9: a street in the fictional town of Fairview in the fictional Eagle State
column10: Desperate Housewives follows the lives of a group of women as seen through the eyes of their friend and neighbor who committed suicide in the pilot episode. The storyline covers thirteen years of the women's lives over eight seasons
column11: set between the years 2004–2008
column12: and later 2013–2017 (the storyline includes a five-year jump in time
column13: as well as flashbacks and flashforwards ranging from the 1980s to the 2020s). They work through domestic struggles and family life
column14: while facing the secrets
column15: crimes
column16: and mysteries hidden behind the doors of their—on the surface—beautiful and seemingly perfect suburban neighborhood. The series features an ensemble cast
column17: headed by Teri Hatcher as Susan Mayer
column18: Felicity Huffman as Lynette Scavo
column19: Marcia Cross as Bree Van de Kamp
column20: and Eva Longoria as Gabrielle Solis. Brenda Strong narrates the series as the late Mary Alice Young
column21: appearing sporadically in flashbacks or dream sequences.Desperate Housewives was well received by viewers and critics alike. It won multiple Primetime Emmy
column22: Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild Awards. From the 2004–05 through the 2008–09 television seasons
column23: its first five seasons were rated amongst the top ten most-watched series. In 2007
column24: it was reported to be the most popular show in its demographic worldwide
column25: with an audience of approximately 120 million and was also reported as the third-most-watched television series in a study of ratings in twenty countries. In 2012
column26: it remained the most-watched comedy series internationally based on data from Eurodata TV Worldwide
column27: which measured ratings across five continents; it has held this position since 2006. Moreover
column28: it was the third-highest revenue-earning series for 2010
column29: with $2.74 million per half an hour. The show was ranked at number fifty-six on Entertainment Weekly's ""New TV Classics"" list.In 2011
column30: it was confirmed that Desperate Housewives would conclude after its eighth season; the series finale aired on May 13
column31: 2012. By the end of the series
column32: it had surpassed Charmed as the longest-running hour-long television series featuring all-female leads by two episodes."

column1: 898017 Empire_(film_magazine) "Empire is a British film magazine published monthly by Bauer Consumer Media  of Hamburg based Bauer Media Group. From the first issue in July 1989

column1: 932477 Tuf_Voyaging "Tuf Voyaging is a 1986 science fiction fix-up novel by American writer George R. R. Martin
column2: first published in hardcover by Baen Books. It is a darkly comic meditation on environmentalism and absolute power. This novel is a collection of related short fiction works
column3: originally published over several years
column4: beginning with 1976's ""A Beast for Norn"". The book includes a prologue and Martin's S'uthlam storyline (published in Analog Science Fiction and Fact)
column5: adding them as bridging material
column6: and gathering them with other Tuf stories into one episodic novel.The novel concerns the (mis)adventures of Haviland Tuf
column7: an exceptionally tall
column8: bald
column9: very pale
column10: overweight
column11: phlegmatic
column12: vegetarian
column13: cat-loving-but-otherwise solitary space trader. Tuf inadvertently becomes the master of the Ark
column14: an ancient
column15: 30-kilometre-long (19 mi) ""seedship"" - a very powerful warship with advanced ecological engineering capabilities - after a deal with several venal and cutthroat traders goes awry.  Tuf travels the galaxy
column16: offering his services to worlds with environmental problems
column17: and sometimes imposing solutions of his own. The stories in Tuf Voyaging are set in the same fictional ""Thousand Worlds"" universe as several of Martin's other works
column18: including Dying of the Light
column19: Sandkings. Nightflyers
column20: A Song for Lya and ""The Way of Cross and Dragon"".Martin cited fantasy fiction and science fiction Grand Master Jack Vance as having a large influence on his Tuf stories
column21: and he emulated Vance's writing style in most of them.In 2006
column22: Tuf Voyaging was nominated for a Seiun Award in Japan for translated long form novel. Several of the individual stories have also been honored. In 1982
column23: ""Guardians"" won the Locus Award for Best Novelette  and was nominated for the Hugo Award for Best Novelette. In the 1986 Analog Readers Poll in the novella/novelette category
column24: ""Loaves and Fishes"" won and ""Manna from Heaven"" took second place."

column1: 935492 Jerome_Flynn "Jerome Patrick Flynn (born 16 March 1963) is an English actor and singer. He is best known for his roles as Paddy Garvey of the King's Fusiliers in the ITV series Soldier Soldier

column1: 982115 Principal_photography "Principal photography is the phase of film production in which the bulk of the movie is filmed
column2: with actors on set and cameras rolling
column3: as distinct from pre-production and post-production. Principal photography is typically the most expensive phase of film production
column4: due to actor
column5: director
column6: and set crew salaries
column7: as well as the costs of certain shots
column8: props
column9: and on-set special effects.  Its start generally marks a point of no return for the financiers
column10: because until it is complete
column11: there is unlikely to be enough material filmed to release a final product needed to recoup costs.While it is common for a film to lose its greenlight status during pre-production – for example
column12: when an essential cast member drops out or unexpectedly dies
column13: or some scandal engulfs the studio or an actor – it is rare for the film to lose financing once principal photography has begun.Feature films usually have insurance in place by the time principal photography begins. The death of a bankable star before completing all planned takes or the loss of sets or footage can render a film impossible to complete as planned. For example
column14: sets are notoriously flammable. Furthermore
column15: professional-quality movie cameras are usually rented as needed
column16: and most camera houses do not allow rentals of their equipment without proof of insurance.Once a film concludes principal photography
column17: it is said to have wrapped
column18: and a wrap party may be organized to celebrate. During post-production
column19: it may become apparent that some shots or sequences are missing or incomplete and are required to complete the film
column20: or that a particular scene is not playing as expected
column21: or that a performer needs to be replaced entirely. In these circumstances
column22: additional material may have to be shot.  If the material has already been shot once or is substantial
column23: this process is referred to as a re-shoot. However
column24: if the material is new and relatively minor
column25: it is often referred to as a pick-up."

column1: 1060418 The_10th_Kingdom "The 10th Kingdom is an American fairytale fantasy miniseries written by Simon Moore and produced by Britain's Carnival Films

column4: through a magical mirror into a parallel world of fairy tales. The miniseries was initially broadcast over five nights in two-hour episodes on NBC
column5: beginning February 27

column1: 1102458 The_Wire "The Wire is an American crime drama television series created and primarily written by author and former police reporter David Simon. The series was broadcast by the cable network HBO in the United States. The Wire premiered on June 2
column2: 2002 and ended on March 9
column4: comprising 60 episodes over five seasons. Set and produced in Baltimore
column5: Maryland
column6: The Wire introduces a different institution of the city and its relationship to law enforcement in each season
column7: while retaining characters and advancing storylines from previous seasons. The five subjects are
column8: in chronological order: the illegal drug trade
column9: the seaport system
column10: the city government and bureaucracy
column11: education and schools
column12: and the print news medium. The large cast consists mainly of actors who are little known for their other roles
column13: as well as numerous real-life Baltimore and Maryland figures in guest and recurring roles. Simon has said that despite its framing as a crime drama
column14: the show is ""really about the American city
column15: and about how we live together. It's about how institutions have an effect on individuals. Whether one is a cop
column16: a longshoreman
column17: a drug dealer
column18: a politician
column19: a judge or a lawyer
column20: all are ultimately compromised and must contend with whatever institution to which they are committed.""The Wire is lauded for its literary themes
column21: its uncommonly accurate exploration of society and politics
column22: and its realistic portrayal of urban life. Although during its original run the series received only average ratings and never won any major television awards
column23: it is now widely regarded to be one of the greatest television shows of all time."

column1: 1318361 Eyes_on_the_Prize "Eyes on the Prize is an American television series and 14-part documentary about the Civil Rights Movement in the United States.  The documentary originally aired on the PBS network and also aired in the United Kingdom on BBC2.  Created and executive produced by Henry Hampton at the film production company Blackside and narrated by Julian Bond
column2: the series uses archival footage
column3: stills and interviews of participants and opponents of the movement.  The title of the series is derived from the folk song ""Keep Your Eyes on the Prize
column4: which is used in each episode as the opening theme music. A total of 14 episodes of Eyes on the Prize were produced in two separate parts.  The first part
column5: Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years 1954–1965
column6: chronicles the time period between the United States Supreme Court ruling Brown v. Board of Education (1954) to the Selma to Montgomery marches of 1965.  It consists of six episodes
column7: which premiered on January 21
column8: 1987 and concluded on February 25
column9: 1987.  The second part
column10: Eyes on the Prize II: America at the Racial Crossroads 1965–1985
column11: chronicles the time period between the national emergence of Malcolm X during 1964 to the 1983 election of Harold Washington as the first African-American mayor of Chicago.  It consists of eight episodes
column12: which aired on January 15
column13: 1990 and ended on March 5
column15: and was made widely available to educators on VHS tape. All 14 hours were re-released on DVD in 2006 by PBS."

column1: 1324684 Real_Time_with_Bill_Maher "Real Time with Bill Maher is a talk show that airs weekly on HBO

column1: 1358672 Hula_Valley "The Hula Valley (Hebrew: עמק החולה
column2: translit. Emek Ha-Ḥula; also transliterated as Huleh Valley) is an agricultural region in northern Israel with abundant fresh water
column3: which used to be Lake Hula

column5: Europe
column6: and Asia. Lake Hula and the marshland surrounding it were a breeding ground for mosquitoes carrying malaria
column7: and so were drained in the 1950s. A small section of the valley was later re-flooded in an attempt to revive a nearly extinct ecosystem. An estimated 500 million migrating birds now pass through the Hula Valley every year."

column2: Harry Potter
column3: and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley

column10: critical acclaim and commercial success worldwide. They have attracted a wide adult audience as well as younger readers and are often considered cornerstones of modern young adult literature. As of February 2018

column20: Brown. The original seven books were adapted into an eight-part namesake film series by Warner Bros. Pictures

column24: including fantasy
column25: drama
column26: coming of age

column11: Ofelia

Pictures in Spain on 11 October and in Mexico on 20 October. It was produced and distributed internationally by Esperanto Filmoj and Warner Bros. Pictures

column28: direction
