4699587 Fish "Fish are gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals that lack limbs with digits. They form a sister group to the tunicates
column2: together forming the olfactores. Included in this definition are the living hagfish
column3: lampreys
column4: and cartilaginous and bony fish as well as various extinct related groups. Tetrapods emerged within lobe-finned fishes
column5: so cladistically they are fish as well. However
column6: traditionally fish are rendered paraphyletic by excluding the tetrapods (i.e.
column7: the amphibians
column8: reptiles
column9: birds and mammals which all descended from within the same ancestry). Because in this manner the term ""fish"" is defined negatively as a paraphyletic group
column10: it is not considered a formal taxonomic grouping in systematic biology
column11: unless it is used in the cladistic sense
column12: including tetrapods. The traditional term pisces (also ichthyes) is considered a typological
column13: but not a phylogenetic classification. The earliest organisms that can be classified as fish were soft-bodied chordates that first appeared during the Cambrian period. Although they lacked a true spine
column14: they possessed notochords which allowed them to be more agile than their invertebrate counterparts. Fish would continue to evolve through the Paleozoic era
column15: diversifying into a wide variety of forms. Many fish of the Paleozoic developed external armor that protected them from predators. The first fish with jaws appeared in the Silurian period
column16: after which many (such as sharks) became formidable marine predators rather than just the prey of arthropods. Most fish are ectothermic (""cold-blooded"")
column17: allowing their body temperatures to vary as ambient temperatures change
column18: though some of the large active swimmers like white shark and tuna can hold a higher core temperature.Fish can communicate in their underwater environments through the use of acoustic communication. Acoustic communication in fish involves the transmission of acoustic signals from one individual of a species to another. The production of sounds as a means of communication among fish is most often used in the context of feeding
column19: aggression or courtship behaviour. The sounds emitted by fish can vary depending on the species and stimulus involved. They can produce either stridulatory sounds by moving components of the skeletal system
column20: or can produce non-stridulatory sounds by manipulating specialized organs such as the swimbladder.Fish are abundant in most bodies of water. They can be found in nearly all aquatic environments
column21: from high mountain streams (e.g.
column22: char and gudgeon) to the abyssal and even hadal depths of the deepest oceans (e.g.
column23: gulpers and anglerfish)
column24: although no species has yet been documented in the deepest 25% of the ocean. With 33
column25: 600 described species
column26: fish exhibit greater species diversity than any other group of vertebrates.Fish are an important resource for humans worldwide
column27: especially as food. Commercial and subsistence fishers hunt fish in wild fisheries (see fishing) or farm them in ponds or in cages in the ocean (see aquaculture). They are also caught by recreational fishers
column28: kept as pets
column29: raised by fishkeepers
column30: and exhibited in public aquaria. Fish have had a role in culture through the ages
column31: serving as deities
column32: religious symbols
column33: and as the subjects of art
column34: books and movies."

column1: 5018529 Practical_Fishkeeping "Practical Fishkeeping (also known as PFK) is a United Kingdom-based aquarium magazine. It is published every four weeks by Warners Publications Plc. The title covers the entire aquatic market from tropical freshwater and tropical marine fishkeeping throughout the year to small amounts of pond and coldwater fish coverage during the summer months."
5981816 Dexter_(TV_series) "Dexter is an American television crime drama mystery series that aired on Showtime from October 1
column3: to September 22
column4: 2013. Set in Miami
column5: the series centers on Dexter Morgan (Michael C. Hall)
column6: a forensic technician specializing in blood spatter pattern analysis for the fictional Miami Metro Police Department
column7: who leads a secret parallel life as a vigilante serial killer
column8: hunting down murderers who have slipped through the cracks of the justice system. The show's first season was derived from the novel Darkly Dreaming Dexter (2004)

column10: who wrote the first episode. Subsequent seasons evolved independently of Lindsay's works.  In February 2008

column12: thus the reruns on CBS ended after one run of the first season. The series enjoyed mostly positive reviews throughout its run and popularity. The first four seasons have received universal acclaim
column13: although reception dropped drastically as the series progressed. The show has also won many awards
column14: including two Golden Globe awards won by Michael C. Hall and John Lithgow for their roles as Dexter Morgan and Arthur Mitchell
column15: respectively. Season four aired its season finale on December 13
column17: to a record-breaking audience of 2.6 million viewers
column18: making it the most-watched original series episode ever on Showtime at that time.In April 2013
column19: Showtime announced that season eight would be the final season of Dexter. The season-eight premiere was the most watched Dexter episode with more than 3 million viewers total for all airings that night. The original broadcast of the series finale—shown at 9 pm on September 22
column20: 2013—drew 2.8 million viewers

7285190 Spin-off_(media) "In media
column2: a spin-off (or spinoff) is a radio program
column3: television program
column4: video game
column5: film
column6: or any narrative work
column7: derived from already existing works that focus on more details and different aspects from the original work (e.g. particular topics
column8: characters or events). One of the earliest spin-offs of the modern media era
column9: if not the first
column10: happened in 1941 when the supporting character Throckmorton P. Gildersleeve from the old time radio comedy show Fibber McGee and Molly became the star of his own program The Great Gildersleeve (1941–1957).In genre fiction
column11: the term parallels the usage in television; it is usually meant to indicate a substantial change in narrative viewpoint and activity from that (previous) storyline based on the activities of the series' principal protagonist and so is a shift to that action and overall narrative thread of some other protagonist
column12: which now becomes the central or main thread (storyline) of the new sub-series. The new protagonist generally appears first as a minor or supporting character in the main story line within a given milieu
column13: and it is very common for the previous protagonist to have a supporting or cameo role
column14: at the least as a historical mention
column15: in the new sub-series. Spin offs sometimes generate their own spin-offs
column16: leaving the new show in its own series only vaguely connected to the original series."

column1: 7500259 Crop "A crop is a plant or animal product that can be grown and harvested extensively for profit or subsistence. Crop may refer either to the harvested parts or to the harvest in a more refined state. Most crops are cultivated in agriculture or aquaculture. A crop is usually expanded to include macroscopic fungus (e.g. mushrooms)
column2: or alga (algaculture). Most crops are harvested as food for humans or fodder for livestock. Some crops are gathered from the wild (including intensive gathering
column3: e.g. ginseng). Important non-food crops include horticulture
column4: floriculture and industrial crops. Horticulture crops include plants used for other crops (e.g. fruit trees). Floriculture crops include bedding plants
column5: houseplants
column6: flowering garden and pot plants
column7: cut cultivated greens
column8: and cut flowers. Industrial crops are produced for clothing (fiber crops)
column9: biofuel (energy crops
column10: algae fuel)
column11: or medicine (medicinal plants)."

column1: 7529378 Facebook "Facebook
column2: Inc. is an American online social media and social networking service company based in Menlo Park
column3: California. It was founded by Mark Zuckerberg
column4: along with fellow Harvard College students and roommates Eduardo Saverin
column5: Andrew McCollum
column6: Dustin Moskovitz and Chris Hughes. It is considered one of the Big Four technology companies along with Amazon
column7: Apple
column8: and Google.The founders initially limited the website's membership to Harvard students and subsequently Columbia
column9: Stanford
column10: and Yale students. Membership was eventually expanded to the remaining Ivy League schools
column11: MIT
column12: and higher education institutions in the Boston area
column13: then various other universities
column14: and lastly high school students. Since 2006
column15: anyone who claims to be at least 13 years old has been allowed to become a registered user of Facebook
column16: though this may vary depending on local laws. The name comes from the face book directories often given to American university students. Facebook held its initial public offering (IPO) in February 2012
column17: valuing the company at $104 billion
column18: the largest valuation to date for a newly listed public company. Facebook makes most of its revenue from advertisements that appear onscreen and in users' News Feeds. The Facebook service can be accessed from devices with Internet connectivity
column19: such as personal computers
column20: tablets and smartphones. After registering
column21: users can create a customized profile revealing information about themselves. They can post text
column22: photos and multimedia which is shared with any other users that have agreed to be their ""friend""
column23: or
column24: with a different privacy setting
column25: with any reader. Users can also use various embedded apps
column26: join common-interest groups
column27: and receive notifications of their friends' activities. Facebook claimed that had more than 2.3 billion monthly active users as of December 2018. However
column28: it faces a big problem of fake accounts. It caught 3 billion fake accounts in the last quarter of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019. Many critics questioned whether Facebook knows how many actual users it has. Facebook is one of the world's most valuable companies. It receives prominent media coverage
column29: including many controversies. These often involve user privacy (as with the Cambridge Analytica data scandal)
column30: political manipulation (as with the 2016 U.S. elections)
column31: psychological effects such as addiction and low self-esteem
column32: and content that some users find objectionable
column33: including fake news
column34: conspiracy theories
column35: and copyright infringement. Commentators have accused Facebook of helping to spread false information and fake news. In 2017
column36: Facebook partnered with fact checkers from the Poynter Institute's International Fact-Checking Network to identify and mark false content
column37: though most ads from political candidates are exempt from this program. Critics of the program accuse Facebook of not doing enough to remove false information from its website.Facebook offers other products and services. It acquired Instagram
column38: WhatsApp
column39: Oculus
column40: and GrokStyle and independently developed Facebook Messenger
column42: and Facebook Portal."

column1: 7558795 Dear_America:_Letters_Home_from_Vietnam "Dear America: Letters Home from Vietnam is a 1987 American documentary film inspired by the anthology of the same title

column1: 9795023 Azure_Window "The Azure Window (Maltese: it-Tieqa Żerqa)

column10: and ""The Messenger"") were initially broadcast on December 7

column14: and ""Heaven

column1: 10597978 The_Pacific_(miniseries) "The Pacific is a 2010 American television series produced by HBO

column9: and 7th

column11: one of the main writers on Band of Brothers. Hugh Ambrose

column1: 13873779 Sugarcane "Sugarcane
column2: or sugar cane
column3: or simply cane
column4: are several species of tall perennial true grasses of the genus Saccharum
column5: tribe Andropogoneae
column6: used for sugar production. It has stout
column7: jointed
column8: fibrous stalks that are rich in sucrose
column9: a simple sugar which accumulates in the stalk internodes. The plant is two to six metres (six to twenty feet) tall. All sugar cane species can interbreed and the major commercial cultivars are complex hybrids. Sugarcane belongs to the grass family Poaceae
column10: an economically important seed plant family that includes maize
column11: wheat
column12: rice
column13: and sorghum
column14: and many forage crops. It is native to the warm temperate to tropical regions of South Asia
column15: Southeast Asia New Guinea
column16: and South America. The global demand for sugar is the primary driver of sugarcane agriculture. Sugarcane is the world's largest crop by production quantity
column17: with 1.9 billion tonnes produced in 2015
column18: with Brazil accounting for 41% of the world total. In 2012
column19: the Food and Agriculture Organization estimated it was cultivated on about 26 million hectares (64 million acres)
column20: in more than 90 countries.  About 70% of the sugar produced globally comes from a species of sugarcane called Saccharum officinarum and hybrids using this species. Sugarcane accounts for 79% of sugar produced; most of the rest is made from sugar beets. Sugarcane predominantly grows in tropical and subtropical regions
column21: while sugar beets grow in colder temperate regions.  Sucrose (table sugar)
column22: extracted from sugarcane in specialized mill factories
column23: is either used as raw material in the food industry or fermented to produce ethanol.  Other than sugar
column24: products derived from sugarcane include falernum
column25: molasses
column26: rum
column27: cachaça (a traditional spirit from Brazil)
column28: bagasse. In some regions
column29: people use sugarcane reeds to make pens
column30: mats
column31: screens
column32: and thatch. The young
column33: unexpanded inflorescence of Saccharum edule (duruka or tebu telor) is eaten raw
column34: steamed
column35: or toasted
column36: and prepared in various ways in Southeast Asia
column37: including Fiji and certain island communities of Indonesia.Sugarcane was an ancient crop of the Austronesian and Papuan people. It was introduced to Polynesia
column38: Island Melanesia
column39: and Madagascar in prehistoric times via Austronesian sailors. It was also introduced to southern China and India by Austronesian traders at around 1200 to 1000 BC. The Persians
column40: followed by the Greeks

column1: 14145137 John_Adams_(miniseries) "John Adams is a 2008 American television miniseries chronicling most of U.S. President John Adams's political life and his role in the founding of the United States. Paul Giamatti portrays John Adams. The miniseries was directed by Tom Hooper.  Kirk Ellis wrote the screenplay based on the 2001 book John Adams by David McCullough. The biopic of John Adams and the story of the first 50 years of the United States was broadcast in seven parts by HBO between March 16 and April 20
column2: 2008. John Adams received widespread critical acclaim and many prestigious awards. The show won four Golden Globe awards and 13 Emmy awards
column3: more than any other miniseries in history."

column1: 15704166 Inuit "Inuit (; syllabics: ᐃᓄᐃᑦ
column2: ""the people""
column3: singular: Inuk ᐃᓄᒃ
column4: dual: Inuuk ᐃᓅᒃ) are a group of culturally similar indigenous peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Greenland
column5: Canada and Alaska. The Inuit languages are part of the Eskimo–Aleut family. Inuit Sign Language is a critically endangered language isolate used in Nunavut.In Canada and the United States

column9: Iñupiat and Inuit. Since the late 20th century

column11: and they more frequently identify as ""Inuit"" for an autonym. In Canada
column12: sections 25 and 35 of the Constitution Act of 1982 classified Inuit as a distinctive group of Aboriginal Canadians who are not included under either the First Nations or the Métis.Inuit live throughout most of Northern Canada in the territory of Nunavut
column13: Nunavik in the northern third of Quebec
column14: Nunatsiavut and NunatuKavut in Labrador
column15: and in various parts of the Northwest Territories
column16: particularly around the Arctic Ocean
column17: in the  Inuvialuit Settlement Region. With the exception of NunatuKavut these areas are known in the Inuit languages as Inuit Nunangat.In the United States
column18: the Iñupiat live primarily on the Alaska North Slope and on Little Diomede Island. The Greenlandic Inuit are descendants of ancient indigenous migrations from Canada
column19: as these people migrated to the east through the continent. Inuit of Denmark are Danish citizens
column20: although not the citizens of the European Union."

column1: 17158563 Sheep "Domestic sheep (Ovis aries) are quadrupedal
column2: ruminant mammals typically kept as livestock. Like most ruminants
column3: sheep are members of the order Artiodactyla
column4: the even-toed ungulates. Although the name sheep applies to many species in the genus Ovis
column5: in everyday usage it almost always refers to Ovis aries. Numbering a little over one billion
column6: domestic sheep are also the most numerous species of sheep. An adult female sheep is referred to as an ewe ()
column7: an intact male as a ram or occasionally a tup
column8: a castrated male as a wether
column9: and a younger sheep as a  lamb. Sheep are most likely descended from the wild mouflon of Europe and Asia. One of the earliest animals to be domesticated for agricultural purposes
column10: sheep are raised for fleeces
column11: meat (lamb
column12: hogget or mutton) and milk. A sheep's wool is the most widely used animal fiber
column13: and is usually harvested by shearing. Ovine meat is called lamb when from younger animals and mutton when from older ones in Commonwealth countries
column14: and lamb in the United States (including from adults).  Sheep continue to be important for wool and meat today
column15: and are also occasionally raised for pelts
column16: as dairy animals
column17: or as model organisms for science. Sheep husbandry is practised throughout the majority of the inhabited world
column18: and has been fundamental to many civilizations. In the modern era
column19: Australia
column20: New Zealand
column21: the southern and central South American nations
column22: and the British Isles are most closely associated with sheep production. Sheepraising has a large lexicon of unique terms which vary considerably by region and dialect. Use of the word sheep began in Middle English as a derivation of the Old English word scēap; it is both the singular and plural name for the animal. A group of sheep is called a flock
column23: herd or mob. Many other specific terms for the various life stages of sheep exist
column24: generally related to lambing
column25: shearing
column26: and age. Being a key animal in the history of farming
column27: sheep have a deeply entrenched place in human culture
column28: and find representation in much modern language and symbology. As livestock
column29: sheep are most often associated with pastoral
column30: Arcadian imagery. Sheep figure in many mythologies—such as the Golden Fleece—and major religions
column31: especially the Abrahamic traditions. In both ancient and modern religious ritual
column32: sheep are used as sacrificial animals."

column1: 17782843 Lady_Gaga "Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta (born March 28
column3: known professionally as Lady Gaga
column4: is an American singer

Its title track became the fastest selling song on the iTunes Store with over a million downloads in less than a week. Gaga experimented with EDM on her third studio album

column1: 18933066 Florida "Florida ( (listen)
column2: Spanish pronunciation: [floˈɾi.ða]) is the southernmost contiguous state in the United States. The state is bordered to the west by the Gulf of Mexico
column3: to the northwest by Alabama
column4: to the north by Georgia

column6: and to the south by the Straits of Florida. Florida is the 22nd-most extensive (65
column7: 755 sq mi or 170
column9: the 3rd-most populous (21

Jacksonville is the most populous municipality in the state and the largest city by area in the contiguous United States. The Miami metropolitan area is Florida's most populous urban area. Tallahassee is the state's capital. Florida's $1.0 trillion economy is the fourth largest in the United States. If it were a country
column13: Florida would be the 16th largest economy in the world
column14: and the 58th most populous as of 2018. In 2017
column15: Florida's per capita personal income was $47
column17: ranking 26th in the nation. The unemployment rate in September 2018 was 3.5% and ranked as the 18th in the United States. Florida exports nearly $55 billion in goods made in the state
column18: the 8th highest among all states. The Miami Metropolitan Area is by far the largest urban economy in Florida and the 12th largest in the United States with a GDP of $345 billion as of 2017. This is more than twice the number of the next metro area
column19: the Tampa Bay Area
column20: which has a GDP of $145 billion. Florida is home to 51 of the world's billionaires with most of them residing in South Florida.The first European contact was made in 1513 by Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de León
column21: who called it la Florida ([la floˈɾiða] ""the land of flowers"") upon landing there in the Easter season
column22: known in Spanish as Pascua Florida. Florida was a challenge for the European colonial powers before it gained statehood in the United States in 1845. It was a principal location of the Seminole Wars against the Native Americans
column23: and racial segregation after the American Civil War. Today
column24: Florida is distinctive for its large Cuban expatriate community and high population growth
column25: as well as for its increasing environmental issues. The state's economy relies mainly on tourism
column26: agriculture
column27: and transportation
column28: which developed in the late 19th century. Florida is also renowned for amusement parks
column29: orange crops
column30: winter vegetables
column31: the Kennedy Space Center
column32: and as a popular destination for retirees. Florida is the flattest state in the United States. Lake Okeechobee is the largest freshwater lake in Florida.Florida's close proximity to the ocean influences many aspects of Florida culture and daily life. Florida is a reflection of influences and multiple inheritance; African
column33: European
column34: indigenous
column35: and Latino heritages can be found in the architecture and cuisine. Florida has attracted many writers such as Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings
column36: Ernest Hemingway and Tennessee Williams
column37: and continues to attract celebrities and athletes. It is internationally known for golf
column38: tennis
column39: auto racing
column40: and water sports. Several beaches in Florida have turquoise and emerald-colored coastal waters.About two-thirds of Florida occupies a peninsula between the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean. Florida has the longest coastline in the contiguous United States
column42: 350 miles (2
column44: not including the contribution of the many barrier islands. Florida has a total of 4
column45: 510 islands that are ten acres or larger in area. This is the second-highest number of islands of any state in the United States; only Alaska has more. It is the only state that borders both the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean. Much of the state is at or near sea level and is characterized by sedimentary soil. Florida has the lowest high point of any U.S. state. The American alligator
column46: American crocodile
column47: American flamingo
column51: and manatee can be found in Everglades National Park in the southern part of the state. The climate varies from subtropical in the north to tropical in the south. Along with Hawaii
column52: Florida is one of only two states that has a tropical climate
column53: and is the only continental state that has both a tropical climate and a coral reef. The Florida Reef is the only living coral barrier reef in the continental United States
column54: and the third-largest coral barrier reef system in the world (after the Great Barrier Reef and Belize Barrier Reef)."

column2: _Croatia "Split (
column3: as the English word split; Croatian pronunciation: [splît] (listen); see other names) is the second-largest city of Croatia and the largest city of the region of Dalmatia
column4: with about 250
column5: 000 people living in its urban area. It lies on the eastern shore of the Adriatic Sea and is spread over a central peninsula and its surroundings. An intraregional transport hub and popular tourist destination
column6: the city is linked to the Adriatic islands and the Apennine peninsula.  Home to Diocletian's Palace
column7: built for the Roman emperor in AD 305
column8: the city was founded as the Greek colony of Aspálathos (Aσπάλαθος) in the 3rd or 2nd century BC. It became a prominent settlement around 650 when it succeeded the ancient capital of the Roman province of Dalmatia
column9: Salona. After the sack of Salona by the Avars and Slavs
column10: the fortified Palace of Diocletian was settled by Roman refugees. Split became a Byzantine city. Later it drifted into the sphere of the Republic of Venice and the Kingdom of Croatia
column11: with the Byzantines retaining nominal suzerainty. For much of the High and Late Middle Ages
column12: Split enjoyed autonomy as a free city of the Dalmatian city-states
column13: caught in the middle of a struggle between Venice and the Croatian-Hungarian Kingdom for control over the Dalmatian cities. Venice eventually prevailed and during the early modern period Split remained a Venetian city
column14: a heavily fortified outpost surrounded by Ottoman territory. Its hinterland was won from the Ottomans in the Morean War of 1699
column15: and in 1797
column16: as Venice fell to Napoleon
column17: the Treaty of Campo Formio rendered the city to the Habsburg Monarchy. In 1805
column18: the Peace of Pressburg added it to the Napoleonic Kingdom of Italy and in 1806 it was included in the French Empire
column19: becoming part of the Illyrian Provinces in 1809. After being occupied in 1813
column20: it was eventually granted to the Austrian Empire following the Congress of Vienna
column21: where the city remained a part of the Austrian Kingdom of Dalmatia until the fall of Austria-Hungary in 1918 and the formation of Yugoslavia. In World War II
column22: the city was annexed by Italy
column23: then liberated by the Partisans after the Italian capitulation in 1943. It was then re-occupied by Germany
column24: which granted it to its puppet Independent State of Croatia. The city was liberated again by the Partisans in 1944
column25: and was included in the post-war Socialist Yugoslavia
column26: as part of its republic of Croatia. In 1991
column27: Croatia seceded from Yugoslavia amid the Croatian War of Independence."

column1: 19009060 Anthropomorphism "Anthropomorphism is the attribution of human traits
column2: emotions
column3: or intentions to non-human entities. It is considered to be an innate tendency of human psychology.Personification is the related attribution of human form and characteristics to abstract concepts such as nations
column4: emotions
column5: and natural forces
column6: such as seasons and weather. Both have ancient roots as storytelling and artistic devices
column7: and most cultures have traditional fables with anthropomorphized animals as characters. People have also routinely attributed human emotions and behavioral traits to wild as well as domesticated animals."

column1: 19230351 Aquarium "An aquarium (plural: aquariums or aquaria) is a vivarium of any size having at least one transparent side in which aquatic plants or animals are kept and displayed. Fishkeepers use aquaria to keep fish
column2: invertebrates
column3: amphibians
column4: aquatic reptiles such as turtles
column5: and aquatic plants. The term ""aquarium""
column6: coined by English naturalist Philip Henry Gosse
column7: combines the Latin root aqua
column8: meaning water
column9: with the suffix -arium
column10: meaning ""a place for relating to"". The aquarium principle was fully developed in 1850 by the chemist Robert Warington
column11: who explained that plants added to water in a container would give off enough oxygen to support animals
column12: so long as the numbers of animals did not grow too large. The aquarium craze was launched in early Victorian England by Gosse
column13: who created and stocked the first public aquarium at the London Zoo in 1853
column14: and published the first manual
column15: The Aquarium: An Unveiling of the Wonders of the Deep Sea in 1854. An aquarium is a water-filled tank in which fish swim about. Small aquariums are kept in the home by hobbyists. There are larger public aquariums in many cities. This kind of aquarium is a building with fish and other aquatic animals in large tanks. A large aquarium may have otters
column16: turtles
column17: dolphins
column18: and other sea animals. Most aquarium tanks also have plants.An aquarist owns fish or maintains an aquarium
column19: typically constructed of glass or high-strength acrylic. Cuboid aquaria are also known as fish tanks or simply tanks
column20: while bowl-shaped aquaria are also known as fish bowls. Size can range from a small glass bowl
column21: under a gallon in volume
column22: to immense public aquaria of several thousand gallons. Specialized equipment maintains appropriate water quality and other characteristics suitable for the aquarium's residents."

column2: a basilisk ( or
column3: from the Greek βασιλίσκος basilískos
column4: ""little king""; Latin regulus) is a legendary reptile reputed to be a serpent king
column5: who can cause death with a single glance. According to the Naturalis Historia of Pliny the Elder
column6: the basilisk of Cyrene is a small snake
column7: ""being not more than twelve fingers in length""
column8: that is so venomous

column12: according to Pliny

It is possible that the legend of the basilisk and its association with the weasel in Europe was inspired by accounts of certain species of Asiatic snakes (such as the king cobra) and their natural predator

column3: also known as corn

column1: 23141006 Orc "An orc  (also spelled ork) is a fictional humanoid creature that is part of a fantasy race akin to goblins.  While the overall concept of orcs draws on a variety of pre-existing mythology

column5: aggressive

column1: 23538713 Bat "Bats are mammals of the order Chiroptera; with their forelimbs adapted as wings
column2: they are the only mammals naturally capable of true and sustained flight. Bats are more manoeuvrable than birds
column3: flying with their very long spread-out digits covered with a thin membrane or patagium. The smallest bat
column4: and arguably the smallest extant mammal
column5: is Kitti's hog-nosed bat
column6: which is 29–34 mm (1.14–1.34 in) in length
column7: 15 cm (5.91 in) across the wings and 2–2.6 g (0.07–0.09 oz) in mass. The largest bats are the flying foxes and the giant golden-crowned flying fox
column8: Acerodon jubatus
column9: which can weigh 1.6 kg (4 lb) and have a wingspan of 1.7 m (5 ft 7 in). The second largest order of mammals after rodents
column10: bats comprise about 20% of all classified mammal species worldwide
column11: with over 1
column12: 200 species. These were traditionally divided into two suborders: the largely fruit-eating megabats
column13: and the echolocating microbats. But more recent evidence has supported dividing the order into Yinpterochiroptera and Yangochiroptera
column14: with megabats as members of the former along with several species of microbats. Many bats are insectivores
column15: and most of the rest are frugivores (fruit-eaters). A few species feed on animals other than insects; for example
column16: the vampire bats feed on blood. Most bats are nocturnal
column17: and many roost in caves or other refuges; it is uncertain whether bats have these behaviours to escape predators. Bats are present throughout the world

column19: at the cost of some threats. Bat dung has been mined as guano from caves and used as fertiliser. Bats consume insect pests
column20: reducing the need for pesticides. They are sometimes numerous enough to serve as tourist attractions
column21: and are used as food across Asia and the Pacific Rim. They are natural reservoirs of many pathogens
column22: such as rabies; and since they are highly mobile
column23: social
column24: and long-lived
column25: they can readily spread disease. In many cultures
column26: bats are popularly associated with darkness
column27: malevolence
column28: witchcraft
column29: vampires
column30: and death."

column1: 24459898 Walls_of_Dubrovnik "The Walls of Dubrovnik (Croatian: Dubrovačke gradske zidine) are a series of defensive stone walls surrounding the city of Dubrovnik in southern Croatia. With numerous additions and modifications throughout their history
column2: they have been considered to be amongst the great fortification systems of the Middle Ages
column3: as they were never breached by a hostile army during this time period. In 1979
column4: the old city of Dubrovnik
column5: which includes a substantial portion of the old walls of Dubrovnik
column6: joined the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites.The oldest systems of fortifications around the town were likely wooden palisades. Today's intact city walls
column7: constructed mainly during the 12th–17th centuries
column8: mostly a double line
column9: have long been a source of pride for Dubrovnik. The walls run an uninterrupted course of approximately 1
column10: 940 metres (6
column11: 360 ft) in length
column12: encircling most of the old city
column13: and reach a maximum height of about 25 metres (82 ft). The bulk of the existing walls and fortifications were constructed during the 14th and 15th centuries
column14: but were continually extended and strengthened up until the 17th century.This complex structure
column15: amongst the largest and most complete in Europe
column16: protected the freedom and safety of a ""civilised"" and ""sophisticated"" republic that flourished in peace and prosperity for some five centuries. The walls were reinforced by three circular and 14 quadrangular towers
column17: five bastions (bulwarks)
column18: two angular fortifications and the large St. John's Fortress. Land walls were additionally reinforced by one larger bastion  and nine smaller semicircular ones
column19: like the casemate Fort Bokar
column20: the oldest preserved fort of that kind in Europe. The moat that ran around the outside section of the city walls
column21: which were armed by more than 120 cannons
column22: provided superb city defense capabilities."

column1: 35198122 National_Federation_of_Independent_Business_v._Sebelius "National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius

column10: including Chief Justice Roberts
column11: agreed that the individual mandate was not a proper use of Congress's Commerce Clause or Necessary and Proper Clause powers
column12: though they did not join in a single opinion. A majority of the justices also agreed that another challenged provision of the Act
column13: a significant expansion of Medicaid
column14: was not a valid exercise of Congress's spending power as it would coerce states to either accept the expansion or risk losing existing Medicaid funding."

column31: Julia Louis-Dreyfus won her record sixth consecutive award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series for the same category for the same role in a single series as Selina Meyer on Veep; she is now tied with Cloris Leachman for the most wins as a performer.The awards ceremony drew 11.4 million viewers
column32: on par with the previous awards ceremony
column33: but one of the lowest viewerships for the Primetime Emmy Awards overall. Analysts attribute this to younger audiences preferring to watch clips or summaries than the entire event and to Florida markets being affected by Hurricane Irma."

column1: 53403353 Good_and_evil "In religion
column2: ethics
column3: philosophy
column4: and psychology ""good and evil"" is a very common dichotomy. In cultures with Manichaean and Abrahamic religious influence
column5: evil is usually perceived as the dualistic antagonistic opposite of good
column6: in which good should prevail and evil should be defeated. In cultures with Buddhist spiritual influence
column7: both good and evil are perceived as part of an antagonistic duality that itself must be overcome through achieving Śūnyatā meaning emptiness in the sense of recognition of good and evil being two opposing principles but not a reality
column8: emptying the duality of them
column9: and achieving a oneness.Evil
column10: in a general context
column11: is the absence or opposite of that which is described as being good. Often
column12: evil is used to denote profound immorality. In certain religious contexts
column13: evil has been described as a supernatural force. Definitions of evil vary
column14: as does the analysis of its motives. However
column15: elements that are commonly associated with evil involve unbalanced behavior involving expediency
column16: selfishness
column17: ignorance
column18: or neglect.The modern philosophical questions regarding good and evil are subsumed into three major areas of study: meta-ethics concerning the nature of good and evil
column19: normative ethics concerning how we ought to behave
column20: and applied ethics concerning particular moral issues."

column1: 55876266 Chernobyl_(miniseries) "Chernobyl is a 2019 historical drama television miniseries produced by HBO in association with Sky UK. Created and written by Craig Mazin and directed by Johan Renck
column2: the series revolves around the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of April 1986 and the unprecedented cleanup efforts that followed. It features an ensemble cast led by Jared Harris
column3: Stellan Skarsgård and Emily Watson. The series premiered in five parts in the United States on May 6
column5: and concurrently in the United Kingdom on May 7
column6: to critical acclaim. At the 71st Primetime Emmy Awards
column7: it received nineteen nominations
column8: and won for Outstanding Limited Series
column9: Outstanding Directing
column10: and Outstanding Writing
column11: while Harris
column12: Skarsgård
column13: and Watson received acting nominations."

column1: 663 Apollo_8 "Apollo 8 was the first crewed spacecraft to leave low Earth orbit and the first to reach the Moon
column2: orbit it
column3: and return. Its three-astronaut crew—Frank Borman
column4: James Lovell
column5: and William Anders—were the first humans to fly to the Moon
column6: to witness and photograph an Earthrise
column7: and to escape the gravity of a celestial body.  Apollo 8 launched on December 21
column9: and was the second crewed spaceflight mission flown in the United States Apollo space program after Apollo 7
column10: which stayed in Earth orbit. Apollo 8 was the third flight and the first crewed launch of the Saturn V rocket
column11: and was the first human spaceflight from the Kennedy Space Center
column12: located adjacent to Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. Originally planned as the second crewed Apollo Lunar Module and command module test
column13: to be flown in an elliptical medium Earth orbit in early 1969
column14: the mission profile was changed in August 1968 to a more ambitious command-module-only lunar orbital flight.  The object was to buy some time for necessary refinements to the lunar module
column15: while providing an opportunity for a different test that could be done. Astronaut Jim McDivitt's crew
column16: who were training to fly the first lunar module flight in low Earth orbit
column17: became the crew for the Apollo 9 mission
column18: and Borman's crew were moved to the Apollo 8 mission. This left Borman's crew with two to three months' less training and preparation time than originally planned
column19: and replaced the planned lunar module training with translunar navigation training. Apollo 8 took 68 hours (almost three days) to travel the distance to the Moon. The crew orbited the Moon ten times over the course of twenty hours
column20: during which they made a Christmas Eve television broadcast in which they read the first ten verses from the Book of Genesis. At the time
column21: the broadcast was the most watched TV program ever. Apollo 8's successful mission paved the way for Apollo 11 to fulfill U.S. president John F. Kennedy's goal of landing a man on the Moon before the end of the 1960s. The Apollo 8 astronauts returned to Earth on December 27
column23: when their spacecraft splashed down in the northern Pacific Ocean. The crew members were named Time magazine's ""Men of the Year"" for 1968 upon their return."

column1: 1623 Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson (March 15
column2: 1767 – June 8
column3: 1845) was an American soldier and statesman who served as the seventh president of the United States from 1829 to 1837. Before being elected to the presidency
column4: Jackson gained fame as a general in the United States Army and served in both houses of Congress. As president
column5: Jackson sought to advance the rights of the ""common man"" against a ""corrupt aristocracy"" and to preserve the Union. Born in the colonial Carolinas to a Scotch-Irish family in the decade before the American Revolutionary War
column6: Jackson became a frontier lawyer and married Rachel Donelson Robards. He served briefly in the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate
column7: representing Tennessee. After resigning
column8: he served as a justice on the Tennessee Supreme Court from 1798 until 1804. Jackson purchased a property later known as The Hermitage
column9: and became a wealthy
column10: slaveowning planter. In 1801
column11: he was appointed colonel of the Tennessee militia and was elected its commander the following year. He led troops during the Creek War of 1813–1814
column12: winning the Battle of Horseshoe Bend. The subsequent Treaty of Fort Jackson required the Creek surrender of vast lands in present-day Alabama and Georgia. In the concurrent war against the British
column13: Jackson's victory in 1815 at the Battle of New Orleans made him a national hero. Jackson then led U.S. forces in the First Seminole War
column14: which led to the annexation of Florida from Spain. Jackson briefly served as Florida's first territorial governor before returning to the Senate. He ran for president in 1824
column15: winning a plurality of the popular and electoral vote. As no candidate won an electoral majority
column16: the House of Representatives elected John Quincy Adams in a contingent election. In reaction to the alleged ""corrupt bargain"" between Adams and Henry Clay and the ambitious agenda of President Adams
column17: Jackson's supporters founded the Democratic Party. Jackson ran again in 1828
column18: defeating Adams in a landslide. Jackson faced the threat of secession by South Carolina over what opponents called the ""Tariff of Abominations."" The crisis was defused when the tariff was amended
column19: and Jackson threatened the use of military force if South Carolina attempted to secede. In Congress
column20: Henry Clay led the effort to reauthorize the Second Bank of the United States. Jackson
column21: regarding the Bank as a corrupt institution
column22: vetoed the renewal of its charter. After a lengthy struggle
column23: Jackson and his allies thoroughly dismantled the Bank. In 1835
column24: Jackson became the only president to completely pay off the national debt
column25: fulfilling a longtime goal. His presidency marked the beginning of the ascendancy of the party ""spoils system"" in American politics. In 1830
column26: Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act
column27: which forcibly relocated most members of the Native American tribes in the South to Indian Territory. The relocation process dispossessed the Indians and resulted in widespread death and disease. Jackson opposed the abolitionist movement
column28: which grew stronger in his second term. In foreign affairs
column29: Jackson's administration concluded a ""most favored nation"" treaty with Great Britain
column30: settled claims of damages against France from the Napoleonic Wars
column31: and recognized the Republic of Texas. In January 1835
column32: he survived the first assassination attempt on a sitting president. In his retirement
column33: Jackson remained active in Democratic Party politics
column34: supporting the presidencies of Martin Van Buren and James K. Polk. Though fearful of its effects on the slavery debate
column35: Jackson advocated the annexation of Texas
column36: which was accomplished shortly before his death. Jackson has been widely revered in the United States as an advocate for democracy and the common man. Many of his actions proved divisive
column37: garnering both fervent support and strong opposition from many in the country. His reputation has suffered since the 1970s
column38: largely due to his role in Native American removal. Surveys of historians and scholars have ranked Jackson favorably among U.S. presidents."

column1: 3747 Bill_Gates "William Henry Gates III  (born October 28
column2: 1955) is an American business magnate
column3: software developer
column4: and philanthropist. He is best known as the co-founder of Microsoft Corporation. During his career at Microsoft
column5: Gates held the positions of chairman
column6: chief executive officer (CEO) and chief software architect
column7: while also being the largest individual shareholder until May 2014. He is one of the best-known entrepreneurs and pioneers of the microcomputer revolution of the 1970s and 1980s. Born and raised in Seattle
column8: Washington
column9: Gates launched Microsoft with childhood friend Paul Allen in 1975 in Albuquerque
column10: New Mexico; it went on to become the world's largest personal computer software company. Gates led the company as chairman and CEO until stepping down as CEO in January 2000
column11: but he remained chairman and became chief software architect. In June 2006
column12: Gates announced that he would be transitioning to a part-time role at Microsoft and full-time work at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
column13: the private charitable foundation that he and his wife
column14: Melinda Gates
column15: established in 2000. He gradually transferred his duties to Ray Ozzie and Craig Mundie. He stepped down as chairman of Microsoft in February 2014 and assumed a new post as technology adviser to support the newly appointed CEO Satya Nadella.Gates has been criticized for his business tactics
column16: which have been considered anti-competitive. This opinion has been upheld by numerous court rulings.Since 1987
column17: he has been included in the Forbes list of the world's wealthiest documented individuals. From 1995 to 2017
column18: he held the Forbes title of the richest person in the world all but four of those years. In 2017 he was surpassed by Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos
column19: who had an estimated net worth of US$90.6 billion. As of November 9
column21: Gates had a net worth of $107.1 billion
column22: still ranked second. Later in his career and since leaving day-to-day operations at Microsoft in 2008
column23: Gates pursued a number of philanthropic endeavors. He donated large amounts of money to various charitable organizations and scientific research programs through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
column24: reported to be the world's largest private charity. In 2009
column25: Gates and Warren Buffett founded The Giving Pledge
column26: whereby they and other billionaires pledge to give at least half of their wealth to philanthropy. The foundation works to save lives and improve global health
column27: and is working with Rotary International to eliminate polio."

column1: 4035 Black "Black is the darkest color
column2: the result of the absence or complete absorption of visible light. It is an achromatic color
column3: a color without hue
column4: like white and gray. It is often used symbolically or figuratively to represent darkness
column5: while white represents light. Black and white have often been used to describe opposites such as good and evil
column6: the Dark Ages versus Age of Enlightenment
column7: and night versus day. Since the Middle Ages
column8: black has been the symbolic color of solemnity and authority
column9: and for this reason is still commonly worn by judges and magistrates
column10: including the justices of the U.S. Supreme Court.Black was one of the first colors used by artists in neolithic cave paintings. In the 14th century
column11: it was worn by royalty
column12: clergy
column13: judges and government officials in much of Europe. It became the color worn by English romantic poets
column14: businessmen and statesmen in the 19th century
column15: and a high fashion color in the 20th century. In the Roman Empire
column16: it became the color of mourning
column17: and over the centuries it was frequently associated with death
column18: evil
column19: witches and magic. According to surveys in Europe and North America
column20: it is the color most commonly associated with mourning
column21: the end
column22: secrets
column23: magic
column24: force
column25: violence
column26: evil
column27: and elegance.Black ink is the most common color used for printing books
column28: newspapers and documents
column29: as it provides the highest contrast with white paper and thus the easiest color to read. Similarly
column30: black text on a white screen is the most common format used on computer screens."

column1: 4543 Blue "Blue is one of the three primary colours of pigments in painting and traditional colour theory
column2: as well as in the RGB colour model. It lies between violet and green on the spectrum of visible light. The eye perceives blue when observing light with a dominant wavelength between approximately 450 and 495 nanometres. Most blues contain a slight mixture of other colours; azure contains some green
column3: while ultramarine contains some violet. The clear daytime sky and the deep sea appear blue because of an optical effect known as Rayleigh scattering. An optical effect called Tyndall scattering explains blue eyes. Distant objects appear more blue because of another optical effect called aerial perspective. Blue has been an important colour in art and decoration since ancient times. The semi-precious stone lapis lazuli was used in ancient Egypt for jewellery and ornament and later
column4: in the Renaissance
column5: to make the pigment ultramarine
column6: the most expensive of all pigments. In the eighth century Chinese artists used cobalt blue to colour fine blue and white porcelain. In the Middle Ages
column7: European artists used it in the windows of cathedrals. Europeans wore clothing coloured with the vegetable dye woad until it was replaced by the finer indigo from America. In the 19th century
column8: synthetic blue dyes and pigments gradually replaced mineral pigments and synthetic dyes. Dark blue became a common colour for military uniforms and later
column9: in the late 20th century
column10: for business suits. Because blue has commonly been associated with harmony
column11: it was chosen as the colour of the flags of the United Nations and the European Union.Surveys in the US and Europe show that blue is the colour most commonly associated with harmony
column12: faithfulness
column13: confidence
column14: distance
column15: infinity
column16: the imagination
column17: cold
column18: and sometimes with sadness. In US and European public opinion polls it is the most popular colour
column19: chosen by almost half of both men and women as their favourite colour. The same surveys also showed that blue was the colour most associated with the masculine
column20: just ahead of black
column21: and was also the colour most associated with intelligence
column22: knowledge
column23: calm and concentration."

column1: 4792 Barry_Goldwater "Barry Morris Goldwater (January 2
column3: 1998) was an American politician
column4: businessman
column5: and author who was a five-term Senator from Arizona (1953–1965
column6: 1969–1987) and the Republican Party nominee for president of the United States in 1964. Despite his loss of the 1964 presidential election in a landslide
column7: Goldwater is the politician most often credited with having sparked the resurgence of the American conservative political movement in the 1960s. He also had a substantial impact on the libertarian movement.Goldwater rejected the legacy of the New Deal and fought with the conservative coalition against the New Deal coalition. Although he had supported earlier civil rights legislation
column8: he notably opposed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as he believed it to be an overreach by the federal government. In 1964
column9: Goldwater mobilized a large conservative constituency to win the hard-fought Republican presidential primaries. Although raised as an Episcopalian
column10: Goldwater was the first candidate of ethnically Jewish heritage to be nominated for President by a major American party (his father was Jewish). Goldwater's platform ultimately failed to gain the support of the electorate and he lost the 1964 presidential election to incumbent Democrat Lyndon B. Johnson.  Goldwater returned to the Senate in 1969 and specialized in defense and foreign policy. As an elder statesman of the party
column11: Goldwater successfully urged President Richard Nixon to resign in 1974 when evidence of a cover-up in the Watergate scandal became overwhelming and impeachment was imminent. Goldwater's views grew more libertarian as he reached the end of his career; he retired from the Senate in 1987. A significant accomplishment of his career was the passage of the Goldwater–Nichols Act of 1986. He was succeeded by John McCain
column12: who praised his predecessor as the man who ""transformed the Republican Party from an Eastern elitist organization to the breeding ground for the election of Ronald Reagan."" Goldwater strongly supported the 1980 presidential campaign of Reagan
column13: who had become the standard-bearer of the conservative movement after his ""A Time for Choosing"" speech. Reagan reflected many of the principles of Goldwater's earlier run in his campaign. The Washington Post columnist George Will took note of this
column14: writing: ""We [...] who voted for him in 1964 believe he won
column15: it just took 16 years to count the votes."" After leaving the Senate
column16: Goldwater's views cemented as libertarian. He criticized the ""moneymaking ventures by fellows like Pat Robertson and others [in the Republican Party] who are trying to...make a religious organization out of it."" He lobbied for homosexuals to be able to serve openly in the military
column17: opposed the Clinton administration's plan for health care reform
column18: and supported abortion rights and the legalization of medicinal marijuana. In 1997
column19: Goldwater was revealed to be in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. He died one year later at the age of 89."

column1: 6102 Cyan "Cyan (
column2: ) is a greenish-blue color. It is evoked by light with a predominant wavelength of between 490–520 nm
column3: between the wavelengths of green and blue.In the subtractive color system
column4: or CMYK (subtractive)
column5: which can be overlaid to produce all colors in paint and color printing
column6: cyan is one of the primary colors
column7: along with magenta
column8: yellow
column9: and black. In the additive color system
column10: or RGB (additive) color model
column11: used to create all the colors on a computer or television display
column12: cyan is made by mixing equal amounts of green and blue light. Cyan is the complement of red; it can be made by the removal of red from white light. Mixing red light and cyan light at the right intensity will make white light. The web color cyan is synonymous with aqua.   Other colors in the cyan color range are teal
column13: turquoise
column14: electric blue
column15: aquamarine
column16: and others described as blue-green."

column1: 6195 Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge (born John Calvin Coolidge Jr.; ; July 4
column2: 1872 – January 5
column3: 1933) was an American politician and lawyer who served as the 30th president of the United States from 1923 to 1929. A Republican lawyer from New England
column4: born in Vermont
column5: Coolidge worked his way up the ladder of Massachusetts state politics
column6: eventually becoming governor. His response to the Boston Police Strike of 1919 thrust him into the national spotlight and gave him a reputation as a man of decisive action. The next year
column7: he was elected vice president of the United States
column8: and he succeeded to the presidency upon the sudden death of Warren G. Harding in 1923. Elected in his own right in 1924
column9: he gained a reputation as a small government conservative and also as a man who said very little and had a rather dry sense of humor.Coolidge restored public confidence in the White House after the scandals of his predecessor's administration
column10: and left office with considerable popularity. As a Coolidge biographer wrote: ""He embodied the spirit and hopes of the middle class
column11: could interpret their longings and express their opinions. That he did represent the genius of the average is the most convincing proof of his strength"".Scholars have ranked Coolidge in the lower half of those presidents that they have assessed. He is praised by advocates of smaller government and laissez-faire economics
column12: while supporters of an active central government generally view him less favorably
column13: though most praise his stalwart support of racial equality."

column1: 6310 Columbia_University "Columbia University (also known as Columbia
column2: and officially as Columbia University in the City of New York) is a private Ivy League research university in New York City. Established in 1754 on the grounds of Trinity Church in Manhattan
column3: Columbia is the oldest institution of higher education in New York and the fifth-oldest institution of higher learning in the United States. It is one of nine colonial colleges founded prior to the Declaration of Independence
column4: seven of which belong to the Ivy League. It has been ranked by numerous major education publications as among the top ten universities in the world.Columbia was established as King's College by royal charter of George II of Great Britain in reaction to the founding of Princeton University in New Jersey. It was renamed Columbia College in 1784 following the American Revolution
column5: and in 1787 was placed under a private board of trustees headed by former students Alexander Hamilton and John Jay. In 1896
column6: the campus was moved to its current location in Morningside Heights and renamed Columbia University.Columbia scientists and scholars have played an important role in the development of notable scientific fields and breakthroughs including: brain-computer interface; the laser and maser; nuclear magnetic resonance; the first nuclear pile; the first nuclear fission reaction in the Americas; Thomas Hunt Morgan's drosophila experiment – considered the origin of modern genetics; the first evidence for plate tectonics and continental drift; and much of the initial research and planning of the Manhattan Project during World War II. The Columbia University Physics Department has been affiliated with 33 Nobel Prize winners as alumni
column7: faculty or research staff
column8: the third most of any American institution behind MIT and Harvard. In addition
column9: 22 Nobel Prize winners in Physiology or Medicine have been affiliated with Columbia
column10: the third most of any American institution. The university's research efforts include the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory
column11: Goddard Institute for Space Studies and accelerator laboratories with major technology firms such as IBM. Columbia is one of the fourteen founding members of the Association of American Universities and was the first school in the United States to grant the M.D. degree. The university administers the Pulitzer Prize annually. Columbia is organized into twenty schools
column12: including three undergraduate schools and numerous graduate schools. It maintains research centers outside of the United States known as Columbia Global Centers. In 2019
column13: Columbia's undergraduate acceptance rate was 5.1%
column14: making it one of the most selective colleges in the United States
column15: and the second most selective in the Ivy League after Harvard. Columbia is ranked as the 3rd best university in the United States by U.S. News & World Report behind Princeton and Harvard. In athletics
column16: the Lions field varsity teams in 29 sports as a member of the NCAA Division I Ivy League conference. The university's endowment stood at $10.9 billion in 2018
column17: among the largest of any academic institution. As of 2018
column18: Columbia's alumni and affiliates include: five Founding Fathers of the United States — among them an author of the United States Constitution and a co-author of the Declaration of Independence; three U.S. presidents; 29 foreign heads of state; ten Justices of the United States Supreme Court
column19: two of whom currently serve; 96 Nobel laureates; 101 National Academy members; 53 living billionaires; eleven Olympic medalists; 39 Academy Award winners; and 125 Pulitzer Prize recipients."

column1: 7164 Color_temperature "Not to be confused with warm and cool colors. The color temperature of a light source is the temperature of an ideal black-body radiator that radiates light of a color comparable to that of the light source. Color temperature is a characteristic of visible light that has important applications in lighting
column2: photography
column3: videography
column4: publishing
column5: manufacturing
column6: astrophysics
column7: horticulture
column8: and other fields. In practice
column9: color temperature is meaningful only for light sources that do in fact correspond somewhat closely to the radiation of some black body
column10: i.e.
column11: light in a range going from red to orange to yellow to white to blueish white; it does not make sense to speak of the color temperature of
column12: e.g.
column13: a green or a purple light. Color temperature is conventionally expressed in kelvins
column14: using the symbol K
column15: a unit of measure for absolute temperature. Color temperatures over 5000 K are called ""cool colors"" (bluish)
column16: while lower color temperatures (2700–3000 K) are called ""warm colors"" (yellowish). ""Warm"" in this context is an analogy to radiated heat flux of traditional incandescent lighting rather than temperature. The spectral peak of warm-coloured light is closer to infrared
column17: and most natural warm-coloured light sources emit significant infrared radiation. The fact that ""warm"" lighting in this sense actually has a ""cooler"" color temperature often leads to confusion."

column1: 7376 Cosmic_microwave_background "The cosmic microwave background (CMB
column2: CMBR)
column3: in Big Bang cosmology
column4: is electromagnetic radiation as a remnant from an early stage of the universe
column5: also known as ""relic radiation"". The CMB is faint cosmic background radiation filling all space. It is an important source of data on the early universe because it is the oldest electromagnetic radiation in the universe
column6: dating to the epoch of recombination. With a traditional optical telescope
column7: the space between stars and galaxies (the background) is completely dark. However
column8: a sufficiently sensitive radio telescope shows a faint background noise
column9: or glow
column10: almost isotropic
column11: that is not associated with any star
column12: galaxy
column13: or other object. This glow is strongest in the microwave region of the radio spectrum. The accidental discovery of the CMB in 1964 by American radio astronomers Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson was the culmination of work initiated in the 1940s
column14: and earned the discoverers the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physics. CMB is landmark evidence of the Big Bang origin of the universe. When the universe was young
column15: before the formation of stars and planets
column16: it was denser
column17: much hotter
column18: and filled with a uniform glow from a white-hot fog of hydrogen plasma. As the universe expanded
column19: both the plasma and the radiation filling it grew cooler. When the universe cooled enough
column20: protons and electrons combined to form neutral hydrogen atoms. Unlike the uncombined protons and electrons
column21: these newly conceived atoms could not scatter the thermal radiation by Thomson scattering
column22: and so the universe became transparent instead of being an opaque fog. Cosmologists refer to the time period when neutral atoms first formed as the recombination epoch
column23: and the event shortly afterwards when photons started to travel freely through space rather than constantly being scattered by electrons and protons in plasma is referred to as photon decoupling. The photons that existed at the time of photon decoupling have been propagating ever since
column24: though growing fainter and less energetic
column25: since the expansion of space causes their wavelength to increase over time (and wavelength is inversely proportional to energy according to Planck's relation). This is the source of the alternative term relic radiation. The surface of last scattering refers to the set of points in space at the right distance from us so that we are now receiving photons originally emitted from those points at the time of photon decoupling."

column1: 7397 Color_blindness "Color blindness
column2: also known as color vision deficiency
column3: is the decreased ability to see color or differences in color. Simple tasks such as selecting ripe fruit
column4: choosing clothing
column5: and reading traffic lights can be more challenging. Color blindness may also make some educational activities more difficult. However
column6: problems are generally minor
column7: and most people find that they can adapt. People with total color blindness (achromatopsia) may also have decreased visual acuity and be uncomfortable in bright environments.The most common cause of color blindness is an inherited problem in the development of one or more of the three sets of color-sensing cones in the eye. Males are more likely to be color blind than females
column8: as the genes responsible for the most common forms of color blindness are on the X chromosome. As females have two X chromosomes
column9: a defect in one is typically compensated for by the other
column10: therefore females can be carriers. Males only have one X chromosome and therefore express the genetic disorder. Color blindness can also result from physical or chemical damage to the eye
column11: optic nerve or parts of the brain. Diagnosis is typically with the Ishihara color test; however
column12: a number of other testing methods
column13: including genetic testing
column14: also exist.There is no cure for color blindness. Diagnosis may allow a person's teacher to change their method of teaching to accommodate the decreased ability to recognize colors. Special lenses may help people with red–green color blindness when under bright conditions. There are also mobile apps that can help people identify colors.Red–green color blindness is the most common form
column15: followed by blue–yellow color blindness and total color blindness. Red–green color blindness affects up to 8% of males and 0.5% of females of Northern European descent. The ability to see color also decreases in old age. Being color blind may make people ineligible for certain jobs in certain countries. This may include being a pilot
column16: train driver
column17: crane operator
column18: and working in the armed forces. The effect of color blindness on artistic ability
column19: however
column20: is controversial. The ability to draw appears to be unchanged
column21: and a number of famous artists are believed to have been color blind."

column1: 8182 Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight David ""Ike"" Eisenhower ( EYE-zən-how-ər; October 14
column2: 1890 – March 28
column3: 1969) was an American army general and statesman who served as the 34th president of the United States from 1953 to 1961. During World War II
column4: he was a five-star general in the Army and served as Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force in Europe. He was responsible for planning and supervising the invasion of North Africa in Operation Torch in 1942–43 and the successful Invasion of Normandy in 1944–45 from the Western Front. Eisenhower was born David Dwight Eisenhower in Denison
column5: Texas
column6: and he was raised in Kansas in a large family of mostly Pennsylvania Dutch ancestry. His family had a strong religious background. His mother was a Lutheran
column7: married as a River Brethren
column8: and later became a Jehovah's Witness. Eisenhower
column9: however
column10: did not belong to any organized church until 1952. He cited constant relocation during his military career as one reason. He graduated from West Point in 1915 and later married Mamie Doud
column11: with whom he had two sons. During World War I
column12: he was denied a request to serve in Europe and instead commanded a unit that trained tank crews. Following the war
column13: he served under various generals and was promoted to the rank of brigadier general in 1941. After the United States entered World War II
column14: Eisenhower oversaw the invasions of North Africa and Sicily before supervising the invasions of France and Germany. After the war
column15: he served as Army Chief of Staff (1945–1948) and then took on the role as president of Columbia University (1948–1953). In 1951–52
column16: he served as the first Supreme Commander of NATO. In 1952
column17: Eisenhower entered the presidential race as a Republican to block the isolationist foreign policies of Senator Robert A. Taft
column18: who opposed NATO and wanted no foreign entanglements. He won that election and the 1956 election in landslides
column19: both times defeating Adlai Stevenson II. He became the first Republican to win since Herbert Hoover in 1928. Eisenhower's main goals in office were to contain the spread of communism and reduce federal deficits. In 1953
column20: he threatened to use nuclear weapons until China agreed to peace terms in the Korean War. China did agree and an armistice resulted which remains in effect. His New Look policy of nuclear deterrence prioritized inexpensive nuclear weapons while reducing funding for expensive Army divisions. He continued Harry S. Truman's policy of recognizing Taiwan as the legitimate government of China
column21: and he won congressional approval of the Formosa Resolution. His administration provided major aid to help the French fight off Vietnamese Communists in the First Indochina War. After the French left
column22: he gave strong financial support to the new state of South Vietnam. He supported military coups in Iran and Guatemala. During the Suez Crisis of 1956
column23: he condemned the Israeli
column24: British
column25: and French invasion of Egypt
column26: and he forced them to withdraw. He also condemned the Soviet invasion during the Hungarian Revolution of 1956 but took no action. During the Syrian Crisis of 1957 he approved a CIA-MI6 plan to stage fake border incidents as an excuse for an invasion by Syria's pro-Western neighbors. After the Soviet Union launched Sputnik in 1957
column27: Eisenhower authorized the establishment of NASA
column28: which led to the Space Race. He deployed 15
column29: 000 soldiers during the 1958 Lebanon crisis. Near the end of his term
column30: he failed to set up a summit meeting with the Soviets when a U.S. spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union. He approved the Bay of Pigs invasion
column31: which was left to John F. Kennedy to carry out.On the domestic front
column32: Eisenhower was a moderate conservative who continued New Deal agencies and expanded Social Security. He covertly opposed Joseph McCarthy and contributed to the end of McCarthyism by openly invoking executive privilege. He signed the Civil Rights Act of 1957 and sent Army troops to enforce federal court orders which integrated schools in Little Rock
column33: Arkansas. His largest program was the Interstate Highway System. He promoted the establishment of strong science education via the National Defense Education Act. His two terms saw widespread economic prosperity except for a minor recession in 1958. In his farewell address to the nation
column34: he expressed his concerns about the dangers of massive military spending
column35: particularly deficit spending and government contracts to private military manufacturers. Historical evaluations of his presidency place him among the upper tier of American presidents."

column1: 9334 Ecuador "Ecuador ( (listen) EK-wə-dor; Spanish pronunciation: [ekwaˈðoɾ] (listen); Quechua: Ikwayur; Shuar: Ecuador or Ekuatur)
column2: officially the Republic of Ecuador (Spanish: República del Ecuador
column3: which literally translates as ""Republic of the Equator""; Quechua: Ikwadur Ripuwlika; Shuar: Ekuatur Nunka)
column4: is a country in northwestern South America
column5: bordered by Colombia on the north
column6: Peru on the east and south
column7: and the Pacific Ocean on the west. Ecuador also includes the Galápagos Islands in the Pacific
column8: about 1
column9: 000 kilometres (620 mi) west of the mainland. The capital city is Quito
column10: which is also its largest city.The territories of modern-day Ecuador were once home to a variety of Amerindian groups that were gradually incorporated into the Inca Empire during the 15th century. The territory was colonized by Spain during the 16th century
column11: achieving independence in 1820 as part of Gran Colombia
column12: from which it emerged as its own sovereign state in 1830. The legacy of both empires is reflected in Ecuador's ethnically diverse population
column13: with most of its 17.1 million people being mestizos
column14: followed by large minorities of European
column15: Amerindian
column16: and African descendants. Spanish is the official language and is spoken by a majority of the population
column17: though 13 Amerindian languages are also recognized
column18: including Quichua and Shuar. The sovereign state of Ecuador is a middle-income representative democratic republic with a developing economy that is highly dependent on commodities
column19: namely petroleum and agricultural products. It is governed as a democratic presidential republic. One of 18 megadiverse countries in the world
column20: Ecuador hosts many endemic plants and animals
column21: such as those of the Galápagos Islands. In recognition of its unique ecological heritage
column22: the new constitution of 2008 is the first in the world to recognize legally enforceable Rights of Nature
column23: or ecosystem rights. It also has the fifth lowest homicide rate in the Americas. Between 2006 and 2016
column24: poverty decreased from 36.7% to 22.5% and annual per capita GDP growth was 1.5 percent (as compared to 0.6 percent over the prior two decades). At the same time
column25: inequalities
column26: as measured by the Gini index
column27: decreased from 0.55 to 0.47."

column1: 12460 Green "Green is the color between blue and yellow on the visible spectrum. It is evoked by light which has a dominant wavelength of roughly 495–570 nm. In subtractive color systems
column2: used in painting and color printing
column3: it is created by a combination of yellow and blue
column4: or yellow and cyan; in the RGB color model
column5: used on television and computer screens
column6: it is one of the additive primary colors
column7: along with red and blue
column8: which are mixed in different combinations to create all other colors. By far the largest contributor to green in nature is chlorophyll
column9: the chemical by which plants photosynthesize and convert sunlight into chemical energy. Many creatures have adapted to their green environments by taking on a green hue themselves as camouflage. Several minerals have a green color
column10: including the emerald
column11: which is colored green by its chromium content. During post-classical and early modern Europe
column12: green was the color commonly associated with wealth
column13: merchants
column14: bankers and the gentry
column15: while red was reserved for the nobility. For this reason
column16: the costume of the Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci and the benches in the British House of Commons are green while those in the House of Lords are red. It also has a long historical tradition as the color of Ireland and of Gaelic culture. It is the historic color of Islam
column17: representing the lush vegetation of Paradise. It was the color of the banner of Muhammad
column18: and is found in the flags of nearly all Islamic countries.In surveys made in American
column19: European
column20: and Islamic countries
column21: green is the color most commonly associated with nature
column22: life
column23: health
column24: youth
column25: spring
column26: hope
column27: and envy. In the European Union and the United States
column28: green is also sometimes associated with toxicity and poor health
column29: but in China and most of Asia
column30: its associations are very positive
column31: as the symbol of fertility and happiness. Because of its association with nature
column32: it is the color of the environmental movement. Political groups advocating environmental protection and social justice describe themselves as part of the Green movement
column33: some naming themselves Green parties. This has led to similar campaigns in advertising
column34: as companies have sold green
column35: or environmentally friendly
column36: products. Green is also the traditional color of safety and permission; a green light means go ahead
column37: a green card permits permanent residence in the United States."

column1: 14919 International_Standard_Book_Number "The International Standard Book Number (ISBN) is a numeric commercial book identifier which is intended to be unique. Publishers purchase ISBNs from an affiliate of the International ISBN Agency.An ISBN is assigned to each separate edition and variation (except reprintings) of a publication. For example
column2: an e-book
column3: a paperback and a hardcover edition of the same book will each have a different ISBN. The ISBN is ten digits long if assigned before 2007
column4: and thirteen digits long if assigned on or after 1 January 2007. The method of assigning an ISBN is nation-specific and varies between countries
