column5: often depending on how large the publishing industry is within a country. The initial ISBN identification format was devised in 1967
column6: based upon the 9-digit Standard Book Numbering (SBN) created in 1966. The 10-digit ISBN format was developed by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and was published in 1970 as international standard ISO 2108 (the 9-digit SBN code can be converted to a 10-digit ISBN by prefixing it with a zero digit '0'). Privately published books sometimes appear without an ISBN. The International ISBN Agency sometimes assigns such books ISBNs on its own initiative.Another identifier
column7: the International Standard Serial Number (ISSN)
column8: identifies periodical publications such as magazines and newspapers. The International Standard Music Number (ISMN) covers musical scores."

column1: 15654 John_Quincy_Adams "John Quincy Adams ( (listen); July 11
column2: 1767 – February 23
column3: 1848) was an American statesman
column4: diplomat
column5: lawyer
column6: and diarist who served as the sixth president of the United States from 1825 to 1829. He previously served as the eighth United States Secretary of State from 1817 to 1825. During his long diplomatic and political career
column7: Adams also served as an ambassador
column8: and represented Massachusetts as a United States Senator and as a member of the United States House of Representatives. He was the eldest son of John Adams
column9: who served as the second US president from 1797 to 1801
column10: and First Lady Abigail Adams. Initially a Federalist like his father
column11: he won election to the presidency as a member of the Democratic-Republican Party
column12: and in the mid-1830s became affiliated with the Whig Party. Born in Braintree
column13: Massachusetts
column14: Adams spent much of his youth in Europe
column15: where his father served as a diplomat. After returning to the United States
column16: Adams established a successful legal practice in Boston. In 1794
column17: President George Washington appointed Adams as the U.S. ambassador to the Netherlands
column18: and Adams would serve in high-ranking diplomatic posts until 1801
column19: when Thomas Jefferson took office as president. Federalist leaders in Massachusetts arranged for Adams's election to the United States Senate in 1802
column20: but Adams broke with the Federalist Party over foreign policy and was denied re-election. In 1809
column21: Adams was appointed as the U.S. ambassador to Russia by President James Madison
column22: a member of the Democratic-Republican Party. Adams held diplomatic posts for the duration of Madison's presidency
column23: and he served as part of the American delegation that negotiated an end to the War of 1812. In 1817
column24: newly-elected President James Monroe selected Adams as his Secretary of State. In that role
column25: Adams negotiated the Adams–Onís Treaty
column26: which provided for the American acquisition of Florida. He also helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine
column27: which became a key tenet of U.S. foreign policy. The 1824 presidential election was contested by Adams
column28: Andrew Jackson
column29: William H. Crawford
column30: and Henry Clay
column31: all of whom were members of the Democratic-Republican Party. As no candidate won a majority of the electoral vote
column32: the House of Representatives held a contingent election to determine the president
column33: and Adams won that contingent election with the support of Clay. As president
column34: Adams called for an ambitious agenda that included federally-funded infrastructure projects
column35: the establishment of a national university
column36: and engagement with the countries of Latin America
column37: but many of his initiatives were defeated in Congress. During Adams's presidency
column38: the Democratic-Republican Party polarized into two major camps: one group
column39: known as the National Republican Party
column40: supported President Adams
column42: known as the Democratic Party
column43: was led by Andrew Jackson. The Democrats proved to be more effective political organizers than Adams and his National Republican supporters
column44: and Jackson decisively defeated Adams in the 1828 presidential election. Rather than retiring from public service
column45: Adams won election to the House of Representatives
column46: where he would serve from 1831 to his death in 1848. He joined the Anti-Masonic Party in the early 1830s before becoming a member of the Whig Party
column47: which united those opposed to President Jackson. During his time in Congress
column48: Adams became increasingly critical of slavery and of the Southern leaders whom he believed controlled the Democratic Party. He was particularly opposed to the annexation of Texas and the Mexican–American War
column49: which he saw as a war to extend slavery. He also led the repeal of the ""gag rule
column50: which had prevented the House of Representatives from debating petitions to abolish slavery. Historians generally concur that Adams was one of the greatest diplomats and secretaries of state in American history
column51: but they tend to rank him as an above-average president."

column1: 15980 James_K._Polk "James Knox Polk (November 2
column3: 1849) was the 11th president of the United States
column4: serving from 1845 to 1849. He previously was Speaker of the House of Representatives (1835–1839) and governor of Tennessee (1839–1841). A protégé of Andrew Jackson
column5: he was a member of the Democratic Party and an advocate of Jacksonian democracy. Polk is chiefly known for extending the territory of the United States during the Mexican–American War; during his presidency
column6: the United States expanded significantly with the annexation of the Republic of Texas
column7: the Oregon Territory
column8: and the Mexican Cession following the American victory in the Mexican–American War. After building a successful law practice in Tennessee
column9: Polk was elected to the state legislature (1823) and then to the United States House of Representatives in 1825
column10: becoming a strong supporter of Andrew Jackson. After serving as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee
column11: he became Speaker in 1835
column12: the only president to have been Speaker. Polk left Congress to run for governor; he won in 1839
column13: but lost in 1841 and 1843. He was a dark horse candidate for the Democratic nomination for president in 1844; he entered his party's convention as a potential nominee for vice president
column14: but emerged as a compromise to head the ticket when no presidential candidate could secure the necessary two-thirds majority. In the general election
column15: Polk defeated Henry Clay of the rival Whig Party. Historians consider Polk the most effective president of the pre–Civil War era
column16: having met during his four-year term every major domestic and foreign policy goal he had set. After a negotiation fraught with risk of war
column17: he reached a settlement with Great Britain over the disputed Oregon Country
column18: the territory for the most part being divided along the 49th parallel. Polk achieved a sweeping victory in the Mexican–American War
column19: which resulted in the cession by Mexico of nearly all the American Southwest. He secured a substantial reduction of tariff rates with the Walker tariff of 1846. The same year
column20: he achieved his other major goal
column21: re-establishment of the Independent Treasury system. Historian Thomas A. Bailey says that during the Mexican war
column22: ""Polk was an energetic and indefatigable war leader
column23: and he emerged
column24: partly through rare good luck
column25: with uninterrupted success. He kept the sole direction of the war in his own hands
column26: from grand strategy to the procurement of mules.""  True to his campaign pledge to serve only one term
column27: Polk left office in 1849 and returned to Tennessee where he died three months after leaving the White House. Though he is relatively obscure today
column28: scholars have ranked Polk favorably for his ability to promote and achieve the major items on his presidential agenda. However
column29: he has also been criticized for leading the country into an unnecessary war against Mexico and for exacerbating sectional divides. A slaveholder for most of his adult life
column30: he owned a plantation in Mississippi and bought slaves while president. A major legacy of Polk's presidency is territorial expansion
column31: as the United States reached the Pacific coast and became poised to be a world power.  "

column1: 16044 J._Edgar_Hoover "John Edgar Hoover (January 1
column3: 1972) was the first Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) of the United States and an American law enforcement administrator. He was appointed as the director of the Bureau of Investigation – the FBI's predecessor – in 1924 and was instrumental in founding the FBI in 1935
column4: where he remained director for another 37 years until his death in 1972 at the age of 77. Hoover has been credited with building the FBI into a larger crime-fighting agency than it was at its inception and with instituting a number of modernizations to police technology
column5: such as a centralized fingerprint file and forensic laboratories. Later in life and after his death
column6: Hoover became a controversial figure as evidence of his secretive abuses of power began to surface. He was found to have exceeded the jurisdiction of the FBI
column7: and to have used the FBI to harass political dissenters and activists
column8: to amass secret files on political leaders
column9: and to collect evidence using illegal methods. Hoover consequently amassed a great deal of power and was in a position to intimidate and threaten others
column10: including sitting presidents of the United States."

column1: 18290 Light-emitting_diode "A light-emitting diode (LED) is a  semiconductor light source that emits light when current flows through it. Electrons in the semiconductor recombine with electron holes
column2: releasing energy in the form of photons. The color of the light (corresponding to the energy of the photons) is determined by the energy required for electrons to cross the band gap of the semiconductor. White light is obtained by using multiple semiconductors or a layer of light-emitting phosphor on the semiconductor device.Appearing as practical electronic components in 1962
column3: the earliest LEDs emitted low-intensity infrared light. Infrared LEDs are used in remote-control circuits
column4: such as those used with a wide variety of consumer electronics. The first visible-light LEDs were of low intensity and limited to red. Modern LEDs are available across the visible
column5: ultraviolet
column6: and infrared wavelengths
column7: with high light output. Early LEDs were often used as indicator lamps
column8: replacing small incandescent bulbs
column9: and in seven-segment displays. Recent developments have produced high-output white light LEDs suitable for room and outdoor area lighting. LEDs have led to new displays and sensors
column10: while their high switching rates are useful in advanced communications technology. LEDs have many advantages over incandescent light sources
column11: including lower energy consumption
column12: longer lifetime
column13: improved physical robustness
column14: smaller size
column15: and faster switching. LEDs are used in applications as diverse as aviation lighting
column16: automotive headlamps
column17: advertising
column18: general lighting
column19: traffic signals
column20: camera flashes
column21: lighted wallpaper
column22: plant growing light
column23: and medical devices.Unlike a laser
column24: the light emitted from an LED is neither spectrally coherent nor even highly monochromatic. However its spectrum is sufficiently narrow that it appears to the human eye as a pure (saturated) color. Nor
column25: unlike most lasers
column26: is its radiation spatially coherent
column27: so that it cannot approach the very high brightnesses characteristic of lasers."

column1: 19763 Martin_Van_Buren "Martin Van Buren ( van BEWR-ən; born Maarten Van Buren; December 5
column3: 1862) was an American statesman who served as the eighth president of the United States from 1837 to 1841. He was the first president born after the independence of the United States from the British Empire. A founder of the Democratic Party
column4: he previously served as the ninth governor of New York
column5: the tenth United States secretary of state
column6: and the eighth vice president of the United States. He won the 1836 presidential election with the endorsement of popular outgoing President Andrew Jackson and the organizational strength of the Democratic Party. He lost his 1840 reelection bid to Whig Party nominee William Henry Harrison
column7: due in part to the poor economic conditions of the Panic of 1837. Later in his life
column8: Van Buren emerged as an elder statesman and important anti-slavery leader
column9: who led the Free Soil Party ticket in the 1848 presidential election. Van Buren was born in Kinderhook
column10: New York
column11: to a family of Dutch Americans; his father was a Patriot during the American Revolution. He was raised speaking Dutch and learned English at school
column12: making him the only U.S. president who spoke English as a second language. He trained as a lawyer and quickly became involved in politics as a member of the Democratic-Republican Party. He won election to the New York State Senate and became the leader of the Bucktails
column13: the faction of Democratic-Republicans opposed to Governor DeWitt Clinton. Van Buren established a political machine known as the Albany Regency and in the 1820s emerged as the most influential politician in his home state. He was elected to the United States Senate in 1821 and supported William H. Crawford in the 1824 presidential election. John Quincy Adams won the 1824 election and Van Buren opposed his proposals for federally funded internal improvements and other measures. Van Buren's major political goal was to re-establish a two-party system with partisan differences based on ideology rather than personalities or sectional differences
column14: and he supported Jackson's candidacy against Adams in the 1828 presidential election with this goal in mind. To support Jackson's candidacy
column15: Van Buren ran for Governor of New York; he won
column16: but resigned a few months after assuming the position to accept appointment as U.S. Secretary of State after Jackson took office in March 1829. Van Buren was a key advisor during Jackson's eight years as President of the United States and he built the organizational structure for the coalescing Democratic Party
column17: particularly in New York. He resigned from his position to help resolve the Petticoat affair
column18: then briefly served as the U.S. ambassador to the United Kingdom. At Jackson's behest
column19: the 1832 Democratic National Convention nominated Van Buren for Vice President of the United States
column20: and he took office after the Democratic ticket won the 1832 presidential election. With Jackson's strong support
column21: Van Buren faced little opposition for the presidential nomination at the 1835 Democratic National Convention
column22: and he defeated several Whig opponents in the 1836 presidential election. Van Buren's response to the Panic of 1837 centered on his Independent Treasury system
column23: a plan under which the Federal government of the United States would store its funds in vaults rather than in banks. He also continued Jackson's policy of Indian removal; he maintained peaceful relations with Britain but denied the application to admit Texas to the Union
column24: seeking to avoid heightened sectional tensions. In the 1840 election
column25: the Whigs rallied around Harrison's military record and ridiculed Van Buren as ""Martin Van Ruin""
column26: and a surge of new voters helped turn him out of office. At the opening of the Democratic convention in 1844
column27: Van Buren was the leading candidate for the party's nomination for the presidency. Southern Democrats
column28: however
column29: were angered by his continued opposition to the annexation of Texas
column30: and the party nominated James K. Polk. Van Buren grew increasingly opposed to slavery after he left office
column31: and he agreed to lead a third party ticket in the 1848 presidential election
column32: motivated additionally by intra-party differences at the state and national level. He finished in a distant third nationally
column33: but his presence in the race most likely helped Whig nominee Zachary Taylor defeat Democrat Lewis Cass. Van Buren returned to the Democratic fold after the 1848 election
column34: but he supported Abraham Lincoln's policies during the American Civil War. His health began to fail in 1861
column35: and he died in July 1862
column36: at age 79. He has been generally ranked as an average or below-average U.S. president by historians and political scientists."

column1: 21920 Napalm "Napalm is an incendiary mixture of a gelling agent and a volatile petrochemical (usually gasoline (petrol) or diesel fuel). The title is a portmanteau of the names of two of the constituents of the original thickening and gelling agents: co-precipitated aluminium salts of naphthenic acid and palmitic acid. Napalm B is the more modern version of napalm (utilizing styrene derivatives) and
column2: although distinctly different in its chemical composition
column3: is often referred to simply as ""napalm"".A team led by chemist Louis Fieser originally developed napalm for the  United States Chemical Warfare Service in 1942 in a secret laboratory at Harvard University. Of immediate first interest was its viability as an incendiary device to be used in fire bombing campaigns during World War II and its potential to be coherently projected into a solid stream that would carry for distance (instead of the bloomy fireball of pure gasoline) resulted in widespread adoption in infantry/combat engineer flamethrowers as well. Napalm burns at the same temperature as gasoline
column4: and for a greater duration
column5: as well as being more easily dispersed and sticking tenaciously to its targets; these traits make it extremely effective (and controversial) in the anti-structure and antipersonnel role. It has been widely used in both the air and ground role
column6: with the largest used to date being via air-dropped bombs in World War II (most notably in the gruesomely effective  incendiary attacks on Japanese cities in 1945)
column7: and later close air support roles in Korea and Vietnam. Napalm also has fueled most of the flamethrowers (tank
column8: ship and infantry-based) used since World War II
column9: giving them much greater range
column10: and was used in this role as a common (and feared) weapon of urban combat by both the Axis and the Allies in World War II. Multiple nations (including the United States
column11: China
column12: Russia
column13: Iran and North Korea) maintain large stockpiles of napalm-based weapons of various types."

column1: 22605 Oil_painting "Oil painting is the process of painting with pigments with a medium of drying oil as the binder. Commonly used drying oils include linseed oil
column2: poppy seed oil
column3: walnut oil
column4: and safflower oil. The choice of oil imparts a range of properties to the oil paint
column5: such as the amount of yellowing or drying time. Certain differences
column6: depending on the oil
column7: are also visible in the sheen of the paints. An artist might use several different oils in the same painting depending on specific pigments and effects desired. The paints themselves also develop a particular consistency depending on the medium. The oil may be boiled with a resin
column8: such as pine resin or frankincense
column9: to create a varnish prized for its body and gloss. Although oil paint was first used for Buddhist paintings by painters in central and western Afghanistan sometime between the fifth and tenth centuries
column10: it did not gain popularity until the 15th century. Its practice may have migrated westward during the Middle Ages. Oil paint eventually became the principal medium used for creating artworks as its advantages became widely known. The transition began with Early Netherlandish painting in Northern Europe
column11: and by the height of the Renaissance oil painting techniques had almost completely replaced the use of tempera paints in the majority of Europe. In recent years
column12: water miscible oil paint has become available. Water-soluble paints are either engineered or an emulsifier has been added that allows them to be thinned with water rather than paint thinner
column13: and allows
column14: when sufficiently diluted
column15: very fast drying times (1–3 days) when compared with traditional oils (1–3 weeks)."

column1: 23301 Project_Gutenberg "Project Gutenberg (PG) is a volunteer effort to digitize and archive cultural works
column2: to ""encourage the creation and distribution of eBooks"". It was founded in 1971 by American writer Michael S. Hart and is the oldest digital library. Most of the items in its collection are the full texts of public domain books. The Project tries to make these as free as possible
column3: in long-lasting
column4: open formats that can be used on almost any computer. As of 23 June 2018
column5: Project Gutenberg reached 57
column6: 000 items in its collection of free eBooks.The releases are available in plain text but
column7: wherever possible
column8: other formats are included
column9: such as HTML
column10: PDF
column11: EPUB
column12: MOBI
column13: and Plucker. Most releases are in the English language
column14: but many non-English works are also available. There are multiple affiliated projects that are providing additional content
column15: including regional and language-specific works. Project Gutenberg is also closely affiliated with Distributed Proofreaders
column16: an Internet-based community for proofreading scanned texts."

column1: 23604 Photography "Photography is the art
column2: application and practice of creating durable images by recording light or other electromagnetic radiation
column3: either electronically by means of an image sensor
column4: or chemically by means of a light-sensitive material such as photographic film. It is employed in many fields of science
column5: manufacturing (e.g.
column6: photolithography)
column7: and business
column8: as well as its more direct uses for art
column9: film and video production
column10: recreational purposes
column11: hobby
column12: and mass communication.Typically
column13: a lens is used to focus the light reflected or emitted from objects into a real image on the light-sensitive surface inside a camera during a timed exposure. With an electronic image sensor
column14: this produces an electrical charge at each pixel
column15: which is electronically processed and stored in a digital image file for subsequent display or processing. The result with photographic emulsion is an invisible latent image
column16: which is later chemically ""developed"" into a visible image
column17: either negative or positive depending on the purpose of the photographic material and the method of processing. A negative image on film is traditionally used to photographically create a positive image on a paper base
column18: known as a print
column19: either by using an enlarger or by contact printing."

column1: 25080 Photograph "A photograph (also known as a photo) is an image created by light falling on a photosensitive surface
column2: usually photographic film or an electronic image sensor
column3: such as a CCD or a CMOS chip. Most photographs are created using a camera
column4: which uses a lens to focus the scene's visible wavelengths of light into a reproduction of what the human eye would see. The process and practice of creating such images is called photography. The word photograph was coined in 1839 by Sir John Herschel and is based on the Greek φῶς (phos)
column5: meaning ""light
column6: and γραφή (graphê)
column7: meaning ""drawing
column8: writing
column9: together meaning ""drawing with light."""

column1: 25825 Red "Red is the color at the end of the visible spectrum of light
column2: next to orange and opposite violet. It has a dominant wavelength of approximately 625–740 nanometres. It is a primary color in the RGB color model and the CMYK color model
column3: and is the complementary color of cyan. Reds range from the brilliant yellow-tinged scarlet and vermillion to bluish-red crimson
column4: and vary in shade from the pale red pink to the dark red burgundy. The red sky at sunset results from Rayleigh scattering
column5: while the red color of the Grand Canyon and other geological features is caused by hematite or red ochre
column6: both forms of iron oxide. Iron oxide also gives the red color to the planet Mars. The red color of blood comes from the protein hemoglobin
column7: while ripe strawberries
column8: red apples and reddish autumn leaves are colored by anthocyanins.Red pigment made from ochre was one of the first colors used in prehistoric art. The Ancient Egyptians and Mayans colored their faces red in ceremonies; Roman generals had their bodies colored red to celebrate victories. It was also an important color in China
column9: where it was used to color early pottery and later the gates and walls of palaces. In the Renaissance
column10: the brilliant red costumes for the nobility and wealthy were dyed with kermes and cochineal. The 19th century brought the introduction of the first synthetic red dyes
column11: which replaced the traditional dyes. Red also became the color of revolution; Soviet Russia adopted a red flag following the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917
column12: later followed by China
column13: Vietnam
column14: and other communist countries. Since red is the color of blood
column15: it has historically been associated with sacrifice
column16: danger and courage. Modern surveys in Europe and the United States show red is also the color most commonly associated with heat
column17: activity
column18: passion
column19: sexuality
column20: anger
column21: love and joy. In China
column22: India and many other Asian countries it is the color of symbolizing happiness and good fortune."

column1: 29328 Six-Day_War "The Six-Day War (Hebrew: מִלְחֶמֶת שֵׁשֶׁת הַיָּמִים
column2: Milhemet Sheshet Ha Yamim; Arabic: النكسة
column3: an-Naksah
column4: ""The Setback"" or حرب 1967
column5: Ḥarb 1967
column7: also known as the June War
column8: 1967 Arab–Israeli War
column9: or Third Arab–Israeli War
column10: was fought between 5 and 10 June 1967 by Israel and the neighboring states of Egypt (known at the time as the United Arab Republic)
column11: Jordan
column12: and Syria. Relations between Israel and its neighbours were not fully normalised after the 1948 Arab–Israeli War. In 1956 Israel invaded the Sinai peninsula in Egypt
column13: with one of its objectives being the reopening of the Straits of Tiran that Egypt had blocked to Israeli shipping since 1950. Israel was eventually forced to withdraw
column14: but was guaranteed that the Straits of Tiran would remain open. A United Nations Emergency Force was deployed along the border
column15: but there was no demilitarisation agreement.In the months prior to June 1967
column16: tensions became dangerously heightened. Israel reiterated its post-1956 position that the closure of the Straits of Tiran to Israeli shipping would be a cause for war (a casus belli). In May Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced that the straits would be closed to Israeli vessels and then mobilised its Egyptian forces along its border with Israel. On 5 June
column17: Israel launched what it claimed were a series of preemptive airstrikes against Egyptian airfields. The question of which side caused the war is one of a number of controversies relating to the conflict. The Egyptians were caught by surprise
column18: and nearly the entire Egyptian air force was destroyed with few Israeli losses
column19: giving the Israelis air supremacy. Simultaneously
column20: the Israelis launched a ground offensive into the Gaza Strip and the Sinai
column21: which again caught the Egyptians by surprise. After some initial resistance
column22: Nasser ordered the evacuation of the Sinai. Israeli forces rushed westward in pursuit of the Egyptians
column23: inflicted heavy losses
column24: and conquered the Sinai. Jordan had entered into a defence pact with Egypt a week before the war began; the agreement envisaged that in the event of war Jordan would not take an offensive role but would attempt to tie down Israeli forces to prevent them making territorial gains. About an hour after the Israeli air attack
column25: the Egyptian commander of the Jordanian army was ordered by Cairo to begin attacks on Israel; in the initially confused situation
column26: the Jordanians were told that Egypt had repelled the Israeli air strikes. Egypt and Jordan agreed to a ceasefire on 8 June
column27: and Syria agreed on 9 June; a ceasefire was signed with Israel on 11 June. In the aftermath of the war
column28: Israel had crippled the Egyptian
column29: Syrian and Jordanian militaries
column30: having killed over 20
column31: 000 troops while only losing fewer than 1
column32: 000 of its own. The Israeli success was the result of a well-prepared and enacted strategy
column33: the poor leadership of the Arab states
column34: and their poor military leadership and strategy. Israel seized the Gaza Strip and the Sinai Peninsula from Egypt
column35: the West Bank
column36: including East Jerusalem
column37: from Jordan and the Golan Heights from Syria. Israel's international standing greatly improved in the following years. Its victory humiliated Egypt
column38: Jordan and Syria
column39: leading Nasser to resign in shame; he was later reinstated after protests in Egypt against his resignation. The speed and ease of Israel's victory would later lead to a dangerous overconfidence within the ranks of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
column40: contributing to initial Arab successes in the subsequent 1973 Yom Kippur War
column41: although ultimately Israeli forces were successful and defeated the Arab militaries. The displacement of civilian populations resulting from the war would have long-term consequences
column42: as 300
column43: 000 Palestinians fled the West Bank and about 100
column44: 000 Syrians left the Golan Heights. Across the Arab world
column45: Jewish minority communities fled or were expelled
column46: with refugees going mainly to Israel or Europe."

column1: 29922 Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson (April 13
column2: 1743 – July 4
column3: 1826) was an American statesman
column4: diplomat
column5: lawyer
column6: architect
column7: philosopher
column8: and Founding Father who served as the third president of the United States from 1801 to 1809. Previously
column9: he had served as the second vice president of the United States from 1797 to 1801. The principal author of the Declaration of Independence
column10: Jefferson was a proponent of democracy
column11: republicanism
column12: and individual rights
column13: motivating American colonists to break from the Kingdom of Great Britain and form a new nation; he produced formative documents and decisions at both the state and national level. During the American Revolution
column14: he represented Virginia in the Continental Congress that adopted the Declaration
column15: drafted the law for religious freedom as a Virginia legislator
column16: and served as the second Governor of Virginia from 1779 to 1781
column17: during the American Revolutionary War. He became the United States Minister to France in May 1785
column18: and subsequently the nation's first secretary of state under President George Washington from 1790 to 1793. Jefferson and James Madison organized the Democratic-Republican Party to oppose the Federalist Party during the formation of the First Party System. With Madison
column19: he anonymously wrote the controversial Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions in 1798 and 1799
column20: which sought to strengthen states' rights by nullifying the federal Alien and Sedition Acts. As president
column21: Jefferson pursued the nation's shipping and trade interests against Barbary pirates and aggressive British trade policies. He also organized the Louisiana Purchase
column22: almost doubling the country's territory. As a result of peace negotiations with France
column23: his administration reduced military forces. He was reelected in 1804. Jefferson's second term was beset with difficulties at home
column24: including the trial of former vice president Aaron Burr. American foreign trade was diminished when Jefferson implemented the Embargo Act of 1807
column25: responding to British threats to U.S. shipping. In 1803
column26: Jefferson began a controversial process of Indian tribe removal to the newly organized Louisiana Territory
column27: and he signed the Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves in 1807. After retiring from public office
column28: Jefferson founded the University of Virginia. Jefferson
column29: while primarily a planter
column30: lawyer and politician
column31: mastered many disciplines
column32: which ranged from surveying and mathematics to horticulture and mechanics. He was an architect in the classical tradition. Jefferson's keen interest in religion and philosophy led to his presidency of the American Philosophical Society; he shunned organized religion but was influenced by both Christianity and deism. A philologist
column33: Jefferson knew several languages. He was a prolific letter writer and corresponded with many prominent people. His only full-length book is Notes on the State of Virginia (1785)
column34: considered perhaps the most important American book published before 1800.Although regarded as a leading spokesman for democracy and republicanism in the era of the Enlightenment
column35: some modern scholarship has been critical of Jefferson's private life
column36: finding a contradiction between his ownership of the large numbers of slaves that worked his plantations and his famous declaration that ""all men are created equal"". Although the matter remains a subject of debate
column37: most historians believe that Jefferson had a sexual relationship with his slave Sally Hemings
column38: a mixed-race woman who was a half-sister to his late wife
column39: and that he fathered at least one of her children.  Presidential scholars and historians generally praise Jefferson's public achievements
column40: including his advocacy of religious freedom and tolerance in Virginia. Jefferson continues to rank highly among U.S. presidents."

column1: 30680 The_New_York_Times "The New York Times (sometimes abbreviated as the NYT and NYTimes) is an American newspaper based in New York City with worldwide influence and readership. Founded in 1851
column2: the paper has won 127 Pulitzer Prizes
column3: more than any other newspaper. The Times is ranked 18th in the world by circulation and 3rd in the U.S.The paper is owned by The New York Times Company
column4: which is publicly traded and is controlled by the Sulzberger family through a dual-class share structure. It has been owned by the family since 1896; A.G. Sulzberger
column5: the paper's publisher
column6: and his father
column7: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr.
column8: the company's chairman
column9: are the fourth and fifth generation of the family to head the paper.Nicknamed ""The Gray Lady
column10: the Times has long been regarded within the industry as a national ""newspaper of record."" The paper's motto
column11: ""All the News That's Fit to Print""
column12: appears in the upper left-hand corner of the front page. Since the mid-1970s
column13: The New York Times has greatly expanded its layout and organization
column14: adding special weekly sections on various topics supplementing the regular news
column15: editorials
column16: sports
column17: and features. Since 2008
column18: the Times has been organized into the following sections: News
column19: Editorials/Opinions-Columns/Op-Ed
column20: New York (metropolitan)
column21: Business
column22: Sports of The Times
column23: Arts
column24: Science
column25: Styles
column26: Home
column27: Travel
column28: and other features. On Sunday
column29: the Times is supplemented by the Sunday Review (formerly the Week in Review)
column30: The New York Times Book Review
column31: The New York Times Magazine and T: The New York Times Style Magazine. The Times stayed with the broadsheet full-page set-up and an eight-column format for several years after most papers switched to six
column32: and was one of the last newspapers to adopt color photography
column33: especially on the front page."

column1: 31979 United_States_Capitol "The United States Capitol
column2: often called the Capitol Building
column3: is the home of the United States Congress and the seat of the legislative branch of the U.S. federal government. It is located on Capitol Hill at the eastern end of the National Mall in Washington
column4: D.C. Though no longer at the geographic center of the Federal District
column5: the Capitol forms the origin point for the District's street-numbering system and the District's four quadrants. The original building was completed in 1800 and was subsequently expanded
column6: particularly with the addition of the massive dome
column7: and expanded chambers for the bicameral legislature
column8: the House of Representatives in the south wing and the Senate in the north wing. Like the principal buildings of the executive and judicial branches
column9: the Capitol is built in a distinctive neoclassical style and has a white exterior. Both its east and west elevations are formally referred to as fronts
column10: though only the east front was intended for the reception of visitors and dignitaries."

column1: 32070 Republican_Party_(United_States) "The Republican Party
column2: also referred to as the GOP (Grand Old Party)
column3: is one of the two major political parties in the United States; the other is its historic rival
column4: the Democratic Party. The GOP was founded in 1854 by opponents of the Kansas–Nebraska Act
column5: which allowed for the potential expansion of slavery into certain U.S. territories. The party supported classical liberalism
column6: opposed the expansion of slavery
column7: and supported economic reform. Abraham Lincoln was the first Republican president. Under the leadership of Lincoln and a Republican Congress
column8: slavery was banned in the United States in 1865. The Party was generally dominant during the Third Party System and the Fourth Party System. After 1912
column9: the Party underwent an ideological shift to the right. Following the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965
column10: the party's core base shifted
column11: with Southern states becoming more reliably Republican in presidential politics. Since the 1990s
column12: the Party's support has chiefly come from the South
column13: the Great Plains
column14: the Mountain States and rural and exurban areas in the Midwest.The 21st century Republican Party ideology is American conservatism. The GOP supports lower taxes
column15: free market capitalism
column16: a strong national defense
column17: gun rights
column18: pro-life
column19: deregulation and restrictions on labor unions. In addition to advocating for conservative economic policies
column20: the Republican Party is socially conservative. After the Supreme Court's 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade
column21: the Republican Party opposed abortion in its party platform and grew its support among evangelicals. The GOP was strongly committed to protectionism and tariffs at its founding
column22: but grew more supportive of free trade in the 20th century. There have been 19 Republican presidents
column23: the most from any one political party (including current president Donald Trump
column24: who was elected in 2016). As of 2019
column25: the GOP controls the presidency
column26: a majority in the U.S. Senate
column27: a majority of state governorships
column28: a majority (30) of state legislatures
column29: and 22 state government trifectas (governorship and both legislative chambers). Five of the nine sitting U.S. Supreme Court justices were nominated by Republican presidents."

column1: 32173 United_States_Military_Academy "The United States Military Academy (USMA)
column2: also known as West Point
column3: Army
column4: Army West Point
column5: The Academy
column6: or simply The Point
column7: is a four-year federal service academy in West Point
column8: New York. It was originally established as a fort that sits on strategic high ground overlooking the Hudson River with a scenic view
column9: 50 miles (80 km) north of New York City. It is one of the five U.S. service academies. The academy traces its roots to 1801
column10: when President Thomas Jefferson directed
column11: shortly after his inauguration
column12: that plans be set in motion to establish the United States Military Academy at West Point. The entire central campus is a national landmark and home to scores of historic sites
column13: buildings
column14: and monuments. The majority of the campus's Norman-style buildings are constructed from gray and black granite. The campus is a popular tourist destination
column15: with a visitor center and the oldest museum in the United States Army. Candidates for admission must both apply directly to the academy and receive a nomination
column16: usually from a member of Congress or Delegate/Resident Commissioner in the case of Washington
column17: D.C.
column18: Puerto Rico
column19: Northern Mariana Islands
column20: Guam
column21: American Samoa
column22: and the Virgin Islands. Other nomination sources include the President and Vice President of the United States. Students are officers-in-training and are referred to as ""cadets"" or collectively as the ""United States Corps of Cadets"" (USCC). Tuition for cadets is fully funded by the Army in exchange for an active duty service obligation upon graduation. Approximately 1
column23: 300 cadets enter the Academy each July
column24: with about 1
column25: 000 cadets graduating. The academic program grants a bachelor of science degree with a curriculum that grades cadets' performance upon a broad academic program
column26: military leadership performance
column27: and mandatory participation in competitive athletics. Cadets are required to adhere to the Cadet Honor Code
column28: which states that ""a cadet will not lie
column29: cheat
column30: steal
column31: or tolerate those who do."" The academy bases a cadet's leadership experience as a development of all four pillars of performance: academics
column32: character
column33: physical
column34: and military. Most graduates are commissioned as second lieutenants in the Army. Foreign cadets are commissioned into the armies of their home countries. Since 1959
column35: cadets have also been eligible for an interservice commission
column36: a commission in one of the other armed services
column37: provided they meet that service's eligibility standards. Most years
column38: a very small number of cadets do this. The academy's traditions have influenced other institutions because of its age and unique mission. It was the first American college to have an accredited civil engineering program and the first to have class rings
column39: and its technical curriculum was a model for later engineering schools. West Point's student body has a unique rank structure and lexicon. All cadets reside on campus and dine together en masse on weekdays for breakfast and lunch. The academy fields fifteen men's and nine women's National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) sports teams. Cadets compete in one sport every fall
column40: winter
column41: and spring season at the intramural
column42: club
column43: or intercollegiate level. Its football team was a national power in the early and mid-20th century
column44: winning three national championships. Its alumni and students are collectively referred to as ""The Long Gray Line"" and its ranks include two Presidents of the United States (as well as the President of the Confederate States of America)
column45: presidents of Costa Rica
column46: Nicaragua
column47: and the Philippines
column49: and seventy-six Medal of Honor recipients."

column1: 32310 Lockheed_U-2 "The Lockheed U-2
column2: nicknamed ""Dragon Lady""
column3: is an American single-jet engine
column4: ultra-high altitude reconnaissance aircraft operated by the United States Air Force (USAF) and previously flown by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). It provides day and night
column5: high-altitude (70
column6: 000 feet; 21
column8: all-weather intelligence gathering.Lockheed Corporation originally proposed it in 1953
column9: it was approved in 1954
column10: and its first test flight was in 1955. It was flown during the Cold War over the Soviet Union
column11: China
column12: Vietnam
column13: and Cuba. In 1960
column14: Gary Powers was shot down in a CIA U-2A over the Soviet Union by a surface-to-air missile (SAM).  Major Rudolf Anderson Jr. was shot down in a U-2 during the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962. U-2s have taken part in post-Cold War conflicts in Afghanistan and Iraq
column15: and supported several multinational NATO operations. The U-2 has also been used for electronic sensor research
column16: satellite calibration
column17: scientific research
column18: and communications purposes. The U-2 is one of a handful of aircraft types to have served the USAF for over 50 years
column19: such as the Boeing B-52 and Boeing KC-135. The newest models (TR-1
column20: U-2R
column21: U-2S) entered service in the 1980s
column22: and the latest model
column23: the U-2S
column24: had a technical upgrade in 2012."

column1: 33299 William_Henry_Harrison "William Henry Harrison (February 9
column2: 1773 – April 4
column3: 1841) was an American military officer and politician who served as the ninth president of the United States in 1841. He died of typhoid
column4: pneumonia or paratyphoid fever 31 days into his term (the shortest tenure)
column5: becoming the first president to die in office. His death sparked a brief constitutional crisis regarding succession to the presidency
column6: because the Constitution was unclear as to whether Vice President John Tyler should assume the office of president or merely execute the duties of the vacant office. Tyler claimed a constitutional mandate to become the new president and took the presidential oath of office
column7: setting an important precedent for an orderly transfer of the presidency and its full powers when the previous president fails to complete the elected term.Harrison was a son of Founding Father Benjamin Harrison V and the paternal grandfather of Benjamin Harrison
column8: the 23rd president of the United States. He was the last president born as a British subject in the Thirteen Colonies before the start of the Revolutionary War in 1775. During his early military career
column9: he participated in the 1794 Battle of Fallen Timbers
column10: an American military victory that effectively ended the Northwest Indian War. Later
column11: he led a military force against Tecumseh's Confederacy at the Battle of Tippecanoe in 1811
column12: where he earned the nickname ""Old Tippecanoe"". He was promoted to major general in the Army in the War of 1812
column13: and in 1813 led American infantry and cavalry at the Battle of the Thames in Upper Canada.Harrison began his political career in 1798
column14: when he was appointed Secretary of the Northwest Territory
column15: and in 1799 he was elected as the territory's delegate in the House of Representatives. Two years later
column16: President John Adams named him governor of the newly established Indiana Territory
column17: a post he held until 1812. After the War of 1812
column18: he moved to Ohio where he was elected to represent the state's 1st district in the House in 1816. In 1824
column19: the state legislature elected him to the U.S. Senate; his term was truncated by his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary to Gran Colombia in May 1828. Afterward
column20: he returned to private life in Ohio until he was nominated as the Whig Party candidate for president in the 1836 election; he was defeated by Democratic vice president Martin Van Buren. Four years later
column21: the party nominated him again with John Tyler as his running mate
column22: and the Whig campaign slogan was ""Tippecanoe and Tyler Too"". They defeated Van Buren in the 1840 election
column23: making Harrison the first Whig to win the presidency. At 68 years
column24: 23 days of age at the time of his inauguration
column25: Harrison was the oldest person to assume the U.S. presidency
column26: a distinction he held until 1981
column27: when Ronald Reagan was inaugurated at age 69 years
column28: 349 days. Due to his brief tenure
column29: scholars and historians often forgo listing him in historical presidential rankings. However
column30: historian William W. Freehling calls him ""the most dominant figure in the evolution of the Northwest territories into the Upper Midwest today""."

column1: 33501 White_dwarf "A white dwarf
column2: also called a degenerate dwarf
column3: is a stellar core remnant composed mostly of electron-degenerate matter. A white dwarf is very dense: its mass is comparable to that of the Sun
column4: while its volume is comparable to that of Earth. A white dwarf's faint luminosity comes from the emission of stored thermal energy; no fusion takes place in a white dwarf. The nearest known white dwarf is Sirius B
column5: at 8.6 light years
column6: the smaller component of the Sirius binary star. There are currently thought to be eight white dwarfs among the hundred star systems nearest the Sun. The unusual faintness of white dwarfs was first recognized in 1910. The name white dwarf was coined by Willem Luyten in 1922. White dwarfs are thought to be the final evolutionary state of stars whose mass is not high enough to become a neutron star
column7: that of about 10 solar masses. This includes over 97% of the other stars in the Milky Way.
column8: § 1. After the hydrogen-fusing period of a main-sequence star of low or medium mass ends
column9: such a star will expand to a red giant during which it fuses helium to carbon and oxygen in its core by the triple-alpha process. If a red giant has insufficient mass to generate the core temperatures required to fuse carbon (around 1 billion K)
column10: an inert mass of carbon and oxygen will build up at its center. After such a star sheds its outer layers and forms a planetary nebula
column11: it will leave behind a core
column12: which is the remnant white dwarf. Usually
column13: white dwarfs are composed of carbon and oxygen. If the mass of the progenitor is between 8 and 10.5 solar masses (M☉)
column14: the core temperature will be sufficient to fuse carbon but not neon
column15: in which case an oxygen–neon–magnesium white dwarf may form. Stars of very low mass will not be able to fuse helium
column16: hence
column17: a helium white dwarf may form by mass loss in binary systems. The material in a white dwarf no longer undergoes fusion reactions
column18: so the star has no source of energy. As a result
column19: it cannot support itself by the heat generated by fusion against gravitational collapse
column20: but is supported only by electron degeneracy pressure
column21: causing it to be extremely dense. The physics of degeneracy yields a maximum mass for a non-rotating white dwarf
column22: the Chandrasekhar limit—approximately 1.44 times M☉—beyond which it cannot be supported by electron degeneracy pressure. A carbon-oxygen white dwarf that approaches this mass limit
column23: typically by mass transfer from a companion star
column24: may explode as a type Ia supernova via a process known as carbon detonation; SN 1006 is thought to be a famous example. A white dwarf is very hot when it forms
column25: but because it has no source of energy
column26: it will gradually cool as it radiates its energy. This means that its radiation
column27: which initially has a high color temperature
column28: will lessen and redden with time. Over a very long time
column29: a white dwarf will cool and its material will begin to crystallize
column30: starting with the core. The star's low temperature means it will no longer emit significant heat or light
column31: and it will become a cold black dwarf. Because the length of time it takes for a white dwarf to reach this state is calculated to be longer than the current age of the universe (approximately 13.8 billion years)
column32: it is thought that no black dwarfs yet exist. The oldest white dwarfs still radiate at temperatures of a few thousand kelvins."

column1: 34139 Xenon "Xenon is a chemical element with the symbol Xe and atomic number 54. It is a colorless
column2: dense
column3: odorless noble gas found in Earth's atmosphere in trace amounts. Although generally unreactive
column4: xenon can undergo a few chemical reactions such as the formation of xenon hexafluoroplatinate
column5: the first noble gas compound to be synthesized.Xenon is used in flash lamps and arc lamps
column6: and as a general anesthetic. The first excimer laser design used a xenon dimer molecule (Xe2) as the lasing medium
column7: and the earliest laser designs used xenon flash lamps as pumps. Xenon is used to search for hypothetical weakly interacting massive particles and as the propellant for ion thrusters in spacecraft.Naturally occurring xenon consists of seven stable isotopes and two long-lived radioactive isotopes. More than 40 unstable xenon isotopes undergo radioactive decay
column8: and the isotope ratios of xenon are an important tool for studying the early history of the Solar System. Radioactive xenon-135 is produced by beta decay from iodine-135 (a product of nuclear fission)
column9: and is the most significant (and unwanted) neutron absorber in nuclear reactors."

column1: 38902 Brown "Brown is a composite color. In the CMYK color model used in printing or painting
column2: brown is made by combining red
column3: black
column4: and yellow
column5: or red
column6: yellow
column7: and blue. In the RGB color model used to project colors onto television screens and computer monitors
column8: brown is made by combining red and green
column9: in specific proportions. In painting
column10: brown is generally made by adding black to orange. Mixing red-green-blue pigments makes mud color. The brown color is seen widely in nature
column11: in wood
column12: soil
column13: human hair color
column14: eye color and skin pigmentation. Brown is the color of dark wood or rich soil. According to public opinion surveys in Europe and the United States
column15: brown is the least favorite color of the public; the color is most often associated with plainness
column16: the rustic and poverty."

column1: 39034 J._Robert_Oppenheimer "Julius Robert Oppenheimer (; April 22
column2: 1904 – February 18
column3: 1967) was an American theoretical physicist and professor of physics at the University of California
column4: Berkeley. Oppenheimer was the wartime head of the Los Alamos Laboratory and is among those who are credited with being the ""father of the atomic bomb"" for their role in the Manhattan Project
column5: the World War II undertaking that developed the first nuclear weapons. The first atomic bomb was successfully detonated on July 16
column7: in the Trinity test in New Mexico. Oppenheimer later remarked that it brought to mind words from the Bhagavad Gita: ""Now I am become Death
column8: the destroyer of worlds."" In August 1945
column9: the weapons were used in the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. After the war ended
column10: Oppenheimer became chairman of the influential General Advisory Committee of the newly created United States Atomic Energy Commission. He used that position to lobby for international control of nuclear power to avert nuclear proliferation and a nuclear arms race with the Soviet Union. After provoking the ire of many politicians with his outspoken opinions during the Second Red Scare
column11: he suffered the revocation of his security clearance in a much-publicized hearing in 1954
column12: and was effectively stripped of his direct political influence; he continued to lecture
column13: write and work in physics. Nine years later
column14: President John F. Kennedy awarded (and Lyndon B. Johnson presented) him with the Enrico Fermi Award as a gesture of political rehabilitation. Oppenheimer's achievements in physics included the Born–Oppenheimer approximation for molecular wave functions
column15: work on the theory of electrons and positrons
column16: the Oppenheimer–Phillips process in nuclear fusion
column17: and the first prediction of quantum tunneling. With his students he also made important contributions to the modern theory of neutron stars and black holes
column18: as well as to quantum mechanics
column19: quantum field theory
column20: and the interactions of cosmic rays. As a teacher and promoter of science
column21: he is remembered as a founding father of the American school of theoretical physics that gained world prominence in the 1930s. After World War II
column22: he became director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton
column23: New Jersey."

column1: 42317 United_Press_International "United Press International (UPI) is an international news agency whose newswires
column2: photo
column3: news film
column4: and audio services provided news material to thousands of newspapers
column5: magazines
column6: radio and television stations for most of the 20th century. At its peak
column7: it had more  than 6
column8: 000 media subscribers. Since the first of several sales and staff cutbacks in 1982
column9: and the 1999 sale of its broadcast client list to its rival
column10: the Associated Press
column11: UPI has concentrated on smaller information-market niches."

column1: 43950 Interstate_Highway_System "The Dwight D. Eisenhower National System of Interstate and Defense Highways
column2: commonly known as the Interstate Highway System or Interstate
column3: is a network of controlled-access highways that forms part of the National Highway System in the United States. Construction of the system was authorized by the Federal Aid Highway Act of 1956. The system extends throughout the contiguous United States and has routes in Hawaii
column4: Alaska
column5: and Puerto Rico. The U.S. federal government first funded roadways through the Federal Aid Road Act of 1916
column6: and began an effort to construct a national road grid with the passage of the Federal Aid Highway Act of 1921. After Dwight D. Eisenhower became president in 1953
column7: his administration developed a proposal for an interstate highway system
column8: eventually resulting in the passage of the Federal Aid Highway Act of 1956. Construction of the Interstate Highway System was proclaimed complete in 1992
column9: though some planned routes were canceled and several routes have stretches that do not fully conform with federal standards. The cost of construction of the Interstate Highway System was approximately $114 billion (equivalent to $521 billion in 2018). The original system has been expanded numerous times through the creation of new designations and the extension of existing designations.  Though much of their construction was funded by the federal government
column10: Interstate highways are owned by the state in which they were built. All Interstate highways must meet federal standards such as having controlled access
column11: using a minimal number of traffic lights
column12: and complying with federal traffic sign specifications. Interstate highways use a numbering scheme in which primary interstates are assigned one- or two-digit numbers and shorter routes are assigned three-digit numbers where the last two digits match the parent route. The Interstate Highway System is partially financed through the Highway Trust Fund
column13: which itself is funded by a federal fuel tax. Though federal legislation initially banned the collection of tolls
column14: some Interstate routes are toll roads. As of 2016
column15: about one-quarter of all vehicle miles driven in the country used the Interstate Highway System
column16: which had a total length of 48
column17: 191 miles (77
column18: 556 km). Several future routes are in development."

column1: 49248 Byron_White "Byron Raymond ""Whizzer"" White (June 8
column2: 1917 – April 15
column3: 2002) was an American lawyer and professional football player who served as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States from 1962 to 1993. Born and raised in Colorado
column4: he played college football
column5: basketball
column6: and baseball for the University of Colorado
column7: finishing as the runner up for the Heisman Trophy in 1937. He was selected in the first round of the 1938 NFL Draft by the Pittsburgh Steelers and led the National Football League in rushing yards in his rookie season. White was admitted to Yale Law School in 1939 and played for the Detroit Lions in the 1940 and 1941 seasons. During World War II
column8: he served as an intelligence officer with the United States Navy in the Pacific. After the war
column9: he graduated from Yale and clerked for Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson. White entered private practice in Denver
column10: Colorado
column11: working primarily as a transactional attorney. He served as the Colorado state chair of John F. Kennedy's 1960 presidential campaign and accepted appointment as the United States Deputy Attorney General in 1961. In 1962
column12: President Kennedy successfully nominated White to the Supreme Court
column13: making White the first Supreme Court Justice from Colorado. He retired in 1993 and was succeeded by Ruth Bader Ginsburg. White is the twelfth longest-serving justice in Supreme Court history. White viewed his own court decisions as based on the facts of each case rather than as representative of a specific legal philosophy. He wrote the majority opinion in cases including Coker v. Georgia
column14: Washington v. Davis and Bowers v. Hardwick. He wrote dissenting opinions in notable cases such as Miranda v. Arizona
column15: Immigration and Naturalization Service v. Chadha
column16: NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma
column17: and Roe v. Wade."

column1: 49260 Willy_Brandt "Willy Brandt (German: [ˈvɪliː ˈbʁant]; born Herbert Ernst Karl Frahm; 18 December 1913 – 8 October 1992) was a German politician and statesman who was leader of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD) from 1964 to 1987 and served as Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany) from 1969 to 1974. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1971 for his efforts to strengthen cooperation in western Europe through the EEC and to achieve reconciliation between West Germany and the countries of Eastern Europe. He was the first Social Democrat chancellor since 1930. Fleeing to Norway and then Sweden during the Nazi regime and working as a left-wing journalist
column2: he took the name Willy Brandt as a pseudonym to avoid detection by Nazi agents
column3: and then formally adopted the name in 1948. Brandt was originally considered one of the leaders of the right wing of the SPD
column4: and earned initial fame as Governing Mayor of West Berlin. He served as Foreign Minister and as Vice Chancellor in Kurt Georg Kiesinger's cabinet
column5: and became chancellor in 1969. As chancellor
column6: he maintained West Germany's close alignment with the United States and focused on strengthening European integration in western Europe
column7: while launching the new policy of Ostpolitik aimed at improving relations with Eastern Europe. Brandt was controversial on both the right wing
column8: for his Ostpolitik
column9: and on the left wing
column10: for his support of American policies
column11: including the Vietnam War
column12: and right-wing authoritarian regimes. The Brandt Report became a recognised measure for describing the general North-South divide in world economics and politics between an affluent North and a poor South. Brandt was also known for his fierce anti-communist policies at the domestic level
column13: culminating in the Radikalenerlass (Anti-Radical Decree) in 1972. Brandt resigned as chancellor in 1974
column14: after Günter Guillaume
column15: one of his closest aides
column16: was exposed as an agent of the Stasi
column17: the East German secret service."

column1: 49598 Pigment "A pigment is a material that changes the color of reflected or transmitted light as the result of wavelength-selective absorption.  This physical process differs from fluorescence
column2: phosphorescence
column3: and other forms of luminescence
column4: in which a material emits light.  Most materials selectively absorb certain wavelengths of light. Materials that humans have chosen and developed for use as pigments usually have special properties that make them useful for coloring other materials. A pigment must have a high tinting strength relative to the materials it colors. It must be stable in solid form at ambient temperatures. For industrial applications
column5: as well as in the arts
column6: permanence and stability are desirable properties.  Pigments that are not permanent are called fugitive. Fugitive pigments fade over time
column7: or with exposure to light
column8: while some eventually blacken.  Pigments are used for coloring paint
column9: ink
column10: plastic
column11: fabric
column12: cosmetics
column13: food
column14: and other materials. Most pigments used in manufacturing and the visual arts are dry colorants
column15: usually ground into a fine powder.  For use in paint
column16: this powder is added to a binder (or vehicle)
column17: a relatively neutral or colorless material that suspends the pigment and gives the paint its adhesion.  A distinction is usually made between a pigment
column18: which is insoluble in its vehicle (resulting in a suspension)
column19: and a dye
column20: which either is itself a liquid or is soluble in its vehicle (resulting in a solution). A colorant can act as either a pigment or a dye depending on the vehicle involved. In some cases
column21: a pigment can be manufactured from a dye by precipitating a soluble dye with a metallic salt. The resulting pigment is called a lake pigment. The term biological pigment is used for all colored substances independent of their solubility.In 2006
column22: around 7.4 million tons of inorganic
column23: organic and special pigments were marketed worldwide.  Asia has the highest rate on a quantity basis followed by Europe and North America.  The global demand on pigments was roughly US$20.5 billion in 2009."

column1: 55284 Coat_of_arms "A coat of arms is a heraldic visual design on an escutcheon (i.e.
column2: shield)
column3: surcoat
column4: or tabard. The coat of arms on an escutcheon forms the central element of the full heraldic achievement which in its whole consists of shield
column5: supporters
column6: crest
column7: and motto. A coat of arms is traditionally unique to an individual person
column8: family
column9: state
column10: organization or corporation. The Roll of Arms is a collection of many coats of arms
column11: and since the early Modern Age centuries it has been a source of information for public showing and tracing the membership of a noble family
column12: and therefore its genealogy across time."

column1: 58702 John_Glenn "John Herschel Glenn Jr. (July 18
column2: 1921 – December 8
column3: 2016) was a United States Marine Corps aviator
column4: engineer
column5: astronaut
column6: businessman
column7: and politician. He was the first American to orbit the Earth

column9: he served from 1974 to 1999 as a Democratic United States Senator from Ohio
column10: and in 1998 flew into space again at age 77. Before joining NASA
column11: Glenn was a distinguished fighter pilot in World War II
column12: China and Korea. He shot down three MiG-15s
column13: and was awarded six Distinguished Flying Crosses and eighteen Air Medals. In 1957
column14: he made the first supersonic transcontinental flight across the United States. His on-board camera took the first continuous
column15: panoramic photograph of the United States. He was one of the Mercury Seven
column16: military test pilots selected in 1959 by NASA as the nation's first astronauts. On February 20
column18: Glenn flew the Friendship 7 mission
column19: becoming the first American to orbit the Earth
column20: and the fifth person and third American in space. He received the NASA Distinguished Service Medal in 1962
column21: the Congressional Space Medal of Honor in 1978
column22: was inducted into the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame in 1990
column23: and received the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2012. Glenn resigned from NASA in January 1964. A member of the Democratic Party
column24: Glenn was first elected to the Senate in 1974 and served for 24 years
column25: until January 1999. In 1998

column28: making him
column29: at age 77
