column1: 65651 Holocaust_denial "Holocaust denial is the act of denying the genocide of Jews in the Holocaust during World War II. Holocaust deniers make one or more of the following false statements: that Nazi Germany's Final Solution was aimed only at deporting Jews from the Reich and did not include their extermination; that Nazi authorities did not use extermination camps and gas chambers for the genocidal mass murder of Jews; or that the actual number of Jews murdered is significantly lower than the accepted figure of 5 to 6 million
column2: typically around a tenth of that figure.Because Holocaust denial is a common facet of certain racist propaganda
column3: it is considered a serious societal problem in many places where it occurs and is illegal in several European countries and Israel. Holocaust denial is sponsored by some Middle Eastern governments
column4: including Iran and Syria. Scholars use the term denial to describe the views and methodology of Holocaust deniers in order to distinguish them from legitimate historical revisionists
column5: who challenge orthodox interpretations of history using established historical methodologies. Holocaust deniers generally do not accept denial as an appropriate description of their activities and use the euphemism revisionism instead. The methodologies of Holocaust deniers are often based on a predetermined conclusion that ignores overwhelming historical evidence to the contrary.  In some post-Soviet states
column6: Holocaust deniers do not deny the very fact of mass murder of Jews
column7: but they deny the participation of their own nationals in the Holocaust.Most Holocaust deniers claim
column8: either explicitly or implicitly
column9: that the Holocaust is a hoax—or an exaggeration—arising from a deliberate Jewish conspiracy designed to advance the interest of Jews at the expense of other people. For this reason
column10: Holocaust denial is generally considered to be an antisemitic conspiracy theory."

column1: 71234 Orange_(colour) "Orange is the colour between yellow and red on the spectrum of visible light. Human eyes perceive orange when observing light with a dominant wavelength between roughly 585 and 620 nanometres. In painting and traditional colour theory
column2: it is a secondary colour of pigments
column3: created by mixing yellow and red. It is named after the fruit of the same name. The orange colour of carrots
column4: pumpkins
column5: sweet potatoes
column6: oranges
column7: and many other fruits and vegetables comes from carotenes
column8: a type of photosynthetic pigment. These pigments convert the light energy that the plants absorb from the sun into chemical energy for the plants' growth. Similarly the hues of autumn leaves are from the same pigment after chlorophyll is removed. In Europe and America
column9: surveys show that orange is the colour most associated with amusement
column10: the unconventional
column11: extroverts
column12: warmth
column13: fire
column14: energy
column15: activity
column16: danger
column17: taste and aroma
column18: the autumn and Allhallowtide seasons
column19: as well as having long been the national colour of the Netherlands and the House of Orange. It also serves as the political colour of Christian democracy political ideology and most Christian democratic political parties. In Asia it is an important symbolic colour of Buddhism and Hinduism."

column1: 72243 Surname "A surname
column2: family name
column3: or last name is the portion (in some cultures) of a personal name that indicates a person's family (or tribe or community
column4: depending on the culture). Depending on the culture
column5: all members of a family unit may have identical surnames or there may be variations based on the cultural rules. In the English-speaking world
column6: a surname is commonly referred to as a last name because it is usually placed at the end of a person's full name
column7: after any given names. In many parts of Asia
column8: as well as some parts of Europe and Africa
column9: the family name is placed before a person's given name. In most Spanish-speaking and Portuguese-speaking countries
column10: two surnames are commonly used and in some families even three or more are used (often due to a family claim to nobility). Surnames have not always existed and today are not universal in all cultures. This tradition has arisen separately in different cultures around the world. In Europe
column11: the concept of surnames became popular in the Roman Empire and expanded throughout the Mediterranean and Western Europe as a result. During the Middle Ages this practice died out as Germanic
column12: Persian
column13: and other influences took hold. During the late Middle Ages surnames gradually re-emerged
column14: first in the form of bynames (typically indicating individual's occupation or area of residence)
column15: which gradually evolved into modern surnames. In China surnames have been the norm since at least the 2nd century BC.A family name is typically a part of a person's personal name which
column16: according to law or custom
column17: is passed or given to children from one or both of their parents' family names. The use of family names is common in most cultures around the world
column18: with each culture having its own rules as to how these names are formed
column19: passed and used. However
column20: the style of having both a family name (surname) and a given name (forename) is far from universal. In many cultures
column21: it is common for people to have one name or  mononym
column22: with some cultures not using family names. In most Slavic countries
column23: as well as other countries including Greece and Iceland
column24: for example
column25: there are different family name forms for male and female members of the family. Issues of family name arise especially on the passing of a name to a new-born child
column26: on the adoption of a common family name on marriage
column27: on renouncing of a family name and on changing of a family name. Surname laws vary around the world. Traditionally in many European countries for the past few hundred years
column28: it was the custom or law that a woman would on marriage use the surname of her husband and that children of a man would have the father's surname. If a child's paternity was not known
column29: or if the putative father denied paternity
column30: the new-born child would have the surname of the mother. That is still the custom or law in many countries. The surname for children of married parents is usually inherited from the father. In recent years there has been a trend towards equality of treatment in relation to family names
column31: with women being not automatically required or expected
column32: or in some places even forbidden
column33: to take the husband's surname on marriage
column34: and children not automatically being given the father's surname. In this article
column35: family name and surname both mean the patrilineal surname
column36: handed down from or inherited from the father's
column37: unless explicitly stated otherwise. Thus
column38: the term ""maternal surname"" means the patrilineal surname which one's mother inherited from either or both of her parents. For a discussion of matrilineal ('mother-line') surnames
column39: passing from mothers to daughters
column40: see matrilineal surname. It is common for women in the entertainment industry (like celebrities) to keep their maiden name after they get married
column41: especially if they achieved their fame before marriage. The same can be said for women who achieved their fame during a previous marriage; For example: Kris Jenner (born Kris Houghton) was married to her second spouse Kaitlyn Jenner when she rose to prominence in the reality show Keeping Up with the Kardashians and singer Britney Spears has been married twice after she rose to prominence
column42: but she still uses her maiden name. In English-speaking cultures
column43: family names are often used by children when referring to adults but are also used to refer to someone in authority
column44: the elderly
column45: or in a formal setting
column46: and are often used with a title or honorific such as Mr.
column47: Mrs.
column51: and so on. Generally the given name is the one used by friends
column53: and other intimates to address an individual. It may also be used by someone who is in some way senior to the person being addressed. This practice also differs between cultures; see T–V distinction. The study of proper names (in family names
column55: or places) is called onomastics. A one-name study is a collection of vital and other biographical data about all persons worldwide sharing a particular surname."

column1: 80140 Alexander_Haig "Alexander Meigs Haig Jr. (; December 2
column2: 1924 – February 20
column3: 2010) was the United States Secretary of State under President Ronald Reagan and the White House chief of staff under presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.  Prior to these cabinet-level positions
column4: he retired as a general from the United States Army
column5: having been Supreme Allied Commander Europe after serving as the vice chief of staff of the Army. Born in Bala Cynwyd
column6: Pennsylvania
column7: Haig served in the Korean War after graduating from the United States Military Academy. In the Korean War
column8: he served as an aide to General Alonzo Patrick Fox and General Edward Almond. After the war
column9: he served as an aide to Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara. During the Vietnam War
column10: Haig commanded a battalion and later a brigade of the 1st Infantry Division. For his service
column11: Haig was a recipient of the Distinguished Service Cross
column12: the Silver Star with oak leaf cluster
column13: and the Purple Heart.In 1969 Haig became an assistant to National Security Adviser Henry Kissinger. He became vice chief of staff of the Army
column14: the second-highest-ranking position in the Army
column15: in 1972. After the 1973 resignation of H. R. Haldeman
column16: Haig became President Nixon's chief of staff. Serving in the wake of the Watergate scandal
column17: he became especially influential in the final months of Nixon's tenure
column18: and played a role in persuading Nixon to resign in August 1974. Haig continued to serve as chief of staff for the first month of President Ford's tenure. From 1974 to 1979
column19: Haig served as Supreme Allied Commander Europe
column20: commanding all NATO forces in Europe. He retired from the Army in 1979 and pursued a career in business. After Reagan won the 1980 presidential election
column21: he nominated Haig to be his secretary of state. After the attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan
column22: Haig asserted ""I am in control here
column23: allegedly suggesting (erroneously since 1947
column24: when the Speaker of the House of Representatives was designated the second in the line of succession after the Vice President) that he served as acting president in Reagan's and Bush's absence
column25: later iterating that he meant that he was functionally in control of the government. During the Falklands War
column26: Haig sought to broker peace between the United Kingdom and Argentina. He resigned from Reagan's cabinet in July 1982. After leaving office
column27: he unsuccessfully sought the presidential nomination in the 1988 Republican primaries. He also served as the head of a consulting firm and hosted the television program World Business Review."

column1: 91440 John_C._Fr%C3%A9mont "John Charles Frémont  or Fremont (January 21
column3: 1890) was an American explorer
column4: politician
column5: and soldier who
column7: became the first candidate of the Republican Party for the office of President of the United States. During the 1840s
column8: when he led five expeditions into the American West
column9: that era's penny press and admiring historians accorded Frémont the sobriquet The Pathfinder.During the Mexican–American War
column10: Frémont
column11: a major in the U.S. Army
column12: took control of California from the California Republic in 1846. Frémont was convicted in court-martial for mutiny and insubordination over a conflict of who was the rightful military governor of California. After his sentence was commuted and he was reinstated by President Polk
column13: Frémont resigned from the Army. Frémont led a private fourth expedition
column14: which cost ten lives
column15: seeking a rail route over the mountains around the 38th parallel in the winter of 1849. Afterwards
column16: Frémont settled in California at Monterey while buying cheap land in the Sierra foothills. When gold was found on his Mariposa ranch
column17: Frémont became a wealthy man during the California Gold Rush
column18: but he was soon bogged down with lawsuits over land claims
column19: between the dispossession of various land owners during the Mexican–American War and the explosion of Forty-Niners immigrating during the Rush. These cases were settled by the U.S. Supreme Court allowing Frémont to keep his property. Frémont's fifth and final privately funded expedition
column20: between 1853 and 1854
column21: surveyed a route for a transcontinental railroad. Frémont became one of the first two U.S. senators elected from the new state of California in 1850. Frémont was the first presidential candidate of the new Republican Party
column22: carrying most of the North. He lost the 1856 presidential election to Democrat James Buchanan when Know Nothings split the vote. Democrats warned that his election would lead to civil war.During the American Civil War
column23: he was given command of Department of the West by President Abraham Lincoln. Although Frémont had successes during his brief tenure as Commander of the Western Armies
column24: he ran his department autocratically
column25: and made hasty decisions without consulting Washington D.C. or President Lincoln. After Frémont's emancipation edict that freed slaves in his district
column26: he was relieved of his command by President Lincoln for insubordination. In 1861
column27: Frémont was the first commanding Union general who recognized in Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant an ""iron will"" to fight and promoted him commander at the strategic base near Cairo
column28: Illinois. Defeating the Confederates at Springfield
column29: Frémont was the only Union General in the West to have a Union victory for 1861. After a brief service tenure in the Mountain Department in 1862
column30: Frémont resided in New York
column31: retiring from the Army in 1864. The same year Frémont was a presidential candidate for the Radical Democracy Party
column32: but he resigned before the election. After the Civil War
column33: Frémont's wealth declined after investing heavily and purchasing an unsuccessful Pacific Railroad in 1866
column34: and lost much of his wealth during the Panic of 1873. Frémont served as Governor of Arizona from 1878 to 1881 appointed by President Rutherford B. Hayes. After his resignation as governor
column35: Frémont retired from politics and died destitute in New York City in 1890. Historians portray Frémont as controversial
column36: impetuous
column37: and contradictory. Some scholars regard him as a military hero of significant accomplishment
column38: while others view him as a failure who repeatedly defeated his own best purposes. The keys to Frémont's character and personality may lie in his being born illegitimately
column39: his ambitious drive for success
column40: self-justification
column41: and passive-aggressive behavior. Frémont's published reports and maps produced from his explorations significantly contributed to massive American emigration overland into the West starting in the 1840s. In June 1846
column42: Frémont's and his army expedition's return to California
column43: spurred the formation of the California Battalion
column44: and his military advice led to the capture of Sonoma
column45: and the formation of the Bear Flag Republic. Many people during his lifetime believed his court martial by General Kearny in 1848 was unjustified. His biographer Allan Nevins in 1939 believed that Frémont lived a dramatic lifestyle
column46: one of remarkable successes
column47: and one of dismal failures."

column1: 103177 Daguerreotype "The daguerreotype (; French: daguerréotype) process
column2: or daguerreotypy
column3: was the first publicly available photographic process
column4: widely used during the 1840s and 1850s. Invented by Louis-Jacques-Mandé Daguerre and introduced worldwide in 1839
column5: daguerreotype was almost completely superseded by 1860 with new
column6: less expensive processes yielding more readily viewable images. There was a revival of daguerreotypy in the late 20th century by a small number of photographers interested in making artistic use of early photographic processes. To make the image
column7: a daguerrotypist would polish a sheet of silver-plated copper to a mirror finish
column8: treat it with fumes that made its surface light sensitive
column9: expose it in a camera for as long as was judged to be necessary
column10: which could be as little as a few seconds for brightly sunlit subjects or much longer with less intense lighting; make the resulting latent image on it visible by fuming it with mercury vapor; remove its sensitivity to light by liquid chemical treatment
column11: rinse and dry it
column12: then seal the easily marred result behind glass in a protective enclosure. The image is on a mirror-like silver surface
column13: normally kept under glass
column14: and will appear either positive or negative
column15: depending on the angle at which it is viewed
column16: how it is lit and whether a light or dark background is being reflected in the metal. The darkest areas of the image are simply bare silver; lighter areas have a microscopically fine light-scattering texture. The surface is very delicate
column17: and even the lightest wiping can permanently scuff it. Some tarnish around the edges is normal. Several types of antique photographs
column18: most often ambrotypes and tintypes
column19: but sometimes even old prints on paper
column20: are very commonly misidentified as daguerreotypes
column21: especially if they are in the small
column22: ornamented cases in which daguerreotypes made in the US and UK were usually housed. The name ""daguerreotype"" correctly refers only to one very specific image type and medium
column23: the product of a process that was in wide use only from the early 1840s to the late 1850s."

column1: 142528 Jeff_Bezos "Jeffrey Preston Bezos (; né Jorgensen; born January 12
column2: 1964) is an American internet and aerospace entrepreneur
column3: media proprietor
column4: and investor. He is best known as the founder
column5: CEO
column6: and president of Amazon.com
column7: Inc. Bezos was born in Albuquerque
column8: New Mexico
column9: and raised in Houston
column10: Texas. He graduated from Princeton University in 1986 with degrees in electrical engineering and computer science. He worked on Wall Street in a variety of related fields from 1986 to early 1994. He founded the online retailer Amazon in late 1994 on a cross-country road trip from New York City to Seattle. The company began as an online bookstore and has since expanded to a wide variety of other e-commerce products and services
column11: including video and audio streaming
column12: cloud computing
column13: and artificial intelligence. It is currently the world's largest online sales company
column14: the largest internet company by revenue
column15: as well as the world's largest provider of AI assistance and cloud infrastructure services via its Amazon Web Services arm. Bezos added to his business interests when he founded the aerospace manufacturer and sub-orbital spaceflight services company Blue Origin in 2000. A Blue Origin test flight successfully first reached space in 2015
column16: and the company has plans to begin commercial suborbital human spaceflight in 2019. He purchased major American newspaper publisher The Washington Post in 2013 for US$250 million in cash
column17: and manages his other businesses and investments through his venture capital firm
column18: Bezos Expeditions. On July 27
column20: Bezos momentarily became the world's wealthiest person when his estimated net worth increased to just over $90 billion. His wealth surpassed $100 billion for the first time on November 24
column22: and he was formally designated the wealthiest person in the world by Forbes on March 6
column24: with a net worth of $112 billion. The first centi-billionaire on the Forbes wealth index
column25: he was named the ""richest man in modern history"" after his net worth increased to $150 billion in July 2018. In September 2018
column26: Forbes described Bezos as ""far richer than anyone else on the planet"" as he added $1.8 billion to his worth when Amazon's market cap briefly reached $1 trillion."

column1: 148475 Air_Force_One "Air Force One is the official air traffic control call sign for a United States Air Force aircraft carrying the President of the United States. In common parlance
column2: the term is used to denote U.S. Air Force aircraft modified and used to transport the president. The aircraft are prominent symbols of the American presidency and its power.The idea of designating specific military aircraft to transport the President arose in 1943
column3: when officials of the United States Army Air Forces
column4: the predecessor to the U.S. Air Force
column5: became concerned about using commercial airlines for presidential travel. A C-87 Liberator Express was reconfigured for use as the first dedicated VIP-and-presidential transport aircraft and named Guess Where II
column6: but the Secret Service rejected it because of its safety record. A C-54 Skymaster was then converted for presidential use; dubbed the Sacred Cow
column7: it carried President Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Yalta Conference in February 1945 and was used for another two years by President Harry S. Truman. The ""Air Force One"" call sign was created in 1953
column8: after a Lockheed Constellation named Columbine II carrying President Dwight D. Eisenhower entered the same airspace as a commercial airline flight using the same flight number.Other Air Force Ones have included another Lockheed Constellation
column9: Columbine III
column10: and two Boeing 707s
column11: introduced in the 1960s and 1970s. Since 1990
column12: the presidential fleet has consisted of two Boeing VC-25As: highly customized Boeing 747-200B aircraft. The U.S. Air Force plans to buy two Boeing 747-8s to serve as the next Air Force Ones."

column1: 158894 Bill_Cosby "William Henry Cosby Jr. (; born July 12

column3: actor
column4: musician
column5: author
column6: and convicted sex offender. He held an active career for over six decades before being convicted and imprisoned for sex offenses in 2018. Cosby began his career as a stand-up comic at the hungry i in San Francisco during the 1960s. He then landed a starring role in the television show I Spy

column10: Cosby created

column13: centering on a group of young friends growing up in an urban area. Throughout the 1970s

column19: which aired from 1987 to 1993. He also starred in The Cosby Mysteries from 1994 to 1995 and in the sitcom Cosby from 1996 to 2000

column1: 163395 Traffic_light "Traffic lights
column2: also known as traffic signals
column3: traffic lamps
column4: traffic semaphore
column5: signal lights
column6: stop lights
column7: redlights (In the Southern United States)
column8: robots (in South Africa
column9: Zimbabwe and other parts of Africa)
column10: and traffic control signals in technical parlance
column11: are signalling devices positioned at road intersections
column12: pedestrian crossings
column13: and other locations to control flows of traffic. The world's first traffic light was a manually operated gas-lit signal installed in London in December 1868. It exploded less than a month after it was implemented
column14: injuring its policeman operator. Earnest Sirrine from Chicago patented the first automated traffic control system in 1910. It used the words ""STOP"" and ""PROCEED""
column15: although neither word was illuminated.Traffic lights alternate the right of way accorded to users by illuminating lamps or LEDs of standard colours (red
column16: amber (yellow)
column17: and green) following a universal colour code. In the typical sequence of colour phases:  The green light allows traffic to proceed in the direction denoted
column18: if it is safe to do so and there is room on the other side of the intersection. The amber light warns that the signal is about to change to red.  In a number of European countries – among them the United Kingdom – a phase during which red and yellow are displayed together indicates that the signal is about to change to green. Actions required by drivers on a yellow light vary
column19: with some jurisdictions requiring drivers to stop if it is safe to do so
column20: and others allowing drivers to go through the intersection if safe to do so. A flashing amber indication is a warning signal. In the United Kingdom
column21: a flashing amber light is used only at pelican crossings
column22: in place of the combined red–amber signal
column23: and indicates that drivers may pass if no pedestrians are on the crossing. The red signal prohibits any traffic from proceeding. A flashing red indication requires traffic to stop and then proceed when safe (equivalent to a stop sign).In some countries traffic signals will go into a flashing mode if the conflict monitor detects a problem
column24: such as a fault that tries to display green lights to conflicting traffic. The signal may display flashing yellow to the main road and flashing red to the side road
column25: or flashing red in all directions. Flashing operation can also be used during times of day when traffic is light
column26: such as late at night."

column1: 166504 Phi_Beta_Kappa "The Phi Beta Kappa Society (ΦΒΚ) is the oldest academic honor society in the United States
column2: and is often described as its most prestigious honor society
column3: due to its long history and academic selectivity. Phi Beta Kappa aims to promote and advocate excellence in the liberal arts and sciences
column4: and to induct the most outstanding students of arts and sciences at American colleges and universities. It was founded at the College of William and Mary on December 5
column5: 1776 as the first collegiate Greek-letter fraternity and was among the earliest collegiate fraternal societies.Phi Beta Kappa (ΦΒΚ) stands for Φιλοσοφία Βίου Κυβερνήτης (Philosophia Biou Kybernētēs)
column6: which means ""Love of learning is the guide of life""."

column1: 167079 Smartphone "Smartphones are a class of mobile phones and of multi-purpose mobile computing devices. They are distinguished from feature phones by their stronger hardware capabilities and extensive mobile operating systems
column2: which facilitate wider software
column3: internet (including web browsing over mobile broadband)
column4: and multimedia functionality (including music
column5: video
column6: cameras
column7: and gaming)
column8: alongside core phone functions such as voice calls and text messaging. Smartphones typically include various sensors that can be leveraged by their software
column9: such as a magnetometer
column10: proximity sensors
column11: barometer
column12: gyroscope and accelerometer
column13: and support wireless communications protocols such as Bluetooth
column14: Wi-Fi
column15: and satellite navigation. Early smartphones were marketed primarily towards the enterprise market
column16: attempting to bridge the functionality of standalone personal digital assistant (PDA) devices with support for cellular telephony
column17: but were limited by their bulky form
column18: short battery life
column19: slow analog cellular networks
column20: and the immaturity of wireless data services. These issues were eventually resolved with the exponential scaling and miniaturization of MOS transistors down to sub-micron levels (Moore's law)
column21: the improved lithium-ion battery
column22: faster digital mobile data networks (Edholm's law)
column23: and more mature software platforms that allowed mobile device ecosystems to develop independently of data providers. In the 2000s
column24: NTT DoCoMo's i-mode platform
column25: BlackBerry
column26: Nokia's Symbian platform
column27: and Windows Mobile began to gain market traction
column28: with models often featuring QWERTY keyboards or resistive touchscreen input
column29: and emphasizing access to push email and wireless internet. Since the unveiling of the iPhone in 2007
column30: the majority of smartphones have featured thin
column31: slate-like form factors
column32: with large
column33: capacitive screens with support for multi-touch gestures rather than physical keyboards
column34: and offer the ability for users to download or purchase additional applications from a centralized store
column35: and use cloud storage and synchronization
column36: virtual assistants
column37: as well as mobile payment services. Improved hardware and faster wireless communication (due to standards such as LTE) have bolstered the growth of the smartphone industry. In the third quarter of 2012
column38: one billion smartphones were in use worldwide. Global smartphone sales surpassed the sales figures for feature phones in early 2013."

column1: 168568 Film_speed "Film speed is the measure of a photographic film's sensitivity to light
column2: determined by sensitometry and measured on various numerical scales
column3: the most recent being the ISO system. A closely related ISO system is used to describe the relationship between exposure and output image lightness in digital cameras. Relatively insensitive film
column4: with a correspondingly lower speed index
column5: requires more exposure to light to produce the same image density as a more sensitive film
column6: and is thus commonly termed a slow film. Highly sensitive films are correspondingly termed fast films. In both digital and film photography
column7: the reduction of exposure corresponding to use of higher sensitivities generally leads to reduced image quality (via coarser film grain or higher image noise of other types). In short
column8: the higher the sensitivity
column9: the grainier the image will be. Ultimately sensitivity is limited by the quantum efficiency of the film or sensor."

column1: 176931 Internet_Archive "The Internet Archive is an American digital library with the stated mission of ""universal access to all knowledge."" It provides free public access to collections of digitized materials
column2: including websites
column3: software applications/games
column4: music
column5: movies/videos
column6: moving images
column7: and millions of public-domain books. In addition to its archiving function
column8: the Archive is an activist organization
column9: advocating for a free and open Internet. The Internet Archive allows the public to upload and download digital material to its data cluster
column10: but the bulk of its data is collected automatically by its web crawlers
column11: which work to preserve as much of the public web as possible. Its web archive
column12: the Wayback Machine
column13: contains hundreds of billions of web captures. The Archive also oversees one of the world's largest book digitization projects."

column1: 185239 Thermal_radiation "Thermal radiation is electromagnetic radiation generated by the thermal motion of particles in matter. All matter with a temperature greater than absolute zero emits thermal radiation. Particle motion results in charge-acceleration or dipole oscillation which produces electromagnetic radiation. The infrared radiation emitted by animals that is detectable with an infrared camera
column2: and the cosmic microwave background radiation
column3: are all examples of thermal radiation. If a radiation-emitting object meets the physical characteristics of a black body in thermodynamic equilibrium
column4: the radiation is called blackbody radiation. Planck's law describes the spectrum of blackbody radiation
column5: which depends solely on the object's temperature. Wien's displacement law determines the most likely frequency of the emitted radiation
column6: and the Stefan–Boltzmann law gives the radiant intensity.Thermal radiation is also one of the fundamental mechanisms of heat transfer."

column1: 191902 Kerosene_lamp "A kerosene lamp (also known as a paraffin lamp in some countries) is a type of lighting device that uses kerosene as a fuel. Kerosene lamps have a wick or mantle as light source
column2: protected by a glass chimney or globe; lamps may be used on a table
column3: or hand-held lanterns may be used for portable lighting. Like oil lamps
column4: they are useful for lighting without electricity
column5: such as in regions without rural electrification
column6: in electrified areas during power outages
column7: at campsites
column8: and on boats. There are three types of kerosene lamp: flat-wick
column9: central-draught (tubular round wick)
column10: and mantle lamp. Kerosene lanterns meant for portable use have a flat wick and are made in dead-flame
column11: hot-blast
column12: and cold-blast variants. Pressurized kerosene lamps use a gas mantle; these are known as Petromax
column13: Tilley lamps
column14: or Coleman lamps
column15: among other manufacturers. They produce more light per unit of fuel than wick-type lamps
column16: but are more complex and expensive in construction and more complex to operate. A hand-pump pressurizes air
column17: which forces liquid fuel from a reservoir into a gas chamber. Vapor from the chamber burns
column18: heating a mantle to incandescence and also providing heat. Kerosene lamps are widely used for lighting in rural areas of Africa and Asia
column19: where electricity is not distributed or is too costly. Kerosene lamps consume an estimated 77 billion litres of fuel per year
column20: equivalent to 1.3 million barrels of oil per day
column21: comparable to annual U.S. jet-fuel consumption of 76 billion litres per year."

column1: 195698 Wide-angle_lens "In photography and cinematography
column2: a wide-angle lens refers to a lens whose focal length is substantially smaller than the focal length of a normal lens for a given film plane. This type of lens allows more of the scene to be included in the photograph
column3: which is useful in architectural
column4: interior and landscape photography where the photographer may not be able to move farther from the scene to photograph it. Another use is where the photographer wishes to emphasise the difference in size or distance between objects in the foreground and the background; nearby objects appear very large and objects at a moderate distance appear small and far away. This exaggeration of relative size can be used to make foreground objects more prominent and striking
column5: while capturing expansive backgrounds.A wide angle lens is also one that projects a substantially larger image circle than would be typical for a standard design lens of the same focal length. This large image circle enables either large tilt & shift movements with a view camera
column6: or a wide field of view. By convention
column7: in still photography
column8: the normal lens for a particular format has a focal length approximately equal to the length of the diagonal of the image frame or digital photosensor. In cinematography
column9: a lens of roughly twice the diagonal is considered ""normal""."

column1: 195699 Telephoto_lens "In photography and cinematography
column2: a telephoto lens is a specific type of a long-focus lens in which the physical length of the lens is shorter than the focal length. This is achieved by incorporating a special lens group known as a telephoto group that extends the light path to create a long-focus lens in a much shorter overall design. The angle of view and other effects of long-focus lenses are the same for telephoto lenses of the same specified focal length. Long-focal-length lenses are often informally referred to as telephoto lenses although this is technically incorrect: a telephoto lens specifically incorporates the telephoto group.Telephoto lenses are sometimes broken into the further sub-types of short telephoto (85mm to 135mm in 35mm film format)
column3: medium telephoto: (135mm to 300mm in 35mm film format) and super telephoto (over 300mm in 35mm film format) .  "

column1: 206515 Matsu_Islands "The Matsu Islands (Chinese: 馬祖列島; pinyin: Mǎzǔ Lièdǎo; Wade–Giles: Ma³-tsu³ Lieh⁴-tao³; Foochow Romanized: Mā-cū liĕk-dō̤) are an archipelago of 36 islands and islets in the East China Sea officially named Lienchiang County (Chinese: 連江縣; pinyin: Liánjiāng Xiàn; Wade–Giles: Lien²-chiang¹ Hsien⁴; Foochow Romanized: Lièng-gŏng-gâing) in the Republic of China (Taiwan). It is the smallest county of Taiwan Area. The historical Lienchiang County included both the Matsu Islands and today's Lianjiang County of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The PRC claims the three northern townships of the Matsu Islands as Matsu Township (馬祖鄉; Mǎzǔ Xiāng; Mā-cū hiŏng) and the southernmost islands as part of Changle District."
210411 International_Democrat_Union "The International Democrat Union (IDU) is an  international alliance of centrist to centre-right political parties.  Headquartered in Munich
column2: Germany
column3: the IDU comprises 73 full and associate members from 63 different countries. It is chaired by Stephen Harper
column4: former Prime Minister of Canada. The IDU provides a forum in which political parties holding similar beliefs can come together and exchange views on matters of policy and organisational interest. From this
column5: they act cooperatively
column6: establish contacts
column7: and present a unified voice toward the promotion of centre-right policies around the globe.  The IDU has some overlap of member parties with the Centrist Democrat International (CDI)
column8: but the CDI is more centrist and communitarian than the IDU.The group was founded in 1983 as the umbrella organisation for the European Democrat Union (EDU)
column9: Caribbean Democrat Union (CDU)
column10: and the Asia Pacific Democrat Union (APDU).  Created at the instigation of the Konrad Adenauer Foundation and US Vice President George H. W. Bush
column11: the organisation was founded at a joint meeting of the EDU and APDU in London
column12: England
column13: UK.The IDU has several regional affiliates: the Democrat Union of Africa
column14: the Union of Latin American Parties
column15: the Asia Pacific Democrat Union
column16: the Caribbean Democrat Union
column17: and the European People's Party
column18: the Alliance of Conservatives and Reformists in Europe and the (dormant since 2002) European Democrat Union in Europe.  It also has an affiliated youth wing the International Young Democrat Union led by Australian Simon Breheny and an affiliated women's wing in the International Women's Democrat Union."

column1: 215567 Pink "Pink is a pale red color that is named after a flower of the same name. It was first used as a color name in the late 17th century. According to surveys in Europe and the United States
column2: pink is the color most often associated with charm
column3: politeness
column4: sensitivity
column5: tenderness
column6: sweetness
column7: childhood
column8: femininity and the romantic. A combination of pink and white is associated with chastity and innocence
column9: whereas a combination of pink and black links to eroticism and seduction."

column1: 220533 Black_and_white "Black-and-white (B/W or B&W) images combine black and white in a continuous spectrum
column2: producing a range of shades of gray."

column1: 230331 Oval_Office "The Oval Office is
column2: since 1909
column3: the working office space of the president of the United States
column4: located in the West Wing of the White House
column5: Washington
column6: D.C. Opened in 1909
column7: the room features three large south-facing windows behind the president's desk
column8: and a fireplace at the north end. It has four doors: the east door opens to the Rose Garden; the west door leads to a private study and dining room; the northwest door opens onto the main corridor of the West Wing; and the northeast door opens to the office of the president's secretary. Presidents generally decorate the office to suit their personal taste
column9: choosing new furniture
column10: new drapery
column11: and designing their own oval-shaped carpet to take up most of the floor. Artwork is selected from the White House's on collection
column12: or borrowed from museums for the president's term in office."

column1: 237365 National_colours "National colours are frequently part of a country's set of national symbols. Many states and nations have formally adopted a set of colours as their official ""national colours"" while others have de facto national colours that have become well-known through popular use. National colours often appear on a variety of different media
column2: from the nation's flag to the colours used in sports."

column1: 243594 Socialist_Party_of_America "The Socialist Party of America (SPA) was a multi-tendency democratic socialist and social democratic political party in the United States formed in 1901 by a merger between the three-year-old Social Democratic Party of America and disaffected elements of the Socialist Labor Party of America which had split from the main organization in 1899.In the first decades of the 20th century
column2: it drew significant support from many different groups
column3: including trade unionists
column4: progressive social reformers
column5: populist farmers and immigrants. However
column6: it refused to form coalitions with other parties
column7: or even to allow its members to vote for other parties. Eugene V. Debs twice won over 900
column8: 000 votes in presidential elections (1912 and 1920) while the party also elected two Representatives (Victor L. Berger and Meyer London)
column9: dozens of state legislators
column10: more than a hundred mayors and countless lesser officials. The party's staunch opposition to American involvement in World War I
column11: although welcomed by many
column12: also led to prominent defections
column13: official repression and vigilante persecution. The organization was further shattered by a factional war over how to respond to the October Revolution in Imperial Russia in 1917 and the establishment of the Communist International in 1919—many members left the party in favor of the Communist Party USA. After endorsing Robert M. La Follette's presidential campaign in 1924
column14: the party returned to independent action at the presidential level. It had modest growth in the early 1930s behind presidential candidate Norman Thomas. The party's appeal was weakened by the popularity of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal
column15: the organization and flexibility of the Communist Party under Earl Browder and the resurgent labor movement's desire to support sympathetic Democratic Party politicians. A divisive and ultimately unsuccessful attempt to broaden the party by admitting followers of Leon Trotsky and Jay Lovestone caused the traditional Old Guard to leave and form the Social Democratic Federation. While the party was always strongly anti-fascist as well as anti-Stalinist
column16: its opposition to American entry in World War II cost it both internal and external support. The party stopped running presidential candidates after 1956
column17: when its nominee Darlington Hoopes won fewer than 6
column18: 000 votes. In the party's last decades
column19: its members
column20: many of them prominent in the labor
column21: peace
column22: civil rights and civil liberties movements
column23: fundamentally disagreed about the socialist movement's relationship to the labor movement and the Democratic Party and about how best to advance democracy abroad. In 1970–1973
column24: these strategic differences had become so acute that the Socialist Party of America changed its name to Social Democrats
column25: USA. Leaders of two of its caucuses formed separate socialist organizations
column26: namely the Socialist Party USA and the Democratic Socialist Organizing Committee
column27: the latter of which became a precursor to the largest present-day socialist organization in the United States
column28: the Democratic Socialists of America."

column1: 291260 Underwater_photography "Underwater photography is the process of taking photographs while under water. It is usually done while scuba diving
column2: but can be done while diving on surface supply
column3: snorkeling
column4: swimming
column5: from a submersible or remotely operated underwater vehicle
column6: or from automated cameras lowered from the surface. Underwater photography can also be categorised as an art form and a method for recording data.  Successful underwater imaging is usually done with specialized equipment and techniques. However
column7: it offers exciting and rare photographic opportunities. Animals such as fish and marine mammals are common subjects
column8: but photographers also pursue shipwrecks
column9: submerged cave systems
column10: underwater ""landscapes""
column11: invertebrates
column12: seaweeds
column13: geological features
column14: and portraits of fellow divers."

column1: 298129 Little_Rock_Central_High_School "Little Rock Central High School (LRCHS) is an accredited comprehensive public high school in Little Rock
column2: Arkansas
column3: United States. The school was the site of forced desegregation in 1957 after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional three years earlier. This was during the period of heightened activism in the civil rights movement.Central is located at the intersection of Park Street and Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street). Bates was an African-American journalist and state NAACP president who played a key role in bringing about
column4: through the 1957 crisis
column5: the integration of the school. Central can trace its origins to 1869 when the Sherman School operated in a wooden structure at 8th and Sherman streets; it graduated its first class on June 13
column6: 1873. In 1885 the Sherman School was moved to 14th and Scott streets and was named Scott Street School
column7: but was more commonly called City High School.  Five years later in 1890
column8: the Peabody School was constructed at West Capitol and Gaines streets. It was named in honor of philanthropist George Peabody from US$200
column9: 000 received via the Peabody Education Fund. In 1905
column10: the city founded Little Rock High School at the intersection of 14th and Cumberland streets
column11: and shuttered the Peabody and Scott Street schools to serve as the city's sole public high school. At the time only white students were enrolled. In 1927 at a cost of US$1.5 million
column12: the city completed construction on the nation's largest and most expensive high school facility
column13: which remains in use today. In 1953 with the construction of Hall High School
column14: the school was renamed as Little Rock Central High School. It has since been listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places and named as a U.S. National Historic Landmark and National Historic Site. Central High School
column15: which covers grades 9 through 12
column16: has an enrollment of 2
column17: 456 (2010–11). It is in the Little Rock School District. The current principal is Nancy Rousseau
column18: who became principal in 2002."

column1: 307316 Prohibition_Party "The Prohibition Party (PRO) is a political party in the United States best known for its historic opposition to the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages. It is the oldest existing third party in the US. The party is an integral part of the temperance movement. While never one of the leading parties in the United States
column2: it was once an important force in the Third Party System during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It declined dramatically after the repeal of Prohibition in 1933. The party's candidate received 518 votes in the 2012 presidential election and 5
column3: 617 votes in the 2016 presidential election. The platform of the party is liberal in that it supports environmental stewardship and free education
column4: but is conservative on social issues
column5: such as supporting temperance and advocating for an anti-abortion stance."

column1: 326279 Aerial_photography "Aerial photography (or airborne imagery) is the taking of photographs from an aircraft or other flying object. Platforms for aerial photography include fixed-wing aircraft
column2: helicopters
column3: unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs or ""drones"")
column4: balloons
column5: blimps and dirigibles
column6: rockets
column7: pigeons
column8: kites
column9: parachutes
column10: stand-alone telescoping and vehicle-mounted poles. Mounted cameras may be triggered remotely or automatically; hand-held photographs may be taken by a photographer. Aerial photography should not be confused with air-to-air photography
column11: where one or more aircraft are used as chase planes that ""chase"" and photograph other aircraft in flight."

column1: 343261 Mug_shot "A mug shot or mugshot (an informal term for police photograph or booking photograph) is a photographic portrait of a person from the waist up
column2: typically taken after a person is arrested. The original purpose of the mug shot was to allow law enforcement to have a photographic record of an arrested individual to allow for identification purposes by victims
column3: the public and investigators. However
column4: in the United States
column5: entrepreneurs have recently begun to monetize these public records via the mug shot publishing industry. Photographing of criminals began in the 1840s only a few years after the invention of photography
column6: but it was not until 1888 that French police officer Alphonse Bertillon standardized the process."

column1: 352711 Zoom_lens "A zoom lens is a mechanical assembly of lens elements for which the focal length (and thus angle of view) can be varied
column2: as opposed to a fixed focal length (FFL) lens (see prime lens). A true zoom lens
column3: also called a parfocal lens
column4: is one that maintains focus when its focal length changes.. Most consumer zoom lenses do not maintain perfect focus
column5: but are still parfocal designs.  The convenience of variable focal length comes at the cost of complexity – and some compromises on image quality
column6: weight
column7: dimensions
column8: aperture
column9: autofocus performance
column10: and cost. For example
column11: all zoom lenses suffer from at least slight
column12: if not considerable
column13: loss of image resolution at their maximum aperture
column14: especially at the extremes of their focal length range. This effect is evident in the corners of the image
column15: when displayed in a large format or high resolution. The greater the range of focal length a zoom lens offers
column16: the more exaggerated these compromises must become."

column1: 362823 Large_format "Large format refers to any imaging format of 4×5 inches (102×127 mm)  or larger. Large format is larger than ""medium format""
column2: the 6×6 cm (2¼×2¼ inch) or 6×9 cm (2¼×3½ inch) size of Hasselblad
column3: Mamiya
column4: Rollei
column5: Kowa
column6: and Pentax cameras (using 120- and 220-roll film)
column7: and much larger than the 24×36 mm (0.95×1.42 inch) frame of 35 mm format. The main advantage of large format
column8: film or digital
column9: is a higher resolution at the same pixel pitch
column10: or the same resolution with larger pixels or grains. A 4×5 inch image has about 15 times the area
column11: and thus 15× the total resolution
column12: of a 35 mm frame. Large format cameras were some of the earliest photographic devices
column13: and before enlargers were common
column14: it was normal to just make 1:1 contact prints from a 4×5
column16: or 8×10-inch negative."

column1: 368995 Tincture_(heraldry) "Tinctures constitute the limited palette of colours and patterns used in heraldry. The need to define
column2: depict
column3: and correctly blazon the various tinctures is one of the most important aspects of heraldic art and design."

column1: 376458 Emilio_Segr%C3%A8 "Emilio Gino Segrè (1 February 1905 – 22 April 1989) was an Italian-American physicist and Nobel laureate
column2: who discovered the elements technetium and astatine
column3: and the antiproton
column4: a subatomic antiparticle
column5: for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1959. From 1943 to 1946 he worked at the Los Alamos National Laboratory as a group leader for the Manhattan Project. He found in April 1944 that Thin Man
column6: the proposed plutonium gun-type nuclear weapon
column7: would not work because of the presence of plutonium-240 impurities. Born in Tivoli
column8: near Rome
column9: Segrè studied engineering at the University of Rome La Sapienza before taking up physics in 1927. Segrè was appointed assistant professor of physics at the University of Rome in 1932 and worked there until 1936
column10: becoming one of the Via Panisperna boys. From 1936 to 1938 he was director of the Physics Laboratory at the University of Palermo. After a visit to Ernest O. Lawrence's Berkeley Radiation Laboratory
column11: he was sent a molybdenum strip from the laboratory's cyclotron deflector in 1937
column12: which was emitting anomalous forms of radioactivity. After careful chemical and theoretical analysis
column13: Segrè was able to prove that some of the radiation was being produced by a previously unknown element
column14: named technetium
column15: which was the first artificially synthesized chemical element that does not occur in nature. In 1938
column16: Benito Mussolini's fascist government passed anti-Semitic laws barring Jews from university positions. As a Jew
column17: Segrè was now rendered an indefinite émigré. At the Berkeley Radiation Lab
column18: Lawrence offered him a job as a research assistant. While at Berkeley
column19: Segrè helped discover the element astatine and the isotope plutonium-239
column20: which was later used to make the Fat Man nuclear bomb dropped on Nagasaki. In 1944
column21: he became a naturalized citizen of the United States. On his return to Berkeley in 1946
column22: he became a professor of physics and of history of science
column23: serving until 1972. Segrè and Owen Chamberlain were co-heads of a research group at the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory that discovered the antiproton
column24: for which the two shared the 1959 Nobel Prize in Physics. Segrè was also active as a photographer and took many photographs documenting events and people in the history of modern science
column25: which were donated to the American Institute of Physics after his death. The American Institute of Physics named its photographic archive of physics history in his honor."

column1: 379518 Panoramic_photography "Panoramic photography is a technique of photography
column2: using specialized equipment or software
column3: that captures images with horizontally elongated fields of view. It is sometimes known as wide format photography. The term has also been applied to a photograph that is cropped to a relatively wide aspect ratio
column4: like the familiar letterbox format in wide-screen video. While there is no formal division between ""wide-angle"" and ""panoramic"" photography
column5: ""wide-angle"" normally refers to a type of lens
column6: but using this lens type does not necessarily make an image a panorama. An image made with an ultra wide-angle fisheye lens covering the normal film frame of 1:1.33 is not automatically considered to be a panorama. An image showing a field of view approximating
column7: or greater than
column8: that of the human eye – about 160° by 75° – may be termed panoramic. This generally means it has an aspect ratio of 2:1 or larger
column9: the image being at least twice as wide as it is high. The resulting images take the form of a wide strip. Some panoramic images have aspect ratios of 4:1 and sometimes 10:1
column10: covering fields of view of up to 360 degrees. Both the aspect ratio and coverage of field are important factors in defining a true panoramic image.  Photo-finishers and manufacturers of Advanced Photo System (APS) cameras use the word ""panoramic"" to define any print format with a wide aspect ratio
column11: not necessarily photos that encompass a large field of view."

column1: 407044 Negative_(photography) "In photography
column2: a negative is an image
column3: usually on a strip or sheet of transparent plastic film
column4: in which the lightest areas of the photographed subject appear darkest and the darkest areas appear lightest. This reversed order occurs because the extremely light-sensitive chemicals a camera film must use to capture an image quickly enough for ordinary picture-taking are darkened
column5: rather than bleached
column6: by exposure to light and subsequent photographic processing. In the case of color negatives
column7: the colors are also reversed into their respective complementary colors. Typical color negatives have an overall dull orange tint due to an automatic color-masking feature that ultimately results in improved color reproduction. Negatives are normally used to make positive prints on photographic paper by projecting the negative onto the paper with a photographic enlarger or making a contact print. The paper is also darkened in proportion to its exposure to light
column8: so a second reversal results which restores light and dark to their normal order. Negatives were once commonly made on a thin sheet of glass rather than a plastic film
column9: and some of the earliest negatives were made on paper. It is incorrect to call an image a negative solely because it is on a transparent material. Transparent prints can be made by printing a negative onto special positive film
column10: as is done to make traditional motion picture film prints for use in theaters. Some films used in cameras are designed to be developed by reversal processing
column11: which produces the final positive
column12: instead of a negative
column13: on the original film. Positives on film or glass are known as transparencies or diapositives
column14: and if mounted in small frames designed for use in a slide projector or magnifying viewer they are commonly called slides."

column1: 422994 Digital_object_identifier "In computing
column2: a digital object identifier (DOI) is a persistent identifier or handle used to identify objects uniquely
column3: standardized by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). An implementation of the Handle System
column4: DOIs are in wide use mainly to identify academic
column5: professional
column6: and government information
column7: such as journal articles
column8: research reports and data sets
column9: and official publications though they also have been used to identify other types of information resources
column10: such as commercial videos. A DOI aims to be ""resolvable""
column11: usually to some form of access to the information object to which the DOI refers. This is achieved by binding the DOI to metadata about the object
column12: such as a URL
column13: indicating where the object can be found. Thus
column14: by being actionable and interoperable
column15: a DOI differs from identifiers such as ISBNs and ISRCs which aim only to identify their referents uniquely. The DOI system uses the indecs Content Model for representing metadata. The DOI for a document remains fixed over the lifetime of the document
column16: whereas its location and other metadata may change. Referring to an online document by its DOI is supposed to provide a more stable link than simply using its URL. But every time a URL changes
column17: the publisher has to update the metadata for the DOI to link to the new URL. It is the publisher's responsibility to update the DOI database. If they fail to do so
column18: the DOI resolves to a dead link leaving the DOI useless. The developer and administrator of the DOI system is the International DOI Foundation (IDF)
column19: which introduced it in 2000. Organizations that meet the contractual obligations of the DOI system and are willing to pay to become a member of the system can assign DOIs. The DOI system is implemented through a federation of registration agencies coordinated by the IDF. By late April 2011 more than 50 million DOI names had been assigned by some 4
column20: 000 organizations
column21: and by April 2013 this number had grown to 85 million DOI names assigned through 9
column22: 500 organizations."

column1: 423388 Political_colour "Political colours are colours used to represent a political ideology
column2: movement or party
column3: either officially or unofficially. Parties in different countries with similar ideologies sometimes use similar colours. For example
column4: the colour red symbolises left-wing ideologies in many countries (see the red flag
column5: Red Army and Red Scare) while the colour yellow is most commonly associated with liberalism and right-libertarianism.  However
column6: the political associations of a given colour vary from country to country: red is also the colour associated with the conservative Republican Party in the United States. Politicians making public appearances will often identify themselves by wearing rosettes
column7: flowers or ties in the colour of their political party."

column1: 444758 Color_photography "Color photography is photography that uses media capable of reproducing colors. By contrast
column2: black-and-white (monochrome) photography records only a single channel of luminance (brightness) and uses media capable only of showing shades of gray. In color photography
column3: electronic sensors or light-sensitive chemicals record color information at the time of exposure. This is usually done by analyzing the spectrum of colors into three channels of information
column4: one dominated by red
column5: another by green and the third by blue
column6: in imitation of the way the normal human eye senses color. The recorded information is then used to reproduce the original colors by mixing various proportions of red
column7: green and blue light (RGB color
column8: used by video displays
column9: digital projectors and some historical photographic processes)
column10: or by using dyes or pigments to remove various proportions of the red
column11: green and blue which are present in white light (CMY color
column12: used for prints on paper and transparencies on film). Monochrome images which have been ""colorized"" by tinting selected areas by hand or mechanically or with the aid of a computer are ""colored photographs""
column13: not ""color photographs"". Their colors are not dependent on the actual colors of the objects photographed and may be inaccurate. The foundation of virtually all practical color processes
column14: the three-color method was first suggested in an 1855 paper by Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell
column15: with the first color photograph produced by Thomas Sutton for a Maxwell lecture in 1861.  Color photography has been the dominant form of photography since the 1970s
column16: with monochrome photography mostly relegated to niche markets such as art photography."

column1: 474909 Rudolf_Abel "Rudolf Ivanovich Abel (Russian: Рудольф Иванович Абель)
column2: real name  William August Fisher (July 11
column3: 1903 – November 15
column4: 1971) was a Soviet intelligence officer. He adopted his alias when arrested on charges of conspiracy by FBI agents in 1957. Fisher was born in the United Kingdom to Russian émigré parents.  He moved to Russia in the 1920s
column5: and served in the Soviet military before undertaking foreign service as a radio operator in Soviet intelligence in the late 1920s and early 1930s. He later served in an instructional role before taking part in intelligence operations against the Germans during World War II. After the war
column6: he began working for the KGB
column7: which sent him to the United States where he worked as part of a spy ring based in New York City. In 1957
column8: the U.S. Federal Court in New York convicted Fisher on three counts of conspiracy as a Soviet spy for his involvement in what became known as the Hollow Nickel Case and sentenced him to 30 years' imprisonment at Atlanta Federal Penitentiary
column9: Georgia. He served just over four years of his sentence before he was exchanged for captured American U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers. Back in the Soviet Union
column10: he lectured on his experiences. He died in 1971 at the age of 68."

column1: 505605 John_Wooden "John Robert Wooden (October 14
column2: 1910 – June 4
column3: 2010) was an American basketball player and head coach at the University of California
column4: Los Angeles. Nicknamed the ""Wizard of Westwood
column5: he won ten NCAA national championships in a 12-year period as head coach at UCLA
column6: including a record seven in a row. No other team has won more than four in a row in Division 1 college men's or women's basketball. Within this period
column7: his teams won an NCAA men's basketball record 88 consecutive games. Wooden won the prestigious Henry Iba Award as national coach of the year a record seven times and won the AP award five times. He also won a Helms national championship (which was decided by a poll) at Purdue as a player 1931–1932. As a 5'10"" guard
column8: Wooden was the first player to be named basketball All-American three times
column9: and the 1932 Purdue team on which he played as a senior was retroactively recognized as the pre-NCAA Tournament national champion by the Helms Athletic Foundation and the Premo-Porretta Power Poll. column13: among them Lew Alcindor (later Kareem Abdul-Jabbar) and Bill Walton. Wooden was renowned for his short
column14: simple inspirational messages to his players
column15: including his ""Pyramid of Success."" These often were directed at how to be a success in life as well as in basketball. Wooden's 29-year coaching career and overwhelmingly positive critical acclaim have created a legacy of great interest in not only sports
column16: but in business
column17: personal success
column18: and organizational leadership as well."

column1: 575590 Navy_blue "Navy blue is a very dark shade of the color blue.  Navy blue got its name from the dark blue (contrasted with naval white) worn by officers in the British Royal Navy since 1748 and subsequently adopted by other navies around the world. When this color name
column2: taken from the usual color of the uniforms of sailors
column3: originally came into use in the early 19th century
column4: it was initially called marine blue
column5: but the name of the color soon changed to navy blue.An early use of navy blue as a color name in English was in 1840 though the Oxford English Dictionary has a citation from 1813. In practice

column7: in order to combat fading.  "

column1: 645042 New_York_City "The City of New York

column5: 748 distributed over a land area of about 302.6 square miles (784 km2)

column9: with an estimated 19
column11: 477 people in its 2018 Metropolitan Statistical Area and 22
column13: 948 residents in its Combined Statistical Area. A global power city
column14: New York City has been described as the cultural
column15: financial
column16: and media capital of the world
column17: and exerts a significant impact upon commerce
column18: entertainment
column19: research
column20: technology
column21: education
column22: politics
column23: tourism
column24: art
column25: fashion

The city and its surroundings came under English control in 1664 and were renamed New York after King Charles II of England granted the lands to his brother
column38: the Duke of York. New York was the capital of the United States from 1785 until 1790
column39: and has been the largest US city since 1790. The Statue of Liberty greeted millions of immigrants as they came to the U.S. by ship in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and is an international symbol of the U.S. and its ideals of liberty and peace. In the 21st century
column40: New York has emerged as a global node of creativity and entrepreneurship
column42: and environmental sustainability
column43: and as a symbol of freedom and cultural diversity. In 2019
column44: New York was voted the greatest city in the world per a survey of over 30
column45: 000 people from 48 cities worldwide

column56: with 472 rail stations. The city has over 120 colleges and universities

column1: 676646 The_Night_Watch "Militia Company of District II under the Command of Captain Frans Banninck Cocq
column2: also known as The Shooting Company of Frans Banning Cocq and Willem van Ruytenburch
column3: but commonly referred to as The Night Watch (Dutch: De Nachtwacht)
column4: is a 1642 painting by Rembrandt van Rijn. It is in the collection of the Amsterdam Museum but is prominently displayed in the Rijksmuseum as the best-known painting in its collection. The Night Watch is one of the most famous Dutch Golden Age paintings. The painting is famous for three things: its colossal size (363 cm × 437 cm (11.91 ft × 14.34 ft))
column5: the dramatic use of light and shadow (tenebrism) and the perception of motion in what would have traditionally been a static military group portrait.  The painting was completed in 1642
column6: at the peak of the Dutch Golden Age. It depicts the eponymous company moving out
column7: led by Captain Frans Banninck Cocq (dressed in black
column8: with a red sash) and his lieutenant
column9: Willem van Ruytenburch (dressed in yellow
column10: with a white sash). With effective use of sunlight and shade
column11: Rembrandt leads the eye to the three most important characters among the crowd: the two men in the center (from whom the painting gets its original title)
column12: and the woman in the centre-left background carrying a chicken. Behind them
column13: the company's colors are carried by the ensign
column14: Jan Visscher Cornelissen.  The figures are almost life-size. Rembrandt has displayed the traditional emblem of the arquebusiers in a natural way
column15: with the woman in the background carrying the main symbols. She is a kind of mascot herself; the claws of a dead chicken on her belt represent the clauweniers (arquebusiers)
column16: the pistol behind the chicken represents clover and she is holding the militia's goblet. The man in front of her is wearing a helmet with an oak leaf
column17: a traditional motif of the arquebusiers. The dead chicken is also meant to represent a defeated adversary. The colour yellow is often associated with victory. In July 2019 a long and complex restoration began. The restoration is taking place in public
column18: in a specially-made glass enclosure built and placed in the Rijksmuseum
column19: and is being livestreamed. The plan was to move the 337kg painting into it starting when the museum closed for the day on 9 July
column20: then to map the painting ""layer by layer and pigment by pigment""
column21: and plan conservation work according to what was found. As the painting has always been on display
column22: even those who knew it best had much to learn. Taco Dibbits
column23: the Rijksmuseum's general director
column24: said that despite working there for 17 years he had never seen the top of the painting; ""We know so little on how he worked on making The Night Watch""."

column1: 698830 Street_light "A street light
column2: light pole
column3: lamppost
column4: street lamp
column5: light standard or lamp standard is a raised source of light on the edge of a road or path. When urban electric power distribution became ubiquitous in developed countries in the 20th century
column6: lights for urban streets followed
column7: or sometimes led. Many lamps have light-sensitive photocells that activate automatically when light is or is not needed: dusk
column8: dawn
column9: or the onset of dark weather. This function in older lighting systems could have been performed with the aid of a solar dial. Many street light systems are being connected underground instead of wiring from one utility post to another."

column1: 726748 Black-body_radiation "Black-body radiation is the thermal electromagnetic radiation within or surrounding a body in thermodynamic equilibrium with its environment
column2: emitted by a black body (an idealized opaque
column3: non-reflective body).  It has a specific spectrum of wavelengths
column4: inversely related to intensity that depend only on the body's temperature
column5: which is assumed for the sake of calculations and theory to be uniform and constant.The thermal radiation spontaneously emitted by many ordinary objects can be approximated as black-body radiation.  A perfectly insulated enclosure that is in thermal equilibrium internally contains black-body radiation and will emit it through a hole made in its wall
column6: provided the hole is small enough to have negligible effect upon the equilibrium. A black body at room temperature appears black
column7: as most of the energy it radiates is in the infrared spectrum and cannot be perceived by the human eye. Since the human eye cannot perceive light waves below the visible frequency
column8: a black body
column9: viewed in the dark at the lowest just faintly visible temperature
column10: subjectively appears grey
column11: even though its objective physical spectrum peak is in the infrared range. When it becomes a little hotter
column12: it appears dull red. As its temperature increases further it becomes yellow
column13: white
column14: and ultimately blue-white. Although planets and stars are neither in thermal equilibrium with their surroundings nor perfect black bodies
column15: black-body radiation is used as a first approximation for the energy they emit. Black holes are near-perfect black bodies
column16: in the sense that they absorb all the radiation that falls on them. It has been proposed that they emit black-body radiation (called Hawking radiation)
column17: with a temperature that depends on the mass of the black hole.The term black body was introduced by Gustav Kirchhoff in 1860. Black-body radiation is also called thermal radiation
column18: cavity radiation
column19: complete radiation or temperature radiation.  "

column1: 850048 Gas_lighting "Gas lighting is production of artificial light from combustion of a gaseous fuel
column2: such as hydrogen
column3: methane
column4: carbon monoxide
column5: propane
column6: butane
column7: acetylene
column8: ethylene
column9: or natural gas. The light is produced either directly by the flame
column10: generally by using special mixes of illuminating gas to increase brightness
column11: or indirectly with other components such as the gas mantle or the limelight
column12: with the gas primarily functioning as a fuel source. Before electricity became sufficiently widespread and economical to allow for general public use
column13: gas was the most popular method of outdoor and indoor lighting in cities and suburbs. Early gas lights were ignited manually
column14: but many later designs are self-igniting. Gas lighting now is generally used for camping
column15: where the high energy density of a hydrocarbon fuel
column16: combined with the modular nature of canisters (a strong metal container) allows bright and long lasting light to be produced cheaply and without complex equipment.  In addition
column17: some urban historical districts retain gas street lighting
column18: and gas lighting is used indoors or outdoors to create or preserve a nostalgic effect."

column1: 875488 World_War_I_Victory_Medal_(United_States) "The World War I Victory Medal (originally known as the Victory Medal) was a United States World War I service medal designed by James Earle Fraser.Award of a common allied service medal was recommended by an inter-allied committee in March 1919. Each allied nation would design a 'Victory Medal' for award to their military personnel
column2: all issues having certain common features
column3: including a winged figure of victory on the obverse and the same ribbon.The Victory Medal was originally intended to be established by an act of Congress. The bill authorizing the medal never passed
column4: however
column5: thus leaving the military departments to establish it through general orders. The War Department published orders in April 1919
column6: and the Navy in June of the same year."

column1: 1061913 Chromotherapy "Chromotherapy
column2: sometimes called color therapy
column3: colorology or cromatherapy
column4: is an alternative medicine method

column7: emotional
column8: spiritual
column9: or mental levels. Color therapy is distinct from other types of light therapy

column11: which are scientifically accepted medical treatments for a number of conditions
column12: as well as from photobiology

column15: peer-reviewed research."
