column1: 1687680 Pope_Francis "Pope Francis (Latin: Franciscus; Italian: Francesco; Spanish: Francisco; born Jorge Mario Bergoglio; 17 December 1936) is the head of the Catholic Church and sovereign of the Vatican City State. Francis is the first Jesuit pope
column2: the first from the Americas
column3: the first from the Southern Hemisphere
column4: and the first pope from outside Europe since the Syrian Gregory III
column5: who reigned in the 8th century. Born in Buenos Aires
column6: Argentina
column7: Bergoglio was ordained a Catholic priest in 1969
column8: and from 1973 to 1979 was Argentina's provincial superior of the Society of Jesus (Jesuits). He became the archbishop of Buenos Aires in 1998 and was created a cardinal in 2001 by Pope John Paul II. He led the Argentine Church during the December 2001 riots in Argentina. The administrations of Néstor Kirchner and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner considered him a political rival. Following the resignation of Pope Benedict XVI on 28 February 2013
column9: a papal conclave elected Bergoglio as his successor on 13 March. He chose Francis as his papal name in honor of Saint Francis of Assisi. Throughout his public life
column10: Pope Francis has been noted for his humility
column11: emphasis on God's mercy
column12: international visibility as pope
column13: concern for the poor and commitment to interfaith dialogue. He is credited with having a less formal approach to the papacy than his predecessors
column14: for instance choosing to reside in the Domus Sanctae Marthae guesthouse rather than in the papal apartments of the Apostolic Palace used by previous popes. He maintains that the Church should be more open and welcoming. He does not support unbridled capitalism
column15: Marxism
column16: or Marxist versions of liberation theology. Francis maintains the traditional views of the Church regarding abortion
column17: marriage
column18: ordination of women
column19: and clerical celibacy. He opposes consumerism and overdevelopment
column20: and supports taking action on climate change
column21: a focus of his papacy with the promulgation of Laudato si'. In international diplomacy
column22: he helped to temporarily restore full diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba and supported the cause of refugees during the European and Central American migrant crises. Since 2018
column23: he has been a vocal opponent of neo-nationalism. Francis has faced increasingly open criticism
column24: particularly from theological conservatives
column25: on many questions
column26: including the admission of civilly divorced and remarried Catholics to Communion with the publication of Amoris laetitia and on the question of the alleged cover-up of clergy sexual abuse
column27: against which he promulgated Vos estis lux mundi."

column1: 1866009 Environmentalism "Environmentalism or environmental rights is a broad philosophy
column2: ideology
column3: and social movement regarding concerns for environmental protection and improvement of the health of the environment
column4: particularly as the measure for this health seeks to incorporate the impact of changes to the environment on humans
column5: animals
column6: plants and non-living matter. While environmentalism focuses more on the environmental and nature-related aspects of green ideology and politics

column8: restoration and/or improvement of the natural environment and critical earth system elements or processes such as the climate
column9: and may be referred to as a movement to control pollution or protect plant and animal diversity. For this reason
column10: concepts such as a land ethic
column11: environmental ethics
column12: biodiversity
column13: ecology
column14: and the biophilia hypothesis figure predominantly. At its crux
column15: environmentalism is an attempt to balance relations between humans and the various natural systems on which they depend in such a way that all the components are accorded a proper degree of sustainability. The exact measures and outcomes of this balance is controversial and there are many different ways for environmental concerns to be expressed in practice. Environmentalism and environmental concerns are often represented by the colour green
column16: but this association has been appropriated by the marketing industries for the tactic known as greenwashing. Environmentalism is opposed by anti-environmentalism
column17: which says that the Earth is less fragile than some environmentalists maintain
column18: and portrays environmentalism as overreacting to the human contribution to climate change or opposing human advancement."

column1: 2269463 Thermonuclear_weapon "A thermonuclear weapon
column2: or fusion weapon (generally called a hydrogen bomb)
column3: is a second-generation nuclear weapon design. Its greater sophistication affords it vastly greater destructive power than first-generation atomic bombs
column4: a more compact size
column5: a lower mass or a combination of these benefits. Characteristics of nuclear fusion reactions make possible the use of non-fissile depleted uranium as the weapon's main fuel
column6: thus allowing more efficient use of scarce fissile material (such as U-235 and Pu-239). Modern fusion weapons consist essentially of two main components: a nuclear fission primary stage (fueled by uranium-235 or plutonium-239) and a separate nuclear fusion secondary stage containing thermonuclear fuel: the heavy hydrogen isotopes deuterium and tritium
column7: or in modern weapons lithium deuteride. For this reason
column8: thermonuclear weapons are often colloquially called hydrogen bombs or H-bombs.A fusion explosion begins with the detonation of the fission primary stage. Its temperature soars past approximately one hundred million kelvins
column9: causing it to glow intensely with thermal X-radiation. These X-rays flood the void (the ""radiation channel"" often filled with polystyrene foam) between the primary and secondary assemblies placed within an enclosure called a radiation case
column10: which confines the X-ray energy and resists its outward pressure. The distance separating the two assemblies ensures that debris fragments from the fission primary (which move much slower than X-ray photons) cannot disassemble the secondary before the fusion explosion runs to completion. The secondary fusion stage—consisting of outer pusher/tamper
column11: fusion fuel filler and central plutonium spark plug—is imploded by the X-ray energy impinging on its pusher/tamper. This compresses the entire secondary stage and drives up the density of the plutonium spark plug. The density of the plutonium fuel rises to such an extent that the spark plug is driven into a supercritical state
column12: and it begins a nuclear fission chain reaction. The fission products so produced heat the highly compressed
column13: and thus superdense
column14: thermonuclear fuel surrounding the spark plug to the region of some three hundred million Kelvins
column15: igniting fusion reactions between fusion fuel nuclei. In modern weapons fueled by lithium deuteride
column16: the fissioning plutonium spark plug also emits free neutrons which collide with lithium nuclei and supply the tritium component of the thermonuclear fuel. The secondary's relatively massive tamper (which resists outward expansion as the explosion proceeds) also serves as a thermal barrier to keep the fusion fuel filler from becoming too hot
column17: which would spoil the compression. If made of uranium
column18: enriched uranium or plutonium
column19: the tamper captures fast fusion neutrons and undergoes fission itself
column20: increasing the overall explosive yield. Additionally
column21: in most designs the radiation case is also constructed of a fissile material that undergoes fission driven by fast thermonuclear neutrons. Such bombs are classified as three stage weapons
column22: and most current Teller–Ulam designs are such fission-fusion-fission weapons. Fast fission of the tamper and radiation case is the main contribution to the total yield and is the dominant process that produces radioactive fission product fallout.The first full-scale thermonuclear test was carried out by the United States in 1952; the concept has since been employed by most of the world's nuclear powers in the design of their weapons. The design of all modern thermonuclear weapons in the United States is known as the Teller–Ulam configuration for its two chief contributors
column23: Edward Teller and Stanislaw Ulam
column24: who developed it in 1951 for the United States
column25: with certain concepts developed with the contribution of physicist John von Neumann. Similar devices were developed by the Soviet Union
column26: United Kingdom
column27: France
column28: and China.  As thermonuclear weapons represent the most efficient design for weapon energy yield in weapons with yields above 50 kilotons of TNT (210 TJ)
column29: virtually all the nuclear weapons of this size deployed by the five nuclear-weapon states under the Non-Proliferation Treaty today are thermonuclear weapons using the Teller–Ulam design."

column1: 2452325 Fine-art_photography "Fine-art photography is photography created in accordance with the vision of the artist as a photographer
column2: using photography as a medium to bring something to life that only lives in the artist's mind. Simply capturing what one sees in an artistic way is the art of photography and not creating fine art. The goal of fine-art photography is to express an idea
column3: a message
column4: or an emotion. This stands in contrast to representational photography
column5: such as photojournalism
column6: which provides a documentary visual account of specific subjects and events
column7: literally representing objective reality rather than the subjective intent of the photographer; and commercial photography
column8: the primary focus of which is to advertise products or services."

column1: 2676242 Republican_Study_Committee "The Republican Study Committee (RSC) is a caucus of conservative members of the Republican Party in the United States House of Representatives. Although the primary functions of the RSC vary from year to year
column2: it has always pushed for significant cuts in non-defense spending
column3: spearheaded efforts to pass free trade agreements
column4: advocated socially conservative legislation
column5: and supported the right to keep and bear arms. It has proposed an alternative budget every year since 1995. In 2007
column6: in conjunction with the unveiling of its ""Taxpayer Bill of Rights""
column7: it presented an alternative budget resolution that claimed would balance the budget within five years without increasing income taxes.Entering the 116th United States Congress
column8: the RSC is the largest ideological caucus in Congress of either party."

column1: 2984782 Hot_shoe "A hot shoe is a mounting point on the top of a camera to attach a flash unit and other compatible accessories. It takes the form of an angled metal bracket surrounding a metal contact point which shorts an electrical connection between camera and accessory for standard
column2: brand-independent flash synchronization. The hot shoe is a development of the standardised ""accessory shoe""
column3: with no flash contacts
column4: formerly fitted to cameras to hold accessories such as a rangefinder
column5: or flash connected by a cable. The dimensions of the hot shoe are defined by the International Organization for Standardization in ISO 518:2006. Details such as trigger voltage are not standardised; electrical incompatibilities are still possible between brands.  "

column1: 3031811 Oregon_Republican_Party "The Oregon Republican Party is the state affiliate of the United States Republican Party in Oregon
column2: headquartered in Wilsonville. The party was established in the Oregon Territory in February 1857 as the ""Free State Republican Party of Oregon"" and held its first state convention after Oregon's admission to the union on April 1
column3: 1859. The Republican Party was the dominant political organization in the state of Oregon from the time of the American Civil War through the decade of the 1960s
column4: before moving to a position of approximate parity with the rival Democratic Party of Oregon for the next four decades. During the 21st Century the Oregon Republican Party has generally assumed the role of minority party in state government
column5: with majorities of Congressional delegations
column6: elected statewide officials
column7: and legislative majorities generally controlled by the Democrats. The Oregon Republican Party's fiscal conservative platform calls for limited government
column8: lower taxes
column9: defense of individual rights. The social conservative platform opposes abortion
column10: physician-assisted suicide
column11: and same-sex marriage
column12: which indicates a belief that human life begins from the moment of conception."

column1: 3188407 Republican_Main_Street_Partnership "The Republican Main Street Partnership is a group of moderately conservative members of the United States Republican Party within the United States Congress
column2: somewhat similar to the Blue Dog Democrats.The Republican Main Street Partnership presents what it describes as centrist Republican solutions. According to the group
column3: its members advocate for conservative pragmatic government and legislators who govern in the Republican tradition as ""solutions-oriented fiscal realists"" who advance policies with bipartisan support.  "

column1: 3428791 Blue_hour "The blue hour (from French l'heure bleue; pronounced [lœʁ blø]) is the period of twilight (in the morning or evening
column2: around the nautical stage) when the Sun is at a significant depth below the horizon and residual
column3: indirect sunlight takes on a predominantly blue shade
column4: which differs from the one visible during most of a clear day
column5: which is caused by Rayleigh scattering. The blue hour occurs when the Sun is far enough below the horizon so that the sunlight's blue wavelengths dominate due to the Chappuis absorption caused by ozone. Since the term is colloquial
column6: it lacks an official definition similar to dawn
column7: dusk
column8: and the three stages of twilight. Rather
column9: it refers to a state of natural lighting that usually occurs around the nautical stage of the twilight period (at dawn or dusk)."

column1: 3482895 Georgia_Republican_Party "This article is on the political party of the U.S. state of Georgia. For a political party in the Caucasian nation of Georgia
column2: see Republican Party of Georgia.The Georgia Republican Party is one of the two major political parties in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is affiliated with the United States Republican Party (GOP)."

column1: 3538046 Rule_of_tincture "The most basic rule of heraldic design is the rule of tincture: metal should not be put on metal
column2: nor colour on colour (Humphrey Llwyd
column3: 1568). This means that or and argent (gold and silver
column4: represented by yellow and white) may not be placed on each other; nor may any of the colours (i.e. azure
column5: gules
column6: sable
column7: vert and purpure
column8: along with some other rarer examples) be placed on another colour. Heraldic furs (i.e. ermine
column9: vair and their variants) as well as ""proper"" (a charge coloured as it normally is in nature -- although that may be as defined by heralds) are exempt from the rule of tincture. The rule seems to have operated from the inception of the age of heraldry
column11: but seemingly was never written down. It was rather deduced by later commentators as a rule which must have existed
column12: based on the evidence it produced. Although the vast majority of coats of arms ever used across the whole of Europe follow the rule
column13: a very few coats which contravened the rule were borne in the mediaeval era by certain families or corporate bodies for many centuries without effective censure by the heraldic authorities. The reason for the original contraventions and for the toleration of them is unknown
column14: although in the case of the arms of the Kingdom of Jerusalem clearly extreme high status was involved."

column1: 3823289 California_Republican_Party "The California Republican Party (CAGOP) is the California affiliate of the United States Republican Party. The party is based in Sacramento
column2: and is led by Chairwoman Jessica Patterson.As of 2018
column3: Republicans represent approximately 24% of the state's registered voters
column4: placing the Republicans in third place in California behind the Democratic Party and no party preference voters. The party is a superminority in the California State Legislature
column5: holding only 19 seats out of 80 in the California State Assembly
column6: and 11 seats of 40 in the California State Senate. The California GOP also holds none of the 8 statewide executive branch offices
column7: only 7 of the state's seats in the House of Representatives
column8: and neither of California's seats in the United States Senate."

column1: 3871014 Rainbow "A rainbow is a meteorological phenomenon that is caused by reflection
column2: refraction and dispersion of light in water droplets resulting in a spectrum of light appearing in the sky. It takes the form of a multicoloured circular arc. Rainbows caused by sunlight always appear in the section of sky directly opposite the sun. Rainbows can be full circles. However
column3: the observer normally sees only an arc formed by illuminated droplets above the ground
column4: and centered on a line from the sun to the observer's eye. In a primary rainbow
column5: the arc shows red on the outer part and violet on the inner side. This rainbow is caused by light being refracted when entering a droplet of water
column6: then reflected inside on the back of the droplet and refracted again when leaving it. In a double rainbow
column7: a second arc is seen outside the primary arc
column8: and has the order of its colours reversed
column9: with red on the inner side of the arc. This is caused by the light being reflected twice on the inside of the droplet before leaving it."

column1: 3976426 Progressive_Party_(United_States
column2: _1948) "The United States Progressive Party of 1948 was a left-wing political party that served as a vehicle for former Vice President Henry A. Wallace's 1948 presidential campaign. The party sought desegregation
column3: the establishment of a national health insurance system
column4: an expansion of the welfare system
column5: and the nationalization of the energy industry. The party also sought conciliation with the Soviet Union during the early stages of the Cold War. Wallace had served as vice president under Franklin D. Roosevelt but was dumped from the Democratic ticket in 1944. After the end of World War II
column6: Wallace emerged as a prominent critic of President Harry S. Truman's Cold War policies. Wallace's supporters held the 1948 Progressive National Convention
column7: which nominated a ticket consisting of Wallace and Democratic Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho. Despite challenges from Wallace
column8: Republican nominee Thomas E. Dewey
column9: and Strom Thurmond of the segregationist Dixiecrats
column10: Truman won re-election in the 1948 election. Wallace won 2.4% of the vote
column11: which was far less than the share received by Theodore Roosevelt and Robert La Follette
column12: the presidential candidates of the 1912 and 1924 Progressive Party tickets
column13: respectively. Neither of those parties were directly related to Wallace's party
column14: though these parties did carry over ideological groups and influenced many members of the 1948 Progressive Party. After the election
column15: Wallace recanted his foreign policy views and became estranged from his former supporters. The party nominated attorney Vincent Hallinan in the 1952 presidential election
column16: and Hallinan won 0.2% of the national popular vote. The party began to disband in 1955 as opponents of anti-Communism became increasingly unpopular
column17: and was mostly fully dissolved by the late 1960s with the exception of a few affiliated state Progressive Parties. The Progressive Party of Henry Wallace was
column18: and remains
column19: controversial due to the issue of communist influence. The party served as a safe haven for communists
column20: fellow travelers
column21: and anti-war liberals during the Second Red Scare. Prominent Progressive Party supporters included U.S. Representative Vito Marcantonio and writer Norman Mailer."

column1: 4357603 Interstate_80_in_California "Interstate 80 (I-80) is a transcontinental Interstate Highway in the United States
column2: stretching from San Francisco
column3: California
column4: to Teaneck
column5: New Jersey. The segment of I-80 in California runs east from San Francisco across the Bay Bridge to Oakland
column6: where it turns north and crosses the Carquinez Bridge before turning back northeast through the Sacramento Valley. I-80 then traverses the Sierra Nevada
column7: cresting at Donner Summit
column8: before crossing into the state of Nevada within the Truckee River Canyon. The speed limit is at most 65 miles per hour (105 km/h) along the entire route instead of the state's maximum of 70 mph (110 km/h) and most of the route is in either urban areas or mountainous terrain. I-80 has portions designated as the Eastshore Freeway and Alan S. Hart Freeway. Throughout California
column9: I-80 was built along the corridor of U.S. Route 40 (US 40)
column10: eventually replacing this designation entirely. The prior US 40 corridor itself was built along several historic corridors in California
column11: notably the California Trail and Lincoln Highway. The route has changed from the original plans in San Francisco due to freeway revolts canceling segments of the originally planned alignment. Similarly in Sacramento
column12: the freeway was re-routed around the city after plans to upgrade the original grandfathered route through the city to Interstate highway standards were cancelled."

column1: 4663436 Lavender_scare "The ""Lavender Scare"" refers to a witch hunt and the mass firings of homosexual people in the 1950s from the United States government. It contributed to and paralleled the anti-communist campaign known as McCarthyism and the Second Red Scare. Gay men and lesbians were said to be national security risks and communist sympathizers
column2: which led to the call to remove them from state employment. It was thought that the gays were more susceptible to being manipulated which could pose a threat to the country. The Lavender Scare – the federal government's official response to both a visible lesbian and gay community and a perceived homosexual menace – normalized persecution of homosexuals through bureaucratic institutionalization of homophobic discrimination policy. Former U.S. Senator Alan K. Simpson has written: ""The so-called 'Red Scare' has been the main focus of most historians of that period of time. A lesser-known element ... and one that harmed far more people was the witch-hunt McCarthy and others conducted against homosexuals."""

column1: 4764461 World_War_I "World War I (often abbreviated as WWI or WW1)
column2: also known as the First World War
column3: the Great War
column4: the Seminal Catastrophe
column5: and initially in North America as the European War
column6: was a global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918. Contemporaneously described as ""the war to end all wars""
column7: it led to the mobilisation of more than 70 million military personnel
column8: including 60 million Europeans
column9: making it one of the largest wars in history. It is also one of the deadliest conflicts in history
column10: with an estimated nine million combatants and seven million civilian deaths as a direct result of the war
column11: while resulting genocides and the resulting 1918 influenza pandemic caused another 50 to 100 million deaths worldwide.On 28 June 1914
column12: Gavrilo Princip
column13: a Bosnian Serb Yugoslav nationalist
column14: assassinated the Austro-Hungarian heir Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo
column15: leading to the July Crisis. In response
column16: on 23 July Austria-Hungary issued an ultimatum to Serbia. Serbia's reply failed to satisfy the Austrians
column17: and the two moved to a war footing. A network of interlocking alliances enlarged the crisis from a bilateral issue in the Balkans to one involving most of Europe. By July 1914
column18: the great powers of Europe were divided into two coalitions: the Triple Entente—consisting of France
column19: Russia
column20: and Britain—and the Triple Alliance of Germany
column21: Austria-Hungary
column22: and Italy (the Triple Alliance was only defensive in nature
column23: allowing Italy to stay out of the war until April 1915
column24: when it joined the Allied Powers after its relations with Austria-Hungary deteriorated). Russia felt it necessary to back Serbia and
column25: after Austria-Hungary shelled the Serbian capital of Belgrade on the 28 July
column26: approved partial mobilisation. Full Russian mobilisation was announced on the evening of 30 July; on the 31st
column27: Austria-Hungary and Germany did the same
column28: while Germany demanded Russia demobilise within twelve hours. When Russia failed to comply
column29: Germany declared war on Russia on 1 August in support of Austria-Hungary
column30: with Austria-Hungary following suit on 6 August; France ordered full mobilisation in support of Russia on 2 August.German strategy for a war on two fronts against France and Russia was to rapidly concentrate the bulk of its army in the West to defeat France within six weeks
column31: then shift forces to the East before Russia could fully mobilise; this was later known as the Schlieffen Plan. On 2 August
column32: Germany demanded free passage through Belgium
column33: an essential element in achieving a quick victory over France. When this was refused
column34: German forces invaded Belgium on 3 August and declared war on France the same day; the Belgian government invoked the 1839 Treaty of London and in compliance with its obligations under this
column35: Britain declared war on Germany on 4 August. On 12 August
column36: Britain and France also declared war on Austria-Hungary; on the 23 August
column37: Japan sided with Britain
column38: seizing German possessions in China and the Pacific. In November 1914
column39: the Ottoman Empire entered the war on the side of the Central Powers
column40: opening fronts in the Caucasus
column42: and the Sinai Peninsula. The war was fought in and drew upon each power's colonial empire as well
column43: spreading the conflict to Africa and across the globe. The Entente and its allies would eventually become known as the Allied Powers
column44: while the grouping of Austria-Hungary
column45: Germany and their allies would become known as the Central Powers. The German advance into France was halted at the Battle of the Marne and by the end of 1914
column46: the Western Front settled into a battle of attrition
column47: marked by a long series of trench lines that changed little until 1917 (the Eastern Front
column49: was marked by much greater exchanges of territory). In 1915
column50: Italy joined the Allied Powers and opened a front in the Alps. Bulgaria joined the Central Powers in 1915 and Greece joined the Allies in 1917
column51: expanding the war in the Balkans. The United States initially remained neutral
column52: though even while neutral it became an important supplier of war materiel to the Allies. Eventually
column53: after the sinking of American merchant ships by German submarines
column54: the declaration by Germany that its navy would resume unrestricted attacks on neutral shipping
column55: and the revelation that Germany was trying to incite Mexico to make war on the United States
column56: the U.S. declared war on Germany on 6 April 1917. Trained American forces would not begin arriving at the front in large numbers until mid-1918
column57: but ultimately the American Expeditionary Force would reach some two million troops.Though Serbia was defeated in 1915
column58: and Romania joined the Allied Powers in 1916 only to be defeated in 1917
column59: none of the great powers were knocked out of the war until 1918. The 1917 February Revolution in Russia replaced the Tsarist autocracy with the Provisional Government
column60: but continuing discontent with the cost of the war led to the October Revolution
column61: the creation of the Soviet Socialist Republic
column62: and the signing of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk by the new government in March 1918
column63: ending Russia's involvement in the war. This allowed the transfer of large numbers of German troops from the East to the Western Front
column64: resulting in the German March 1918 Offensive. This offensive was initially successful
column65: but failed to score a decisive victory and exhausted the last of the German reserves. The Allies rallied and drove the Germans back in their Hundred Days Offensive
column66: a continual series of attacks to which the Germans had no reply. Bulgaria was the first Central Power to sign an armistice—the Armistice of Salonica on 29 September 1918. On 30 October
column68: signing the Armistice of Mudros. On 4 November
column69: the Austro-Hungarian empire agreed to the Armistice of Villa Giusti. With its allies defeated
column71: and the military no longer willing to fight
column72: Kaiser Wilhelm abdicated on 9 November and Germany signed an armistice on 11 November 1918
column73: effectively ending the war. World War I was a significant turning point in the political
column76: and social climate of the world. It is considered to mark the end of the Second Industrial Revolution and the Pax Britannica. The war and its immediate aftermath sparked numerous revolutions and uprisings. The Big Four (Britain
column79: and Italy) imposed their terms on the defeated powers in a series of treaties agreed at the 1919 Paris Peace Conference
column80: the most well known being the German peace treaty—the Treaty of Versailles. Ultimately
column81: as a result of the war the Austro-Hungarian
column84: and Russian Empires ceased to exist
column85: with numerous new states created from their remains. However
column86: despite the conclusive Allied victory (and the creation of the League of Nations during the Peace Conference
column88: a second world war would follow just over twenty years later."

column1: 5043324 Iraq_War "The Iraq War was a protracted armed conflict that began in 2003 with the invasion of Iraq by a United States-led coalition that overthrew the government of Saddam Hussein. The conflict continued for much of the next decade as an insurgency emerged to oppose the occupying forces and the post-invasion Iraqi government. An estimated 151
column3: 000 Iraqis were killed in the first three to four years of conflict. In 2009
column4: official US troops were withdrawn
column5: but American soldiers remain on the ground fighting in Iraq
column6: most redeployed following the spread of the Syrian Civil War
column7: and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria having invaded Iraq from Syria
column8: and captured large areas quickly
column9: while carrying out widespread atrocities and global terrorist attacks. A number of these are hired by defence contractors and private military companies. The U.S. became re-involved in 2014 at the head of a new coalition; the insurgency and many dimensions of the civil armed conflict continue. The invasion occurred as part of a declared war against international terrorism and its sponsors under the administration of U.S. President George W. Bush following the September 11 terrorist attacks.In October 2002
column10: Congress authorized President Bush to use military force against Iraq should he choose to. The Iraq War began on 19 March 2003
column11: when the U.S.
column12: joined by the U.K. and several coalition allies
column13: launched a ""shock and awe"" bombing campaign. Iraqi forces were quickly overwhelmed as U.S.-led forces swept through the country. The invasion led to the collapse of the Ba'athist government; Saddam was captured during Operation Red Dawn in December of that same year and executed by a military court three years later. However
column14: the power vacuum following Saddam's demise and the mismanagement of the occupation led to widespread sectarian violence between Shias and Sunnis
column15: as well as a lengthy insurgency against U.S. and coalition forces. Many violent insurgent groups were supported by Iran and al-Qaeda in Iraq. The United States responded with a troop surge in 2007
column16: a build up of 170
column17: 000 troops. The surge in troops gave greater security to Iraq's government and military
column18: and was largely a success. The winding down of U.S. involvement in Iraq accelerated under President Barack Obama. The U.S. formally withdrew all combat troops from Iraq by December 2011.The Bush administration based its rationale for the war principally on the assertion that Iraq
column19: which had been viewed by the U.S. as a rogue state since the 1990–1991 Gulf War
column20: supposedly possessed an active weapons of mass destruction (WMDs) program
column21: and that the Iraqi government posed a threat to the United States and its coalition allies. Some U.S. officials falsely accused Saddam of harbouring and supporting al-Qaeda
column22: while others cited the desire to end a repressive dictatorship and bring democracy to the people of Iraq. In 2004
column23: the 9/11 Commission said there was no evidence of an operational relationship between the Saddam Hussein regime and al-Qaeda. No stockpiles of WMDs or an active WMD program were ever found in Iraq. Bush administration officials made numerous assertions about a purported Saddam-Al-Qaeda relationship and WMDs that were based on sketchy evidence
column24: and which intelligence officials pushed back on. The rationale of U.S. pre-war intelligence faced heavy criticism both domestically and internationally. The Chilcot Report
column25: a British inquiry into its decision to go to war
column26: was published in 2016 and concluded military action may have been necessary but was not the last resort at the time and that the consequences of invasion were underestimated.In seven months of secret FBI debriefings after his capture
column27: Saddam admitted that he faked having weapons of mass destruction when he was in power but had planned on developing a weapons of mass destruction program with nuclear capability within a year. Saddam made the admissions in videotaped interviews with George L. Piro
column28: an FBI agent who was assigned by the FBI with the CIA's approval to try to develop the former dictator's cooperation
column29: according to interviews Piro gave to journalist Ronald Kessler
column30: a former Washington Post and Wall Street Journal investigative reporter
column31: for Kessler's book The Terrorist Watch: Inside the Desperate Race to the Next Attack.In the aftermath of the invasion
column32: Iraq held multi-party elections in 2005. Nouri al-Maliki became Prime Minister in 2006 and remained in office until 2014. The al-Maliki government enacted policies that were widely seen as having the effect of alienating the country's Sunni minority and worsening sectarian tensions. In the summer of 2014
column33: the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) launched a military offensive in northern Iraq and declared a worldwide Islamic caliphate
column34: eliciting another military response from the United States and its allies. The Iraq War caused over a hundred thousand civilian deaths and tens of thousands of military deaths (see estimates below). The majority of deaths occurred as a result of the insurgency and civil conflicts between 2004 and 2007. Subsequently
column35: the Iraqi Civil War
column36: which was largely considered a domino effect of the invasion
column37: propelled at least 67
column38: 000 civilian deaths in addition to the displacement of five million people within the country."

column1: 5043544 Democratic_Party_(United_States) "The Democratic Party is one of the two major contemporary political parties in the United States
column2: along with its main rival
column3: the Republican Party. Tracing its heritage back to Thomas Jefferson and James Madison's Democratic-Republican Party
column4: the modern-day Democratic Party was founded around 1828 by supporters of Andrew Jackson
column5: making it the world's oldest active political party.In its early years
column6: the Party supported limited government
column7: state sovereignty and opposed banks and the abolition of slavery. Since Franklin D. Roosevelt and his New Deal coalition in the 1930s
column8: the Democratic Party has promoted a social liberal platform
column9: Well into the 20th century
column10: the party had conservative pro-business and Southern conservative-populist wings; following the New Deal
column11: however
column12: the conservative wing of the party largely withered outside the South. The New Deal Coalition of 1932–1964 attracted strong support from voters of recent European extraction—many of whom were Catholics based in the cities. After the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965
column13: the core bases of the two parties shifted
column14: with the Southern states becoming more reliably Republican in presidential politics and the Northeastern states becoming more reliably Democratic. The once-powerful labor union element became smaller and less supportive after the 1970s. White evangelicals and Southerners have become heavily Republican at the state and local levels since the 1990s. People living in urban areas
column15: women
column16: college graduates
column17: sexual and gender minorities
column18: millennials
column19: and black
column20: Latino
column21: Jewish
column22: and Asian Americans tend to support the Democratic Party.The Democratic Party's philosophy of modern liberalism advocates social and economic equality
column23: along with the welfare state. It seeks to provide government regulation in the economy. Policies such as environmental protection
column24: support for organized labor and labor unions
column25: the introduction of social programs
column26: affordable college tuition
column27: universal health care
column28: equal opportunity
column29: and consumer protection form the core of the party's economic policy. On social issues
column30: it advocates campaign finance reform
column31: LGBT rights
column32: police and immigration reform
column33: stricter gun laws
column34: and the legalization of marijuana.There have been 15 Democrats who have served as president of the United States. The first was Andrew Jackson
column35: who was the seventh president and served from 1829 to 1837. The most recent was Barack Obama
column36: who was the 44th and held office from 2009 to 2017. As of 2019
column37: the Democrats hold a majority in the House of Representatives
column38: 14 state government trifectas (governorship and both legislative chambers)
column39: the mayoralty of numerous major American cities
column40: and 18 total state legislatures. Four of the nine sitting justices of the Supreme Court had been appointed by Democratic presidents."

column1: 5104014 Utah_Republican_Party "The Utah Republican Party works to nominate and support the election of Republican candidates in partisan races for public office in the state of Utah; promote the principles of the State Party Platform; and abide by the elections laws
column2: constitution
column3: and bylaws of the Party."

column1: 5130939 Colorado_Republican_Party "The Colorado Republican Party is the state affiliate of the Republican Party in the U.S. state of Colorado. The party's headquarters is located in Greenwood Village
column2: Colorado. The state party chair is U.S. Representative Ken Buck."

column1: 5710507 Pornography "Pornography (often abbreviated porn) is the portrayal of sexual subject matter for the exclusive purpose of sexual arousal. Pornography may be presented in a variety of media
column2: including books
column3: magazines
column4: postcards
column5: photographs
column6: sculpture
column7: drawing
column8: painting
column9: animation
column10: sound recording
column11: phone calls
column12: writing
column13: film
column14: video
column15: and video games. The term applies to the depiction of the act rather than the act itself
column16: and so does not include live exhibitions like sex shows and striptease. The primary subjects of present-day pornographic depictions are pornographic models
column17: who pose for still photographs
column18: and pornographic actors or ""porn stars""
column19: who perform in pornographic films. If dramatic skills are not involved
column20: a performer in pornographic media may also be called a model. Various groups within society have considered depictions of a sexual nature immoral
column21: addictive
column22: and noxious
column23: labeling them pornographic
column24: and attempting to have them suppressed under obscenity and other laws
column25: with varying degrees of success. Such works have also often been subject to censorship and other legal restraints to publication
column26: display
column27: or possession
column28: leading in many cases to their loss. Such grounds
column29: and even the definition of pornography
column30: have differed in various historical
column31: cultural
column32: and national contexts.Social attitudes towards the discussion and presentation of sexuality have become more tolerant in Western countries
column33: and legal definitions of obscenity have become more limited
column34: notably beginning in 1969 with Blue Movie by Andy Warhol
column35: the first adult erotic film depicting explicit sex to receive wide theatrical release in the United States
column36: and the subsequent Golden Age of Porn (1969–1984)

column1: 5761137 United_States_Capitol_rotunda "The United States Capitol rotunda is the central rotunda of the United States Capitol in Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: built 1818–1824. It is located below the Capitol dome
column4: built 1857–1866; the later construction also extended the height of the rotunda walls. It is the tallest part of the Capitol and has been described as its ""symbolic and physical heart."" The rotunda is connected by corridors leading south to the House of Representatives and north to the Senate chambers. To the immediate south is the semi-circular National Statuary Hall
column5: which was the House of Representatives chamber until 1857. To the northeast is the Old Senate Chamber
column6: used by the Senate until 1859 and by the Supreme Court until 1935. The rotunda is 96 feet (29 m) in diameter
column7: rises 48 feet (15 m) to the top of its original walls and 180 feet 3 inches (54.94 m) to the canopy of the dome
column8: and is visited by thousands of people each day. It is also used for ceremonial events authorized by concurrent resolution
column9: including the lying in state of honored dead."

column1: 5793818 Eisenhower_jacket "The Eisenhower jacket
column2: or ""Ike"" jacket
column3: is a type of waist length jacket or blouson developed for the U.S. Army during the later stages of World War II and named after Dwight D. Eisenhower.  Intended to be worn on its own or as an insulating layer beneath the M-43 Field Jacket
column4: it featured a pleated back

column1: 11334331 West_Virginia_Republican_Party "The West Virginia Republican Party is the affiliate of the United States Republican Party in West Virginia. In 2018

column1: 11344094 Wyoming_Republican_Party "The Wyoming Republican Party is the affiliate of the Republican Party in Wyoming."

11344378 Republican_Party_of_Texas "The Republican Party of Texas (RPT) is the more dominant of the two major political parties in the U.S. State of Texas. It is affiliated with the United States Republican Party. The State Chairman is James Dickey
column2: an insurance executive from Austin
column3: and the Vice-Chairman is Alma Jackson of San Antonio. The RPT is headquartered in Downtown Austin. The RPT is legally classified as a political action committee whose structure is determined by state law and by party rules not in conflict with state law."

column1: 11345249 Republican_Party_of_Arkansas "The Republican Party of Arkansas (RPA) is the affiliate of the United States Republican Party in Arkansas. The party is led by state chairman Doyle Webb
column2: who was re-elected to serve a sixth term in December 2018. Webb
column3: an attorney and former state senator
column4: was once chief of staff for the late Lieutenant Governor Winthrop Paul Rockefeller. Chairman Webb also currently serves as the General Counsel to the Republican National Committee.   The RPA's headquarters is at 1201 West 6th Street in downtown Little Rock. Sarah Jo Reynolds serves as the executive director. Ashley Wells serves as finance director. Bea Grayes serves as the executive assistant.  Stephen Houserman serves as communications director."

The State Central Committee is led by Chairman Jeff Kaufmann. The RPI operates the Republican side of the Iowa caucuses and previously sponsored the Iowa Straw Poll."

11345596 Republican_Party_of_Kentucky "The Republican Party of Kentucky is the affiliate of the Republican Party in Kentucky and follows its nationally established platform. Headquarters for the party have been established in Frankfort
column2: Kentucky. The Republican Party of Kentucky gained relevancy in the political realm of Kentucky around the 1940s. Since this emergence
column3: the party did poorly in state office elections until 2015
column4: but saw consistent success on the national scale and in the Kentucky General Assembly. The party is organized into two main committees who hold the most authority in decision making within the party. In the 2015 Kentucky elections
column5: the party captured the offices of Governor
column6: Lt. Governor
column7: Treasurer and Auditor
column8: thus gaining the majority of the state executive offices for the first time in modern history.  In 2016
column9: the Republicans gained control of the state house for the first time since 1920."

column1: 11351653 Maine_Republican_Party "The Maine Republican Party is an affiliate of the United States Republican Party (GOP) in Maine. It was founded in Strong
column2: Maine on August 7
column3: 1854. The Maine GOP is noted for its historically strong state College Republican federation. Other affiliate groups include the Maine Federation of Republican Women and the Maine Federation of Young Republicans."

Also it has its own by-laws that go into details about how the organization should be structured and organized."

11765254 Air_Force_blue "Air Force blue colours are a variety of colours that are mostly various tones of the colour azure

column4: may look like they are tones of blue instead of azure.  However

column6: not blue.  These air force blue colours are used by these various air forces for colour identification."

column7: a shade being mixed with black. A large selection of these various colors is shown below."

column1: 13812997 District_of_Columbia_Republican_Party "The District of Columbia Republican Party (DC GOP) is the DC affiliate of the United States Republican Party. It was founded on June 19
column2: 1855 and is made up of registered Republican voters living in the District of Columbia elected to serve as the governing body of the Party. The party chairman is Jose Cunningham and the party is housed in the District of Columbia alongside the Republican Party national headquarters. The party faces steep difficulties in getting its candidates elected
column3: as Democrats hugely outnumber Republicans in the District of Columbia. No Republican has ever been elected mayor since D.C. home rule began in 1975. The DC Republicans have had no representation in the D.C. Council since Carol Schwartz left office in 2009. As of January 7
column5: there are 30
column6: 001 registered voters affiliated with the Republican Party of the District of Columbia. That is 6.15% of all registered voters."

column1: 14024925 Abilene_High_School_(Kansas) "Abilene High School is a fully accredited public high school located in Abilene
column2: Kansas
column3: United States
column4: serving grades 9-12. The school is a part of Abilene USD 435. The current building serves students from the city itself as well as outlying areas covered by the nearby Chapman district. Abilene is a member of the Kansas State High School Activities Association and offers a variety of sports programs. Athletic teams compete in class 4A Division 1. Extracurricular activities are also offered in the form of performing arts
column5: school publications
column6: and clubs."

column4: and read e-books
column5: newspapers
