column1: 16134471 Liberty_Caucus "The House Liberty Caucus is a congressional caucus consisting of conservative
column2: libertarian and libertarian conservative Republican members of the United States House of Representatives. It hosts a bimonthly luncheon in Washington
column3: D.C. The group was founded by Rep. Justin Amash of Michigan and joined by Republican members who wanted to ""focus on specific issues like economic freedom
column4: individual liberty
column5: and following the Constitution"". The caucus has also been characterized as ""conservative with a libertarian emphasis"" and associated with the Tea Party movement."

column1: 17599355 White "White is the lightest color and is achromatic (having no hue). It is the color of fresh snow
column2: chalk and milk
column3: and is the opposite of black. White objects fully reflect and scatter all the visible wavelengths of light.  White on television and computer screens is created by a mixture of red
column4: blue and green light. In ancient Egypt and ancient Rome
column5: priestesses wore white as a symbol of purity
column6: and Romans wore a white toga as a symbol of citizenship. In the Middle Ages and Renaissance a white unicorn symbolized chastity
column7: and a white lamb sacrifice and purity. It was the royal color of the kings of France
column8: and of the monarchist movement that opposed the Bolsheviks during the Russian Civil War (1917–1922). Greek and Roman temples were faced with white marble
column9: and beginning in the 18th century
column10: with the advent of neoclassical architecture
column11: white became the most common color of new churches
column12: capitols and other government buildings
column13: especially in the United States. It was also widely used in 20th century modern architecture as a symbol of modernity and simplicity. According to surveys in Europe and the United States
column14: white is the color most often associated with perfection
column15: the good
column16: honesty
column17: cleanliness
column18: the beginning
column19: the new
column20: neutrality
column21: and exactitude. White is an important color for almost all world religions. The pope
column22: the head of the Roman Catholic Church
column23: has worn white since 1566
column24: as a symbol of purity and sacrifice.  In Islam
column25: and in the Shinto religion of Japan
column26: it is worn by pilgrims. In Western cultures and in Japan
column27: white is the most common color for wedding dresses
column28: symbolizing purity and virginity. In many Asian cultures
column29: white is also the color of mourning."

column1: 18426568 NASA "The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA
column2: ) is an independent agency of the United States Federal Government responsible for the civilian space program
column3: as well as aeronautics and aerospace research.NASA was established in 1958
column4: succeeding the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA). The new agency was to have a distinctly civilian orientation
column5: encouraging peaceful applications in space science. Since its establishment
column6: most US space exploration efforts have been led by NASA
column7: including the Apollo Moon landing missions
column8: the Skylab space station
column9: and later the Space Shuttle. NASA is supporting the International Space Station and is overseeing the development of the Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle
column10: the Space Launch System and Commercial Crew vehicles. The agency is also responsible for the Launch Services Program which provides oversight of launch operations and countdown management for uncrewed NASA launches. NASA science is focused on better understanding Earth through the Earth Observing System; advancing heliophysics through the efforts of the Science Mission Directorate's Heliophysics Research Program; exploring bodies throughout the Solar System with advanced robotic spacecraft missions such as New Horizons; and researching astrophysics topics
column11: such as the Big Bang
column12: through the Great Observatories and associated programs."

column1: 18457137 Personal_computer "A personal computer (PC) is a multi-purpose computer whose size
column2: capabilities
column3: and price make it feasible for individual use. Personal computers are intended to be operated directly by an end user
column4: rather than by a computer expert or technician. Unlike large costly minicomputer and mainframes
column5: time-sharing by many people at the same time is not used with personal computers. Institutional or corporate computer owners in the 1960s had to write their own programs to do any useful work with the machines. While personal computer users may develop their own applications
column6: usually these systems run commercial software
column7: free-of-charge software (""freeware"") or free and open-source software
column8: which is provided in ready-to-run form. Software for personal computers is typically developed and distributed independently from the hardware or operating system manufacturers. Many personal computer users no longer need to write their own programs to make any use of a personal computer
column9: although end-user programming is still feasible. This contrasts with mobile systems
column10: where software is often only available through a manufacturer-supported channel
column11: and end-user program development may be discouraged by lack of support by the manufacturer.Since the early 1990s
column12: Microsoft operating systems and Intel hardware have dominated much of the personal computer market
column13: first with MS-DOS and then with Microsoft Windows. Alternatives to Microsoft's Windows operating systems occupy a minority share of the industry. These include Apple's macOS and free and open-source Unix-like operating systems. The advent of personal computers and the concurrent Digital Revolution have significantly affected the lives of people in all countries."

column1: 18852926 International_Standard_Name_Identifier "The International Standard Name Identifier (ISNI) is an identifier for uniquely identifying the public identities of contributors to media content such as books
column2: television programmes
column3: and newspaper articles. Such an identifier consists of 16 digits. It can optionally be displayed as divided into four blocks. ISNI can be used to disambiguate names that might otherwise be confused
column4: and links the data about names that are collected and used in all sectors of the media industries. It was developed under the auspices of the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) as Draft International Standard 27729; the valid standard was published on 15 March 2012. The ISO technical committee 46
column5: subcommittee 9 (TC 46/SC 9) is responsible for the development of the standard."

column1: 19167840 Chronology_of_the_universe "The chronology of the universe describes the history and future of the universe according to Big Bang cosmology. The earliest stages of the universe's existence are estimated as taking place 13.8 billion years ago
column2: with an uncertainty of around 21 million years at the 68% confidence level."

column1: 19593121 Kelvin "The kelvin is the base unit of temperature in the International System of Units (SI)
column2: having the unit symbol K. It is named after the Belfast-born
column3: Glasgow University engineer and physicist William Thomson
column4: 1st Baron Kelvin (1824–1907). The kelvin is defined by fixing the numerical value of the Boltzmann constant k to 1.380 649×10−23 J⋅K−1. This unit is equal to kg⋅m2⋅s−2⋅K−1
column5: where the kilogram
column6: metre and second are defined in terms of the Planck constant
column7: the speed of light
column8: and the duration of the caesium-133 ground-state hyperfine transition. Thus
column9: this definition depends only on universal constants
column10: and not on any physical artifacts as practiced previously
column11: such as the IPK
column12: whose mass diverged over time from the original value. One kelvin is equal to a change in the thermodynamic temperature T that results in a change of thermal energy kT by 1.380 649×10−23 J.The Kelvin scale fulfills Thomson's requirements as an absolute thermodynamic temperature scale. It uses absolute zero as its null point. Unlike the degree Fahrenheit and degree Celsius
column13: the kelvin is not referred to or written as a degree. The kelvin is the primary unit of temperature measurement in the physical sciences
column14: but is often used in conjunction with the degree Celsius
column15: which has the same magnitude."

column1: 19729624 Zachary_Taylor "Zachary Taylor (November 24
column2: 1784 – July 9
column3: 1850) was the 12th president of the United States
column4: serving from March 1849 until his death in July 1850. Taylor previously was a career officer in the United States Army
column5: rose to the rank of major general and became a national hero as a result of his victories in the Mexican–American War. As a result
column6: he won election to the White House despite his vague political beliefs. His top priority as president was preserving the Union
column7: but he died sixteen months into his term
column8: before making any progress on the status of slavery
column9: which had been inflaming tensions in Congress. Taylor was born into a prominent family of plantation owners who moved westward from Virginia to Kentucky in his youth. He was commissioned as an officer in the U.S. Army in 1808 and made a name for himself as a captain in the War of 1812. He climbed the ranks establishing military forts along the Mississippi River and entered the Black Hawk War as a colonel in 1832. His success in the Second Seminole War attracted national attention and earned him the nickname ""Old Rough and Ready"". In 1845
column10: during the annexation of Texas
column11: President James K. Polk dispatched Taylor to the Rio Grande in anticipation of a battle with Mexico over the disputed Texas–Mexico border. The Mexican–American War broke out in April 1846
column12: and Taylor defeated Mexican troops commanded by General Mariano Arista at the battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma and drove his troops out of Texas. Taylor then led his troops into Mexico
column13: where they defeated Mexican troops commanded by Pedro de Ampudia at the Battle of Monterrey. Defying orders
column14: Taylor led his troops further south and
column15: despite being severely outnumbered
column16: dealt a crushing blow to Mexican forces under Antonio López de Santa Anna at the Battle of Buena Vista. Taylor's troops were transferred to the command of Major General Winfield Scott
column17: but Taylor retained his popularity. The Whig Party convinced the reluctant Taylor to lead their ticket in the 1848 presidential election
column18: despite his unclear political tenets and lack of interest in politics. At the 1848 Whig National Convention
column19: Taylor defeated Scott and former Senator Henry Clay to take the nomination. He won the general election alongside New York politician Millard Fillmore
column20: defeating Democratic Party candidates Lewis Cass and William Orlando Butler
column21: as well as a third-party effort led by former president Martin Van Buren and Charles Francis Adams
column22: Sr. of the Free Soil Party. Taylor became the first president to be elected without having served in a prior political office. As president
column23: Taylor kept his distance from Congress and his cabinet
column24: even though partisan tensions threatened to divide the Union. Debate over the status of slavery in the Mexican Cession dominated the political agenda and led to threats of secession from Southerners. Despite being a Southerner and a slaveholder himself
column25: Taylor did not push for the expansion of slavery
column26: and sought sectional harmony above all other concerns. To avoid the issue of slavery
column27: he urged settlers in New Mexico and California to bypass the territorial stage and draft constitutions for statehood
column28: setting the stage for the Compromise of 1850. Taylor died suddenly of a stomach disease on July 9
column30: with his administration having accomplished little aside from the ratification of the Clayton–Bulwer Treaty. Fillmore served the remainder of his term. Historians and scholars have ranked Taylor in the bottom quartile of U.S. presidents
column31: owing in part to his short term of office (16 months)
column32: and he has been described as ""more a forgettable president than a failed one."""

column1: 20518076 United_States_Navy "The United States Navy (USN) is the naval warfare service branch of the United States Armed Forces and one of the seven uniformed services of the United States. It is the largest and most capable navy in the world and it has been estimated that in terms of tonnage of its active battle fleet alone
column2: it is larger than the next 13 navies combined
column3: which includes 11 U.S. allies or partner nations. It has the highest combined battle fleet tonnage and the world's largest aircraft carrier fleet
column4: with eleven in service
column5: and two new carriers under construction. With 336
column6: 978 personnel on active duty and 101
column7: 583 in the Ready Reserve
column8: the U.S. Navy is the third largest of the U.S. military service branches in terms of personnel. It has 290 deployable combat vessels and more than 3
column9: 700 operational aircraft as of June 2019
column10: making it the third-largest air force in the world
column11: after the United States Air Force and the United States Army. The U.S. Navy traces its origins to the Continental Navy
column12: which was established during the American Revolutionary War and was effectively disbanded as a separate entity shortly thereafter. After suffering significant loss of goods and personnel at the hands of the Barbary pirates from Algiers
column13: the U.S. Congress passed the Naval Act of 1794 for the construction of six heavy frigates
column14: the first ships of the U.S. Navy. The U.S. Navy played a major role in the American Civil War by blockading the Confederacy and seizing control of its rivers. It played the central role in the World War II defeat of Imperial Japan. The U.S. Navy emerged from World War II as the most powerful navy in the world. The 21st century U.S. Navy maintains a sizable global presence
column15: deploying in strength in such areas as the Western Pacific
column16: the Mediterranean
column17: and the Indian Ocean. It is a blue-water navy with the ability to project force onto the littoral regions of the world
column18: engage in forward deployments during peacetime and rapidly respond to regional crises
column19: making it a frequent actor in U.S. foreign and military policy. The Navy is administratively managed by the Department of the Navy
column20: which is headed by the civilian Secretary of the Navy. The Department of the Navy is itself a division of the Department of Defense
column21: which is headed by the Secretary of Defense. The Chief of Naval Operations (CNO) is the most senior naval officer serving in the Department of the Navy."

column1: 20647050 Temperature "A temperature expresses hot and cold
column2: as measured with a thermometer. In physics
column3: hotness is a body's ability to impart energy as heat to another body that is colder. In a body in which there are processes of chemical reaction and flow of matter
column4: temperature may vary over its parts
column5: and over time
column6: as measured by a suitably small and rapidly responding thermometer
column7: and may depend also on the match of the processes to the characteristics of the thermometer. There are various temperature scales that nearly or approximately agree with one another
column8: but differ slightly because of the various characteristics of particular thermometric substances. The most commonly used scales are the Celsius scale (formerly called centigrade) (denoted °C)
column9: Fahrenheit scale (denoted °F)
column10: and Kelvin scale (denoted K). When a body has no macroscopic chemical reactions or flows of matter or energy
column11: it is said to be in its own internal state of thermodynamic equilibrium. Its temperature is uniform in space and unchanging in time. Then
column12: referring to the Boltzmann constant
column13: a temperature scale is defined and said to be absolute because it is independent of the characteristics of particular thermometric substances and thermometer mechanisms. This is the Kelvin scale
column14: widely used in science and technology. The kelvin (the word is spelled with a lower-case k) is the unit of temperature in the International System of Units (SI). The temperature of a body in its own state of thermodynamic equilibrium is always positive
column15: relative to the absolute zero. For some conditions other than thermodynamic equilbrium
column16: a suitable thermometer calibrated on the Kelvin scale
column17: including absolute zero
column18: can register a negative temperature; such conditions are hotter than absolute zero. Temperature is important in all fields of natural science
column19: including physics
column20: chemistry
column21: Earth science
column22: medicine
column23: and biology
column24: as well as most aspects of daily life."

column1: 21556842 Photographic_film "Photographic film is a strip or sheet of transparent plastic film base coated on one side with a gelatin emulsion containing microscopically small light-sensitive silver halide crystals. The sizes and other characteristics of the crystals determine the sensitivity
column2: contrast
column3: and resolution of the film.The emulsion will gradually darken if left exposed to light
column4: but the process is too slow and incomplete to be of any practical use. Instead
column5: a very short exposure to the image formed by a camera lens is used to produce only a very slight chemical change
column6: proportional to the amount of light absorbed by each crystal. This creates an invisible latent image in the emulsion
column7: which can be chemically developed into a visible photograph. In addition to visible light
column8: all films are sensitive to ultraviolet light
column9: X-rays and gamma rays
column10: and high-energy particles. Unmodified silver halide crystals are sensitive only to the blue part of the visible spectrum
column11: producing unnatural-looking renditions of some colored subjects. This problem was resolved with the discovery that certain dyes
column12: called sensitizing dyes
column13: when adsorbed onto the silver halide crystals made them respond to other colors as well. First orthochromatic (sensitive to blue and green) and finally panchromatic (sensitive to all visible colors) films were developed. Panchromatic film renders all colors in shades of gray approximately matching their subjective brightness. By similar techniques
column14: special-purpose films can be made sensitive to the infrared (IR) region of the spectrum.In black-and-white photographic film
column15: there is usually one layer of silver halide crystals. When the exposed silver halide grains are developed
column16: the silver halide crystals are converted to metallic silver
column17: which blocks light and appears as the black part of the film negative. Color film has at least three sensitive layers
column18: incorporating different combinations of sensitizing dyes. Typically the blue-sensitive layer is on top
column19: followed by a yellow filter layer to stop any remaining blue light from affecting the layers below. Next comes a green-and-blue sensitive layer
column20: and a red-and-blue sensitive layer
column21: which record the green and red images respectively. During development
column22: the exposed silver halide crystals are converted to metallic silver
column23: just as with black-and-white film. But in a color film
column24: the by-products of the development reaction simultaneously combine with chemicals known as color couplers that are included either in the film itself or in the developer solution to form colored dyes. Because the by-products are created in direct proportion to the amount of exposure and development
column25: the dye clouds formed are also in proportion to the exposure and development. Following development
column26: the silver is converted back to silver halide crystals in the bleach step. It is removed from the film during the process of fixing the image on the film with a solution of ammonium thiosulfate or sodium thiosulfate (hypo or fixer). Fixing leaves behind only the formed color dyes
column27: which combine to make up the colored visible image. Later color films
column28: like Kodacolor II
column29: have as many as 12 emulsion layers
column30: with upwards of 20 different chemicals in each layer."

column1: 24147412 State_funerals_in_the_United_States "State funerals in the United States are the official funerary rites conducted by the Federal government of the United States in the nation's capital
column2: Washington
column3: D.C. that are offered to a sitting or former President of the United States
column4: a President-elect
column5: and others who have rendered distinguished service to the nation. Administered by the Military District of Washington (MDW)
column6: a command unit of the Joint Force Headquarters National Capital Region
column7: state funerals are greatly influenced by protocol
column8: steeped in tradition
column9: and rich in history. However
column10: the overall planning as well as the decision to hold a state funeral
column11: is largely determined by a president and his family."

column1: 25344742 Netherlands_Institute_for_Art_History "The Netherlands Institute for Art History or RKD (Dutch: RKD-Nederlands Instituut voor Kunstgeschiedenis) is located in The Hague and is home to the largest art history center in the world. The center specializes in documentation
column2: archives
column3: and books on Western art from the late Middle Ages until modern times. All of this is open to the public
column4: and much of it has been digitized and is available on their website. The main goal of the bureau is to collect
column5: categorize
column6: and make art research available
column7: most notably in the field of Dutch Masters. Via the available databases
column8: the visitor can gain insight into archival evidence on the lives of many artists of past centuries. The library owns approximately 450
column9: 000 titles
column10: of which ca. 150
column11: 000 are auction catalogs. There are ca. 3
column12: 000 magazines
column13: of which 600 are currently running subscriptions. Though most of the text is in Dutch
column14: the standard record format includes a link to library entries and images of known works
column15: which include English as well as Dutch titles. The RKD also manages the Dutch version of the Art and Architecture Thesaurus
column16: a thesaurus of terms for management of information on art and architecture. The original version is an initiative of the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles
column17: California."

column1: 27715261 Presidents_of_the_United_States_on_U.S._postage_stamps "Presidents of the United States have frequently appeared on U.S. postage stamps since the mid–1800s. The United States Post Office Department released its first two postage stamps in 1847
column2: featuring George Washington on one
column3: and Benjamin Franklin on the other. The advent of presidents on postage stamps has been definitive to U.S. postage stamp design since the first issues were released and set the precedent that U.S. stamp designs would follow for many generations. The paper postage stamp itself was born of utility (in England
column5: as something simple and easy to use was needed to confirm that postage had been paid for an item of mail. People could purchase several stamps at one time and no longer had to make a special trip to pay for postage each time an item was mailed. The postage stamp design was usually printed from a fine engraving and were almost impossible to forge adequately. This is where the appearance of presidents on stamps was introduced. Moreover
column6: the subject theme of a president
column7: along with the honors associated with it
column8: is what began to define the stamp issues in ways that took it beyond the physical postage stamp itself and is why people began to collect them. There exist entire series of stamp issues whose printing was inspired by the subject alone. The portrayals of Washington and Franklin on U.S. postage are among the most definitive of examples and have appeared on numerous postage stamps. The presidential theme in stamp designs would continue as the decades passed
column9: each period issuing stamps with variations of the same basic presidential-portrait design theme. The portrayals of U.S. presidents on U.S. postage has remained a significant subject and design theme on definitive postage throughout most of U.S. stamp issuance history.Engraved portrayals of U.S. presidents were the only designs found on U.S. postage from 1847 until 1869
column10: with the one exception of Benjamin Franklin
column11: whose historical stature was comparable to that of a president
column12: although his appearance was also an acknowledgement of his role as the first U. S. Postmaster General. During this period
column13: the U.S. Post Office issued various postage stamps bearing the depictions of George Washington foremost
column14: Benjamin Franklin
column15: Thomas Jefferson
column16: Andrew Jackson
column17: and Abraham Lincoln
column18: the last of whom first appeared in 1866
column19: one year after his death. After twenty-two years of issuing stamps with only presidents and Franklin
column20: the Post Office in 1869 issued a series of eleven postage stamps that were generally regarded by the American public as being abruptly different from the previous issues and whose designs were considered at the time to be a break from the tradition of honoring American forefathers on the nation's postage stamps. These new issues had other nonpresidential subjects and a design style that was also different
column21: one issue bearing a horse
column22: another a locomotive
column23: while others were depicted with nonpresidential themes. Washington and Lincoln were to be found only once in this series of eleven stamps
column24: which some considered to be below par in design and image quality. As a result
column25: this pictographic series was met with general disdain and proved so unpopular that the issues were consequently sold for only one year where remaining stocks were pulled from post offices across the United States.In 1870 the Post Office resumed its tradition of printing postage stamps with the portraits of American Presidents and Franklin but now added several other famous Americans
column26: including Henry Clay
column27: Daniel Webster
column28: Alexander Hamilton and General Winfield Scott among other notable Americans. Indeed
column29: the balance had now shifted somewhat; of the ten stamps issued in 1870
column30: only four offered presidential images. Moreover
column31: presidents also appeared on less than half of the denominations in the definitive sets of 1890
column34: while occupying only a slight majority of values in the definitive issues of 1894–98
column35: 1902 and 1922–25. Presidential images did
column36: however
column37: overwhelmingly dominate the definitive sets released in 1908 and 1938: on the former
column38: 10 of the 11 stamps offered the same image of Washington
column39: while in the 1938 ""prexies"" series
column40: 29 of the 32 stamps presented busts of presidents. The 1975 Americana Series marked a clear end to this tradition
column41: being the first U.S. definitive issue on which no presidential portrait appeared; and presidents played only a minor role in the subsequent Great Americans series. Every U.S. president who was deceased as of 2016 has appeared on at least one U.S. postage stamp
column42: and all but Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford have appeared on at least two. A stamp honoring George H. W. Bush
column43: who died November 30
column45: was released and first issued on June 12

column1: 33022390 Sky_blue "Sky blue is a colour that resembles the colour of the unclouded sky at noon (azure) reflecting off a metallic surface. The entry for ""sky-blue"" in Murray's New English Dictionary (1919) reports a first sighting of the term in the article on ""silver"" in Ephraim Chambers's Cyclopaedia of 1728. However
column2: many writers had used the term ""sky blue"" to name a colour before Chambers. For example
column3: we find ""sky blue"" in A Collection of Voyages and Travels (London: Awnsham and John Churchill
column5: vol. 2
column7: where John Nieuhoff describes certain flowers: ""they are of a lovely sky blue colour
column8: and yellow in the middle"".  The sense of this colour may have been first used in 1585 in a book by Nicolas de  Nicolay where he stated ""the tulbant of the merchant must be skie coloured"".  Displayed at right is the web colour sky blue.  "

column1: 33286024 Timeline_of_modern_American_conservatism "This timeline of modern American conservatism lists important events
column2: developments and occurrences which have significantly affected conservatism in the United States. With the decline of the conservative wing of the Democratic Party after 1960
column3: the movement is most closely associated with the Republican Party (GOP). Economic conservatives favor less government regulation
column4: lower taxes and weaker labor unions while social conservatives focus on moral issues and neoconservatives focus on democracy worldwide. Conservatives generally distrust the United Nations and Europe and apart from the libertarian wing favor a strong military and give enthusiastic support to Israel.Although conservatism has much older roots in American history
column5: the modern movement began to gel in the mid–1930s when intellectuals and politicians collaborated with businessmen to oppose the liberalism of the New Deal led by President Franklin D. Roosevelt
column6: newly energized labor unions and big city Democratic machines. After World War II
column7: that coalition gained strength from new philosophers and writers who developed an intellectual rationale for conservatism.Richard Nixon's victory in the 1968 presidential election is often considered a realigning election in American politics. From 1932 to 1968
column8: the Democratic Party was the majority party as during that time period the Democrats had won seven out of nine presidential elections and their agenda gravely affected that undertaken by the Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower administration
column9: but the election of 1968 reversed the situation completely. The Vietnam War split the Democratic Party. White ethnics in the North and white Southerners felt the national Democratic Party had deserted them. The white South has voted Republican at the presidential level since the mid-1960s and at the state and local level since the 1990s. In the 1980s
column10: President Ronald Reagan solidified conservative Republican strength with tax cuts
column11: greatly increased defense spending
column12: deregulation
column13: a policy of rolling back communism rather than just containing it
column14: a greatly strengthened military and appeals to family values and conservative Judeo-Christian morality. His impact has led historians to call the 1980s the Reagan Era. The Reagan model remains the conservative standard for social
column15: economic and foreign policy issues. In recent years
column16: social issues such as abortion
column17: gun control and gay marriage have become important. Since 2009
column18: the Tea Party movement has energized conservatives at the local level against the policies made by the presidency of Barack Obama
column19: leading to a Republican landslide in 2010 and again in 2014
column20: eventually culminating in the election of Republican Donald Trump as President in 2016.  "

column1: 37813727 Tuesday_Group "The Tuesday Group is an informal caucus of approximately 50 moderate Republican members of the United States House of Representatives.  It was founded in 1994 in the wake of the Republican takeover of the House. The Republican House caucus was dominated by conservative Republicans
column2: and the Tuesday Group was founded to counterbalance that conservative trend. There were approximately 40 members when it was founded. In 2007 the Tuesday Group founded its own political action committee.The co-chairs of the Tuesday Group were Charlie Dent
column3: Robert Dold and Adam Kinzinger from 2015 to 2017
column4: and Dent
column5: Tom MacArthur and Elise Stefanik from 2017. MacArthur resigned on May 23
column6: 2017 due to disagreement among members over the American Health Care Act of 2017. John Katko was elected as a co-chair from November 7
column7: 2017. Dent resigned from the House on May 12
column8: 2018. In the 116th Congress
column9: the co-chairs are Susan Brooks
column10: John Katko
column11: and Fred Upton.Former co-chairs include Charlie Bass
column12: Mike Castle
column13: Jo Ann Emerson
column14: Mark Kirk
column15: and Fred Upton. Members have included Judy Biggert
column16: Sherwood Boehlert
column17: Tom Davis
column18: Mike Fitzpatrick
column19: Mark Foley
column20: Jim Gerlach
column21: Nancy Johnson
column22: Sue Kelly
column23: Jim Kolbe
column24: Ray LaHood
column25: Leonard Lance
column26: Jim Leach
column27: John McKernan
column28: Cathy McMorris Rodgers
column29: Bob Michel
column30: Todd Platts
column31: Jim Ramstad
column32: Dave Reichert
column33: Joe Schwarz
column34: Chris Shays
column35: Rob Simmons
column36: Olympia Snowe
column37: James Walsh
column38: and Heather Wilson.The other major GOP group of moderates in Congress is the Republican Main Street Partnership
column39: which includes members of both the U.S. Senate and the U.S. House."

column1: 38195450 List_of_personal_coats_of_arms_of_presidents_of_the_United_States "Many United States presidents have borne a coat of arms; largely through inheritance
column2: assumption
column3: or grants from foreign heraldic authorities. One
column4: Dwight Eisenhower
column5: received his upon becoming a Knight of the Order of the Elephant of Denmark. The President of the United States
column6: as a position
column7: uses the Seal of the President of the United States as a coat of arms
column8: but this is a coat of arms of office
column9: not a personal coat of arms."

column1: 38777001 Socialist_Labor_Party_of_America "The Socialist Labor Party (SLP) is the oldest socialist political party in the United States
column2: established in 1876. Originally known as the Workingmen's Party of the United States
column3: the party changed its name in 1877 to Socialistic Labor Party and again sometime in the late 1880s to Socialist Labor Party. In 1890
column4: the SLP came under the influence of Daniel De Leon
column5: who used his role as editor of The Weekly People
column6: the SLP's English-language official organ
column7: to expand the party's popularity beyond its then largely German-speaking membership. Despite his accomplishments
column8: De Leon was a polarizing figure among the SLP's membership. In 1899
column9: his opponents left the SLP and merged with the Social Democratic Party of America to form the Socialist Party of America. After his death in 1914
column10: De Leon was followed as national secretary by Arnold Petersen. Critical of both the Soviet Union and the reformism of the Socialist Party of America
column11: the SLP became increasingly isolated from the majority of the American Left. Its support increased in the late 1940s
column12: but declined again in the 1950s
column13: when Eric Hass became influential in the party. The SLP experienced another increase in support in the late 1960s
column14: but again subsequently declined. The SLP last nominated a candidate for President in 1976 and in 2008 closed its national office. The party advocates ""socialist industrial unionism""
column15: the belief in a fundamental transformation of society through the combined political and industrial action of the working class organized in industrial unions."

column1: 43441278 Socialist_Workers_Party_(United_States) "The Socialist Workers Party (SWP) is known as a communist party in the United States. Originally a group in the Communist Party USA that supported Leon Trotsky against Soviet leader Joseph Stalin
column2: it places a priority on ""solidarity work"" to aid strikes and is strongly supportive of Cuba. The SWP publishes The Militant
column3: a weekly newspaper that dates back to 1928. It also maintains Pathfinder Press."

column1: 45239953 Freedom_Caucus "The Freedom Caucus
column2: also known as the House Freedom Caucus
column3: is a congressional caucus consisting of conservative and libertarian Republican members of the United States House of Representatives. It was formed in 2015 by what member Jim Jordan called a “smaller
column4: more cohesive
column5: more agile and more active” group of conservative congressmen
column6: and is currently chaired by Representative Andy Biggs of Arizona. Many members are also part of the much larger Republican Study Committee. The caucus is sympathetic to the Tea Party movement. The Freedom Caucus is considered the furthest-right bloc within the House Republican Conference. The caucus supports House candidates through its PAC
column7: the House Freedom Fund."

column1: 60776216 Republican_Party_of_Puerto_Rico "The Republican Party of Puerto Rico (Spanish: Partido Republicano de Puerto Rico) is the local affiliate of the national United States Republican Party in Puerto Rico. The affiliation started in 1903. The party does not participate in the November elections mandated by the Constitution of Puerto Rico for local registered political parties because it is not a registered party in Puerto Rico for local electoral purposes. Instead
column2: the party holds its own elections to select the Puerto Rico delegates to the Republican National Convention and holds presidential primaries on the last Sunday of February.The Republican Party of Puerto Rico's ideology supports statehood for Puerto Rico. Congresswoman Jenniffer González-Colón
column3: resident commissioner of Puerto Rico
column4: is the current local party chairperson. The local affiliate is based in San Juan
column5: Puerto Rico."
